HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE POSTAL SYSTEM; 
Post Offices Handle Less Mail, With More Caution

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 22 

 BODY:
Sorting and stamping and sifting through mail is not what it used to be at the postal processing center in this western suburb of Boston. There is far less mail. There are far more signs of anthrax-related anxiety.
 A television monitor flickers with anthrax safety messages. A poster about suspicious mail lists warning signs: oily stains, excessive postage, misspelled words, strange odor. 
 Outside the processing floor are bulletins about the false anthrax scares this center has had in the last eight days. For Oct. 18, for example, it mentions a "white substance found in bottom of empty tub."
Sorting has slowed because workers are more careful. But there is also less mail to sort, said Robert Cannon, a spokesman for the United States Postal Service in eastern and central Massachusetts.
Mr. Cannon said the Waltham plant was handling 30 percent less mail than it did this time last year, a trend he said was being echoed nationally. "We're seeing a drastic drop in volume," Mr. Cannon said. "There should be a lot more mail than there is right now."
The national decline in mail volume was precipitated by the weak economy but worsened by the terrorist attacks. Volume was down 5 percent in September from the same month last year, said Gerry Kreienkamp, a spokesman for the Postal Service in Washington. Revenue last month was down $4 million to $5 million from its September 2000 level, he said.
Across the country, postal workers are in an altered landscape. Four of the 10 people known to have contracted anthrax were postal workers, two in New Jersey and two in the District of Columbia. The news today that two Washington postal workers died from what the authorities suspect was anthrax only heightened the sense that the Postal Service had been catapulted to the front lines of the war with terrorists.
"We're all dealing with new situations," John Potter, the postmaster general, said today at a White House news conference. "We're working as a team to try to deal with this ever-evolving, changing-by-the-minute environment."
Mr. Cannon said that since Oct. 15, the day that an anthrax-tainted letter was opened in the office of Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, police or hazardous-materials teams had responded to reports by postal workers of about 600 to 700 suspicious packages and letters a day. 
In Glendale Heights, Ill., 39 postal employees were evacuated for eight hours on Saturday after a machine operator saw a substance resembling brown sugar on a letter. The scare, which turned out to be a false alarm, meant that 19 of the post office's 27 routes went undelivered that day, said Donald Sommers, the postmaster. Postal workers came in at 6 this morning, 90 minutes earlier than usual, to deal with the backlog. 
In the central New Jersey postal district, where two of the stricken workers came from, a spokesman, Carl Walton, said mail delivery had fallen behind, with workers delivering "about 60 percent of first-class mail, Express Mail, Priority Mail and the parcels."
In the Seattle area, two false anthrax alarms last week closed a post office in Port Townsend and a carrier center in Tacoma. 
Marty Barron, an arbitration advocate for the greater Seattle postal workers union, said, "There has been a certain degree of paranoia." 
And in Cambridge, Mass., last week, when a mail carrier who discovered white powder on the front of his Postal Service sweater called to tell his supervisor, the carrier quickly found himself surrounded by a hazardous materials team in "moon suits," Mr. Cannon said. 
"They hosed him down in the middle of the busy street while he was wearing only Bermuda shorts and a T-shirt," Mr. Cannon said.
Tension levels are highest, understandably, in places like New Jersey and New York, where anthrax cases have been found.
In the Morgan mail center on the West Side of Manhattan, which probably processed the anthrax-tainted letters sent to NBC News and The New York Post, some workers said they were upset that not all 5,000 employees were to be tested for anthrax exposure and that environmental cleanup had not been done.
William Smith, president of the Metropolitan Postal Workers Union, said the union was considering suing to force the shutdown of the Morgan center.
Pat McGovern, a spokeswoman for the Postal Service in New York City, said that employees who would have worked along the route of the NBC letter were tested starting on Friday, and that on Sunday, testing began for bar code sorters, manual sorting cases and vacuum cleaners at the Morgan center. She said environmental cleanup had not been done because the testing was not completed.
But while postal workers across the country are concerned, there seems to be little, if any, panic. Few employees are staying home and many are handling their new environment with stoicism and calm. 
"Every postal worker that has anything to with the mail is on the front lines," said David Galvin, a 14-year Postal Service veteran here in Waltham whose job is to cancel the stamps on large flat envelopes. "You get very nervous, but you have a job to do and you got to do it."
When Mr. Galvin and the 600 other employees enter the building, they are now subject to more frequent random searches of handbags and mail tubs, said Gordon Spencer, acting manager of district operations. Two postal inspectors are now stationed around the clock in the plant to respond to reports of suspicious packages, Mr. Spencer said. As a result of the six reports so far, the plant has been evacuated once, and other times, employees in the area of the package were quarantined until the substance was found to be safe. 
Many post offices have made surgical masks and gloves available to employees. But in many places, few people have been wearing them.
In Waltham, some employees say the gloves and masks are uncomfortable. And Frank J. Manganaro, the plant manager, said he had told employees that they should weigh the protection of gloves and masks against the risks that, for example, gloves could get caught in machinery and cause injury.
In recent days, Mr. Manganaro has made a point of talking with employees to see how they are feeling. 
"They understood that we are an organization that binds the country and we have an obligation to citizens of this country," Mr. Manganaro said. "I was actually taken with their sense of what their role is."

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Hopes to Avoid Higher Fares, Service Cuts 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA STEWART

 BODY:
Despite the huge, unforeseen cost of having to repair and secure the New York transit system, officials said yesterday they do not not have any immediate plans to increase fares or reduce services.
 Peter S. Kalikow, chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Authority, said at a meeting yesterday that the agency is hoping to solve its financial problems with insurance money, federal grants and cost-cutting measures. 
 The transit authority estimates it will need $4.1 billion over three years to cover the costs of the damage, extra security and lost revenue from the terrorist attacks. Transit officials are hopeful for a large amount of federal aid and full payment on its $1.5 billion insurance policy to come close to meeting those expenses.
Currently, said Mr. Kalikow, the agency is "aggressively dealing" with insurance and federal officials. In particular, it is lobbying for a very substantial slice of New York's $54 billion request for federal aid, he said. "This is a national affair," he said. "Hawaii was not expected to pay for Pearl Harbor by itself and we shouldn't be expected to pay for the terrorist attacks." 
Gene Russianoff of the Straphangers Campaign, a rider advocacy group, called the authority's plan to avoid fare increases and service reductions "sincere" and "plausible."
Even before Sept. 11, the authority was hurt by the weakened economy. Now it needs an extra $1.7 billion to clean transit systems and repair damaged subway lines. It must increase security, improve ventilation systems and find ways to speed up evacuations.

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Schundler Is Counting On Tax Issue To Turn Tide

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 22 

 BODY:
With two weeks until Election Day, Bret D. Schundler and the State Republican Party have stepped up their efforts to portray James E. McGreevey as a threat to New Jersey's taxpayers.
 In campaign advertisements, daily press releases and news conferences, the Republicans are harping on the tax issue with a singular persistence that suggests a focused strategy going into the final days of the campaign for governor. 
 Every day, the state G.O.P. issues a new press release seeking to equate Mr. McGreevey with his fellow Democrat, former Gov. Jim Florio, who pushed through a $2.8 billion tax increase during his first year in office. Today's release featured Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani calling any sentiment to raise taxes "dumb, stupid, idiotic and moronic." Jack Collins, the State Assembly speaker, has scheduled a news conference for Tuesday to say much the same. 
The decision by Mr. Schundler and his supporters to tailor their message in many ways reflects a do-or-die determination to turn the race around in a state where the tax issue has long been paramount. Mr. McGreevey continues to lead by double digits in the polls, and with state politics still overshadowed by the conflict in Afghanistan and by fears about anthrax, the tax attack may be Mr. Schundler's only hope of generating enough attention and momentum to shift the electoral tide. 
"The top issue of concern to voters right now is the economy, and in particular what the next governor is going to do in regard to state tax policy," said Bill Guhl, a spokesman for the Schundler campaign. "I think that is going to be the basis on which many undecided voters out there are going to cast their vote on Election Day." 
Richard McGrath, a spokesman for the McGreevey campaign, said the Republicans had turned to the tax issue as a last, desperate measure. "It has become a kind of a one-note symphony," he said. "And it's an act of political desperation. It's a naked scare tactic that is the byproduct of a desperate candidate whose proposals have been stripped away and shown to be irresponsible and ironically costly to taxpayers from a number of angles."
In pounding on the tax issue in recent days, the Republicans point out that Mr. McGreevey has repeatedly refused to promise that he would not raise taxes if he is elected governor, saying instead that he is committed to a state government that will "live within its means."
Mr. Schundler, by contrast, has eagerly embraced every opportunity to promise that he will not raise taxes even if New Jersey ends up facing a $1 billion deficit next year. 
Mr. Schundler's campaign also recently noted that Mr. McGreevey used the same phrase about living within one's means in 1997 to defend Mr. Florio's tax increases.
The Republicans are betting that voters will reject any possibility of a tax increase. "It is certainly the issue that we want to drive home," said Jeanette Hoffman, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Republican Committee. "Under Republican leadership, we won't raise your taxes, and the Democrats will. I think we have been seeing that people care about their bottom line. People are worried about keeping their jobs. They are worried about their own pocketbooks."
Mr. McGreevey is betting that voters feel so betrayed by politicians that they will not believe Mr. Schundler's promise.
"Voters in New Jersey aren't concerned about tax pledges," said Joel Benenson, Mr. McGreevey's pollster. "They have heard these pledges from politicians for years, and they have watched politicians take the pledge and break it."
Mr. McGrath said Mr. McGreevey "sees no need to raise taxes, but he believes it would be irresponsible to make a permanent pledge that would handcuff New Jersey for any future catastrophic need."
On the campaign trail, Mr. Schundler repeatedly points to his tax-cutting record as mayor of Jersey City. And he points at Mr. McGreevey's record as mayor of Woodbridge as evidence that his opponent has never made tax-cutting a priority. Mr. McGreevey's response is that Mr. Schundler's promises cannot be trusted: not about taxes, not about getting rid of tolls, not about education or anything else.
The different strategies were clearly on display Thursday night during the most recent debate between the two candidates. While asking a question, one man in the debate audience told the candidates: "I see one of you as a fool who doesn't know that he has to raise taxes and the other as a liar who won't tell us that he knows he'll have to raise taxes. Can either of you prove me wrong?"
A moderator of the debate quickly followed up with yet another demand that the candidates take what is now known in American politics simply as the pledge. Mr. Scott said: "Let me put it to you again: if elected governor, will you raise taxes?" 
Mr. Schundler answered first. "Absolutely not," he said. "I am going to be cutting taxes. And if we have a very deep recession, which causes a very significant reduction of state revenues, that's especially when we have to get taxes down to put people back to work." 
Mr. McGreevey said: "I've said publicly where I would cut. I talked about capping the New Jersey Saver program for families earning above $200,000. Clearly, they've enjoyed the benefit of the federal tax cut.
"I've talked about merging government. We're going to have to make some tough decisions, but I'm committed to having our state government live within its means."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE EARLY CASUALTIES; 
2 Soldiers Remembered for Their Focus and Patriotism

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 22 

 BODY:
Wayne Korhonen, a psychology teacher at East High School here, came to work today as many Americans do during a time of war, wearing bold symbols of patriotism. A ribbon of red, white and blue was pinned to his lapel. His tie bore a likeness of the Stars and Stripes.
 But as a striking reminder that pain often comes with patriotism, he also wore a black armband, in memory of Specialist Jonn J. Edmunds, a 1999 honors graduate and one of his former students. 
 Last Friday, Specialist Edmunds and another soldier, Pfc. Kristofer T. Stonesifer of Missoula, Mont., became the first American combat casualties in the war against the Taliban when they were passengers in a Black Hawk helicopter that crashed in Pakistan. Both men served with the 75th Ranger Regiment, based at Fort Benning, Ga.
A Defense Department official said the crash occurred as the helicopter was landing at Dalbandin air base. The wash of the rotor blades kicked up a huge cloud of dust, the official said, which apparently disoriented the pilot or interfered with the equipment.
On Sunday, the bodies of the two soldiers were flown to Ramstein Air Base in Germany, where they received military honors. Today, their families waited to learn from the Army when they could schedule funerals and memorial services. Specialist Edmunds, 20, was married less than a year. Private Stonesifer, 28, was single.
Outside their modest home on the wind-swept prairie outside Cheyenne, Specialist Edmunds's parents, Donn and Mary, held back tears as Donn Edmunds read a statement in which he described his son as "a tough, determined, competitive young man who only accepted the best of himself and wanted to give his best for his country."
That his son became an Army Ranger was hardly a surprise to anyone who knew him. 
"When everyone was planning on college, I asked him what college he wanted to go to," Mr. Korhonen said, recalling Specialist Edmunds's unwavering sense of purpose. "He told me he didn't want to go to college; he was joining the Army to be a Ranger.
"Kids say things like that all the time here, depending on what movie is popular at the time. But with Jonn, I knew there was no doubt."
The military has a big presence in Cheyenne, the capital of Wyoming. The area's largest employer is the F. E. Warren Air Force Base, which manages the nation's nuclear arsenal. Sam Mirich, the East High principal, said that many of students were children of military families, and that every year some graduates chose a military career over college or civilian work.
In Specialist Edmunds's case, he was following family tradition. His father served in the Army in Vietnam. "Jonn wanted to prove he was as tough physically as he was mentally," said Kosta Tsandes, who taught him economics. "He always tried awfully hard. He didn't have the speed or fluidity as someone with God-given gifts. But he would die out there. He wanted to succeed so bad to prove he was good."
Private Stonesifer, who grew up in Doylestown, Pa., and moved to Montana several years ago to attend the University of Montana, was remembered much the same way. A philosophy major with a 3.51 grade point average, he quit the university's R.O.T.C. program last year because he felt it was not strenuous enough. Then he joined the Army.
"All I really knew was, he wanted to be the best soldier in the U.S. Army, and the best soldiers in the Army are in the Ranger battalion," Lt. Col. Jim Clegg, professor of military science and head of the R.O.T.C. program at Montana, told The Associated Press. "He was a very mature and focused young man." 
A classmate of Private Stonesifer in the R.O.T.C. program, Simon Walbruch, 26, was one of the last students from the University of Montana to see him when Mr. Walbruch spent three weeks last summer at the airborne school in Fort Benning, Ga.
"He seemed really happy," Mr. Walbruch said. "He was really glad he made the decision that he did. I'm sure he was happy to be over there and help defend our country."

HEADLINE: Still Dealing, Leaders Study An Expansion Of Gambling 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 22 

 BODY:
Negotiations over a final state budget that would authorize several new American Indian-run casinos and video gambling machines at horse tracks intensified today, but Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders still had not resolved several pivotal details late yesterday evening.
 "I think it's fair to say we are closer," the governor said this afternoon. "But as everyone in Albany knows, it's a question of actually getting the i's dotted and the t's crossed and having an actual agreement, and we're not there." 
 As the day wore on, it became clear one major sticking point in the talks was a disagreement over which racetracks should have video gambling machines. Mr. Pataki and his Republican allies who control the Senate had first proposed putting the machines only in Yonkers Raceway, Aqueduct and one upstate track.
The Democrats who control the Assembly were deeply divided on the question. Several black and Hispanic members complained the machines would further impoverish already poor people in the Bronx and Queens. Upstate Democrats who represent districts with failing harness tracks, meanwhile, are in favor of a proposal to allow local governments to opt for the machines.
The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver of Manhattan, and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, have tied the fate of the video machines to a bill that would let the governor negotiate compacts with Indian tribes for six casinos, three in Western New York and three in the Catskills. Legislative leaders and the governor have already agreed to authorize New York to join the Powerball lottery.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, meanwhile, argued today New York City should also be given a casino, or the Catskills gaming parlors would sap the city's economy. "If you were going to have casino gambling in the Catskills, it would be unfair to New York City to not allow Rockaway, or maybe one or two other places in New York City to have that same option," he said.
But legislative leaders have long been opposed to casinos in the city. 
Along with the gambling proposals, state leaders are trying to hammer out a plan that would add approximately $500 million in spending to the stripped-down $80 billion budget passed in August.
In broad terms, one version of the deal under discussion would appropriate about $200 million to finance nonprofits that every year provide everything from social services and legal representation to the poor, lawmakers and staff members on both sides of the aisle said. An additional $100 million would be earmarked for economic development, and the final $200 million would go for school aid. Those numbers, however, were not etched in stone.
Leaders are discussing how to pay for additions when revenues are expected to drop dramatically because of the shaky economy and the attack on the World Trade Centers
The governor and Senate Republicans have proposed stretching out payments to local school districts for new buildings as one way to save money. But that proposal is opposed by lawmakers in the Assembly from districts where voters have already approved borrowing with the expectation the state would reimburse them faster.
The final major issue on the bargaining table is how much of the state's annual $1.5 billion windfall from the federal government for welfare payments should be spent this year. The state collects the extra money because its grant is based on the number of people who were on the rolls in 1995, and those numbers have fallen.
Governor Pataki wants to keep some of the surplus in a reserve fund to hedge against lost revenues, while the Assembly Democrats are urging the money be spent on social programs this year, people familiar with the talks said. The governor has proposed using about half of the surplus for tax credits, foster care and daycare programs for the poor. The Democrats would like to see the state spend more of the surplus to salvage other social programs.
The disagreement over video-lottery terminals, however, may be the hardest problem to solve, and some lawmakers said it may be the key to an overall deal. Minority lawmakers fear the machines, which some psychologists say are addictive, will beggar some poor families downstate.
"There is some leeriness about the prospect this will create problems among poor and working poor families, where the only breadwinner might become a gambler," said Assemblyman Roger Green, the leader of the black and Hispanic caucus.
After meeting for three hours last night, legislative leaders said they had made progress, although Senator Bruno said, "The hang-up is on everything."

HEADLINE: Chairman of Lincoln Center Redevelopment Resigns 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
The real estate executive in charge of Lincoln Center's fractious billion-dollar redevelopment project resigned yesterday, months before he had planned to leave.
 The executive, Marshall Rose, who has served as the unpaid chairman of the center's redevelopment corporation, said he was stepping down because he had completed his work on a master plan. But it was widely known within Lincoln Center that he was intensely frustrated with the internecine battles that were hindering the project's advancement. 
 The departure, coming only three and a half weeks after the exit of the center's president, Gordon J. Davis, throws new uncertainty over the plan, even though Mr. Rose, a successful real estate developer, maintains that a great majority of the issues that were dividing the center's prestigious constituents had been resolved and that the project had been scaled back to account for post-Sept. 11 economic uncertainty. 
The redevelopment corporation board is considering adoption of a master plan in November with a set of variables, reflecting the difficulty the center and its high-profile constituents, like the Metropolitan Opera, have had at reaching consensus. The plan, with its various options, would then be submitted for approval to the city, which has agreed to provide $240 million over 10 years to the effort. Mr. Rose said he would stay through the November board meeting.
But Mr. Rose said that when Beverly Sills, Lincoln Center's chairman, and Nathan Leventhal, the former president, first met with him about leading the project, he told them he expected to stay about two years, which would have meant until next June.
Some Lincoln Center executives said they were surprised that Mr. Rose -- who has donated his time on the project -- lasted as long as he did. He had become a target, they say, and he was fed up with the squabbling among many of the 11 participating constituents of the center. Also, center executives say, he saw the chance to make his mark eroding given the center's deep-seated internal resentments and the city's economic uncertainty.
"It's a good time to get out," said one Lincoln Center official. "He knows it's a no-win situation at this point for him. He wanted to leave his legacy."
The redevelopment, at least as of now, calls for a widespread refurbishment of deteriorated buildings and grounds, a major overhaul of Avery Fisher Hall, home to the New York Philharmonic; and a $300-million new home for the New York City Opera.
Joseph Volpe, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, has been strongly opposed to two aspects of the plan that have been discussed: creation of a glass dome over Lincoln Center's central outdoor plaza and construction of a building for the New York City Opera in a section of Damrosch Park adjacent to the Met.
There have also been tensions between City Opera and the New York City Ballet, which share the acoustically poor New York State Theater, over whether the ballet would be financially damaged if City Opera left and whether the two organizations could agree on renovations to the stage if the opera company were to stay.
Mr. Rose said the redevelopment project had been scaled back to about $1 billion because of elimination or modification of certain aspects of the plan. Most elements have been agreed upon, Mr. Rose said; the remaining issues have to do with Lincoln Center's public spaces and the new opera house.
The dome is no longer part of the project. "It didn't achieve consensus," Mr. Rose said. Mr. Volpe and Ms. Sills both opposed it. 
Mr. Rose is said to have been surprised, at a recent meeting of the executive committee of Lincoln Center, by Ms. Sills' alliance with the Met on the dome and City Opera issues, and some suggested that this played a central role in his decision to leave. Mr. Rose and Ms. Sills said in interviews that they were parting on good terms. "I'm sad," she said. "It wasn't a total surprise. There was a moment when I knew he was going to cut off."
"The difficulty," she said, "is to get 11 intelligent people who run world-class institutions to find a way to get what they need accomplished. I think Marshall feels he has reached the point where, in his mind, he was finished."
Mr. Rose said he expected the master plan to be submitted with three options for the New York City Opera: having it remain in the State Theater, provided that it can reach agreement with the City Ballet; building a new opera house off-campus; or building a new opera house in Damrosch Park, while making adjustments to keep the park from being significantly diminished.
But executives at Lincoln Center say it is unlikely that Mr. Volpe will agree to a plan that includes such options, and a plan must be unanimously accepted by the constituents to proceed. In a letter Mr. Rose sent to the directors of the constituent project yesterday, he described an Oct. 18 meeting on redevelopment as "productive." But people who were there say it was as argumentative as ever because Mr. Volpe objected to the possibility of a master plan with options.
On the City Opera proposal for a new home in Damrosch Park, Ms. Sills, once that organization's reigning diva and later its general director, said, "They still have a right to dream."
Mr. Volpe declined to comment.
Mr. Rose said of Mr. Volpe: "He's a very intelligent and forceful advocate for his constituent. And I think he would like to play a constructive role."
Paul Kellogg, the executive director of City Opera, said he was sorry to see Mr. Rose go. "It's a terrible loss," he said.
Rebecca Robertson, the executive director of the redevelopment project, said she would stay on. "My obligation as executive director of this is to deliver something I really believe the constituents want and need," she said.
Whether the city will be able to come through on its pledge of support also remains in question in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks.
Although Mr. Rose acknowledged that his task had been a difficult one -- managing "constituents with strong and sometimes conflicting opinions" -- he said in a letter to the various participating arts groups that, "The elements are in place for the constituents to choose a master plan that meets both the needs and the aspirations of Lincoln Center and the various cultural institutions that comprise it."
As a vice chairman of Lincoln Center, Mr. Rose said he expected to continue to be part of the redevelopment project, but that he felt it was time for Lincoln Center to find someone willing to oversee the effort for as much as 15 years. That did not make sense for him at age 65, he said. "It's not a sense of frustration. It's really when you realize you're now at this point when somebody has to get involved and stay involved for a long period of time."
Mr. Rose added that he was following a strategy he had used in other development and real estate projects for the New York Stock Exchange, Madison Square Garden and the New York Public Library. "It's the style that I like to work in," he said.
But Mr. Rose stayed at the library for 19 years.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: City Begins Selling $500 Million In Bonds 

BYLINE:  NYT (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

 BODY:
 New York City began the sale of $500 million in bonds yesterday, its first major borrowing since the attack on the World Trade Center. The sale, set to be completed today, is an important test of the city's ability to borrow money as it begins to rebuild Lower Manhattan. The bonds are known as general obligation bonds because they are backed by the city's taxing power. Credit-rating agencies graded the issue at solidly investment grade, single A by Standard & Poor's and A2 by Moody's. But Colleen Woodell, managing director at Standard & Poor's Public Finance, noted that "future credit direction will be tied to the city's ability to manage these extraordinary fiscal and economic issues at a time when political leadership is changing."

HEADLINE: SOCCER: NOTEBOOK; 
Stadiums Still a Problem After 6 M.L.S. Seasons

BYLINE:  By ALEX YANNIS 

 BODY:
In Major League Soccer's sixth season, attendance was up by 9 percent, the caliber of play was higher and the number of young American players continued to grow. But the league still lacked soccer-only stadiums like the one in Columbus, Ohio, where the M.L.S. Cup was played Sunday.
 There has been a lot of talk about new stadiums, but not a shovel has been lifted since Columbus Crew Stadium was built two years ago by LAMAR HUNT, the team's owner-operator. 
 Commissioner DON GARBER sounded as optimistic as ever during the weekend at the league's championship match, won by the San Jose Earthquakes, 2-1, in overtime over the Los Angeles Galaxy. Garber said the Galaxy was expected to break ground on a stadium next month and the Dallas Burn was not far behind. 
 "Los Angeles is a reality," Garber said, referring to a stadium for the Galaxy that will also be a training site for the United States national teams. "It will be a stadium that will be measured against the best in the world."
 "Los Angeles should be done for the 2003 season, and we have reached the point of having a commitment from the McKinney community outside Dallas for a house for the Burn."
 The MetroStars, meanwhile, have focused their attention on Hudson County in New Jersey and they are working toward building a stadium in Harrison, N.J.
 Garber said the league's owners had enough money to operate for at least the next five years. M.L.S. will not expand in 2003 as previously planned. "This is not the appropriate economic climate," he said.
 The league's announcement of a five-year television package with ESPN and ABC, expected yesterday, will now come later this week.
 The league handed out its annual awards for its top executives over the weekend in conjunction with M.L.S. Cup. JIM SMITH of Columbus was named executive of the year. STEVE PASTORINO of Chicago won for marketing, CHRIS BRIENZA of the MetroStars for public relations and ED AUSTIN of Tampa Bay for operations.

UNITY GAMES
 There will be several guest players in Sunday's doubleheader at Giants Stadium to raise money for the families of the victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The MetroStars will play D.C. United after the New York Power and the Washington Freedom of the Women's United Soccer Association play at 4 p.m. The same four teams will meet again Nov. 3 at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington.
JEFF AGOOS, captain of the champion Earthquakes, will play for D.C. United with two of the team's other former stars, JOHN HARKES and CARLOS LLAMOSA. Also playing for D.C. United, but only in Washington, will be JURGEN KLINSMANN, the former German international. Klinsmann works for PHILIP ANSCHUTZ, who has expanded his M.L.S. owner-operator stake with the acquisition of United. Anschutz also operates teams in Chicago, Colorado and Los Angeles.
 TONY MEOLA of Kansas City and DIEGO SERNA of Miami will be the guests for the MetroStars, who have commitments from RHETT HARTY, MILES JOSEPH and BRIAN KELLY to rejoin the team for the two games. The MetroStars are also trying to secure another former player, JIM ROONEY, who is now with Miami.
 There was no word from the women's teams on whether they would have guest players.

WORLD CUP
 Saudi Arabia reached the finals in World Cup qualifying for the third straight time after its 4-1 victory over Thailand Sunday, joining China as the other representative from Asia. (Japan and South Korea qualify automatically as the host nations.) Iran was one of the favorites, but it lost to Bahrain by 3-1 and will have to play the United Arab Emirates in a two-game, home-and-away playoff to determine who will play Ireland for a spot in the finals.
 Ireland Coach Mick McCarthy said yesterday that he would fly to Tehran tomorrow to watch Thursday's game between Iran and U.A.E. (he also plans to attend the return match, which is scheduled for Oct. 31 in the U.A.E.). McCarthy said he was undaunted about flying there despite the air strikes on Afghanistan.

COLLEGES
 ALECKO ESKANDARIAN scored the only goal to give Virginia a 1-0 overtime victory over Duke and keep the Cavaliers in second place in the coaches' ranking behind Southern Methodist, a winner over Tulsa. Third-ranked St. Louis posted its 10th consecutive victory for its best start since 1971, while St. John's, ranked fourth last week, tied Virginia Tech.
 In other games over the weekend among men's ranked teams, defending champion Connecticut (8-3-3) lost to Georgetown; Seton Hall and Syracuse tied; Notre Dame shut out Boston College; South Carolina and Rutgers tied; Oregon State beat U.C.L.A.; Stanford edged Santa Clara; and Penn State beat Michigan State.
 In women's games, Penn State captured its fourth consecutive Big Ten championship with a victory over Northwestern, and Santa Clara handed neighboring St. Mary's its first loss of the season on a goal by ALY WAGNER on a free kick with a minute left.
 In other games over the weekend, Connecticut upset Notre Dame for the first time since 1997; Maryland edged William & Mary for the first time since 1995; Florida downed Georgia; Tennessee beat South Carolina; Stanford edged Washington; and U.C.L.A. beat Southern California. ALEX YANNIS

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
An upturn in account spending that was expected in 2002 may not come until 2003, executives say.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
THE current steep decline in advertising spending will begin to reverse itself later than had been expected, several leading marketers and agency media executives predicted yesterday, partly because of the effects of the terrorist attacks and partly because of the softness in the economy before Sept. 11.
 The attacks did not affect the advertising economy so much as they "affected the brains, the heart, the psychology" of decision makers in the industry, said Jon Mandel, co-managing director at MediaCom Worldwide in New York, a media services agency that is owned by the Grey Global Group. 
 "We had been projecting the falloff in advertising would run until somewhere between May and July 2002," he added, but it is now possible "the upturn may be pushed to winter 2003."
Mr. Mandel was among the executives offering their forecasts and opinions at a panel during a general session of the 2001 American Magazine Conference at the Sheraton Hotel and Towers in Midtown Manhattan. 
Through the first six months of 2001, the latest period for which data is available from CMR, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres, American ad spending fell 6.4 percent from the first half of 2000.
That decline continued through the third quarter, as evidenced by reports last week from the Wall Street analysts following Madison Avenue, who reduced their estimates for third-quarter earnings for the largest agency companies like the Interpublic Group of Companies, the Omnicom Group and the WPP Group.
"Let's face it, business was lousy on Sept. 10," said David Verklin, chief executive at the Carat North America division of Carat in New York, the media services agency owned by the Aegis Group.
"Clients are not looking for a reason to spend money," he added. "They're looking for reasons not to spend money."
The process of what Mr. Verklin called "de-selection" will probably extend through 2002, he said, as ad spending declines by 5 percent to 5.5 percent from whatever the final figure is for 2001.
Next year "will be very difficult," Mr. Verklin said, "with July the earliest time we see a pickup."
"Some sectors will be particularly badly hurt," he predicted, including travel, financial services, business-to-business and technology.
One marketer panelist underscored that forecast.
"Financial service companies are hurting, all the major firms, including my firm," said Frederick W. Hill, executive vice president for marketing communications at J. P. Morgan Chase & Company in New York.
As a result, he added, for 2001 and "well into 2002, our ad dollars will be curtailed substantially, compared with levels three, four years ago."
Mr. Hill echoed Mr. Mandel by predicting a turnaround "beyond 2002," but offered these encouraging words to the sellers of ad space in the audience: "You have an opportunity, to come to us with creative ideas on how to gain market share, increase sales, in a recession. If you come with ideas other than just increasing your ad pages, we'll listen."
Another advertiser, Jeffrey A. Bell, vice president for marketing communications at the Chrysler Group in Auburn Hills, Mich., forecast that this quarter, as well as the first two quarters of 2002, "will be very painful."
One reason, said Mr. Bell, whose company is part of DaimlerChrysler, is that after the attacks many marketers "are starting to make the difficult decisions they had hoped they would not have to make," which include "filing for Chapter 11, downsizing and layoffs."
The campaigns that the Chrysler Group has run after Sept. 11 are being reshaped, he added, to emphasize "core values" for each brand that may resonate more strongly now, like "safety, security, resilience."
One factor complicating the forecasting for 2002, according to another marketer, is the increasingly shorter lead times for making ad-spending decisions.
Such decisions are being delayed "to an extraordinary degree," said Peggy Kelly, vice president for advertising services at the global marketing services group at Bristol-Myers Squibb in New York. "We're doing it absolutely as late as we can."
The events after the terrorist attacks have only increased the "incredible need all advertisers feel for flexibility," she added. The sitution is manifesting itself, she said, in the way they "need to commit at the last possible moment" as well as in the way "they need to get out of commitments."
Another problem in making predictions, Ms. Kelly said, is the fact "the economy in general is looking like a deflationary economy instead of an inflationary economy," a change that is spreading beyond consumer product categories like computers.
"It's tough to think how to reconfigure your business if you have to show growth every year in a deflationary economy," she added.
The conference, sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America and the American Society of Magazine Editors, continues through today at the Sheraton. About 550 people are attending the conference, which was moved from Phoenix because of a reluctance many potential attendees expressed about traveling outside New York at this time.
The organizers are taking advantage of the new location -- the first time the conference has ever been held in New York -- to help city officials with efforts to spur a recovery from the attacks. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani spoke at the opening session on Sunday night, along with the two mayoral candidates, Michael R. Bloomberg and Mark Green.
Kits distributed to those who attended included discount certificates for purchases at Bloomingdale's as well as for tickets to "Kiss Me, Kate."
Kiss, schmiss, what about buying some ad pages?

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Rise Despite Poor Earnings and Economic Figures

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Stocks climbed yesterday, as investors continued to show confidence in an eventual economic recovery.
 Still, several analysts warned that the stock market's moves these days are dominated by mood rather than news, and that each bold rally is likely to be followed by a sharp retreat for quite some time. 
 Reports on corporate profits and the economy have been pretty much as expected -- bad -- and yesterday's reports were no different. Wall Street analysts seemed to find that sort of news not only unsurprising but also uninteresting. 
"The only other driver is geopolitical events," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company.
Although those events were more anthrax scares and more raids on Afghanistan, investors latched onto a confident mood. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 172.92 points, or 1.9 percent, to close at 9,377.03. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 36.77 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,708.08. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 16.42 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,089.90.
"Is it sustainable?" said David Henwood, chief investment officer for Raymond James & Associates. "We don't think so."
"There is a feeling on the part of some that you just never know when this market's going to take off," Mr. Henwood said. "You need to use these rallies in the market to take some gains on stocks that are moving without any fundamental good news."
Each of the major indexes dropped 1.5 percent or more last week, and the market's rally yesterday was enough to make back the bulk of those losses.
The gains in the Dow were led by Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which rose $5.22, to $107.39. The company reported a 21 percent decline in third-quarter earnings and warned that its fourth-quarter profits would fall at the low end of analysts' estimates.
American Express, another Dow component and a company that has moved its offices temporarily because of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, said its profits had fallen 60 percent, to $298 million, or 22 cents a share, in the quarter. Analysts expected the company to earn 19 cents to 36 cents a share, with an average estimate of 30 cents, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Still, shares of American Express gained $1, to $30.32.
Earnings for companies in the S.& P. 500 are down 22.4 percent from last year, with about 245 companies reporting, according to Thomson Financial/First Call, which made its estimate with the assumption that companies that have not yet reported will match estimates.
Some of those most acutely affected by the terrorist attacks have yet to report. The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines; Starwood Hotels; and the Hilton Hotels Corporation have scheduled announcements for this week. Many other airlines have scheduled announcements for next week.
The Conference Board, an economic research group based in New York, also reported that its index of leading indicators fell 0.5 percent in September, with the drop beginning before the attacks.

Treasury Prices Slip
 (By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as the market awaited a jumbo corporate debt sale from the Ford Motor Company.
Ford Motor planned to sell $9.4 billion in debt in what would be the sixth-largest corporate debt sale ever, and more than three times what the company originally planned, because of heavy investor demand.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 4/32, to a price of 102 30/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.62 percent from 4.61 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32, to 100 3/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.37 percent from 5.36 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: In Tougher Times, It's a Life of Affluence Minus Trimmings; 
Pinched, But Not Really Pinching Pennies

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: COLORADO SPRINGS 

 BODY:
Only one stock in Gary Markle's portfolio is still in the black, but that did not stop him from buying a 2002 Mercury Mountaineer sport utility this month for his wife.
 "She wanted a new car, her car was two or three years old, and we said, well, sure," said Mr. Markle, a software entrepreneur who now runs the Colorado Springs Technology Incubator. "What really pushed us over the edge were the deals out there." he added. "But even without those incentives, we would have bought it." 
 Construction has also continued on the Markles' $1.5 million dream home, which they started in February. They briefly had second thoughts after the terrorist attacks but quickly decided that it made no sense to walk away from the project. 
As the nation heads into an economic period with all the hallmarks of a recession, affluent people in this affluent community of 358,000 splayed at the foot of Pikes Peak are still eating cake. They are beginning, though, to forgo the icing.
"Anything even slightly capricious is out," said Mike Edgar, president of Wells Fargo's retail banking operation here. "But they're still buying cars, and home building is still strong."
Many here, like their counterparts around the country, have lost money in the stock market. Their retirement portfolios have also shrunk. That financial strain, rather than the economic shock delivered by the attacks, seems to be the prime contributor to the more cautious attitude now evident here.
Yet even as some people are losing the well-paid jobs that help support local prosperity, housing values are so far holding up, helping maintain a general sense that the bottom is not falling out of the economy.
Colorado Springs has certainly not escaped economic distress. Layoffs are running at a record pace this year, and sales-tax revenue has sharply dropped off. Intel, the big computer-chip maker, and Atmel, a computer circuitry manufacturer, have both held off on plans for new facilities here. Tourism began to slow even before the attacks on New York and Washington. The large population of retired military people in Colorado Springs -- home to Fort Carson, Peterson Air Force Base and the Air Force Academy -- is feeling pinched, too.
Nonetheless, the well-to-do here are still buying cars, going out to dinner and pumping money into real estate. "We have had three to four years of unprecedented wealth growth in this country," Mr. Markle said. "I think people are saying to themselves, well, 'I had $3 million, and now I only have $2 million. But $2 million is still a lot of money.' "
More broadly, as the stock market posted ever higher highs and housing values doubled and even trippled in some places, economists spent countless hours the last few years analyzing the impact that increased wealth had on overall consumer spending in the United States. Estimates of the increase in spending for every dollar that wealth increases, known as the wealth effect, range from about 3 to 18 cents, depending on the analyst.
"The wealth effect has been the biggest factor behind the economy's enormous growth in recent years," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, a consulting firm, "and so it is also the biggest risk to continued expansion."
Now the question is whether the wealth effect works the same way in reverse. Housing values remain strong but the stock market has taken a beating, pulling down the average net worth of American households -- much of it concentrated in the upper fifth of the income spectrum -- to an estimated $363,000 at the end of the third quarter compared with a peak of $426,000 in the third quarter last year. (The net worth of the typical household is well below the average because most Americans own little stock.)
"The surge in wealth created a surge in spending, and we will go back to more normal spending behavior," Mr. Zandi said.
James Smith, a labor economist at the RAND Corporation, agreed that the fall in the stock market, if it persists, will have a negative impact on spending -- but only over a two- or three-year period. "The wealth effect has to persist for reasonable periods of time," he said. "Worrying about one day, one month or even six- month changes in the stock market is not a reasonable guide."
That is because changes in fundamental spending habits are not made overnight. George Kreigler, a senior vice president at the Quantum Corporation, a California-based data storage and protection company with manufacturing operations here, figures that he is worth twice as much today as he was in 1995, despite some losses in the stock market and a decline in the value of his options.
"In 1995, I lived a very conservative life; I don't live that way anymore," Mr. Kreigler said. "If this downturn continues, I would have to adjust my lifestyle -- and that wouldn't be easy. You get used to going out to shows, to dinner, traveling." 
For now, while self-indulgence is on the wane, signs of serious frugality are hard to see here. Indeed, if anything, many affluent residents are seeking ways to capitalize on the downturn. Nowhere is that more apparent than in real estate.
Matt A. Coleman, who heads strategy and business development for Van Gilder Insurance, a privately held regional insurer, recently took out a home equity loan and used the proceeds to buy a vacant lot in the affluent Kissing Camels residential development here. And he is looking for other opportunities to buy property.
Mr. Coleman, a graduate of the Naval Academy, sold his family's insurance business to Van Gilder in 1998. "I had watched the value of the business grow dramatically since 1992 and decided to sell," he said. "That's a kind of very meaningful wealth creation event that isn't in the public domain, and in the last several years, a lot of people have had similar good fortune."
Jeff Smith, founder of the Classic Companies, a group of housing development and finance companies, said that with mortgage rates so low, housing is still seen as a good value, particularly compared with the stock market.
"People see it as the chance of a lifetime to own a home, and in some cases, a more expensive one than they might have originally planned on," he said. "They see money as cheap."
Larry Nichols, who builds custom homes with an average price of $1 million, said revenue this year -- despite a few canceled or postponed contracts -- will be about the same as last year's record-setting pace.
"One client had to sell a house elsewhere and ran into difficulty with that; one had planned an I.P.O. that was put on hold," he said. "But they've been replaced by new buyers; some cashed in their stock holdings and put the proceeds into real estate."
Not all real estate has retained its allure, however, and some worry that high-end prices will fall a lot further.
Meanwhile, among the affluent there are signs that spending on a host of extra luxuries has already started to slow. Paul Fredell says that for the first time since he started his residential and commercial landscaping business 17 years ago, revenue will be down this year. He is taking out larger ads in the Yellow Pages and trying to increase his commercial business to help offset the decline.
For many well-off people here, the market decline does not mean cutting back on existing spending so much as postponing their ambitions.
"The downturn in the stock market has certainly made us much more conservative when it comes to purchasing big-ticket items," said Jim Johnston, a retired brigadier general who is now an investment adviser. He and his wife had considered trading their $400,000-plus mountain retreat for one in the $700,000 to $750,000 range but have put that off.
That kind of thinking is putting a real crimp in Steven R. King's business. With a partner, Mr. King has spent the last few years buying ranch properties in the area and carving them up into lots for retirement and weekend homes. Until this year it was going great. But no longer. "The only way to say it is that we started careering downhill fast after the first quarter," he said. "We usually do 65 percent of our business in August, September and October, but today we're sitting on zero."
His own investments have suffered, too, so much that the value of his son's college fund dropped to the point where he and his wife felt compelled to dip into other finances to bolster it.
Mr. Kreigler, the Quantum executive, said the drop in the stock market had cut his 18-year-old son's college fund in half, too, but even so, there is plenty left to cover the costs of four years at the University of Nebraska.
And while cautious, Mr. Kreigler is not yet worried about his immediate finances. Attracted by incentives, he recently bought a $40,000 Acura 3.5RL. He and his wife were on vacation in Hawaii on Sept. 11. He has no plans to stop buying expensive new stereo equipment.
His investment portfolio, he said, is fairly safe, heavily weighted to government, municipal and corporate bonds. He might be interested in the right investment property if something strikes his eye.
Still, he realizes that his situation has changed for the worse. His options are worth much less than before; Quantum stock hit its high for the year on Jan. 11 and is now down more than 40 percent.
"One of my longtime goals has been to retire at 50," he said. "I'm now 48, and it looks like I'm going to miss that target."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LEADERS; 
A Flurry of Hugs for 'Gang of Five' in Capital

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 

 BODY:
When President Bush smothered the highest-ranking Democrats, Senator Tom Daschle and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, in bear hugs last month after he addressed a joint meeting of Congress, Mr. Bush wondered if he had gone too far.
 The next day, Mr. Daschle said, the president asked him, "Do you think it was O.K. that we hugged each other in front of all these people?" 
 Of his reply Mr. Daschle recalled, "I said, 'It just seemed like the natural thing to do.' " 
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, did not get a hug, though he was standing behind Mr. Daschle, of South Dakota.
"That was more a bear hug from Daschle than it was from Bush," Mr. Lott said, a tad defensively. "I gave him a very strong handshake. I'm not a hugger, I guess."
They are still working out the kinks in this newfound cuddliness. The latest twist in the relations among the United States' top leaders came late last week when the House shut down because of the anthrax threat. But the Senate stayed open, leaving members of the House to cast the senators as reckless and the senators to cast the House as overly cautious. On Tuesday, the leaders and their Congressional colleagues are due back in their chambers.
Shut down or not, hugs or no hugs, lawmakers said they could not remember when Democratic and Republican leaders in Congress had worked so intimately with each other -- and with the president.
Before Sept. 11, Mr. Bush's relationships with Mr. Lott, Mr. Gephardt, Mr. Daschle and the speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert, were often little more than perfunctory. Mr. Hastert, of Illinois, and Mr. Gephardt, of Missouri, rarely even spoke to each other.
These days, they are the Gang of Five. Often to the exclusion -- and great dismay -- of other lawmakers, they have made fundamental decisions as a group, from the federal budget deal to the $15 billion bailout of the airline industry.
"Instead of having formal, photo-op meetings, they're actually having real working meetings where things are getting done and decisions are being made," said Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana. "There's been grumbling about what's happening to the process of governing though committees."
For the first time, Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Hastert are being accused of working together too closely.
"There are a lot of people who think he is being too accommodating to Denny," Representative James P. Moran, Democrat of Virginia, said of Mr. Gephardt. "I think he is being a genuine statesman."
The five leaders, who sometimes chat with one another several times a day, have formed a breakfast club since Sept. 11. Every Tuesday or Wednesday at 7 a.m., they gather around a table in the private dining room off the Oval Office.
The breakfasts, which began at Mr. Bush's behest, have become so indispensable that the president, resisting advice of aides, held one last Wednesday before he left for China. (Immediately afterward, Mr. Bush's guests escorted him to his helicopter, Marine One, to bid him farewell.) Though not an early riser, Mr. Lott sets his alarm before 5:30 a.m. to get to the breakfasts. He said he would not dare miss one.
Mr. Bush, fresh from the China trip, has scheduled another 7 a.m. breakfast on Tuesday.
The fallout from last week's breakfast was not entirely positive. Aides to Mr. Hastert and Mr. Gephardt complained that their bosses' decision to close the House last week was based on information Mr. Daschle received at the breakfast.
Even so, the leaders say the breakfasts are bound to have long-term benefits. After only four, the group has fallen into a routine. As the lawmakers are ushered into the inner sanctum, their aides are dismissed. There are no place cards, but Mr. Bush presides at the head of the table. Mr. Lott and Mr. Hastert sit on one side; Mr. Daschle and Mr. Gephardt on the other. Mr. Bush, having already had cereal, usually picks at the bowl of fruit in front of him. Mr. Lott orders from the White House menu what he calls "a full load" of coffee, juice, eggs, toast and grits.
At the breakfast last Wednesday, Mr. Bush began by laying out the latest action in Afghanistan. But the unfolding anthrax scare dominated the give and take. Two guests stopped in for presentations: Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, and George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence.
It was not all somber. Mr. Bush teased Vice President Dick Cheney (who has attended three of the four breakfasts) for emerging from seclusion. "He made some light mention of how great it is to see the vice president in the flesh," Mr. Daschle recalled.
The four Congressional leaders said in interviews that their dealings were far more candid than ever in the past.
Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Daschle said they were particularly struck by how Mr. Hastert had not been timid in their presence to ridicule the restive conservatives on his team. They cited one Capitol Hill meeting where Mr. Hastert found himself in a vigorous debate with Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, and Representative Tom DeLay, also of Texas, the majority whip, over their objections to a special relief fund for the attack victims. Mr. Hastert, the most senior, cut them off.
"Dennis, to his great credit, just overruled them," Mr. Gephardt said. "He said, 'We only need four votes to do this -- we're going to do it.' "
Beyond huddling over legislation, the five men have developed a much more personal relationship. Mr. Lott said that when he turned 60 on Oct. 9, his first call was from Mr. Bush. Mr. Gephardt also called.
And Mr. Daschle, with a cake, burst into a luncheon where Republican senators were assembled. Mr. Lott -- the man who resists hugs -- found himself in an embrace.
As Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, recalls the scene: "Daschle shakes his hand, gives him a hug and wishes him a happy birthday. They almost held hands."
Mr. Daschle and Mr. Gephardt said they would probably not have done anything had Mr. Lott's birthday been before Sept. 11.
The bonding has been particularly beneficial for Mr. Gephardt. Because his party does not control the White House and is the minority in the House, the other leaders had no imperative to pay attention to him.
Of his relations with Mr. Hastert before Sept. 11, Mr. Gephardt said: "There was no communication. At least now there's human communication."
Yet for all the stroking, Mr. Gephardt and other Democrats said they expected Mr. Bush to side with conservatives on economic stimulus.
"I know we're going to run into more holes in the road because we don't agree on how to do stimulus," Mr. Gephardt said.
There has always been better communication between Mr. Dachle and Mr. Lott because, with only 100 members, the Senate is more collegial.
"Trent and I have had highs and lows in our relationship," Mr. Daschle said. "But I don't know if I've ever felt that we've worked closer together."
Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Hastert said they bonded out of necessity on Sept. 11. After the attacks, the four Congressional leaders were whisked by helicopter from the Capitol to a secure location, believed to be in West Virginia. They spent hours together, eating bologna sandwiches and monitoring the news.
"We were in this room together and spent more time together than we've probably spent in our lives together," Mr. Hastert said. "When there are four people in a foxhole, you get to learn a lot about each other."
Describing how bonds were created in such dire circumstances, Mr. Gephardt said: "It was, in a way, a nightmare. You've got to remember we still didn't know what all could happen. When we got there, Cheney and others told us there were still planes out there unaccounted for. We didn't know what was going to happen. Scary stuff."
The hugs still loom as the most enduring symbol of the altered relationship.
Mr. Lott appeared rankled by the embrace. Asked if it was excessive, he took a long pause and carefully picked his words, saying, "Not really. I chose not to do that. I don't have any criticism of it either."
The morning after the hugs, Mr. Bush seemed a bit sheepish when he spotted Mr. Lott and Mr. Hastert at the White House. The president's Congressional liaison, Nicholas E. Calio, said Mr. Bush pondered whether to embrace the two Republicans but instead offered soothing words.
"He told them, 'Of course, I know you two a lot better,' " Mr. Calio said. " 'I've kind of hugged you in the past.' "

HEADLINE: Trade Panel Backs Steel Makers, Enabling Broad Sanctions 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 

 BODY:
A United States trade panel decided today that American steel makers had suffered serious injury from foreign competition, a ruling that will allow President Bush to impose the broadest restrictions in a decade on steel imports.
 The Bush administration sought the decision from the panel, the International Trade Commission, last summer and now is widely expected to impose hefty duties or quotas on foreign-made steel early next year. The final shape of the penalties awaits further hearings and a decision from the White House. 
 Sanctions are likely to apply to almost all types of steel goods and would affect the price of everything from automobiles to clothes hangers. Trade restrictions will answer the pleadings of one of the nation's sickest industries, but can be expected to annoy free-traders and alarm major trading partners like Britain, Germany, Mexico, Brazil and South Korea. 
Domestic steel producers have put pressure on Mr. Bush to protect their industry, which they say is on the verge of collapse because of cut-price competition from abroad. So far, the administration has responded more favorably to their appeals than the Clinton administration did.
Leo W. Gerard, president of the United Steelworkers of America, called the decision "the first ray of hope in years" for steelworkers and some 600,000 retirees who depend for their benefits on the shaky finances of the steel companies.
Groups advocating free trade criticized the ruling, urging the Bush administration to refrain from sheltering the industry from imports.
"This is the wrong time for steel protectionism," said Calman J. Cohen, president of the Emergency Committee for American Trade, an industry-backed group that favors open trade. "In this time of an unprecedented crisis, the world is looking to the United States for leadership, not protectionism."
Mr. Bush has often said that expanding free trade is among his top economic priorities, and he and the White House trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, say it is an important component in building an alliance against terrorism. Still, administration officials have been straightforward about aiding the steel industry. Some administration supporters say privately that Mr. Bush and his top aides view help for the steel makers as one way of persuading members of Congress to support their trade proposal.
The industry and its unions are among the most potent in national politics. They make large contributions to candidates and are seen as able to influence the presidential election in several large, often closely divided states like Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Ohio. Mr. Bush won West Virginia, traditionally a Democratic state, last year after the Clinton administration declined to start a broad action against steel imports of the sort that the Bush administration initiated in June.
The sensitivity of the issue has only increased since then, with companies including Bethlehem Steel, the third-largest American producer, recently filing for bankruptcy protection.
But the political calculus is a complex one. The Bush administration is also trying to persuade foreign trade ministers to make it easier for companies to ship goods, invest in projects and win government contracts globally. The ruling against steel imports sends a protectionist signal shortly before those talks are to begin in Doha, Qatar, next month.
Administration officials will also have to weigh the impact of any aggressive tariffs or quotas on Britain and Russia, among the largest exporters of steel and steel products to the United States and most important allies in the campaign against terrorism. 
One possibility is that the administration could try to use the International Trade Commission's ruling as leverage to persuade foreign countries to restrict steel production through so-called voluntary accords, as was done in seeking to stabilize the aluminum industry in the mid-1990's.
The administration brought the steel case before the trade commission under Section 201 of the 1974 trade act. 
That step is a potent one because under Section 201, the White House can impose penalties even without determining that foreign producers gained an advantage by pricing their exports below the cost of production. Likewise, any penalties apply broadly to foreign exporters and are not tailored to punish specific countries or companies viewed as practicing unfair competition.
Judges for the trade panel did not back the domestic steel industry on every count. They rejected complaints that companies manufacturing some kinds of products, like steel wire and nails, had suffered harm from imports. But their ruling covers an estimated 79 percent of domestic production.

HEADLINE: Samsung Electronics Reports Plunge of 75% in Earnings 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 22 

 BODY:
Officials at Samsung Electronics maintained an air of determined optimism today even as they announced a huge plunge in quarterly earnings. But they carefully avoided any mention of what many experts say Samsung needs most: for its ailing rival, Hynix Semiconductor, to collapse once and for all.
 One Samsung official acknowledged privately that the disappearance of Hynix, which ranks third worldwide behind Samsung and Micron Technology in semiconductor sales, could be the ultimate solution for Samsung and other technology companies -- but also acknowledged that the topic was taboo. 
 On Friday, Hynix, formerly Hyundai Electronics, posted a third-quarter net loss of $1.25 billion. Deep in debt, it has turned over control of its finances to its creditors and is negotiating with them over a $4 billion rescue plan. Hynix said last week that it was ready to discuss asset sales with any interested investor.
Its struggles are widely seen as one reason chip prices have been sinking to new lows on world markets, and they help explain why Samsung earnings dropped 75 percent in the third quarter from the corresponding period last year. Desperate for cash, Hynix has been selling semiconductors for half the cost of production, and Samsung and other manufacturers have had to match those bargain-basement prices to compete, analysts said.
The price of benchmark 128-megabyte dynamic random access memory chips has been slipping 1 to 2 percent a day, some analysts said, and may not stabilize until it has fallen another 20 to 30 percent.
As a result, said Kim Gee Soo, an electronics analyst at Nomura Securities here, Samsung has to rely almost exclusively on the sale of telephone handsets for its dwindling profit. On the strength of that business, Samsung earned $323 million in the quarter, down from $1.3 billion in the third quarter of 2000.
Still, James Chung, a Samsung spokesman, said "the results were beyond imagination," considering that some analysts foresaw a loss.
And Chu Woo Sik, a vice president of the company, told investors that it would not cut back on chip production, even though the division lost $292 million in the quarter.
Mr. Kim of Nomura acknowledged that the third-quarter report was better than Nomura expected but added that there was "no upside potential" despite the strong asset value of the handsets. Samsung, he said, relies on sales in the United States, where the economy was already slumping before the Sept. 11 attacks. The digital media and household goods units, which account for nearly half Samsung's revenue, were only slightly profitable, he added.
Mr. Kim predicted that losses from chips would continue to widen and said he saw little chance that Hynix's creditors, led by government-controlled banks, would allow it to die any time soon.
Mr. Chung said Samsung's earnings would increase by late next year, but did not tie that forecast to any assessment of Hynix's future.

HEADLINE: 3M's Profit Declines 21% In Last Period 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Oct. 22 

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that its third-quarter earnings fell 21 percent and that its fourth-quarter profit might be less than some estimates.
 3M, which makes products ranging from Post-It Notes to electronic circuitry, said its net income fell to $394 million, or 99 cents a share, from $499 million, or $1.25 a share, in the quarter a year ago. Sales fell 7.1 percent, to $3.97 billion. 
 Excluding costs related to work force cuts and depreciation, profit in the latest quarter would have been $1.10 a share, the company said. Analysts had expected 3M to earn $1.09 a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
The company's chief executive, James McNerney, who was hired late last year, has been introducing the cost-cutting and efficiency programs he learned at General Electric. 3M has shed about 4,200 of the 5,000 jobs it has said it will eliminate and plans to cut more in coming months to cope with slowing sales, Robert Burgstahler, the chief financial officer, said during a conference call.
"3M has a new focus on costs and working capital," said Lewis Johnson, an analyst at T. Rowe Price. "This will benefit the company when the economic conditions normalize."
Sales of health care products, which account for about 15 percent of annual sales, rose 9.4 percent in the quarter. The business includes dental and pharmaceutical products and health-information systems, like computers that manage patient records.
Sales fell at all of 3M's other businesses including transportation and consumer products. Especially hard hit was the electronic and telecommunications business, where sales fell 21 percent, and profit 60 percent.
Mr. Burgstahler said the drop in the company's total profitability from last quarter to this quarter was solely attributable to the telecommunications and electronic business.
Shares of the company, based in St. Paul, rose $5.22, or 5.1 percent, to $107.39. 
Fourth-quarter profit, before certain expenses, will fall to 95 cents to $1.05 a share from $1.12 in the period a year earlier, 3M said. The company is expected to have profit of $1.05 a share, according to First Call.

HEADLINE: Across America, Restaurants Adjust to a Stay-Put Nation 

BYLINE:  BY FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
THE aftershocks of last month's terrorist attacks have resonated in restaurants far beyond New York and Washington. Perhaps the hardest hit in the rest of the country was the San Francisco region, where restaurants had already been hurt by Internet company failures. The city's restaurants are strongly dependent on visitors. After Sept. 11, leisure travel fell 25 percent and business travel about 80 percent compared with a year ago, according to the Convention and Visitors Bureau.
 "Some San Francisco restaurants are still down by 20 to 40 percent," said Bradley Ogden, an owner of One Market in San Francisco and other restaurants in the Bay Area. "I know of 10 to 12 restaurants that have already closed." 
 Among the restaurants that have gone out of business are high-end places like Montage, Gabbiano's and Splendido. Niki Leondakis, the executive vice president for hotels and restaurants at the Kimpton Group, which owned Splendido, said the restaurant had already been challenged by the economy. "And after Sept. 11, we just couldn't sustain the rent," she said. Sales in the company's restaurants in six other cities, like Seattle and Portland, Ore., have not suffered as much, she added.
According to the National Restaurant Association, a Washington-based trade group, there are 844,000 restaurants in the United States. "And I would say that all felt the impact for the first 10 days," Steven Anderson, the group's president, said. Nationwide, some 100,000 restaurant workers -- 15,000 of them in New York -- have lost their jobs since Sept. 11. Suburban restaurants and neighborhood restaurants in cities seem to be weathering uncertain times better than high-end corporate or tourist-dependent restaurants. 
Tim Zagat, who publishes guides to restaurants in more than 40 American cities, said that downtown restaurants are hurting the most, especially in cities that are not vigorously promoting their restaurants, as New York has been doing.
In Chicago, several restaurateurs said business was back to within 10 percent of where it was a year ago. "Chicago did not suffer as big an economic downturn before the attacks as some other cities," said Rick Bayless, who owns Topolobampo and Frontera Grill. "And if Chicagoans were not traveling to other cities, they were staying here and eating in our restaurants." But business in the four restaurants that the Levy Organization owns in the 110-story Sears Tower is still off, partly because of increased security.
In Los Angeles, mid-level and inexpensive restaurants, especially ethnic ones, are rebounding, though high-end dining is still off. Similarly, Peter Christie, the president of the Massachusetts Restaurant Association, said that restaurants in downtown Boston, like Ambrosia, Radius and Seasons in the Four Seasons Hotel, which depend on corporate fly-in travelers, were suffering the most. "Steakhouses tend to be doing well," he added.
Todd English, who owns restaurants in Boston, Washington, Las Vegas and New York, said the one in Washington is the worst off. "We're two blocks from the White House," he said. "They have all these barriers up, and now this anthrax thing is freaking people out."
In New Orleans, tourism and convention attendance is down, but Susan Spicer, who owns three restaurants, said business has been building steadily. "You have to remember," she said, "in New Orleans the locals support the restaurants." 
In Atlanta, Pano Karatassos, the chairman of the Buckhead Life Restaurant Group, which owns 12 restaurants, predicted that October's sales would be down by only about 4 percent over last year. Nonetheless, he's taken caviar off the menu at his top restaurant, Pano's & Paul's.
Mr. Anderson of the National Restaurant Association is optimistic that restaurants will be resilient. "Fine dining has gone from being a leisure activity to an essential part of people's lives," he said.
Some restaurateurs said recent events have forced them to concentrate on providing better service. "We have to appreciate every customer who walks in the door," Mr. Bayless said. "And if anything good is coming out of all of this, that's it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: LOCKED DOOR -- In San Francisco, the Splendido restaurant has closed. (Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)
