HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
A Legal Tightrope for Employers After Attacks

BYLINE:  By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
Vincent Ferranti is a living management quandary, one that employers everywhere might want to ponder.
 On Sept. 11, Mr. Ferranti, 37, a bond-redemption specialist at Morgan Stanley, was walking by a window near his office on the fifth floor of 5 World Trade Center when the first plane hit 1 World Trade Center. He saw debris flying and people fleeing his building. 
 In the days that followed, he said he often felt too terrified to leave his Queens apartment. He began suffering anxiety attacks, up to 10 to 20 a day.
In an effort to wrestle free of his fears, Mr. Ferranti went back to work on Sept. 24, at temporary offices that Morgan Stanley set up about 10 blocks from the World Trade Center site. But even then, he found himself sobbing uncontrollably from time to time.
"I never experienced anxiety before," Mr. Ferranti said. "But now the slightest little thing triggers it, whether it's going through a subway tunnel or someone dropping something on a train. I just want to be home."
And therein lies the management puzzle. Just how far does his employer have to go to accommodate his concerns?
The first responsibility for corporate managers after the terror attacks was to help employees deal with their grief and fear. But now, they are also having to face up to a more conventional but equally complicated task: preparing for possible legal fallout from the disaster.
It is a delicate balancing act, to say the least. But employment lawyers and workplace specialists advise employers in New York and across the country to examine anew state and federal laws that could cause them legal or financial headaches. These can range from the threat of lawsuits for failing to abide by the Americans With Disabilities Act to the inconvenience of having to ask employees for permission to deposit paychecks automatically into their bank accounts.
"There are so many laws that were once on the back burner but that are now suddenly coming forward," said Peter J. Petesch, a partner in the Washington office of Ford & Harrison, an Atlanta law firm.
The federal disabilities law is a prime example. Most big corporations have complied with its ban on job discrimination and its requirements for special workplace accommodations. But it is not always clear who is covered under the legislation, leaving some employers to wonder what their responsibilities are to people who say the attacks have left them emotionally distraught.
Other difficult questions include:
*Whether employers risk lawsuits if they dismiss employees who refuse to be relocated to other offices, and whether such people are eligible for unemployment benefits.
*Whether employees who request time off for reasons related to the attacks are eligible for the 12 weeks of unpaid job-protected leave stipulated in the 1993 Family and Medical Leave Act.
*Whether companies can be sued if expatriate Americans who are denied requests to return to the States are injured or killed in future terrorist attacks.
*What special measures employers should institute to prevent workplace harassment of people of Mideastern origin.
*What companies' legal requirements are toward employees who are called to active military duty.
And while so far, few employment lawyers are reporting legal actions by workers against their employers, the scale of the national trauma makes it almost inevitable that some disputes will wind up in court.
Joan Caruso, a partner at the Ayers Group, a career management consulting firm in Manhattan, said that nearly all the employees that her company had voluntarily counseled at more than a dozen Wall Street firms had expressed concerns about going back to work or returning to New York.
And that, in turn, is creating confusion among employers, said Orna Guralnik, a Manhattan clinical psychologist who is also a partner at WorkLab Consulting, a Manhattan firm.
"Managers have repeatedly told us that they have people who want to stay home," and don't know whether to let them, Ms. Guralnik said.
David B. Ross, managing partner of the New York office of Seyfarth Shaw, a law firm in Chicago, describes another legal problem. After the attacks, his office heard from a number of Manhattan companies that were reeling from the attacks but to avoid layoffs wanted to ask employees to work less than five days for less than full pay.
It turned out they could not legally do so, because the Fair Labor Standards Act only allows employers to dock the pay of wage earners, not managers or supervisors who are paid weekly or monthly salaries. To comply with the act, companies would have had to reclassify their managerial employees as part-time workers, a hard administrative task, said William P. Perkins, a Seyfarth Shaw partner, who added that most of the companies opted for layoffs.
Some employers ran into another, if less daunting, legal wall when they tried to make sure faraway employees were paid on time. Ordinarily, the paychecks were sent by airmail, but because most planes were grounded, many companies queried the Society for Human Resource Management in Alexandria, Va., to see if they could require employees to use electronic direct-deposit programs for their paychecks.
The center's answer: only 10 states allow employers to make such deposits mandatory, and New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were not among them.
Generating answers for other employer inquiries may take longer. Melody L. Jones, the chief human resources officer at the Aon Corporation, which lost 200 employees in the attacks, said she was prepared for the possibility that some survivors would develop post-traumatic stress disorder, which can set off nonstop nightmares and often debilitate victims.
Ms. Jones said that a few employees had asked for medical leaves to take time off for emotional health.
"Right now our people are so focused on simply getting through this," she said.
As for Mr. Ferranti of Morgan Stanley, he is easing his way back into the workplace. His company has been sensitive to employees' fears, he says, allowing them to return to their jobs at their own pace. On his first day back, Mr. Ferranti worked for four hours and then returned home.
"It is comforting being back with fellow employees," he said. But, he added, "Right now, I don't want to be surrounded by people."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Famous Writer With Ambitions to Be a Working Stiff

BYLINE:  By ANNA MUNDOW; Anna Mundow, a freelance journalist, is also a correpsondent for The Irish Times.

 BODY:
SELLING BEN CHEEVER
Back to Square 1 in a Service Economy
By Benjamin Cheever
286 pages. Bloomsbury. $25.95
 Sometime during the mid-1990's Benjamin Cheever may have wrapped you a sandwich, sold you a computer or tried to sell you a car. You might not have recognized the older man in the ill-fitting uniform from his dust-jacket photographs. Mr. Cheever had recently slipped across the class border in polyester camouflage to become an undercover writer. 
 In 1995, when Mr. Cheever lost his publisher to corporate downsizing and failed to sell his third novel, he decided to write a book about "everybody's worst nightmare," taking entry-level jobs. "Selling Ben Cheever: Back to Square 1 in a Service Economy" is an account of five years spent pursuing and occasionally landing a variety of jobs, from sidewalk Santa to car salesman, that provided some of the happiest and bleakest moments in his life.
Unlike Barbara Enhrenreich in "Nickel and Dimed: On (Not) Getting By in America," Mr. Cheever the worker lived comfortably at home with his wife, Janet Maslin, then the chief film critic of The New York Times and now a book reviewer for the paper. His safety net did not, however, guarantee him immediate success. "This is a book about failure," Mr. Cheever admits at the outset, preparing us for the embarrassing interviews, the unanswered calls, the defeats witnessed by triumphant customers and wincing colleagues.
Failure is of course what we want. For the reader the appeal of an undercover odyssey is not only voyeuristic but mildly sadistic; we get to observe those who usually interpret reality for us receiving an undiluted dose of it themselves. For a novelist, paradoxically, it is an escape into reality. This seems particularly true for Mr. Cheever, a wry observer whose laconic, eliptical style at first seems ill suited to descriptions of life at the nonironic shop-floor level but who gradually relaxes into a more expansive, less mannered approach. Mr. Cheever has always been good at humiliation. In "Selling Ben Cheever," however, it is entertaining and oddly affecting to watch him describe his own.
When Mr. Cheever is recognized selling computers in White Plains, for example, he tries not to squirm. " 'Oh, so you're into this now,' said a woman who had been an editor with me at The Reader's Digest. I can't know, but I thought from the way she worked her face that she was thinking, Ben never was all that smart." Often the squirm is self-induced.
Writing a sales slip for H. Cabot Lodge, Mr. Cheever cannot resist blurting out, "I also have a famous name." Mr. Lodge politely ignores the gaffe and continues to call him Ben.
Answering advertisements, filling out application forms and hounding employers half his age, Mr. Cheever expects to be told, "You're too good for us." But nobody says that. People ask if he can work weekends and in some cases provide a urine sample. He finds that he can.
Descriptions of early stints as a sidewalk Santa and a security guard at a Guerlain warehouse are mildly funny but unengaging, and economic statistics on the number of "failures" out there and their struggle to survive strike a similarly flat note. Mr. Cheever is an unconvincing analyst, no Ehrenreich. What interests him are the messy details that ruin a spreadsheet, the insights provided by experience. At Nobody Beats the Wiz, for instance, a trainer reveals that "if you stink, you can't sell."
Aware that Antioch College in 1966 prepared him inadequately for sales, perhaps for anything ("One woman fulfilled her physical science requirement by having a baby. She got all 15 credits and named the child Lenin."), Mr. Cheever suspects his outlook to be a further impediment: "I've often confused losing with being a good sport." Working at the Cosi Sandwich Bar, however, he is inspired to construct the perfect sandwich. Soon he makes a less wholesome discovery: He loves to sell. He loves to sell cars.
At Wegman Auto, in the book's final section, "Big Game," Mr. Cheever hits his stride, even develops a swagger. Assigned to the G.M. side of the lot when he longs to sell Toyotas (the leather-jacketed Toyota salesmen are "the R.A.F. of Wegman Auto"), he plots a sneaky strategy. "I had a bowl of clementines for my desk, plus a windup toy seal in tin to amuse the children while I charmed their parents into ruinous debt." 
His is just a variation on the Wegman philosophy. It's great to be a salesman, the trainees learn, because you get to create reality: "You want your prospect out there imagining herself in the new car. . . . You want her imagining how the new antilock brakes might save her life."
Mr. Cheever conveys the tedium of the long, customer-starved hours spent calling prospects from his cubicle or pacing the lot, the clammy awkwardness of the first approach and the tension of protracted haggling. 
Describing the economics of the business, the plays, the feints, the lies, he cautions against easy condemnation. "Car salesman are obnoxious, but change the style, and they're a lot like the people we know," he observes, recalling Upper East Side dinner parties at which beautiful women concealed with rhapsodic enthusiasm their disappointment at being seated next to him.
Joking with four other men and one woman in the car dealership, sizing up the customers, closing in on a sale, Mr. Cheever realizes that he is having a better time than he ever had at those dinner parties. "Left to my own devices, I grow self-importance as a pond grows scum," he confesses. But this looser, stripped-down self is easier to please. Having made more than $4,000 in gross profit one February, more than any other new salesman, Mr. Cheever quivers with happiness when the boss grabs his shoulder and announces that "Benny, here, done phenomenal!"
That was the high point. Calculating that he could rely on earning $246.69 for a 50-hour week and despairing of making it across the road to Toyota or even to Nissan, Mr. Cheever quits, with a book to write of course, which is where the undercover writer's illusion dissolves.
He creates and sustains that illusion more elegantly than most as he works to make the person in the uniform more visible. "The book's greatest failing is that it's turned into such a personal story," he warns in his preface, "I'm the character I talk about most." This is true, but he is mistaken. The Ben Cheever revealed in these pages is worth selling.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
Decadence Meets Death On an 1800's Plantation

BYLINE:  By DAVE KEHR

 BODY:
Here's a real UFO, an extremely low-budget, genuinely independent film by a 22-year-old writer-director from Philadelphia that immediately establishes a distinctive and promising voice. 
 Andrew Repasky McElhinney's "Chronicle of Corpses" is a gothic horror tale set in the early 19th century on the grounds of a dying slave plantation somewhere in the Middle Atlantic states. Though once the center of a thriving economy, the plantation has degenerated into inertia and neglect, largely as a result of the deepening decadence of its ruling family, the Elliots. 
 Grandmother (Marj Dusay, of the soap "All My Children") has retreated into wordless dementia, leaving the family affairs in the hands of assorted offspring and in-laws, most of whom have serious problems with drinking and sex. There are a priest (Jerry Perna) still on retainer, a saucy young Irish servant (Margot White) who preserves what's left of the plantation's rapidly dimming life force, and the family's youngest member, Sara (Ryan Foley), a haunted teenager, who together represent what resistance there is to the dark forces gathering both inside the family and outside the house. 
Something strange and possibly supernatural is rampaging through the woods around the Elliot compound, selecting its victims at random and destroying them in assorted awful ways. Mr. McElhinney is careful not to overdefine his metaphors: the monster represents at once the waning of a singularly unjust period of American history and the manifestation of a particular disease infecting American families. 
Shooting on 16-millimeter film and using a cast drawn largely from local theater groups, Mr. McElhinney has created a movie that is not without the flaws endemic in low-budget productions but still projects an amazing degree of stylistic assurance and originality.
Unlike most of today's indie directors, he shows no interest in jittery, hand-held compositions. His film consists of strongly framed long shots in which the characters speak largely in mumbling monotones while remaining motionless, a style that recalls at once the deliberately zomboid acting of Edgar G. Ulmer's grade-Z classics of the 1940's ("Detour," "Strange Illusion") and the Brechtian alienation techniques of experimental European filmmakers like Jean-Marie Straub and Danielle Huillet. The film takes on a hushed, ritualized tone as the bodies begin to pile up, and the family confines itself more and more to the plantation's chapel. 
Mr. McElhinney is obviously an experienced cinephile (he is also the programmer of a long-running film society in Philadelphia, the Chestnut Hill Film Group), but his film doesn't drown in show-offy references to old movies. It is more a case of an antique aesthetic absorbed and revived. 
Though the technology is no longer available to create the kind of stately, formal tracking shots that Ulmer specialized in, Mr. McElhinney and his cinematographer, Abe Holtz, have been able to recreate the dreamy, fateful sense of those shots by using a Steadycam mount. 
"A Chronicle of Corpses" belongs to the small but significant tradition of outsider art in American movies -- films like Herk Harvey's "Carnival of Souls" or George Romero's "Night of the Living Dead" -- that reflect powerful personalities formed outside any academic or professional tradition. That most of these are horror films is no coincidence; they are the films that haunt American cinema, pointing to paths that were never taken, to doors that remain firmly closed. 

A CHRONICLE OF CORPSES

Written, produced and directed by Andrew Repasky McElhinney; director of photography, Abe Holtz; edited by Ron Kalish; released by ARM/Cinema 25 Pictures Inc. At the Two Boots Pioneer Theater, 155 East Third Street, at Avenue A, East Village. Running time: 83 minutes. This film is not rated.

WITH: Marj Dusay (Grandmother Elliot), Ryan Foley (Sara Elliot), Harry Carnahan Green (Tyrone), Kevin Mitchell Martin (Mr. Elliot), Sally Mercer (Mrs. Elliot), Jerry Perna (Father Jerome), Margot White (Bridgette) and Melissa Rex (the Killer).

HEADLINE: The Roots of an Afghan Nation 

BYLINE:  By Thomas W. Simons Jr.; Thomas W. Simons Jr. teaches at the Center for International Security and Cooperation at Stanford. He was America's ambassador to Pakistan from 1996 to 1998.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
We are now heavily engaged in discussions on post-Taliban political structures in Afghanistan. Afghans must be the main players, but outsiders also have major roles, and that clearly includes the United States. We will have much of the responsibility for giving post-Taliban institutions traction and staying power. Political negotiations on Afghanistan have always been extremely intricate. Those now under way can be more successful if we understand that there is space in Afghan politics between universalist Islam and the ethnic groupings that are so often painted as that unhappy country's only options.
 No doubt kinship ties give most Afghans their first identity -- a generation of war has made those ties more significant than ever; and no doubt the general shape of any political arrangement is going to have to reflect their importance. A functioning post-Taliban government will have to be a highly decentralized one in which ethnic groups enjoy substantial autonomy in their home regions. 
 But we should also recognize that the ethnic groupings that gave Afghanistan much of its structure under the Pashtun monarchy -- which ruled for more than two centuries until King Zahir Shah fell in 1973 -- belong to a past that will never return. Such groups were already weakening before the king was expelled, after a period of slow and patchy modernization. By its own choice, the country still had no railroads; but by the 1970's it had built modern roads, dams and irrigation systems, marketing networks, telegraph and telephone lines, and especially schools. All these investments eroded the country's traditional ethnic constituencies by reducing regional isolation, increasing literacy and expanding the national economy, albeit modestly.
The resulting political and social uncertainties helped produce the Communist takeover of 1978, and they helped define the war that followed the Soviet invasion of 1979. This was because freshly educated young men saw too few prospects for themselves or the country within the limits of traditional power structures -- and were able to build new ones. Most of the leaders who emerged in the war -- Communist and mujahedeen alike -- have been from Afghanistan's first college-educated generation. That was why Ahmed Shah Masud, the guerrilla commander assassinated Sept. 9, spoke French, and why Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, Pakistan's longtime favorite Pashtun Islamist who is now edging toward alliance with his old Taliban enemies, can style himself an engineer.
Foreign Minister Abdullah of the Northern Alliance is a medical doctor and speaks exceptional English, and the president of the shadow government he serves, Burhanuddin Rabbani, is always careful to append "professor" to his name. All these men were detribalized. War may have reinforced ethnic identities for many, but those identities are not as simple as they once were or as easy to hold. 
The decades of war have pounded away at the country's tribal structures even further. Historically, Afghans have had no particular reputation for Islamic rigor, but with familiar ethnic contours shifting and slipping, Islamist salvationism offered spiritual relief and, for a time, political clarity. 
When the Taliban arose in the mid-1990's, they were considered an alternative to the competing warlords whose soldiers were either mercenaries or kin. While the Taliban are mainly Pashtun, with their strongest base in tribal groupings around Kandahar, they spoke and fought in the name of a universal God.
For most Afghans, the Taliban's brand of universalism has probably been discredited by their mistakes and misdeeds, and now by the new misery they have brought down on Afghanistan. But the alternative is not a return to ethnic politics. Ethnic loyalties will still be important, but they cannot define the new system. Their weakened position in Afghan society was a factor that helped bring about the decades of war, and the wars have hastened that decay. Those loyalties can and should be subsumed in government structures that encourage a sense of nationhood beyond kinship.
Most Afghans of all ethnic groupings cherish their country, and they associate relative security and modest well-being with the centuries of cohabitation before the war. In the cities, ethnic groups have lived close together. The great shrines, like those in Mazar-i-Sharif, drew pilgrims from all over the country.
 The Afghan version of Persian, Dari, was not just the mother tongue of the Tajik minority, the Pashtun Durrani dynasty, and most inhabitants of Kabul. Dari, not Pashto, has been an Afghan lingua franca. There was, and can still be, a genuine Afghan national community.
If the post-Taliban government is to be stable, the discussions taking place in Pakistan, Rome and elsewhere -- among Afghans, Pakistanis, Americans, the United Nations special representative Lakhdar Brahimi and other parties -- must do more than broker positions at the starting gate. They must also point the way toward national institutions that can work.
From these discussions, a supreme council, with 120 members, is expected to emerge; negotiations on membership are set to begin in Istanbul next week. The council will probably appoint a loya jirga, or grand national assembly -- the basic governing body for a post-Taliban state. This assembly must include respected Pashtun leaders. Pakistani and American efforts to woo some Pashtuns away from the Taliban have been disappointing -- not least because the Pashtun southerners fear their ethnic rivals in the Northern Alliance. Certainly such efforts are crucial; but their very difficulty reveals the limitations of ethnic politics in working toward a national Afghan solution.
If the loya jirga does meet, it will still be only a start. Lasting stabilization will require new institutions with national reach -- government ministries that can build roads and schools and provide health care -- not to enforce centralization but to ensure a viable Afghan government. Afghanistan, like many countries, has failed to achieve a stable balance between central government and decentralized power. It has already paid a very high price for that failure; a new regime should be structured carefully so it might overcome this historic problem.

HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
In a sign of desperate times, many airlines on many of their flights will serve no meals.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
"WOULD you care for dinner?" the flight attendant asks.
 "What are the choices?" the passenger says. 
 "Yes and no," the flight attendant replies.
With the mounting miseries of air travel, that little joke, which was timely as recently as two months ago when airlines were merely cutting back on the quality and variety of the food they served, is already out of date. Very soon, at mealtime on most domestic flights, most airlines will no longer offer even a Hobson's choice -- which is defined as no choice at all. 
That is because many airlines are eliminating most meal service, except on international flights. If you want lunch on that business trip from, say, Boston to Chicago, you'll probably have to brown-bag it yourself.
Yesterday, United Airlines joined most of its major competitors and said it was eliminating a big portion of its meal service. Economy-class passengers "on flights that are 1,635 miles or less, which equates to about 3 hours and 45 minutes, will not have meals," said Chris Nardella, a United spokeswoman.
In first class, meals are being eliminated on flights under two hours, or about 700 miles, she said. Meal service on international flights is largely unchanged.
United thus joined American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines, US Airways, Midwest Express Airlines, T.W.A. and others in announcing sharp reductions in in-flight meal service in recent weeks. The only major holdout was Continental Airlines, which said yesterday that it would continue to serve meals as usual on its planes.
Still, some airline analysts, echoing the refrain that everything has changed since Sept. 11, say that we may be witnessing at least the partial demise of a basic component of air-travel culture: the ubiquitous, long-defamed airline meal.
"I think it's permanent," Michael Boyd, the president of the Boyd Group, an airline consultant firm based in Evergreen, Colo., said of the trend toward ending meals.
"Of course, some of the elimination had already begun," before Sept. 11, he said. "If you were flying in coach on shorter flights, hot meals were going the way of the dodo in any case."
The domestic airline industry, already seeing its worst year in a decade after its lucrative business travel market fell sharply last winter when the economy soured, has been desperately cutting costs since Sept. 11, even after it was granted a $15 billion federal bailout.
Airlines have slashed schedules, benched aircraft and announced layoffs of about 100,000 employees. Eliminating meals on many flights -- the food cost for an economy class meal averages about $4 for an airline --is another step in that process.
American Airlines and its T.W.A. subsidiary announced on Sept. 20 that, effective Nov. 1, they would no longer serve meals in economy class on domestic flights (excluding nonstop transcontinental flights) and in first class on domestic flights of less than two hours.
Next came Northwest. Northwest is cutting meal service in domestic economy-class flights except for those between its three hubs (at Detroit, Minneapolis/St. Paul and Memphis) and the West Coast, and in domestic first-class flights under two hours, according to Kurt Ebenhoch, a spokesman.
Delta then announced last Friday that, starting Nov. 1, it will eliminate meals on domestic flights of less than 1,750 miles in economy and less than 700 miles in first class. US Airways also said it would drop meal service on most domestic flights, except transcontinental nonstops.
Mr. Boyd has projected that domestic air traffic will be off 9 percent this year and that the domestic airline industry will experience a revenue shortfall of $28 billion over previously anticipated revenue in the next 15 months. He said that he even expected some airlines to remove kitchen facilities from some planes.
"You're probably looking at hot galleys being taken off a lot of airplanes to save weight," he said. "Why have them if you're not going to serve any food?"
Continental insisted that its policy to continue serving meals would remain in effect. "We absolutely will not change it," said Rahsaan Johnson, a spokesman.
He added: "It comes down to this: If you're a business traveler who just got out of a 5 o'clock meeting and you want to catch that 7 o'clock flight to get back home and you don't have time to stop to get something to eat, you want the airline to give you a snack or a meal; you want it to be appetizing, and you remember if you didn't get it."
The airline food-catering industry is reeling from the cuts.
Two companies, LSG Sky Chefs, owned by Lufthansa, and Gate Gourmet, owned by SAir Group, the parent of the financially troubled airline Swissair, dominate the in-flight meal business, operating kitchens around the world that turn out about 60 percent of all airline meals.
LSG, whose main customer in the United States is American Airlines, said in late September that it would lay off about 30 percent of its domestic work force of 16,300 at kitchens at 58 domestic airports. Gate Gourmet said it had eliminated 1,800 jobs in the United States.
"We're getting lots of conflicting reports, but across the board, the numbers I'm getting are 20 to 30 percent staff reductions" in the airline catering industry, said Steven P. Bowling, the executive director of the International Inflight Food Service Association.
"It looks very bad, and it could get worse," said Tom Snyder, a spokesman for the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union, which represents many of the in-flight catering industry workers. "We already have about 25 percent of our members in both LSG and Gate Gourmet laid off."
On airplanes, you can still get a cup of coffee, meanwhile. Getting some Sweet 'N Low or powdered creamer might be a problem, though.
Since the anthrax scares began earlier this month, panicked reports of suspicious white powders have diverted or delayed more than a dozen flights. As a result, one carrier, Northwest, said last week that it would no longer serve sugar substitutes or powdered creamer with coffee and tea.
Said Mr. Ebenhoch, the spokesman: "Every time it spills, it's a potential issue."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Evenin a gloomy business outlook, magazine executives see some long-term opportunities.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THOUGH magazines are facing perhaps their most clouded business outlook in decades, executives at a conference said yesterday, the problems confronting the industry bring with them opportunities to strengthen operations to prepare for the inevitable cyclical upturn.
 But as if to underline the chill of the current climate, as the executives were speaking at a panel during a general session of the 2001 American Magazine Conference, not far away, the American Association of Advertising Agencies was deciding to suspend publication of its own magazine, Agency, because of the weak economy. 
 "We have not done our jobs as consumer marketers," said one panelist, Jack Kliger, president and chief executive at Hachette Filipacchi Publications in New York, a division of the Lagardere Group that produces magazines like Elle, Premiere and Woman's Day.
"We have to change the model because we've become too dependent on advertising revenue," he added. "We have been spoiled by advertising revenue being very plentiful, and I don't see it coming back in the same way" after the downturn ends. 
A study by Veronis Suhler & Associates estimates that ad revenue as a contributor to total magazine revenue will reach 62 percent by 2005, compared with 60 percent last year and 53 percent in 1995. As reliance on ad revenue increases, magazines receive less revenue from sources like readers, in the form of payments for subscriptions and copies bought on newsstands; licensing rights fees and merchandise sales.
The dependence on ad revenue is dangerous because of the accelerating decline in demand for ad pages among marketers. Through September, magazine ad pages fell a steep 9.2 percent compared with those in the first nine months of 2000, according to the Publishers Information Bureau in New York. The bureau is an affiliate of the organizations that sponsored the conference, the Magazine Publishers of America and the American Society of Magazine Editors.
For instance, at Business Week magazine, owned by McGraw-Hill in New York, ad pages will have plunged to about 4,000 by the end of the year, said the moderator of the panel, Stephen B. Shepard, editor in chief, from 6,000 last year and 5,000 in 1999.
"What's worse," he added, "profitability levels will go back to 1991," a year of a war and a recession.
A decade later, it is deja vu all over again, as Yogi Berra would say.
"It's the worst marketplace to sell magazines to advertisers and consumers since World War II," said another panelist, Steven T. Florio, president and chief executive at Conde Nast Publications in New York, the unit of Advance Publications that is closing one of its myriad magazines, Mademoiselle, with the November issue.
But "as horrible as it is," he added, you "can examine every part of your business" for potential growth.
For example, Mr. Florio said, Conde Nast is "looking at other revenue sources for the first time" like licensing and merchandising. He joked that another panelist, Martha Stewart, who is known for capitalizing on such revenue sources, was about to introduce a line of F-15 fighter jets, "and on every bomb it'll say, 'And that's a good thing.' "
Ms. Stewart, chairwoman and chief executive at Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia in New York, discussed her actual enterprises, which range from $1.3 billion worth of licensed merchandise sold through Kmart stores to Martha by Mail, her in-house catalog operation, to a coming reintroduction of her Web site (www.marthastewart.com), on which "we've been spending a lot of money," she said, "to the dismay of Wall Street."
Also, "we're thinking about starting a new magazine," Ms. Stewart said, because "it's a good time" to do so as other publishers pull back.
"I'm not going to tell you the subject," she added, laughing, but she did disclose that the company would be "testing the waters with special issues" of its flagship magazine, Martha Stewart Living. In December, about 1.3 million subscribers will receive copies of a special issue called Living With Technology, Ms. Stewart said, to be solely sponsored by Hewlett-Packard.
Mr. Kliger also praised merchandising as an alternative form of revenue, declaring that "Elle merchandise sells $500 million around the world, and I don't think we've lost one page of advertising" from companies that sell competing goods.
Additionally, Mr. Kliger said, "it's a good time to make acquisitions, to get deeper in areas where you have" strong brands already.
Another panelist, Tom Rogers, chairman and chief executive at Primedia in New York, said that his company benefited by acquiring Emap USA, a publisher of enthusiast magazines like Guns & Ammo, Skin Diver and Snowboarder.
"We used to be No. 1 or No. 2 in so many of our categories," Mr. Rogers said. "Now, we are No. 1 and No. 2."
Enthusiast magazines present growth opportunities, he added, because their "endemic advertising has held up in recessions." (Mr. Rogers is, however, "going to sell a couple things," he said, to help "pay down some debt" owed by Primedia, estimated to total $2 billion.)
Mr. Florio was asked by an audience member what he would say "to reassure us in the magazine industry" after advertising agency executives repeated several times during panels on Monday that there were too many magazines.
"First of all, there are too many agencies," Mr. Florio replied, as the audience laughed and applauded. "Four guys in a loft in SoHo, and it's an agency."
But there are fewer agencies than there were a year or two ago as the dot-com collapse and the soft economy take their toll on Madison Avenue as well as among magazine publishers. As a result, said John Wolfe, senior vice president at the agency association in New York, Agency magazine, introduced as a quarterly in spring 1990, will suspend publication after distribution this week of its fall 2001 issue.
"It's another casualty of the media recession," said Mr. Wolfe, who is also editor in chief of Agency, which has a circulation he estimated at about 40,000. "The fall issue is the last one, unfortunately, until the economy improves and we can resume publication."
The suspension is not the first for Agency, he added, which did not publish, also for economic reasons, from spring 1992 until spring 1994. Agency has been published for the agency association by Forbes Custom Communications Partners in Boston and New York, a division of Forbes Inc. that specializes in custom-published magazines.
The magazine conference, held at the Sheraton Hotel and Towers in Midtown Manhattan, concluded yesterday afternoon. It drew about 550 attendees, about 50 fewer than last year but more than had been expected given the declines in attendance at many conferences after Sept. 11.

PERSON: Rev. William Henry Kirk 

HEADLINE: William H. Kirk Dies at 92; Aided East Harlem Diversity 

BYLINE:  By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
The Rev. William Henry Kirk, a prominent figure in the settlement-house movement and a community leader in East Harlem as it underwent a historic transformation, died last Friday in Branford, Conn. He was 92 and lived in Hamden, Conn., and on Isle au Haut, Me. 
 Mr. Kirk was executive director of Union Settlement, a number of sites providing a wide variety of services to its East Harlem neighbors, from 1949 until his retirement in 1971. 
 Under his leadership, the settlement pursued major projects to integrate the neighborhood both socially and economically, especially mixed-income housing projects. These included Metro North Housing and Franklin Plaza, a rental property he helped convert to a mixed-income, mixed-race co-op with adjoining stores, banks and other businesses.
Mr. Kirk's projects were of great interest to Jane Jacobs, the urban theorist, who frequently toured his neighborhood with him. His commitment to cohesion despite ethnic and economic frictions was an inspiration for her own advocacy of preserving neighborhoods diverse in both scale and population. 
"The basic idea," she wrote in the introduction to her classic, "The Death and Life of Great American Cities" (Random House, 1961), "to try to begin understanding the intricate social and economic order under the seeming disorder of cities, was not my idea at all, but that of William Kirk, head worker of Union Settlement in East Harlem, New York, who, by showing me East Harlem, showed me a way of seeing other neighborhoods, and downtowns too."
One of the oldest such agencies in the city, Union Settlement was started in 1895 by graduates of Union Theological Seminary. At the time, the district was peopled chiefly by Italian immigrants. Its first director, or headworker, as he was titled then, was the Rev. William E. McCord, a paragon of muscular Christianity and onetime chaplain of the Seventh Regiment.
The settlement grew into one of the city's largest, with 16 different locations that now serve 12,000 children, adults and the elderly each year. The programs include education, recreation, nutrition, addiction services and the arts, and Mr. Kirk played an important role in their proliferation.
During his tenure the East Harlem community grew, attracting African and Puerto Rican Americans as well as immigrants from Latin America and Africa. With the settlement as his base he helped pioneer strategies for mixed-income housing and the improvement of the blocks abutting the settlement sites, using private, federal and city money.
One of his proudest accomplishments was the settlement's College Readiness Program, which identified students with college potential and helped them with mentors and extra course work. Begun in the early 1960's, the program assisted more than 9,000 East Harlem youths in getting their degrees.
William Kirk was born in Newcastle, Pa., and graduated from Amherst College in 1931. He attended the Virginia Seminary and was ordained in St. Louis after graduating from Episcopal Theological School in Cambridge, Mass., in 1935.
He became rector of Grace Hill Church in St. Louis for a while, but then served as settlement director of Grace Hill House from 1937 to 1944. Five years later, he took that experience with him for his East Harlem assignment.
Mr. Kirk's first wife, Mary Michel Kirk, died in 1989 after 45 years of marriage. His second wife, Ruth Parker Kirk, died in July. He is survived by three daughters, Serena Kirk of Bangor, Me., and Susan K. Semple and Judy K. Fitzsimmons of Cambridge; a sister, Dr. Elizabeth K. Rose of Kennett Square, Pa.; nine grandchildren; and six great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Hindsight's Soldier Is History's 'Best'

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com

 BODY:
AS the United States goes to war, more than a few Americans must be worrying about the performance of our troops. After all, it is widely believed that today's soldiers went to failing schools. Their literacy and numerical skills are regarded as poor. They have been passed from grade to grade without mastering the curriculum. Their drug and alcohol use has been undisciplined. Without a good background in history or literature, they can understand little of the cultural and political traditions they must fight to uphold.
 How can such youths meet the standards set by those who won World War II, we might ask? 
 Tom Brokaw in "The Greatest Generation" (1998) said that the warriors of 60 years ago displayed "towering achievement and modest demeanor." Their sacrifices enabled those who followed to prosper economically, politically and culturally. They were, Mr. Brokaw concluded, "the greatest generation any society has ever produced."
But older adults in the 1930's and early 1940's did not think so highly of the generation Mr. Brokaw praises. The conventional view then, as now, was that schools left graduates unprepared to defend the nation.
In 1940, Walter Lippmann wrote that during the previous half-century, educators had ceased teaching the "Western culture which produced the modern democratic state." In 1941, Robert Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, worried that young people did not have the literary and historical background to participate in a democracy. Mortimer Adler, the philosopher, complained that schools no longer taught the values upon which American society relied. A resulting moral relativism, he said, rendered youth unable to muster the idealism to fight Hitler.
This view was typical. Michael A. Males, a sociologist at the University of California, has reviewed popular literature from the 1930's and found that teenagers who would later save the nation at war were not considered so great. A book about them published in 1936 was titled "The Lost Generation." It said that adolescents suffered from widespread mental illness. A Harper's Monthly article the same year concluded that young people behaved "without thought of social responsibility." A government antidrug agency reported that "dope peddlers infest our high schools."
Although in 1940 Mr. Lippmann thought that things once were better, in earlier years many commentators did not think so. In the 1920's, business leaders said students were not adequately prepared for the work force. In 1927, the National Association of Manufacturers charged that 40 percent of high school graduates could not do simple arithmetic or use English accurately.
Soldiers who fought in World War I were also, in their time, not thought to be particularly great. According to a 1921 report, the overwhelming majority of Army recruits had been taught to read in school but were unable to comprehend even simple written material.
And in the decades before World War I as well, popular magazines and serious scholars bemoaned the declining quality of the young.
This pattern of adult convictions does not compute. If every generation were so superior to the next, we could find a nation of demigods living not too far back in time. Yet although a golden age never existed, adults continually marshal statistics to confirm their disappointment in the young.
Paradoxically, the shrillness of adult dissatisfaction seems to grow in proportion to youths' educational attainment. Soldiers who will fight the war on terrorism not only have more schooling than any previous group but master more complex technologies than the artillery loaders of the past.
This situation would be funny except that the boy-who-cried-wolf fable has a serious moral. Perhaps young people today really are deficient. Perhaps teenagers in the 1930's were uniquely underrated, and those who fought World War II really were better -- in character, morals, and intellect -- than youths who will now fight terrorism. But if adolescents are always deemed inadequate, how can we know when the indictment is true and when we really need to address this crisis?
In 1944, James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, observed that almost all experts felt that America's secondary schools had failed and that students did not know as much mathematics or language as students of 50 years earlier had. But, Dr. Conant said, our citizens should also admit that the young people who were triumphing in Europe and the Pacific apparently had greater moral and intellectual strength than critics had anticipated.
When the war on terrorism draws to a close, will those who denounce today's youth have as much egg on their faces as the experts Dr. Conant described at the end of World War II? We should hope so.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (David Suter)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Selig Denies Two Teams Will Fold

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Commissioner Bud Selig had a conniption about contraction yesterday. The possibility that Major League Baseball will eliminate two teams for economic reasons has existed for the past year or so, but a Canadian newspaper reported that the decision had already been made and that the Montreal Expos and the Florida Marlins would be jettisoned after the World Series.
 Selig flatly denied the report. 
 "I've made no decisions yet," Selig said by telephone from Milwaukee. "I've been saying for a year it's a viable option. We have a lot of work to do. We have lot of questions we haven't answered yet." 
Another baseball official portrayed Selig as being angry about the report in The Windsor Star of Windsor, Ontario, and some baseball people took that reaction as confirmation that it was true. Selig acknowledged that he was upset about it but said that was because "it's misinformation."
"Contraction is a very complex process, even to consider it," he said. "There are all kinds of things to consider -- the players association, cities, stadiums, ownership. There are a myriad of factors. It's not a simple process."
The players association has maintained that the owners have to negotiate contraction and its effects. Donald Fehr, the union's executive director, said yesterday that he had heard nothing about plans to eliminate teams. "We have heard nothing from them suggesting this was a viable possibility within months," Fehr said. "All the schedules we have for next season are on the basis of 30 teams. If the story is accurate, if it's a front-burner item, we assume they will tell us."
The 2002 schedule involves all 30 teams. The union has not approved it because its executive board has to approve interleague play. Changes can be made in the schedule after it is approved as long as it remains in conformity with the basic labor agreement. A reduction to 28 teams would require significant changes to the schedule.
If Selig were planning to lop off two teams and had not had his aides discuss it with the union, the union would see that as an affront and it could have an impact on negotiations to replace the agreement that expires Nov. 7.
But the commissioner apparently has not discussed contraction with the clubs either. A high-ranking executive of one club said he had heard nothing. "Nobody has said anything to most teams," the executive said. "We've all heard the same conjecture, but there's not a shared pot of information on this."
The owners are scheduled to meet in Chicago on Nov. 6, two days after what could be the seventh game of the World Series. 
If the owners act then or subsequently to eliminate teams, they would pay the owners of those teams for their franchises. It has been speculated that the owners of the teams that would most likely be eliminated, Jeffrey Loria of the Expos and John Henry of the Marlins, would become owners of other teams.
The Walt Disney Company has wanted to sell the Anaheim Angels, and the Tampa Bay Devil Rays have been in trouble. Speculation is that Henry could take over the Angels and Loria the Devil Rays.
If teams are eliminated, their players would be distributed to other teams through a draft. If the Marlins and the Expos were eliminated, the National League would be left with 14 teams, the same number as the American League.
Owners have considered contraction as a way of eliminating teams that are weak financially. If they were eliminated, the wealthier teams would not have to share their revenue with them.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Ban the Bonds

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
As bad ideas go, the proposal to create a new class of war bonds hardly seems worth mentioning. After all, it doesn't compare to the tax-cut package the House will probably pass today, which sets new standards for cynicism. So why pick on a proposal that, while generally acknowledged to be silly, also seems harmless? 
 Because it isn't really harmless. When the patriotic fervor abates a bit -- which it will; even the most justified war is inevitably followed by disillusionment -- the war-bonds proposal will probably be regarded as a prime example of post-Sept. 11 hypocrisy, of politicians' belief that as long as they vigorously wave the flag nobody will notice that they are busy catering to special interests. 
 A little background here. The original war bonds were, of course, introduced during World War II, when the nation was mobilized for total war. Everyone was called upon to sacrifice; not only were consumer goods rationed, but taxes were sharply increased. War bonds made sense in this context: they were a substitute for consumer spending, releasing resources for a war effort that absorbed almost 40 percent of G.D.P. 
Our current situation could hardly be more different. Even though the terrorist attack has made an increase in the defense budget inevitable, we're talking about a fraction of a percent of G.D.P. And because the economy is depressed, we want consumers to spend more, not less. So if war bonds are made available, they will be a substitute for . . . what? At best, they will offer the same return as ordinary government bonds, but carry different decorations. So people who buy war bonds will be doing no more for their country than people who choose postage stamps with a patriotic theme. 
At worst, war bonds will offer a lower return than ordinary bonds. And if some people buy them nonetheless, what will they be financing? 
Here's where that tax bill enters the picture. The remarkable thing about the "stimulus" package that passed the Ways and Means Committee on a straight party-line vote is that it barely even pretends to serve its ostensible function. It consists largely of permanent tax cuts, not the temporary cuts that you would expect in a stimulus package. It systematically gives money to those least likely to spend it -- that is, to high-income taxpayers, and above all to large corporations. 
Some of the provisions in the House bill are simply mind-boggling. For example, there is a large retroactive tax cut for corporations that would lead to immediate rebates of hundreds of millions of dollars to each of a select list of giant companies, many of them in the energy industry (though the $1.4 billion check to I.B.M. would top the list). 
On the other hand, there is almost nothing in the bill for people who might actually need more money. The extra unemployment benefits, in particular, are far less generous than those offered in the last recession, when the elder Bush was president. 
The bill, in short, looks as if it was written by corporate lobbyists -- and it probably was. Even Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill was evidently embarrassed by the bill, dismissing its more outlandish components as "show business" designed to impress campaign donors.
But his remark was naive. Those lobbyists are serious men, who are paid by their employers to deliver results, not gestures; they wouldn't have put those provisions in unless they thought they had enough power to get them enacted. And sure enough, the White House soon contradicted Mr. O'Neill; the president, declared Ari Fleischer, was "very pleased" with the House bill. 
Which brings us back to those war bonds. The government not only isn't calling for shared sacrifice; it is "very pleased" with a proposal to give billions in handouts to corporations. And in that case, what is someone who buys a war bond really helping to finance? Put it this way: If the House has its way, the government will give far more in tax breaks to corporations over the next year than it will spend fighting terrorism. Yet somehow one suspects that people would not rush to buy "corporate tax-cut bonds." 
In an ideal world Congress and the White House would stand up to the special interests, and give us no reason to be cynical. Oh, never mind. But at least let's not add insult to injury. Ban those bonds.

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 On the War Front

AGAINST THE TALIBAN -- United States warplanes struck Taliban soldiers on the front lines for a third day. Pentagon officials said for the first time that their goal was to choke off the group's supplies. A1

THE COMMAND STRUCTURE -- President Bush's war team is blending an approach used to run the gulf war with a more civilian-managed model used later in Kosovo. B1

TALIBAN'S TARGET -- Taliban forces stepped up attacks on a rebel-held village, firing on a public market. B2

AFGHAN DEFIANCE -- One weary Afghan refugee, a veteran of the struggle against Soviet forces, predicted a Taliban victory over America. He was echoing the thoughts of many poor Afghans, who are increasingly rallying to the Taliban cause. B4

The Diplomatic Effort

DEMANDS FROM PAKISTAN -- As continuing reports of civilian casualties came out of Afghanistan, Pakistan's leader again called for an early end to bombing. B3

UNITED NATIONS PLAN -- The special envoy to Afghanistan will consult with various Afghan factions on a plan to govern from Kabul. B4

The Anthrax Crisis

DELAYED FEDERAL RESPONSE -- Another postal worker fell ill with anthrax, and two more were confirmed dead from the inhaled form of it. Federal officials stepped up their public health response and acknowledged that they had seriously underestimated the danger to mail carriers and sorters. A1

FRANTICALLY CHANGED TACTICS -- The decision by health officials to treat thousands of postal workers with Cipro just days after warning against overprescribing the antibiotic was essentially an acknowledgment that they are struggling to contain a deliberately created anthrax crisis. A1

THE POSTAL WORKERS -- Hundreds of Washington postal workers lined up for anthrax testing, only to be given a 10-day supply of antibiotics and told that testing was being skipped in favor of immediate treatment. B6

THE PRESIDENT -- George W. Bush assured reporters that he did not have anthrax, but did not say whether he had been tested. B8

Security and Treatments

BAYER'S CANADIAN DEAL -- The drug maker reached an agreement with Canada to provide a million tablets of Cipro within two days, heading off the country's plans to override the company's patent by buying generic versions of the drug. B8

Investigating Terrorism

THE INQUIRY'S SUBJECTS -- Ever since they were pulled off a train in Texas on Sept. 12 while carrying two box cutters, black hair dye and $5,600 in cash, two Indian men from Jersey City have been among the most intriguing witnesses detained in the federal terrorism investigation. B1

TAKEN IN -- A Muslim scholar unwittingly shared his San Diego home with two trade center attackers and then with a series of men who were later detained. And now, after a career spent teaching understanding of Islam, Dr. Abdussattar Shaikh says he feels betrayed and angry. B5

Ripples From Sept. 11

GROUNDED IN KANSAS -- In Wichita, where four of the five biggest employers are airplane manufacturers, the terrorist attacks have proved to be an assault on the local economy. More than 7,000 of the city's 43,500 aircraft workers will be laid off in the next year. A10

THE HEROIN TRADE -- Although the price of Afghan heroin has dropped, police departments across Europe are not reporting much affect on street prices. B4

CRITICIZING THE POST -- The New York Post received complaints, and a cancellation, from advertisers after a cartoon portrayed the tabloid's main competitor as having mailed anthrax spores to the paper. B7

The Aftermath in New York

THE PHANTOM SKYLINE -- These days, capturing the New York skyline on canvas or on film has become a complicated, even emotionally wrenching act. The towers are such powerful symbols that they overshadow everything else -- whether they are present or absent. A1

HATE ATTACKS -- A freelance journalist born in Pakistan has been documenting recent accounts of bias against Arabs in America. Now he has found himself in the middle of his own story after being beaten and told he looked like Osama bin Laden. B10

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE REFUGEE; 
Again, Afghan's Flight Matches His History With His Country's

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: QUETTA, Pakistan, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
Abdul Hadi pulled into the central bus station here today, sitting in the passenger seat of his hired Datsun pickup truck, four sons in the back under the tarpaulin and all his worldly possessions -- a blue wheelbarrow, a bicycle, 12 yellow jerry cans, bundles of clothes and two metal containers -- strapped to the roof. 
 He lightly embraced a cousin, then set down a piece of thin gray cloth on the concrete to pray, removing one canvas shoe and one black leather stump to do so. 
 Mr. Hadi, 53, who lost his left foot while fighting Soviet troops in Afghanistan in the 1980's and has a scarred right eye, finally decided that he had had enough of Afghanistan and closed the door on his house this morning for the ride from a village near Kandahar, the Taliban stronghold, to what he considers the safety of Pakistan. 
A peasant farmer, with a face the color of dark honey and a wild steel-wool beard, Mr. Hadi embodies much of Afghanistan's sad and violent recent history. He was at the prime of his fighting life when the Soviets invaded his nation in 1979, rolling first into his home city, Kandahar. Like most able-bodied Afghan men, Mr. Hadi immediately signed up with the resistance, joining the mujahedeen and fighting with them until the Soviets gave up and withdrew a decade later. 
In the 1990's, Mr. Hadi farmed in the flat land around Kandahar and raised five children as civil war raged among the competing warlords until the Taliban emerged as victors in 1996. 
With the Taliban now under attack from the United States, Mr. Hadi has little doubt about who will win. 
His weathered face creased into a smile: "When the Russians came to Afghanistan, they were defeated. The same thing will be repeated with the Americans." 
"I fought them for 14 years," he said of his battle against the Russians. "We beat them with rocket-propelled grenades and Kalashnikovs." The Soviet air power was irrelevant, he said. "The Americans will be defeated because the Special Forces cannot beat the Taliban. The Taliban are very strong." 
Mr. Hadi said he had heard through the village grapevine how three American helicopters with Special Forces had landed last week near the headquarters of the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar. 
"They cannot do anything with the Taliban," he said. "They will shell from the sky, and the Taliban will be sitting in their caves." 
Despite this public bravado, Mr. Hadi expressed mixed emotions about whether he would volunteer to fight again. 
On his arrival at the bus station, he said that after assuring that his family was safe, he would return home to fight a jihad. "The Taliban are good people; they established Islamic law," he said with some fervor. 
This sentiment seemed to reflect some signs that the duration and the sharpness of the American bombing campaign was beginning to shore up support for the Taliban inside Afghanistan, where their popularity was clearly on the wane before Sept. 11. 
Repeated reports by the Taliban of American bombs' killing civilians appear to have intensified the feeling among Afghans that the United States has attacked Afghanistan, not just its rulers. The Taliban have found much of their support among simple, uneducated people like Mr. Hadi; unlike more educated Afghans here, he had nothing ill to say of them. 
But by tonight, after spending some hours with his extended family here, he said he would not be going back to Kandahar to make holy war, or to farm. 
He locked the door of his emptied house this morning, he explained, because he was worried about his wife and children. He could not work his land anymore. His animals had perished in the drought, and there was nothing to cultivate. He was, it seemed, at the end of his economic tether. 
Most of those fleeing southern Afghanistan into Pakistan since the start of the American bombing are operating on the same principle as Mr. Hadi: they are bunking with relatives and hoping to find work in a region already overloaded with two million Afghan refugees. 
Mr. Hadi is a Pashtun, and his tribesmen pride themselves on being superior warriors in a warrior society. The Pakistanis in Quetta are also Pashtuns. A favorite Pashtun tribal belief goes as follows: first a Pashtun, second a Muslim, a distant third either Afghan or Pakistani. 
Virtually every house in this town, from the few elegant villas to the poorest shanties, is filled with newly arrived Pashtuns from Afghanistan. They seem to fit in fairly seamlessly, but unemployment is high and public services are meager. 
Today's newcomer settled into a mud-and-straw, flat-roofed, two-room house he will share with relatives, who were welcoming and apparently pleased to have another senior male about. By nightfall, Mr. Hadi was being treated to a special dinner at the home of a neighbor. His wife and daughter, who had arrived a week ago, remained inside their new quarters and -- in the tradition of the Taliban -- off limits to foreigners. 
Mr. Hadi's choice of transportation today was actually a modified form of the Taliban war wagons -- Japanese pickup trucks with men stashed in the open back -- that were used in the fight among the warlords in the mid-1990's. 
This time, Mr. Hadi, with his sons on board and his women already safely ahead, seemed to have decided that despite vague glimmerings of joining another jihad, he might be riding the 130 miles from home to Quetta in a vehicle of peace.

HEADLINE: Gambling Expansion Is Part of Albany Budget Agreement 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki has reached a budget agreement with legislative leaders that would allow the largest expansion of gambling in New York State since the lottery began in 1966.
 The agreement authorizes Mr. Pataki to negotiate compacts with American Indian tribes for three casinos in western New York and three in the Catskills. It also provides for New York to join a multistate lottery game, Powerball, and to install video gambling devices similar to slot machines in at least five horse-racing tracks. 
 The governor has promoted these gambling measures as new sources of revenue for the state at a time when the shrinking economy and the financial ripple effects of the terror attack in New York City have severely crimped state tax collections. 
But most of the money from new casinos and video gambling devices will not begin flowing right away. Three years from now, the new gambling venues are expected to produce about $1 billion in annual revenue for the state. That is not nearly enough to offset the $9 billion decline in tax revenues Mr. Pataki has predicted over the next year and a half, even after the $3 billion in cutbacks he has promised to make.
"It remains a fact that we need help from Washington to respond to the unprecedented attack on the World Trade Center," said Michael McKeon, Mr. Pataki's chief spokesman. The governor has asked Congress for $9 billion in compensation for lost revenue.
The gambling package is part of a final budget agreement that would add about $500 million in spending for social programs, education and tax incentives for business to the stripped-down budget the Legislature passed in August. Spending in the current fiscal year, ending next April, would grow about 5.8 percent, to about $84.5 billion, under the agreement, though the state's share would grow less.
The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said late this evening that they were still ironing out some minor details in the agreement, but that both expected to finish drafting bills and to pass them Wednesday.
One unresolved issue is the size of a new economic development zone, called the Liberty Zone, to be established around the devastated area in Lower Manhattan. The state would provide about $10 million in tax credits as well as discounted electrical power to encourage businesses to remain or relocate there.
On the spending side, the agreement would devote about $200 million to nonprofit groups that the state pays every year to provide services like counselors for victims of AIDS and legal representation to the poor. Each house of the Legislature would get $100 million to give to nonprofit groups, and criteria would be written into the bill to ensure that the most critical needs are met. Many of these groups will face severe cutbacks, however, since they usually get $300 million to $500 million a year.
"We had said a long time ago some people would have to lower their expectations," said Senator Bruno, an upstate Republican.
Some advocates for the poor worried that the money might be misused for pork barrel programs dear to lawmakers. "It should go to front-line groups providing vital services," said Michael Kink of Housing Works, an advocacy group for people with AIDS. "There is a risk that it devolves into trout ponds at the sportsmen's club and Little Leagues."
The governor and Legislature have also agreed to add about $200 million in aid for education, with most of that going to finance training centers for teachers and to raise teachers' salaries in urban districts. Some extra money would also go to programs for bilingual children and children with learning disabilities.
The agreed-upon spending package also includes about $100 million in economic development measures to be controlled to a large degree by Governor Pataki. Those will include adding eight empire development zones, which are parks where new businesses receive tax breaks.
Since the gambling measures are not expected to produce much revenue this year, most of the $500 million in new spending would be financed through fiscal gimmicks or by moving money from other programs, the leaders said. The state will change a law in an attempt to keep $115 million in taxes it collected illegally, according to a judge, from a gas pipeline company. The state is also stretching out payments on its share of the cost of building new schools, a move that will save about $160 million in the short run.
But it is the expansion of gambling that will provide the most money in the long run. Under the agreement, video gambling devices would be installed at five racetracks: Aqueduct, Yonkers Raceway, Vernon Downs in Oneida County, Monticello in Sullivan County and Fingerlakes Racetrack southeast of Rochester. Local governments in Saratoga Springs, Batavia and Buffalo could vote to allow the machines at their tracks as well. Part of the earnings from the video gambling would go to increase purses for horse racing.
The machines will be considered part of the state lottery system, so the revenue will go to pay for state aid to schools and not to local governments. The tracks and businesses that operate the machines will also get a small cut.
The agreement also authorizes Governor Pataki to negotiate contracts with the Seneca Indian nation to operate casinos in Niagara Falls and Buffalo and on one of the tribe's reservations in western New York. In negotiations, the Assembly Democrats won the right of unions to organize the casino workers as well as a guarantee that a quarter of the state's share of the revenues will go to local governments.
Another three casinos would go in Sullivan and Ulster Counties to rejuvenate the faded Catskill resorts. At present, one tribe, the Mohawks, has made a proposal, with Park Place Entertainment, to put a casino in the former Kutsher's Country Club.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, speaking to reporters tonight after a town hall meeting in Staten Island, sharply criticized Mr. Silver for his support of the gambling legislation. 
"I don't understand the politics of this," the mayor said. He reiterated comments he has made for years: that any state authority for gambling casinos should include authorization for gambling in New York City to avoid draining revenues from the city to other locations. 
"At a time like this, I don't understand what is driving the speaker to support this," he said. He said he would appeal to Mr. Pataki to block the legislation, and added that he had made his opposition clear to Mr. Silver as recently as Monday.
The agreement to expand gambling drew strong condemnations from the Catholic Conference and the New York State Conservative Party, which argued that it amounted to a tax on compulsive gamblers, many of them poor.
"This is not something that you build the future on," said Mike Long, the chairman of the Conservative Party. "I know that a lot of legislators are using Sept. 11 as an excuse to forgo their principles and approve gambling. We got through the Depression and we got through the fiscal crisis without putting slot machines in again, and that can be done again. This is the easy way out."
But several lawmakers and their leaders said the state's desperate need for revenues in the wake of the attack outweighed whatever moral reservations they might have had.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph L. Bruno, Senate majority leader, discussing gambling issues. (David Jennings for The New York Times)(pg. D5)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: NOTEBOOKS; 
Indictment in Towers Theft

BYLINE:  By JANE FRITSCH 

 BODY:
A Bronx man who the authorities say posed as a rescue worker at the site of the World Trade Center was indicted yesterday on charges that he stole at least six expensive watches and about $2,500 in cash from the Tourneau store below the complex.
 The man, Johnny Dunham, 26, an unemployed security guard, was also charged with stealing a New York Fire Department jacket from a damaged ambulance on Sept. 12. 
 Photographs of Mr. Dunham posing in the jacket and in police clothing near the wreckage were found in his apartment, investigators said.
Investigators are trying to determine whether the firefighter's jacket belonged to someone who died in the disaster. Mr. Dunham, dressed as an emergency worker, went to the disaster scene on Sept. 12, to "look for targets of opportunity," said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. He called Mr. Dunham "a scavenger." At the site, Mr. Dunham ran into an acquaintance, Jacquelin Delgado, an unemployed emergency medical technician who lived in his neighborhood, prosecutors said. Back in the Bronx, Mr. Dunham gave Ms. Delgado one of the stolen watches, a $15,000 Cartier, according to prosecutors. She has been charged with possession of stolen property. 
Prosecutors said Mr. Dunham had been convicted twice before on misdemeanor charges related to impersonating officers.
 JANE FRITSCH

HEADLINE: Daimler Says Chrysler Lost Less Than Expected 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
DaimlerChrysler A.G. gave investors their first positive surprise in nearly two years today, reporting that third-quarter losses at the Chrysler group had been lower than expected and saying that it can still meet an overall profit goal set earlier this year.
 Chrysler's operating loss was $243 million, less than half what many analysts had predicted, though Chrysler's sales and its share of the market both declined. 
 The news helped push shares of DaimlerChrysler up 83 cents in New York, to $35.86, as the company provided evidence that its efforts to cut costs were beginning to bring results. 
Still, the latest report indicated that it was still too early to celebrate any turnaround. For one thing, the results included less than three weeks' worth of sales after the attacks on Sept. 11. Chrysler, like General Motors and Ford, began luring customers with zero-interest car loans after the attacks. The incentives, which compound the pricing battles that DaimlerChrysler had hoped to stop, are likely to dampen earnings this quarter.
Beyond that, Daimler is still struggling with plunging sales and big losses at Freightliner, its big American truck-making business. And Mitsubishi Motors of Japan, in which Daimler owns a 37.3 percent stake, also has declining sales.
Daimler executives emphasized the uncertain economic outlook, particularly in the United States. But they said the company could still meet the goal of a 2001 operating profit in the range of $1 billion to $1.5 billion. And at least for now, they said they were maintaining a goal in 2002 of an operating profit of $5 billion to $6 billion. "Sure, we are sticking to our target, but we are highly dependent on market developments," Manfred Gentz, DaimlerChrysler's chief financial officer, cautioned during a conference call with analysts.
The company's third-quarter operating profit, excluding one-time items, climbed to $606 million from $491 million a year earlier. Including the special items, Daimler said net income dropped 70 percent, to $821 million from $2.7 billion in the corresponding period of 2000. Most of the difference reflected gains last year from the sale of businesses in sectors like automotive electronics and aerospace.
Chrysler, which accounted for half of Daimler's profit just three years ago, ran up losses exceeding $1 billion in the first half of 2001 and is now in a $4 billion restructuring program overseen by its German president, Dieter Zetsche.
The number of Chrysler vehicles sold dropped 6 percent in the third quarter, and the company's market share has declined to 11.8 percent from nearly 15 percent a year ago. The declining market share reflects the inroads of Honda and Toyota in the minivan market that Chrysler once dominated.
Chrysler revenue of $13.3 billion was 4 percent lower than in last year's quarter.
As bad as that was, the Chrysler group's losses were smaller than many analysts had expected and smaller than those recently at G.M. and Ford.
DaimlerChrysler's other big problem is Freightliner, which has experienced a steep drop in truck sales in the United States. Freightliner's revenue fell 19 percent, and operating profit for Daimler's commercial vehicle division dropped 94 percent.
Other sections of the company fared better. Mercedes-Benz sales were up 9 percent, and its operating profit climbed 10 percent. Profit rose in Daimler's financial services business, as well.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Close Moderately Lower, Reversing Early Gains

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, as more reports of anthrax slammed a market already dealing with disappointing results and dim forecasts from companies ranging from SBC Communications to Pharmacia.
 Stocks erased early gains after health authorities said a New Jersey postal worker might have contracted anthrax, and anthrax was found in a mail delivery area for the White House. 
 Reports of anthrax are cropping up around the world, and the White House said it suspected the outbreak was linked to the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States. 
"There's a real lingering fear that as the anthrax issue widens it strikes not only at the physical well-being of people, but of the well-being of the economy," said Peter Coolidge, senior equity trader at Brean Murray & Company.
Worries about the war in Afghanistan also clouded the outlook for stocks, money managers said.
"There's a fear of an escalation in terrorist activity, or a military action that would potentially involve other states around the world," said Eric Wiegand, a portfolio manager for Credit Suisse Asset Management.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 36.95 points, or 0.4 percent, to end at 9,340.08, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 5.12 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,084.78. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell for the first time in four sessions, declining 3.64 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,704.44.
Stocks were higher over the last few sessions, as investors looked beyond the flood of quarterly earnings and bet that a rebound, while still months off, was on its way.
"We can't really point to these earnings and say fundamentals have improved," said Charles Payne, market analyst at Wall Street Strategies. "But the bar has been lowered enough that most companies have either come in line or actually beat estimates, and that's good news."
Quarterly results poured in from many companies. SBC weighed on the Dow average for the second day, racking up the biggest percentage loss among blue chips. It fell $2.62, to $38.78. after investment banks, including Goldman, Sachs, cut their ratings on its stock on fears revenue could fall further.
On Monday, SBC posted a 31 percent drop in earnings and said it would cut thousands of jobs because of the weak economy and stiff competition.
Pharmacia tumbled $4.37, to $38.39, after lowering its profit forecast for next year, which some analysts tied to slowing sales growth for its arthritis drug Celebrex.

 (By Bloomberg News) -- The 10-year Treasury note fell on expectations the government would sell more debt to pay for tax cuts and higher spending. The 10-year note fell 4/32, to a price of 102 26/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 4.64 percent from 4.62 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 8/32, to 99 27/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.39 percent from 5.37 percent on Monday.
