HEADLINE: Where Planes Are Built, a Setback 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 23 

 BODY:
Cattle may once have been king in Wichita, but that was a long time ago. For years, airplanes have been the big thing.
 And here, where four of the five biggest employers in town are airplane manufacturers, where 70 percent of the country's general-aviation aircraft are built and where officials like to use the phrase "air capital of the world," the terrorist attacks on New York and the Pentagon have proved to be an assault on the local economy. 
 Roughly 7,200 of Wichita's 43,500 aircraft workers will be laid off over the next year, with the biggest impact so far at the Boeing Company's commercial aircraft division, where workers assemble parts for new jetliners and convert older passenger jets to freighters. 
When the first round of layoff notices went out a few days ago, informing 1,645 Boeing workers that they would lose their jobs effective Dec. 14, Sheryl Robertson, a sheet-metal mechanic, was on the list, leaving her to scramble for something to replace the $18-an-hour wage she enjoys now. 
"It'll be a lot less than what you can make at Boeing, but then just about everything else around here is," said Mrs. Robertson, 47.
She said she was likely to go back to school to get her certificate as a medical assistant, a job that pays about $9 an hour. 
Even before the Sept. 11 attacks, Wichita was braced for recession, as projected sales for airliners, corporate jets and smaller personal aircraft slowed. But with the plunge in air travel after the terrorist attacks, the airlines' financial turmoil slashed those projections even more. 
That prompted Wichita's mayor, Bob Knight, to convene an emergency conference to deal with layoffs at the airplane companies that will wipe away jobs that collectively pay $350 million a year here. A job fair and ways to speed production were among the ideas discussed.
"There have been incredible resources committed to New York City -- all of our hearts were absolutely broken by what happened to that great city," Mayor Knight said at the second meeting of the conference, on Friday. "But I would ask at this point for us to seriously consider how we are going to take care of our own." 
Counting their strong benefits, the jobs at Boeing and at other airplane companies here -- Cessna, Raytheon and Bombardier Aerospace/Learjet -- are generally the highest paying manufacturing jobs in the area, averaging about $50,000 a year, and growth at all four companies had helped fuel a boom in Wichita in recent years, said Janet Harrah, director of the Center for Economic Development and Business Research at Wichita State University. 
In the 1990's, the growth of service and construction jobs far outstripped the rate in aircraft manufacturing here. Services, including health care, grew by 30 percent, construction by nearly 54 percent, compared with an 11 percent rise in air industry jobs. But the aircraft jobs still amount to about 16 percent of overall employment in the area and, because they pay so relatively well, contribute 25 percent of employment earnings. 
Although total aircraft job losses are higher around Seattle, where Boeing has its commercial aircraft division and where most of the division's cuts of 20,000 to 30,000 jobs will take place, the overall impact is harsher here because Wichita's economy is so reliant on aircraft jobs. (Over all, there are 17,300 Boeing workers here.) 
It is hard to see the immediate effect, since workers here are entitled to 60 days' notice before layoffs and thus are continuing to earn their salaries. The first wave of layoffs will come in December. 
For now, some restaurants and local retail businesses, even as they noticed a sudden drop in sales the week after Sept. 11, say things seem to be back to nearly normal for the moment, although in some cases only because they have been offering deals to lure customers in the door. 
It is hard to know what the layoffs and other impacts of Sept. 11 will do to the unemployment level, which stood at 3.5 percent before the attacks, said Ms. Harrah of Wichita State. If many people take lower-paying jobs, that would not immediately alter the rate but would still have a serious impact on the economy. The aircraft job cuts themselves are the largest since the recession of the early 1980's, she said. 
"Manufacturing is very cyclical, and it's part of the deal that you're going to have some downturns," Ms. Harrah said. 
Many workers here seemed to accept that explanation, saying that cuts in jobs that involve making airplanes were to be expected if fewer people were going to be flying. But others were skeptical. 
"To me, I think Boeing is taking advantage of a tragedy," said Gina Marks, 25, a single mother and material processor who will lose her $16.34-an-hour job on Dec. 14. 
"It doesn't need to be this widespread," Ms. Marks said, then added, referring to Boeing's move last month of its corporate headquarters from Seattle, "Here they just built this office in Chicago -- it must have cost millions and millions of dollars to do that." 
Ms. Marks has been sending out resumes but believes she will be "lucky" to get a job paying anything from $9 to $12 an hour, probably in the clerical field. She continues going to cosmetology school at night and still hopes to pursue her dream of moving to Dallas and opening her own salon, but she acknowledges that the loss of her Boeing job will defer the dream. 
Others expressed optimism that the layoffs would be brief. 
"I think they're anticipating things that aren't going to happen," David Poage, 41, a modification inspector, said of Boeing's move.
Mr. Poage does not face a layoff, but he will be reclassified into a job that pays less. 
"A lot of people are going to take some long car trips at Thanksgiving, and they're not going to like it so much," Mr. Poage explained.
"People will figure out again that flying is real safe, and that it's a better way to go," he said. "So by Christmas, people will be back to flying. And then we'll be back to building airplanes."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
BoomingCar Sales, but at a Price

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
Corporate earnings are plummeting, unemployment is rising, consumer confidence is shaky, the country is at a war footing at home and abroad. Yet auto sales have rarely been better.
 Come again? 
 A forecast from General Motors predicts October will be the second-biggest month ever for overall auto sales in the United States, and many analysts have offered similar outlooks. But if the industry is on pace for one of its best sales months, the question is how it happened and how much it will all cost, not only in financial losses now but also in lost sales down the road.
In reality, the Big Three's interest-free financing plans, offered to revive sales after the Sept. 11 attacks, have evolved into a price war that is great news for car buyers and car dealers but increasingly costly for the automakers footing the bill. Some critics and environmental groups have also criticized domestic automakers for wrapping up their new discounts in patriotic ad campaigns at a time when the nation's dependence on the Middle East's oil is the subject of renewed debate. 
But for car sellers -- like those sales reps and dealers who make their living along a long stretch of showrooms and lots on Central Avenue in Toledo, Ohio -- there have been few better months than October.
"Zero percent is just bringing lots of people in, creating lots of interest," George Ballas, founder of George Ballas Buick GMC, said in an interview this week at his dealership. There is a yard-high "0% A.P.R." banner in the showroom's window and American flags fluttering from car hoods on the lot. On a typical month, Mr. Ballas, who has been a G.M. dealer for more than three decades, said he might sell 125 new G.M. cars and trucks. Last month, sales were just short of 100. This month, he thinks he can sell 150 new vehicles.
Down the road, Ross Yuse, who has been a salesman for 15 years at Jim White Toyota, extended his arm outward and tallied the white, red and green cars before him. Toyota Motor has also offered zero-interest financing on some of its vehicles.
"We're out of cars," he said. "We have four Corolla's and four Camry's. We usually like to carry 60 Camry's and 20 Corolla's."
But Mike Knierim, a previous Corolla owner, did not let that stand in the way. He was set on buying another Toyota. "You can't go wrong with zero percent interest," he said. "Chevy, Ford or Toyota -- it's a deal."
G.M. led the wave of zero percent offers, which were ignited in part by the visit of Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans and Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao to Detroit shortly after the attacks. The Bush administration's focus was on restarting economic activity and it urged the industry to do what it could.
Shortly after the meeting, G.M. introduced its Keep America Rolling interest-free financing with a splashy ad campaign. The subtext was clear: Do your part to fight terrorism by buying American vehicles.
But when G.M. moved recently to extend its program past the end of the month and through at least Nov. 18, it was a bid to sustain its recent glimmer of momentum in recapturing market share. The news, however, was not well received by Ford Motor or Chrysler, whose financial positions appear to many analysts to be worse than that of General Motors. Chrysler is a unit of DaimlerChrysler.
G.M. sees the discounts, coupled with a fresh lineup of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, as a chance to stem years of market share declines. The company needs to maintain its scale, if for no other reason than to keep up with its enormous legacy costs -- G.M. has about 2.5 retirees per worker whose benefits and pensions it must continue to support. On the other hand, such incentives only increase its red ink. Last week, the company reported a net loss of $368 million for the third quarter.
Still, G.M. is gaining a small amount of market share while Ford and Chrysler, which matched G.M.'s zero percent financing offers, continue to lose ground and money. Top executives of both companies have expressed concern recently that the offers are pulling sales from the future and hurting profits now.
"While programs like this make the equation work for our customers, it is unsustainable for us in the longer term," Jacques Nasser, chief executive of Ford, wrote in a memo to employees last Friday. "Even without zero percent financing, our marketing costs are still far too high."
Martin Inglis, Ford's chief financial officer, said last week that incentives had risen from 11 percent of the company's revenue last year to 16 percent this year. Each percentage point increase, he said, deducts about $1 billion from the company's pretax profits. 
In recent forecasts, G.M. predicted October's seasonally adjusted annual sales rate would come in above 19 million. That would rank it right behind the record 21.2 million sales pace the industry achieved in September 1986, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank, a data service in Southfield, Mich. John Casesa, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, projects a rate of 20.2 million vehicles.
But then what? Ending a sale is harder than starting one. When G.M. gave its October forecast, it also lowered its forecast for total 2002 sales of 15 million to 15.5 million units, which would be considered a mediocre year. Mr. Casesa sees 2002 sales dropping to an even worse rate of 14.6 million vehicles.
The falloff, Mr. Casesa said, is "going to lead to very cautious production schedules in the first quarter."
"These companies," he added, "are going to go from working on overtime to working half-shifts."
"That will cause a retrenching in their businesses," he said, "and that will ripple through the supply chain." 
From some perspectives, increasing sales to near record levels at a time of turmoil is distasteful, especially when the Big Three are increasingly dependent on sport utility vehicles and trucks. Take a recent cartoon in the New Republic magazine, which depicted a man putting an "End our dependence on Arab oil!" bumper sticker on a smoke-belching vehicle so enormous his head reached only the top of the wheel.
"Detroit is treating this tragedy as a chance to pad their profits by pushing gas guzzlers," said Daniel F. Becker, director of the global warming and energy program for the Sierra Club. "Real patriotism means showing responsibility by decreasing our oil dependency by producing more fuel-efficient cars." 
For the Big Three, padding profits is not the issue. Stemming losses is.
And holding off the resurgent foreign automakers. "All three of the Big Three are between a rock and a hard place," said Stephen J. Girsky, an auto analyst at Morgan Stanley. "The competition is not each other, but the competition is the outside parties."
A recent Morgan Stanley report pointed to Ford and G.M.'s huge financing operations as areas of concern, for several reasons. First, the residual value of leased vehicles continues to decline as sales of new cars, and leases, increase. That influx of sales reduces the value of vehicles coming off leases that are reclaimed by Ford and G.M. 
Second, recent downgrades of the credit of Ford and G.M. make their loans to customers more expensive. Ford and G.M. raise money to make those loans with big bond offerings and their borrowing rates, while still quite low, will become less attractive for the companies at a time when they are charging customers less, and in many cases, nothing, for loans. Third, the worsening economy has caused the rate of customers' defaulting on auto loans to increase. 
For dealers and buyers, this is not their problem. At least not yet. 
"It's absolutely spectacular," said Michael Maroone, president of AutoNation, which operates dealerships in 17 states, referring to the zero percent deals. 
"It's an absolute windfall for the dealers," he said. "The business climate right now is fantastic."
For some Americans shopping for a new car, there is little doubt that heart-felt patriotism is one of the main reasons they are buying now.
"I had one little old gal tell me that was the only reason she was buying a car," said Jim Nimphie, a vice president of George Ballas Buick GMC.
But Mr. Ballas believes the improving sales have less to do with patriotism and more to do with low prices and free money. With the new offers, he said, "you could save roughly $4,500 on a $20,000 car."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
SPIEGEL POSTS 3RD-QUARTER LOSS AND CUTS OUTLOOK

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 The Spiegel Group, the catalog retailer, posted a third-quarter loss yesterday and cut its fourth-quarter expectations almost in half. The company, which is based in Downers Grove, Ill., and owns the Eddie Bauer retail apparel chain, said it expected weak consumer spending and economic uncertainty to damp its overall results. 
Spiegel said it now expected fourth-quarter revenue to fall 5 percent to 10 percent. Spiegel's loss for the third quarter ended Sept. 29 was $12.3 million, or 9 cents a share. In the year-earlier quarter, Spiegel posted a profit of $13.5 million, or 10 cents a share. Sales for the period fell to $703.8 million from $807.5 million a year earlier. Spiegel's stock fell 69 cents, to $6.30 a share.

HEADLINE: Maker of Small Jets Sees a Silver Lining 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
When the first of the sleek new 70-passenger ERJ-170 jets from Embraer rolls out of the factory next Monday, it will fly off into a world vastly different from the boom times in which it was conceived two years ago.
 Global air travel has fallen by nearly one-third. Airlines are scrapping flights, pruning routes and laying off workers by the tens of thousands; some have collapsed entirely. 
 Embraer, formally known as Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica, knows that it, too, will have to hunker down for a year or two to weather the aviation downturn. But the company's hopes for the ERJ-170 and its regional-jet siblings are undimmed because Embraer expects the current crisis to propel the market to its door even faster than before. 
"Our fleet is flying at an average occupancy of more than 50 percent, while traffic on the big airlines is substantially below that," Mauricio Botelho, the president of Embraer, said in an interview. "Many of the big airlines like Continental and United are already announcing that they are substituting narrow-body aircraft with regional jets."
Mr. Botelho's optimism is shared by a number of analysts, who say that as the major airlines streamline their operations and cut costs, they will move to retire most of their older narrow-body aircraft with 120 to 150 seats -- planes like 737's.
The routes that those planes now fly will be served instead by the big airlines' regional partners, like Continental Express and America West Airlines, which operate the smaller jets made by Embraer and its main rival, Bombardier of Canada.
Because they can be handled by smaller air crews and ground staffs, the regional jets are much cheaper to operate. They are also considered more aptly sized for commuter routes: big enough to accommodate business passengers, but not so big that fickle, fare-conscious tourists are needed to fill seats. 
Jim Parker, a managing director at Raymond James & Associates, said the regional jets could be a good idea for airlines. "By switching to regional jets," he said, "they can hand off most of the unprofitable leisure travelers to the low-fare airlines." 
But even if the long-term tide is running Embraer's way, right now airlines are putting off dates to take delivery, and production is expected to slow considerably at Embraer's factory in the interior of Sao Paulo state. Early this month, the company said it would deliver 25 fewer planes than expected this year, and perhaps only 135 jets next year, down from an earlier target of 205. The slowdown may reduce 2001 revenue by $700 million and 2002 revenue by $1.2 billion.
About $1 billion worth of tentative orders, known as options, have been called off since Sept. 11, the company said on Monday. Still, Mr. Botelho said that none of Embraer's 543 firm orders had been canceled outright. 
Analysts treat that assertion with some care. "There could be some marketing behind pledges that the airlines are going to honor their orders," said Roberto Reis, an aviation analyst at Sudemeris Corretora, a Brazilian brokerage firm. "Airlines need to give the impression that they are continuing to invest so that passengers will feel comfortable buying tickets."
Another issue is the willingness of lenders to finance jet purchases in the current crisis environment. Airlines usually put up 20 percent of the cost of a new jet and finance the rest. Among Embraer's biggest customers, two -- American Eagle and Continental Express -- may benefit from the loan guarantees included in the United States government's airline bailout.
But government aid can cut two ways: Embraer has complained bitterly that Canada has violated global trade rules by offering subsidized financing for airliners to buy Bombardier's regional jets, and it won a favorable ruling from a World Trade Organization panel last week in a case involving a big order by Air Wisconsin.
And it is unclear how the Swiss government's restructuring of Swissair and its former regional subsidiary, Crossair, will affect Embraer. Crossair is one of only a handful of airlines to order the ERJ-170 and the new 108-seat ERJ 190-200, scheduled to be ready in 2004.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Brazil, Embraer builds aircraft that are economical to operate on commuter routes. The company hopes that the downturn in the airline industry will lead to increased demand for its small jets in a year or two. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: City Proposes Priority Uses Of Federal Aid 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration has set two priorities for the aid it is seeking from the federal government to encourage the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan, concentrating on a small portion of the $54 billion that the state had requested.
 Under the city's proposal, businesses that agree to return to or set up shop in Lower Manhattan would receive a $5,000 cash bonus for each employee, and developers would have access to tax-free bonds to help erect buildings in the area destroyed by the terrorist attack last month. The city estimates that the cost of reconstructing downtown at between $8 billion and $15 billion. 
 Earlier this month, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced that the state would ask the federal government for a huge package of incentives, tax breaks and other direct federal subsidies to rebuild New York. Federal officials were polite but cool, and some complained that elements of the plan, like billions of dollars for reimbursements for lost tax revenues and money to build a high-speed train from Manhattan to upstate New York were a bit out of line with normal disaster aid. 
The White House budget chief has rejected supporting any more new aid this year, aside from the $20 billion in emergency relief provided for New York, Virginia and Pennsylvania. 
Senators Hillary Clinton and Charles E. Schumer have been trying to cobble together a more modest proposal, drawing from plans offered by business leaders and New York officials that they believe would have an easier time making it through Congress now that the country's wartime bills are growing, too. 
City officials say they while they do not begrudge the state any of its wish list, they would be happy with a plan that costs the federal government more in lost -- and ultimately unanticipated -- revenue than in pure cash outlays. "The city has a lot of needs," said one official, "but in Lower Manhattan we are looking at specific elements to encourage employers to come in and to encourage developers to build new buildings. The goal is to keep lower Manhattan as the financial hub." Last week, the city's budget director, Adam Barsky, and Deputy Mayor Robert Harding paid calls to legislative leaders in Washington and to officials in the Bush administration to press their case.
The city proposes offering businesses $5,000 per employee the first year, and would decrease that incentive to $2,500 per worker for each of the next two years. The cash benefit could be applied to the company's federal tax bill, or taken as a lump sum. The city offers a modest version of this plan involving city taxes for businesses opening in some neighborhoods outside Manhattan.
The program for returning businesses to lower Manhattan would be capped at $750 million, or the estimated amount needed to repopulate what some calculate is the 25 million square feet of space lost to the attack. The cap is designed to signal to the federal government that the city is not trying to tuck general economic development into the package. 
Other refinements under consideration by Mr. Schumer and Mrs. Clinton include tax credits for businesses and tax-exempt financing for reconstruction projects, according to people familiar with the plan. Their plan would likely lengthen the time period of the cash credit for employees and might not contain a cap. 
However, city officials hinted that since it was unlikely that two huge towers would be built in the World Trade Center's space and that smaller buildings might go there instead, businesses that chose to set up shop in other boroughs might be accommodated by this plan if lower Manhattan became overpopulated.
For some developers, who are loath to build in Manhattan because of high costs and bureaucratic hurdles, the city would like to offer access to tax-exempt bonds that would significantly reduce their costs of building. The city envisions developers going to its Industrial Development Authority to secure bonds on which purchasers would not be obligated to pay city, state or federal taxes, in turn lowering the interest rate for the developers. 
City officials argue that the benefit is attractive because although it would represent a loss of about $13 billion in tax revenues for the federal government, it would not require a cash payout to the city. Tax on bond interest was not anticipated revenue anyway, since there were no plans before Sept. 11 to do major rebuilding in lower Manhattan.
Outside of rebuilding and repopulating the area, known as the Liberty Zone, the city would also like to have a federal insurance pool created for businesses that cannot afford insurance, and pay for the rebuilding of a destroyed power substation, subway station and telephone switching station at a cost of roughly $2 billion.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers' Votes on Economic Legislation Will Test Talk of Bipartisanship 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
For all their recent pledges of bipartisanship, Republicans and Democrats are headed for an ideological showdown over how best to revive the economy.
 Republicans are pushing for tax cuts for corporations. Democrats are seeking to put money in the hands of low- and middle-income people and workers who have lost jobs. Both sides have reached the point where it has become all but impossible to paper over the depth of their differences. 
 The House was scheduled to take up a Republican economic stimulus plan on Wednesday that would cut taxes this year by nearly $100 billion, with more than $70 billion going to companies. It is expected to pass despite strong objections from Democrats.
In the Senate, Democrats seem to be reaching the limits of their willingness to negotiate a bipartisan compromise. The chairman of the Finance Committee, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, today unveiled a $70 billion stimulus plan that would include $33 billion for expanded unemployment and health-insurance benefits, $14 billion of tax rebates for low- and moderate-income people and a $20 billion menu of temporary tax cuts for business.
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said tonight he was disappointed with Mr. Baucus's plan.
The Senate is also likely to consider proposals for billions of dollars in new spending on highways and mass transit to create jobs, a traditional Democratic response to economic downturns.
Republicans say helping companies via tax cuts will avert layoffs, bolster stock prices and encourage investment. Democrats say providing money to individuals will not only help the people who need it most but will also stimulate demand for goods and services.
The most hotly debated of the Republicans' specific proposals would repeal the corporate alternative minimum tax, which was created to insure that companies did not avoid income taxes altogether through deductions.
By decreasing the taxes of many companies at a time when earnings are plummeting, Republicans said, the proposal would reduce the pressure on employers to eliminate jobs. Republicans said it would also give Wall Street confidence that corporations could weather the downturn without too much financial damage and provide companies with more cash to buy equipment and supplies.
The House bill would make the repeal of the tax retroactive to 1986. Companies would get refunds this year equal to the difference between what they paid under the alternative tax since 1986 and the lesser amount they would have paid under the regular corporate income tax.
The combination of the repeal and the refund of past payments would total $25.4 billion this year.
Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal research organization, said more than one-fifth of the benefits would go to just 12 corporations. They include International Business Machines, which the group said would receive a $1.4 billion rebate; General Motors, which would get $833 million; and General Electric, which would get $671 million.
Most Democrats argue that the centerpiece of any stimulus plan should be an expansion of unemployment insurance to cover laid-off workers who otherwise would not be eligible for such benefits. They want to include benefits for many part-time workers and for those who had not worked long enough to qualify under current law.
Democrats are also pressing for more money for a program that helps unemployed people keep their health insurance.
The rationale for focusing the stimulus package on the unemployed is that people who have lost jobs will immediately spend all the benefit payments they receive, helping the economy.
The two parties are also battling over a Republican proposal to accelerate a portion of the income tax-rate reductions enacted in June. The bill the House plans to vote on this week would immediately cut the current 27 percent rate to 25 percent. That rate applies to taxable income starting at $27,000 for individuals and $45,000 for couples.
Republicans say permanent cuts in income tax rates encourage more spending by consumers. Democrats said the provision would benefit only the top 25 percent of earners, who they said would not be likely to spend the money immediately.
Many Republicans are also calling for a reduction in the capital gains tax on profits from the sale of stocks, bonds and other assets. 
Democrats are pressing for big public works projects, like building highways, as a means to create jobs. Economists said increased government spending could have a substantial effect on the economy. But they said it often takes months or even years for government spending programs to begin, delaying the economic effects until after any downturn is over.
While the parties remain at odds over these core issues, there are some areas of agreement.
There is a broad consensus on the need to provide businesses with tax incentives to invest more money in new factories and equipment.
The House bill would try to address the problem by allowing companies to write off 30 percent of the cost of capital investments immediately. That provision, which would remain in place for three years, would amount to a tax break estimated for companies this year at $39.3 billion.
In the Senate, Mr. Baucus's plan would allow companies to write off 10 percent of their capital investments, but would limit the tax break to a single year. His approach would save companies $14 billion.
Advocates of the provision say it would encourage companies to buy new computers and telecommunications equipment, build new factories and invest in cost-saving machinery and software.
Some economists, though, said tax breaks for capital investments would have limited effect as long as corporations continued to have more production capacity than they needed.
The two parties also appear to have reached a general agreement on providing a one-time tax rebate to low- and moderate-income workers. Both the House bill and Mr. Baucus's plan would make the payments -- $300 for individuals and $600 for couples -- to workers who did not qualify for the first round of tax rebates sent out this summer because they did not make enough money to pay federal income taxes.
Both parties had been hoping to put the proposed rebate checks in the hands of consumers by the Christmas shopping season. But the Internal Revenue Service said today that it probably would be unable to get the checks out before Jan. 1.

HEADLINE: Giving Hip-Hop A Cultural Beat; 
Rappers Visiting From Cuba Find a Welcoming Audience

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
They are social chroniclers of a different daily life, one of food quotas that do not last until the end of the month and of women who fall for the capitalist wiles of foreign men.
 They talk about the artist's responsibility to value message over money. And at a recent panel discussion at the Caribbean Cultural Center in Manhattan, they seemed taken aback when somebody asked if there was a gangster element to their music. 
 "In Cuba, people don't have pistols," said Yosmel Sarrias, 27, speaking in Spanish through a translator. "There are problems in Cuba, but we don't have gangsters." 
They rap in Spanish and come from a socialist world, but the first Cuban hip-hop delegation visiting the United States has found an appreciative audience in New York City, where hip-hop was born. The seven artists and two Cuban hip-hop organizers are on a monthlong cultural exchange that has taken them to schools and community organizations to talk about hip-hop in their homeland.
To young New Yorkers like Danny Rivera, 17, dissatisfied with the rap fare on radio and MTV, the visiting Cubans seem closer to American hip-hop in its early political phase -- critical and socially conscious, as opposed to materialistic and self-absorbed -- than today's American hip-hop stars.
"I don't believe Eminem and Jay-Z are hip-hop," said Mr. Rivera, a break dancer who met the Cuban artists last week during a workshop at El Puente Academy for Peace and Justice, an alternative public school in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. "They think about the revolution while Jay-Z is thinking about girls, girls, girls."
This is the first time that Cuba has sent hip-hop artists as official cultural ambassadors (exchanges between Cuba and the United States are allowed under the American economic embargo). After initially rejecting the idea as an American export, the Cuban artists said, the government has increasingly embraced and funded hip-hop as an authentic voice of contemporary Cuban youth.
The visit by three rap groups -- "Anonimo Consejo" (Anonymous Advice), "RCA" (for Crazy Rappers of Alamar) and "Obsesion" -- was arranged by International Hip-Hop Exchange, a group of community organizers, journalists and artists. The group includes Danny Hoch, an actor and executive producer of the New York Hip-Hop Theater Festival, who has taken American hip-hop artists to Cuba in recent years. Mr. Hoch is a fellow at the Vera List Center for Arts and Politics at the New School for Social Research, which is sponsoring the exchange with the Caribbean Cultural Center.
Mr. Hoch said his hope is to steer young Americans back to hip-hop's earlier social awareness, which he said exists today in a growing minority marginalized by the major labels or by the news media. Nowadays, he said, most successful rap in this country is party music devoid of thought-provoking lyrics.
"One of our goals is to have more cultural exchanges so that hip-hop can strengthen itself as a global movement more than just pop culture," Mr. Hoch said.
As in the United States, hip-hop in Cuba is an urban, mostly black movement that in Cuba caught on in the 1980's and was redefined in the 1990's. But despite problems in gaining mainstream acceptance, the delegation said it now counts on more than 400 rap groups, an annual festival in its seventh year and a homegrown version of the form that often lays words over Afro-Cuban rhythms.
But while the hip-hop that sprang up from poor black and Hispanic neighborhoods in the Bronx in the 1970's became an expression of political resistance, the visiting Cuban rappers are critical of society and its individuals, (exposing police harassment of blacks, prostitution and other issues). They do not, though, openly question the government of Fidel Castro.
"Cuba is a country with 42 years of revolution and all the young people were born under the influence of socialism," said Pablo Herrera, a hip-hop music organizer who is traveling with the delegation and also produced "Cuban Hip-Hop All Stars Volume 1," a compilation of Cuban rap released this year by the New York label Papaya Records.
"Our badge has been positive, conscious rap," he said. "In Havana now, if the rapper doesn't talk about something to improve something, the public doesn't respond to it."
But such lofty portrayals have drawn skepticism at some of the group's appearances around the city. At the panel discussion at the Caribbean Cultural Center last Thursday, the Cubans were asked whether they were representative of most rap groups in the island. Do all of them place art above money? 
In fact, Americans knowledgeable about Cuban hip-hop said, every American style is imitated in Cuba, including gangsta rap that talks about guns, drugs and violence, although it may not be the most popular.
"Everybody wants money," said Juan Rodriguez, 20, who studies hip-hop beats at The Door, a Manhattan youth center, and who attended the panel discussion at the Caribbean Cultural Center.
But Yako Prodis, 20, a hip-hop music producer and assistant teacher at The Door, said the Cubans have an advantage in not having a music industry to contend with. The visitors said there is no recording industry to speak of in Cuba -- people hear most performers live -- and only a handful of rap groups have made compact discs.
"Art here is a reflection of what the record labels want," Mr. Prodis said. "That's why you see these negative stereotypes of mostly minorities in hip-hop."
The Cubans, who are staying through November, said they were also concerned about the state of American hip-hop. "Rap has come a long way in Cuba because we've all established goals and worked together," said Magia Lopez, 29, who, with her husband, Alexey Rodriguez, 28, forms "Obsesion."
Around New York, however, the Cubans have often been indistinguishable from the Americans in attire, attitude and bob of the head. At the Nuyoricans Poets Cafe in Manhattan on Saturday night, where the Cubans alternated with local groups on stage, they met performers like Benny Blanco, 26, who rapped about the "hate in your blood" and the military might of the United States in its war against terrorism.
The audience hollered and waved arms in rhythm when the Cubans' turn came, getting their energy and cadence, if not always the deep meaning of their words. Anonimo Consejo, for instance, rapped about "los desaparecidos," the disappeared people all over the world, including those Cubans who take to the sea because of their dire economic condition and end up drowning. 
"I don't know Spanish, I don't understand it," an M.C. who called himself Gaston said after one Cuban performance. "But I don't need to know the language, to know they did damage."

HEADLINE: Israel Rebuffs U.S. Demand To End Its West Bank Raids 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
Israel today rebuffed President Bush's personal request to withdraw its forces from Palestinian-controlled territory, putting new pressure on American-Israeli relations and the United States' counterterrorism coalition with Arab allies.
 The impasse became clear after President Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell met separately today with the Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres. 
 They renewed the United States' demand that Israel pull out of Palestinian-controlled areas of the West Bank. Mr. Peres said Israel would not do so until the security forces of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, arrested the men who murdered Israel's tourism minister last week. 
Mr. Peres said President Bush warned that violence in the Middle East made it harder for the United States to maintain its antiterrorism coalition. "He would like very much the flames to go down, and I told him we shall do whatever we can to reduce them," Mr. Peres said.
Mr. Bush said, "I would hope the Israelis would move their troops as quickly as possible." And Secretary Powell reiterated his demand, made on Monday, for an immediate pullout, a spokesman said.
Mr. Peres said: "We would like to withdraw immediately. The minute the Palestinians will take the necessary steps, this may happen." 
 But the violence continued Wednesday in the West Bank, as three Palestinians were killed by Israeli soldiers in the town of Tulkarem, Agence France-Presse reported. 
Israeli forces began to reoccupy parts of six Palestinian-controlled cities and towns last week after an assassin shot Rehavam Zeevi, the tourism minister, in Jerusalem on Oct. 17. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a secular group with Marxist-Leninist roots, said it killed Mr. Zeevi to avenge Israel's assassination of its leader, Abu Ali Mustafa, in August. 
The ensuing tensions placed the region at its "most dangerous moment in a decade," the United Nations special envoy for Middle East peace, Terje Roed-Larsen, said in a statement released today.
Mr. Peres, who also received Mr. Bush's condolences on Mr. Zeevi's death, took pains to convey the impression that no differences existed between Israel and its strongest ally, the United States. 
"I didn't discover any contradiction in the American policy and the Israeli policy," he said. 
The call for an immediate Israeli withdrawal was balanced by American demands on Mr. Arafat for arrests in Mr. Zeevi's murder, along with suspects in terrorist attacks on Israelis.
"We continue to call upon Chairman Arafat to do everything he can to bring the killer to justice," Mr. Bush said. "It's very important that he arrest the person who did this -- or those who did this act -- and continue to arrest those who would disrupt and harm Israeli citizens. He must show the resolve necessary to bring peace to the region."
Mr. Bush stopped short, however, of calling for Mr. Arafat to turn over the accused killers to Israel for trial there, a demand made by some Israeli officials. 
In Ramallah, on the West Bank, the Palestinian information minister, Yasir Abed Rabbo, said, "The Palestinian Authority is determined to find those responsible for the murder and to take them before Palestinian tribunals." He said that it had made arrests, though he did not provide any details, and he said Mr. Arafat had recommitted Palestinian groups to a cease-fire.
The Palestinian leadership, he said, had held "an intensive dialogue with all factions telling them that this is the end of the game and that everyone should abide by the rules and the obligations that we have made."
Addressing Israeli criticism that the United States was pressuring Israel to build support among Arab nations, Mr. Abed Rabbo said, "What's wrong with getting support from the Arab world?"
Since the Sept. 11 attacks, the United States has tried to build a coalition against terrorism that embraces as many Arab allies as possible. But each of those Arab allies demands some progress toward peace in the Middle East. Each, in varying degrees, sides with the Palestinians.
Israel, long seen as the United States' staunchest ally in the Middle East, and the recipient of billions of dollars in annual American military and economic aid, is also a crucial counter-terrorism partner. Its national security has been a fundamental part of American foreign policy since Israel's creation.
So the American effort to strike a balance is delicate at best. In the days before the killing of Mr. Zeevi, the United States hoped for a return to political talks between the Israelis and Palestinians, said Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman. The killing, the Israeli reaction and Israel's rebuff of the United States' demands today appeared to have damaged those hopes.
The American demand for an Israeli withdrawal was viewed by many Israelis as an effort to score points in the Arab world at Israel's expense. 
Shlomo Ben-Ami, a former Israeli foreign minister and a critic of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, said: "Imagine now that Sharon says, 'Well, all right, I withdraw.' Then what will be the image of Israel in the Arab world?"
Zalman Shoval, a former Israeli ambassador now visiting the United States as Mr. Sharon's envoy, said the American demand "will again encourage the Palestinian side to draw the wrong conclusion, that the pressure is now on Israel and not on them."
"When people speak of a crisis in the relationship, that's perhaps nonsense," said Mr. Shoval, who also has met with senior American officials. "But there are differences of opinion which I have not gotten an answer to from the United States. 
"A senior Israeli political person is assassinated by people who are well known," he said. "So what do you advise us to do? What would you have done in our place? I did not so far hear anything beyond 'wait.' " 
Arab governments have questions for the United States too, Mr. Boucher said.
"Are we really trying to end the violence?" he said. "Are we really trying to create conditions where Palestinians can live better? Are we really trying to offer a path back to negotiations?" The answer, he said, is, "definitely yes."
Mr. Peres, speaking at the Brookings Institution in Washington today, said the United States expected Israel "to calm down as much as we can the situation in the Arab world, namely in the conflict between the Palestinians and ourselves."
"We are asking ourselves how to do it," he said. But Israel cannot do it without clear signs that Mr. Arafat can control militants or arrest suspects within Palestinian-controlled areas, Mr. Peres said. 
"If there is a leader that can do nothing, why do we need him?" he asked. "If a leader cannot lead, who needs him? If he can lead and doesn't, again, what is the value of him?"

HEADLINE: Dazed but Game at Furniture Expo 

BYLINE:  By LIZ SEYMOUR

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C. 

 BODY:
WITH buyer attendance off nearly 30 percent and SWAT teams stationed on the roofs, the International Home Furnishings Market opened here last Thursday on a subdued note. There were few flamboyant debuts or blockbuster collections. Visitors saw a surprising range of sectional sofas, some splashes of orange and chartreuse, new striped fabrics and moderate-price sofas that can be ordered in custom lengths.
 For an industry that just went through its worst six months in two years, world events made a tough situation tougher. "We're used to coming up with something new during bad times, giving people some reason to buy, but what reason can you give them when they're frightened?" said Mitchell Gold, a North Carolina furniture maker. His answer was familiar slouchy slipcovers and saucy stripes, with a program called "Mitchell Gold by the Inch," offering sofas 60 to 120 inches long. 
 At the La-Z-Boy display, Faith Popcorn, who coined the term "cocooning" 20 years ago, demonstrated new cocooning recliners for women ($799). "When a trauma crosses a trend, change ensues," she said. 
Grasping at the thinnest of straws, some speculated that newly introspective Americans might turn to buying furniture. "I don't want anyone to think we're profiting from this, but we're seeing a new appreciation for family, friends and home entertaining," said Jerry Epperson, an industry analyst and partner in the Richmond-based Mann, Armistead & Epperson. "We have an opportunity here."
In normal times the furniture industry would have been near recovery. Factory orders were up in early September, and a strong housing market and low interest rates should have boosted furniture sales. But no one said these were normal times.
The dominant color theme was red, white and blue, from hastily stitched throw pillows to Made in America stickers and giant flags. Larry Laslo, the show's avatar of Modernism, drenched the Directional showroom in chartreuse, charcoal gray and white but still found room on one sofa for a tiny flag pillow of grosgrain ribbon stripes, with pearls on a field of blue satin.
Sectionals, those family room favorites, were back at every price: Directional, Mitchell Gold and Dellarobbia all had striking examples. Dellarobbia's six-piece mix-and-match Capsule sectional by GoodmanCharlton of New York, shown in Necco Wafer shades of brown, blue and off-white ultrasuede, was a hit, even at $12,000. Lower-price fabrics can cut the price to $6,000. Stanley Friedman, the upper-end Modernist, making his debut in the retail market with three new collections for Weiman, showed sleek sectionals. Barbara Barry shook up the staid Baker showroom with a cushy six-piece sectional clad in a topaz rayon-and-linen blend ($23,000).
Many of the new pieces were hiply unhip -- or what might be called the new dowdiness. Thomas O'Brien, whose sophisticated urban collection for Hickory Chair two years ago set off a cycle of dark wood and silver hardware, added a grandmotherly skirted sofa to his Hickory Chair collection. Fabrics were nubbly and comfortable, wood finishes a little warmer, and purely traditional designs were much in evidence.
It was a spirit that predated recent events. American-theme country groups had been planned by Drexel Heritage (American Tempo) and Hickory Chair (American Portfolio). "We came to market looking for furniture that was less gaudy, less ostentatious," said David Kaplan, senior vice president of Beacon Hill, a chain of upper-end design showrooms. "Our customer has been moving in that direction over the last year anyway."
Ready-to-wear was a big inspiration in many showrooms, where Kate Spade-like stripes, Burberry-style plaids, big checks and hot colors were the rule. Modernism was by no means dead: Michael Weiss designed a spiffy new group of pieces for Vanguard Furniture -- saddle-stitched leather, brushed nickel hardware and ash wood, with echoes of elegant French Moderne at a mid-American price.
Manufacturers are trying to remain optimistic. "People who buy our furniture have money, and they're the kind of people who always have money," said Robert Dillon, president of John Widdicomb, which was introducing a new $10,000 mahogany bed in its Studio line. "When the economy goes bad, our business generally stays even. But this time it's different. This time it's very different."

HEADLINE: GOOD FENCES; 
Burb Cocooning? Who Has Time?

BYLINE:  By JOE QUEENAN

 BODY:
ONE inevitable result of a disaster like Sept. 11 is a profusion of quasi-scientific ruminating about the psychic health of the nation. My favorite is the notion that the American people have entered a period of intense national "cocooning" that may last from 3 months to 10 years. 
 Shortly after the attacks, Faith Popcorn, the self-anointed trends prognosticator who coined the term "cocooning" 20 years ago, introduced an even more extravagant neologism, "armored cocooning": stocking up on antibiotics, air filters, viral filters -- the full home nuclear-winter arsenal. 
 Other cocooning buffs draw a distinction between "home cocoons" and "neighborhood cocoons." This leaves open the possibility that we may soon be grappling with concepts like "tract-home cocooning," "time-share cocooning," "split-level cocooning" and "McMansion cocooning." Not to mention "gated-community cocooning." 
Contemporary cocoonery is not devoid of a merchandising component. On Oct. 18, The Wall Street Journal ran an article titled "Retailers Pin Hopes on Cocooning TV buyers." It quoted an electronics chain store executive as saying, "TV, in a time of crisis, feels like a necessary thing, while a speaker and a stereo system might feel more discretionary." One assumes this is because entire families can cocoon around a single 52-inch TV set watching CNN, whereas no self-respecting teenager is going to cocoon in the living room while his parents are playing their old Carly Simon records.
As a resident of Tarrytown, a suburban village 25 miles north of Manhattan, I live in precisely the sort of Norman Rockwell-type community where cocooning should be the modus vivendi. So far, I'm not seeing it. 
The Greek diner up the street from my office is packed day and night. Churches are filled. The high school kids are still getting into trouble with the police. The village hall is still filled with grumpy citizens complaining about unprincipled developers, questionable budgetary expenditures and woefully inadequate warnings that a Richard Dreyfus television program was being filmed downtown. The soccer moms and dads are still overwhelmed by the need to ferry their tykes from one disastrously lopsided game to the next. "I'd love to be able to stay home and cocoon," said T. J. Elliott, a Tarrytown human-resources consultant. "But I've got three kids; I'm driving to soccer games all over the county."
What many people -- particularly young, unmarried urban journalists -- fail to realize about the suburbs is that the tyranny of routine precludes rest.
"Everybody's got a program, and everybody's got a program all the time," said Tom Staudter, a teacher, journalist and father of two who has lived in the area since childhood. He was trying to squeeze in a Jets game between dinner and a Denzel Washington movie while attending the harvest fair at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills nearby. He has not now cocooned, nor will he ever. 
In suburbs like this, the infrastructure of normality eats up enormous amounts of the day (and night): school board meetings, parent association meetings, fund-raisers, swim competitions, teacher conferences, garden club socials, planning board hearings, multiplex visits, football, soccer, volleyball. Senior citizens have flu shots to get, art classes to attend, tai-chi lessons, bills to complain about. And a recital at the library featuring Anton Del Forno, master of the classical guitar. Free.
A cynic might argue that all these activities qualify as "communal cocooning," that by its very nature life in a quiet, unassuming hamlet involves some form of villagewide intellectual vegetation. 
But this sneering perspective overlooks the definition of classic cocooning, with its a sense of hunkering down, hanging crepe over the windows, battening down the hatches, waiting for this awful Taliban thing to blow over. 
This is hardly the kind of behavior we are seeing in the lower Hudson Valley. The leaf watchers have been out in force every weekend, bikers and joggers are even more abundant than usual, caffe lattes are still being sold in prodigious quantities. When the Ying Quartet played at the high school a few Saturdays ago, almost 600 people showed up. War or no war, people are still getting married, boys are still having bar mitzvahs, babies are still getting born. 
At a festive wedding I attended last Saturday it was obviously going to take more than Osama bin Laden to keep the Electric Sliders off the dance floor. Not while the fabulous Jimmy D was spinning the platters.
This is not to say that suburban life has been unaffected. People from here died in those buildings. Other people could have died. There were funerals, vigils, church services. And the economic impact is being felt all over.
A man who runs a service that takes people to airports says business has fallen off 90 percent. Several people I spoke with seem reluctant to visit prominent malls and certainly do not want their children visiting them. Many Thanksgiving travel plans are on hold.
People are worried about anthrax and microbes in their water, just as they are worried about the safety of the Indian Point nuclear power plant a few miles up the river. Judy Kass, who worked in Tower 2 for a subsidiary of Marsh & McLennan, which lost 292 people in the World Trade Center attack, says that she no longer hangs out in Grand Central Terminal, admiring its splendors, visiting its shops. "Now I wait outside until it's time for my train, and get on it," she said.
Still, when she has free time on the weekend, she's not staying indoors. If you're going to cocoon in a place like this, you're going to have to cocoon in your car.
In these information-overloaded times, when "crisis counselors" and "bioterrorism experts" seem to be more numerous than blades of grass, we must be careful to resist the allures of the portentous anecdote.
But here's a little chestnut to nibble on. After my son's soccer game on Sunday, the coach discussed a trip to Hawaii next July for a national tournament. Between now and then, it will be up to the parents to decide whether they feel comfortable having their children fly 6,000 miles.
My wife and I must make a decision soon, even though we have no way of knowing what the world will look like nine months from now. But the kids were already debating which players weren't going to make the final cut. You could see from the look on their faces that a week in Hawaii sounded pretty good. A lot better than a week in a cocoon.

HEADLINE: Several Orchestras Are Troubled Financially 

BYLINE:  By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
Two major symphony orchestras, the St. Louis Symphony and the Toronto Symphony, are on the brink of bankruptcy and are asking musicians to take pay cuts and possibly shorten their seasons, while a third, the Chicago Symphony, is projecting deficits for the first time in 15 years.
 The Toronto Symphony, which is facing an accumulated deficit of $7 million (Canadian), could be bankrupt by the end of the week, orchestra officials said. Last week in California, the San Jose Symphony dissolved its board after posting a $2.5 million deficit on a budget of $7.8 million. That regional orchestra is hoping to restructure. 
 And now the Chicago Symphony, a renowned ensemble that has long been the picture of solvency, is projecting deficits for this season and next. Chicago's problems are by no means as dire as those of St. Louis and Toronto, both highly regarded orchestras, and the Chicago musicians are not being asked to take cuts. But a flagship educational program has been canceled, and a dozen staff positions have been eliminated, most through attrition. 
Through the stock market boom of the late 1990's, many of the best North American orchestras found ways to meet their budgets, build endowments and expand their reach through educational programs and other community projects. But in the current economic downturn, with falling interest rates whittling away at the endowment incomes that some orchestras use to underwrite operations, musicians and managements are nervous.
Spokesmen on both sides have also noted a slowing in ticket sales that they attribute partly to the economy and partly to audience skittishness since Sept. 11. Others say that downturns at a handful of orchestras don't necessarily mean the start of a trend.
"When the economy goes down, you always have orchestras that are vulnerable," said Robert Levine, the chairman of the International Conference of Symphony and Opera Musicians and a member of the Milwaukee Symphony. "But there are quite a few orchestras that are doing fine. The Seattle Symphony just closed its fiscal year with a surplus."
Still, the situation in Toronto is particularly perilous. On Sept. 25, the orchestra's executive director, Edward Smith, resigned abruptly after only 10 months in his post, declaring starkly that "I don't believe the organization will be able to withstand the problems with which it is faced."
That same day, Robert Weiss, the chairman of the Toronto Symphony, told the board that the orchestra had lost $2.26 million this year (all Toronto Symphony figures Canadian), bringing its accumulated deficit to $7 million. Its annual budget is $17 million. Without $1.5 million in immediate cash and $1 million in credit, Mr. Weiss told the board, the orchestra might have to declare bankruptcy by Nov. 30. Within a week, the orchestra hired Lambert Huizingh, the president of International Restructuring Corporation, to restructure the orchestra. By mid-October, the players were asked to consider a 15 percent salary cut as well as a six-week curtailment of the season, which would bring salaries down another 8 percent. The proposal included a reduction in the orchestra's ranks, to 84 from 98.
When the musicians quickly agreed to reopen their contract, the Toronto Symphony Orchestra Foundation agreed to advance $1.5 million in interest payments from the orchestra's $22 million endowment, as an emergency measure. But since that money was to have been paid in 2002 and was expected to cover expenses next season, it does not solve the problem.
The transaction has also angered the musicians, whose contract, won after an 11-week strike in 1999, promises them a 29.8 percent increase over four seasons. The current minimum annual salary at the orchestra is $64,000.
"We came to an agreement almost two years ago, but I don't know what the point was," said Bill Skolnik, the executive director of the Toronto Musicians Association, Local 149 of the American Federation of Musicians. "We saw the books at that time, and we saw that unless there was a major improvement in getting revenue and cutting costs, this was likely. But that required an effort on the board's part, which we thought that the board would undertake in order to fulfill their agreement. But that didn't happen." 
This week, the players and Mr. Weiss closeted themselves in negotiations and imposed a news blackout. But Jane Rannie, the orchestra's spokeswoman, said that the money in the advance from the foundation would last only until Friday. The orchestra could be bankrupt by the end of the week.
At the St. Louis Symphony, the mood has gone from euphoria to near-depression in less than a year. Last December, Andrew C. Taylor, the chief executive of Enterprise Rent-a-Car, announced a $40 million challenge grant from his family, the largest grant ever made to an arts organization. If the challenge is met -- so far the orchestra has raised $18 million -- it will give the organization an $80 million nest egg, $10 million of which can be used for operations, with the rest destined for an endowment currently at $18 million. 
But even as the orchestra celebrated its gift, it was clear that all was not well. The organization had been running annual deficits as high as $7 million for much of the last decade on annual budgets of around $25 million. Last summer, the board proposed severe measures, including possibly reducing the size of the orchestra. Its executive director, Don Roth, abruptly resigned (and was hired by the Aspen Music Festival, which had just lost its executive director, Robert Harth, to Carnegie Hall). W. Randolph Adams, a retired banker and financial consultant, was appointed to succeed him.
"What caused this," Mr. Adams said, "was that over the last 30 years, the orchestra has taken on a set of activities that were well meaning, but which overloaded the boat." He cited as examples a music school, which has now been transferred to Webster University, and some costly pops programs.
His plan to get the orchestra through its crisis includes cutting $7 million from the budget and obtaining $29 million by Dec. 31 (with payments in hand by August) to pay outstanding debts, as well as raising the remaining $22 million needed to match the $40 million Taylor grant. Although Mr. Adams has backed away from the idea of reducing the size of the orchestra, he said that he would probably ask the musicians to trim the season by a few weeks and to take pay cuts of as much as 20 to 30 percent. (The orchestra's minimum salary is $75,400.)
The orchestra has not yet decided whether to reopen its contract, and a faction is said to be too angry to consider it. 
The Chicago Symphony Orchestra's problems may seem trivial by comparison. At a board meeting early this month, the orchestra, which has an annual budget of $60 million and a $168 million endowment, projected deficits of $1.3 million this year and $2 million in 2002. 
"I admit that we spent up to our resources, even as those resources were climbing at the height of the stock market," Henry Fogel, the orchestra president, said. "But the economy turned over the last year and a half, and that had an effect on fund-raising."
Mr. Fogel also noted that while attendance had remained strong, box office income had been flat because of audience resistance to price increases, and that the value of the endowment had dropped.
Ticket sales since Sept. 11 have been about 20 percent below the orchestra's projections. And in an unrelated blow, the orchestra's nationally syndicated radio broadcasts were discontinued this month when new sponsors could not be found to replace BP. 
Mr. Fogel eliminated five administrative jobs and has frozen seven others through attrition. The orchestra also trimmed costs for a staging of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" and closed ECHO, the music education center opened with considerable fanfare in September 1998. 
"The issue isn't the $1.3 million, but what's going to happen to fund-raising and ticket sales post-Sept. 11," Mr. Fogel said. "We've done what we can for 2002, but we're looking to cut $4 million to $5 million from the budget in 2003 and 2004. But where our problems differ from other orchestras in crisis is that we are not looking at cutting core activities. We're looking at extra things we've done and asking if we can afford them." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Chicago Symphony trimmed costs on "Tristan und Isolde." (Chris Lee for The New York Times)(pg. E4)

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Debates Link to Dollar 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
With the economy falling and public discontent rising, Hong Kong has been questioning one of its cornerstones: the linking of its currency to the United States dollar at a fixed exchange rate.
 The debate began last month when the territory's financial secretary, Antony Leung, told a local newspaper that the peg, as the exchange rate is known, was an obstacle to an efficient economy. 
 Mr. Leung, a former banker at J. P. Morgan Chase who joined the government in May, stirred matters further last week when he said that removing the peg would give Hong Kong more flexibility in adjusting prices. 
Both times, he went on to say that Hong Kong had no plans to abandon the policy now because it would invite speculation against the Hong Kong dollar. But few people paid attention to his disclaimers.
Currency traders bet heavily against the Hong Kong dollar, hoping to capitalize on a shift in the government's policy. And longtime opponents of the linked exchange rate urged Tung Chee-hwa, the territory's chief executive, to abandon the policy, which has been in place since 1983. Mr. Tung is widely expected to try for -- and win -- a second term next March.
"Mr. Tung should consider scrapping the peg during his second term," said James Tien, the head of the Liberal Party and a former chairman of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce, in an interview with The South China Morning Post last month.
Asked by reporters in Shanghai after the recent Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meetings about such a possibility , Mr. Tung said, "The answer is no, no, no!"
Few economists believe that Hong Kong will sever the link between its currency and the United States dollar any time soon. Discussions about the wisdom of the policy are almost a parlor game here. But analysts say this debate is more vigorous and public than previous ones have been, and that shows how deeply the global economic downturn has shaken Hong Kong, a former British colony.
Hong Kong's exports tumbled 9 percent in August, and economic growth has stalled. Unemployment is expected to rise close to 6 percent, rivaling the darkest days of the Asian economic crisis in 1997-98.
While most Asian countries, with the notable exception of China, are also suffering, people here say Hong Kong bears an extra burden. Its currency has not depreciated in value like that of its neighbors. That makes Hong Kong expensive as an export market and as a place to do business.
"It is an open secret that the currency is overvalued," said Sin-ming Shaw, a market commentator and former economist at Chase.
Hong Kong has been willing to tolerate this disparity in the past because linking its dollar's exchange rate to the United States dollar has given it stability. Foreign investors could put their money here and be confident that it would not be jeopardized by Hong Kong's stormy transition to Chinese sovereignty.
"It was introduced at a time when the talks over Hong Kong's future were going badly," said Richard Margolis, a former British diplomat who is now a strategist at Merrill Lynch. "There was a bit of panic."
At times, defending the currency link has been costly. In 1998, the government spent $15 billion on shares in the local stock market to foil foreign traders whom it accused of manipulating the currency.
While Hong Kong recovered from the crisis, a bubble in real estate prices that had been building for most of the 1990's burst. As property prices plummeted, many people found themselves holding mortgages exceeding the value of their homes.
"We're going through a slow, painful process of deflation that breeds discontent," Mr. Shaw said.
In this environment, the exchange rate is an easy target. People say it is a costly relic. Hong Kong's political stability is no longer in doubt, as China has mainly stayed out of local affairs. And the strength of the Chinese economy has become one of Hong Kong's prime selling points.
Supporters of the status quo say Hong Kong is mainly a financial center, not an exporter competing with Taiwan and Singapore. So devaluing the currency would not necessarily bolster the economy. They say Hong Kong needs to confront more basic problems, like its real estate market, which is dominated by a cartel.
The most pressing reason for Hong Kong to stick with its policy may have little to do with this city of seven million and more to do with other countries with currencies linked to the United States dollar.
"If you abandoned the dollar peg tomorrow, what would happen in Argentina?" said Simon L. Ogus, the chief executive of DSG Asia, a research group here. "We would have an emerging-market default."
