HEADLINE: With the World Redesigned, What Role for Designers? 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
FOR the last two years, the field of design has enjoyed the popularity of a professional lifetime. It has appeared on the covers of Time and Business Week, its now famous figures profiled on Ted Koppel's "Nightline" and Charlie Rose. Annual awards were created, and new design-related publications proliferated. 
 With its titanium coating and colored gels, design was, literally, the bright surface of economic success, the gleam in the eye of a public eager to play with the products of prosperity, from Target teakettles to iMacs. 
 In light of last month's events, design's sharp flash, as a mirror of public mood, has started to reflect a different picture -- a view of an altered world, pocked by new realities. But design's traditional talent -- to pose then to solve problems -- could give it a role in leading the national recovery, emotionally and economically. 
On Oct. 17, seven accomplished designers were presented with the Chrysler Design Awards, prestigious annual prizes for innovation and achievement in various disciplines of design.
That afternoon, the editors and reporters of House & Home invited them to sit and to discuss their responses to Sept. 11 and to the situations of the last six weeks. Can -- and should -- design play an important part? And how? 
This year's award winners included Robert Mangurian and Mary-Ann Ray, architects whose company, Studio Works in Los Angeles, is working with the Los Angeles Unified School District on high school design that could defuse the battle-like presence of high-security measures.
Susan Kare, an interface graphic designer in San Francisco, is known for the family of desktop icons produced for Apple, including the wristwatch whose hands spin as a task is performed -- work that has become a humorous, reassuring standard for personal computing software.
Stefan Sagmeister, a graphic designer based in New York, is well known for iconoclastic rock music packaging for clients like the Rolling Stones.
Kathryn Gustafson, a landscape architect in Seattle, creates meditative integrations of structure and nature, like the Arthur Ross Terrace for the Rose Center for Earth and Space in New York.
Daniel Rozin is a new-media artist working as director of research at New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program at the Tisch School of the Arts, to transform complex digital technologies into humanistic crafts that engage the imagination.
Thom Mayne is an architect in Santa Monica, Calif., whose company, Morphosis, is presently designing a federal courthouse in Eugene, Ore. He has proposed a glass box for the project that will, he hopes, transcend with optimistic transparence a fortress-like future that may now seem inevitable in the construction of government buildings.
Also participating in the round table were Paula Scher, a graphic designer at Pentagram in New York; David Kelley, an industrial designer and founder of Ideo in Palo Alto, Calif., whose resume includes the Palm V and the Apple mouse; John Hockenberry, an NBC News correspondent and design writer; Patrick Best, an industrial design student; Steven Heller, art director of The New York Times Book Review and the author of 80 books on design; and Phil Patton and Chee Pearlman, who write for House & Home.
Several days later, several designers also responded with actual designs -- ultimately, what designers do when called to answer. Ms. Scher created a pin that is part flag, part memorial in its graphic symbol. Mr. Sagmeister's proposal for Cipro, right, facilitates its correct use in an emergency by incorporating instructions into the packaging itself. He is also at work on a pin, "A Heart (Unbreakable)," stamped from metal from the rubble of the World Trade Center.
As Ms. Kare wrote in a follow-up note, "When times are confusing, it's more important than ever to produce images of clarity and simplicity."

Q: How might design participate now, in the national effort at recovery and reassurance?

STEFAN SAGMEISTER: After the 11th, I felt fairly useless. I would make a really bad fireman or rescue worker. What can one do? What we're working on right now is a pin. Sort of like a personal memorial.

PAULA SCHER: There's going to be a lot of involvement between design and the city -- because they're married. New York City is a design city -- designers will be involved. We're going to rebuild a whole section of town. Which is what designers do -- they make things.

JOHN HOCKENBERRY: It's a city that functions because essential information is communicated to large numbers of people very, very quickly, which is what the signage is about. I think design is, in many ways, a language in which we will understand the aftermath of Sept. 11. There's been an excavation of the function of the city through these events: the image of Con Ed, of the firemen. It's a kind of a beginning to redefine and to reconnect with all these kinds of institutions. And designers will be leading that task.

Q: Should designers be reassessing what they do?

ROBERT MANGURIAN: In the last 10 years, the computer information industry turned the economy into a revved-up, hyped-up machine that is producing endless numbers of extremely well-designed objects. But new things keep the economy rolling. So it's problematic. If you design a perfectly good chair, it really could last forever. Which puts designers out of business. And puts chair makers out of business too.

Q: Should this be seen as a call for designers to be more socially responsible then?

THOM MAYNE: Architecture over the last 20 years has been somewhat aloof from its social tasks. For me it's not at all an issue of responding instantly to this event. It's meaningless -- it's like the flags going out. I find them actually quite disturbing -- somehow kind of intentionally not allowing us to understand the kind of deeper meaning of this. I think in architecture, hopefully, that it's going to force us to, as a community, re-look at our work. Kind of interesting it's taking place in the beginning of a new century.

MARY-ANN RAY: If we have to make do with less, how do we as designers operate in that situation? We travel to other countries that don't have the kind of means that we have, the kind of invention and design. But just on the street, the way things are made have a kind of wisdom.

MANGURIAN: We saw a great thing in Tunisia, at an archaeological site. A person there -- he had a plastic bottle, like any good yuppie would have, walking around drinking his water. But on the plastic bottle was a sock. And every once in a while the sock would get dipped in water, which would chill the water down in here 15 degrees.

RAY: Through evaporative cooling. Basically it was the terra-cotta vessel they've always used.

MANGURIAN: There's nothing to sell. It's a problem. (Laughter.)

SCHER: I didn't feel powerless. The thing that just kept coming to my mind was, design matters. Because what surrounds you -- happiness, love, joy -- that gets into your soul. We create environments for people. We create things that make their soul, hopefully.

MAYNE: It's radically different from my colleagues in Europe. Like all American architects, we've grown up in the private sector. You either support work in the private sector, or you resist it. I'm 57 years old. At 55 you supposedly arrive. You start getting the public work that my pals in Europe get when they're 35. You can do schools and buildings and universities and courthouses. It takes you that long, to get to the point of even dealing with public as an idea or civic as an idea.

Q: Should the public demand, or should designers provide, responsible design then?

SCHER: Both. There's been too much information that's speeded up, so that there's no collective understanding. Part of what's happened to us was a result of a whole nation not paying attention, because they were looking someplace else -- because of the way information is designed. I think that graphic designers have a responsibility both to their client and their public to enable them to understand what they're looking at when they read information -- what the structure of the information is. The New York Times is organized a specific way, and specific things appear in certain sections. Something on Page 3 -- is that necessarily less important? The public has to be informed as to the devices.

HOCKENBERRY: The lifeblood of discourse -- whether you're a storyteller, or a television guy or a designer -- is the shared experience of a community. And one of the impacts of consumer culture is to reduce the amount of shared experience. Without that shared experience, you're atomized: We'll make money off of individual, little fragments of the market. An event like this brings us back to the notion that the shared experience is, in fact, the most profound resource of any designer. This is an opportunity, I think. Designers have to be radical advocates for preservation of this shared experience, rather than successful entrepreneurs of the latest month-old icon. I think World War II created a shared experience in America. I think the frontier created a shared experience in America. But we let it go.

Q: Will design, as it did in World War II, address the national mood?

MAYNE: The problem here is that we live in a culture where, as a designer, regardless of the discipline, to look for that consensus -- it doesn't exist.

DANIEL ROZIN: The biggest question is, Who are we designing for? It seems like we're designing for ourselves, Americans. Once every century or half a century we're thrown into the international arena, and then we tend to sink back to this state of self-sufficiency -- where we design for ourselves. A designer's work is about communication and information. And we have a huge case of misconception here between us and our adversaries. Who are they? We think they're evil; they think we're evil. It's a design problem.

The word "they" is actually the root of it. Is there a "they"? If design is universal?

KATHRYN GUSTAFSON: In Europe, the public demands and asks for a good design. Especially in our fields of landscape and architecture. Our field doesn't move across the Web the way yours does. And so they're very concerned -- it's much more community-oriented. What are we doing wrong that our public doesn't know that it matters?

SCHER: It takes time for a culture to accept and embrace design as part of its way of life. And I actually have seen, in the past 30 years, a tremendous growth of sophistication here. But it's a very slow process.
Q: What have clients been saying?

DAVID KELLEY: The clients still come in, and they're about innovation or business. But we're talking about something that's a little different. Everybody I know has this collective worry, this collective kind of "I don't know what's going to happen next." I've never seen that. I doubt if the Second World War was that way. Certainly Vietnam wasn't that way. There were a bunch of people who were worried about whether they were going to be drafted. But the whole world, at least the whole country, wasn't. It comes back to doing the best you can, to innovating our way out of this mess. They're not talking about whether Maya Lin should design the memorial. We're not there yet. Designers are also going to be who designs the new toothpaste, the new everything.

Q: Is there any indication from clients that designs are being redirected by concern?

KELLEY: I had a whole bunch of clients stuck in my office for eight days. They couldn't get home. Because you now share this collective human feeling, I can bring up subjects with clients that I don't think I could bring up before. Sustainability is much easier to talk about. They're just in a different mood. Anything that has to do with human is on the table now with business-based people. We always talk about emotional stuff, almost spiritual subjects as designers. I think we can engage that kind of discussion with clients. I think we're going to come out of this with a much more human culture in the United States. There are designers who are humanists, and they're going to come to the front.

GUSTAFSON: We're talking about community sustainable. I felt like we were living in our little houses. Hopefully, the public as client will understand that you need tolerance to have a whole world, a whole society.

Q: What role will the economy play now in design's future?

KELLEY: We were already on a downturn. Clients that were big on innovation thought they could get out of it by innovation. You can't just keep cutting cost. You have to have the courage to say, "O.K., our company is going to succeed by doing things that really please people." That's a point where you can make a difference as a designer. Get them excited about the prospects.

SUSAN KARE: In times of stress, people are reassured by what's familiar. Some of that can be imagery. Art history shows the power of imagery. You still look at those cave paintings, you look at those Egyptian figurines in the cases at the Met; you're not aware of exactly what was happening politically as you see those creations. This has made me think about how important symbols are. Everybody got out their flags. Everybody you saw. It was not only a statement that made people feel better -- it was a statement that the wearer was affected.

CHEE PEARLMAN: Given the opportunity to jump on a new job tomorrow if you got the call, what would it be?

SAGMEISTER: Patient information booklet for Cipro. I think this event and this situation would need some sort of unifying symbol.

MANGURIAN: We're doing some work for the L.A.U.S.D. (Los Angeles Unified School District). They have been doing the under-siege sort of tactic for a long time with the schools. The job I would like to do would be to somehow convince people at the L.A.U.S.D. to open the doors, and have the strength to make it work. To "close it all down" -- it produces a war-zone mentality. You see it as you drive through the cities now. We're producing that kind of mentality; it's dangerous. Protecting ourselves, protecting our lifestyle, which I think should be just the opposite.

HOCKENBERRY: What would you do about the mail, in the light of biochemical attacks?

PATRICK BEST: One of the joys of the mail is that it's a surprise. It's like Christmas. You get a letter from your grandmother, a letter from your kid at camp -- you don't want to lose that. You also, obviously, want to get a sense of security. It's a challenge, to experiment with new materials. Because obviously paper envelopes or paper packaging has an extreme limitation.
I think there's an opportunity now to educate people. That's what monuments a lot of times do. Like the Vietnam Memorial. When you read about the Vietnam War in a book it doesn't have any emotional impact. But when you go to the Vietnam wall, you sense the anguish, you sense the monumentality of it. I think I'd propose a monument to enlightenment. That we need to enlighten ourselves in the way we go about designing, living. Because they're completely intertwined.

HOCKENBERRY: I talked to a counterterrorism person. He worked on the Tylenol killer case. What happened there, and the reason it's never happened again, was in part a design. Sealable packaging. It didn't involve the Constitution, and it didn't involve the First Amendment, and it didn't involve any of the values that supposedly we worried were going to be tossed down the drain. It was this simple sort of union of perception meeting a design that is reassuring. And our lives from now on are going to be filled with those things, he said.

MAYNE: The intersection between the reality of defense and the necessity for openness that Robert talked about -- we're doing a courthouse in Eugene. They're going to build a glass box. And it's an absolute symbolic statement of a chief justice, Oregon in this case, who refuses to acknowledge the necessity of a defensive strategy. In fact it is promoting a new openness.

KARE: I'm interested in trying to convey as much clarity, and simplicity and meaning in "small device" spaces. Say, cellphones. Standardize a symbol set that was both clear and warm, and slightly more humane. Screens -- you're able now to have a little photograph of something. I think you can work on a lot of those symbols, that would help.

HOCKENBERRY: If the symbolism is universal, I think that's reassuring, independent of the function of the object often.

Q: Design often plays the "edge." Is that suitable now? Is it acceptable to be funny?

SCHER: It's going to have to be, or what a grim world.

SAGMEISTER: I heard a very young designer from Holland say that the time for being "against" is over. That it's for the old. We actually want to be for something. I know for myself that I'm much less cynical. I mean, you know -- I look at Sting now differently.

Q: We're going into the holidays with an enormous pall. People feel they can't fly, they don't know if they should buy, they're facing enormous layoffs. Do we need another design push, an optimistic movement like the streamlining that accompanied the Depression?

KELLEY: I was thinking more of a kind of simplicity. I had dinner with old friends here last night, and my toast included an acknowledgment to living a charmed life in this culture. And having just been reminded that we're now joining much of the rest of the world in another existence. And how important our friendship is. It was understood a little differently than it was two months ago. The importance of some sort of continuity, or some sort of a constituency, that sustains a design sensibility -- it's beyond the necessity of sustaining some economic goal.

Q: If Americans are in part resented for their cultural imagery, what do designers do about this?

SCHER: I'm uncomfortable with following symbols. I find that the best manipulator of symbols in this whole thing was Osama bin Laden. The image of the World Trade Center being hit by the planes was the most powerful use of symbol. I think that to a degree we may have a responsibility for defusing symbols to make people understand how they may be manipulated by what they see.

SAGMEISTER: It's not the fault of the symbol; it's the fault of how we apply it and for whom we apply it. The swastika by itself was an age-old symbol that had different values in different cultures. But the way it was applied -- and it was a strong application. But did it help make our world a horrible place?

SCHER: The most moving art that I saw made was in Union Square Park and in the parks where people made their own private demonstration, without the intellectual baggage that we bring to all of that stuff. Because it was really human.

ROZIN: It's made us all designers. I think as designers, what we need to develop now is not so much a symbol, but a whole narrative of what it means to be us. What do we stand for? And we need to communicate it to ourselves, because we really don't know who we are right now and what do we stand for? And we really don't understand why they hate us. I don't think a symbol could help you. I think symbols are too powerful. We're talking about a ground-up narrative that has to emerge.

PEARLMAN: If we were around this table a year from now, any thoughts about what we'll be up to?

MANGURIAN: The instructions for living, which I think the Shakers wanted to do, are somehow placed within, into the drawing or the object. Like the Tylenol cap. You don't look at it and think of the problem, and it ruins your life. I think finding a way to place really good instructions that are generous and open, and so on, in things is really -- that's what I would like to be doing a year from now.

LENGTH: 405 words

HEADLINE: The House Acts Badly 

 BODY:
The razor-thin margin by which the House Republicans passed their economic stimulus package yesterday was a tribute to how really dreadful that proposal is. A huge package of tax cuts, no matter how ill advised, can generally attract supporters. But despite desperate pressure from the House leadership, and the assurance that whatever they voted for would be made more sensible by the Senate, the stimulus plan squeaked through the House by only two votes. 
 The House bill was top-heavy with giveaways to corporations and tax cuts to the wealthiest 30 percent of Americans. Since those citizens are the least likely to immediately spend new money they acquire, it made little sense as an economic stimulus. At a time when the country is being urged to make sacrifices for the common good, the idea of well-to-do Americans lining up for a tax break is appalling. Even many of the people to whom the cuts are directed would probably willingly forgo them at this time of crisis. But the nation has been distracted by the anthrax scare and the war against terrorism. Only the House, it seems, has the leisure to dream up giveaways for special interests and campaign donors. 
 Far superior to the House measure was a $70 billion package of tax breaks and subsidies announced Tuesday night by Max Baucus, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. It would provide rebates for families left out of the tax cuts enacted earlier this year, as well as tax cuts to help businesses write off their capital investments at an accelerated rate. Other features would help the poor and unemployed get health coverage. These provisions do everything the House bill does not do: help those who need it most, provide a genuine stimulus to the economy and carry an affordable price tag.
A couple of weeks ago Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill memorably characterized the House measure as "show business," with little likelihood of winning final passage. Yesterday Republicans put on quite a different kind of show, as House Speaker Dennis Hastert and Tom DeLay, the Republican whip, cajoled, threatened and pressured wavering Republicans to go along with this unacceptable legislation. Even so, they barely succeeded. There will now be a negotiation involving Senate Democrats and Republicans in the House, along with President Bush. The Baucus bill should serve as the basis for their discussions and for the final stimulus package enacted into law.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says Protectionism Is Hardly an Antidote to Terror 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Calling globalization "the antithesis of terrorism," Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, set out a case tonight for continuing to knock down trade barriers and integrating economies across borders.
 Acknowledging the spread of protests in recent years against the brand of unfettered capitalism that he supports, Mr. Greenspan said allowing competition, products, money and ideas to flow between countries had proved a powerful force for economic advancement, but that the process yielded losers as well as winners. 
 The Fed chairman said the answer was not to inhibit international competition, but to help people who are hurt by what the economist Joseph Schumpeter called "creative destruction." He cited worker retraining, and long-term unemployment or welfare benefits, as possible solutions.
"Protectionism will only slow the inevitable transition of our work force to more productive endeavors," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech here to the Institute for International Economics. 
"To be sure," he said, "an added few years on the job may enable some workers to reach retirement with reasonable security and dignity, but if we hinder competitive progress, we will almost certainly slow overall economic growth and keep frozen in place younger workers whose opportunities to secure jobs with better long-term prospects diminish with time."
Mr. Greenspan did not comment on the economic outlook or give any hint of how much further the Fed is likely to go in cutting interest rates this year.
His comments seemed an oblique attempt to give his support to a new round of global trade talks at a meeting of trade ministers next month, and to press Congress into giving President Bush expanded authority to negotiate trade deals.
But his speech also appeared to have a broader goal. It set forth an intellectual framework from which advocates of market forces could counter the protests against globalization and the tendency for nations and individuals alike to turn inward when faced with cataclysms like the terrorist attacks on the United States last month.
"Terrorism poses a challenge to the remarkable record of globalization," Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
An Old Tactic: Painting A Rival Red

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
AT a breakfast appearance this week, Mark Green spoke more substantively than ever about the grave problems confronting New York City, about the anemic economy and how to rebuild downtown, about the argument for tax credits and the need for cooperation from Albany and Washington.
 You may not have heard about the Green speech because the event, sponsored by Crain's New York Business, was overshadowed by the distractions of a white-haired man who prowled the back of the room at the Grand Hyatt, muttering and pacing, as if waiting to pounce. That he was. 
 Mr. Green had barely left the stage when William Cunningham, senior adviser to Michael R. Bloomberg, sought out reporters to make an accusation that recalled the redbaiting 1950's. Yes, in the aftermath of a terrorist attack that killed thousands and dealt New York a body blow, a flashback to the painful days of "Are you now or have you ever been . . . ?" 
Noting that Mr. Green had referred to a book he had written, Mr. Cunningham said, "He finally admitted that he wrote some books, and now they can become part of the campaign dialogue, including his defense of Joseph Stalin on one occasion."
He was talking about Mr. Green's "Winning Back America," a 1982 book in which he accused Ronald Reagan of a tendency to revise history. He wrote that Mr. Reagan had been wrong to say that the aim of all leaders of the Soviet Union was world revolution because, Mr. Green wrote, Joseph Stalin "pushed for 'socialism in one country.' "
A brief history lesson: historians have long interpreted Stalin's slogan of "socialism in one country" as meaning that the Soviet Union would not sacrifice its interests for world revolution, but nonetheless dreamed of communism spreading throughout the world. 
Robert Legvold, professor of political science at Columbia University, said yesterday that Mr. Green had oversimplified -- "Stalin saw the Soviet Union as leader of a trend," he said -- but called the Cunningham accusation "nuts."
"This is not a defense of Stalin by any means," Professor Legvold said. "To say what Green wrote represents sympathy with Stalin is crazy. Green oversimplifies and Bloomberg makes a false accusation."
Because Mr. Cunningham is an adviser, not a candidate, his remarks would rate a footnote at most if Mr. Bloomberg had repudiated them, or just distanced himself from them. But the Republican candidate said, "Mark Green has been very liberal all of his life."
He called Mr. Green a "liberal, leftist kind of guy." He added: "I don't know whether he is a Stalinist. I think it is true that he has a record of being a very liberal person."
HERE is what Mr. Bloomberg did not say. He did not say that the tactics of Joseph McCarthy have no place in his campaign. Nor did he say that Mr. Cunningham did not speak for him, or that sometimes campaign advisers become carried away. He said nothing to signal disapproval of the Stalin tactic.
This raises questions about the kind of City Hall staff Mr. Bloomberg would build as mayor, whether he would appoint aides like Mr. Cunningham, a longtime political operative not known for subtlety. This summer he pushed, cursed and ejected a Daily News reporter from a forum because he objected to something the reporter had written. On another occasion he ripped information on Mr. Bloomberg's charitable donations from the hands of a reporter for The New York Observer.
Asked yesterday if he had second thoughts about his Stalin routine, which some political analysts saw as a sign of desperation, Mr. Cunningham said: "History is history. Stalin was a murderer, Stalin was a Communist, he wrote it," referring to Mr. Green.
Mr. Green showed annoyance when a reporter asked him yesterday if he was a Stalinist. "How do you answer that question?" he asked. "I'm also not a fleeing felon." 
But otherwise the job of handling the Cunningham charge has gone to a spokesman, Joseph DePlasco, who parried with a query about Mr. Bloomberg's company and whether it invested in South Africa before apartheid was fully dismantled (another matter of great relevance to running New York City).
Both candidates agree on what is most relevant -- the city 's recovery -- but not on how to achieve it, not even how to rebuild downtown. Mr. Green favors putting a new city-state authority in charge, and Mr. Bloomberg would rely on existing agencies.
Wonder what Stalin would say?

HEADLINE: Pataki Visits Washington, But Aid Plea Meets Doubt 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki of New York emerged from a meeting at the White House today and for the first time expressed doubts about the prospects of his $54 billion plan to help the state recover from last month's terrorist attack at the World Trade Center.
 Mr. Pataki said he had received no firm commitments during his meeting with Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director, and he appeared willing to scale back his request for federal aid. 
 "The bipartisan recognition of the unique impact this has had on New York has been very encouraging," the governor said during a news conference outside the White House. But he added: "That's not to say we're going to get everything we requested. We know that's not the way Washington or the world operates."
Several elements of the request Mr. Pataki delivered to Washington two weeks ago have been unofficially rejected by many leading lawmakers on the Hill. In particular, they pointed to extraneous items like a high-speed rail link to Schenectady, and seemed appalled by the fact that the plan did not account for insurance reimbursements that could offset billions of dollars in losses.
Today the governor acknowledged that that number could be reduced considerably, because insurance companies will have to pay for part of the cost of the reconstruction effort. "There could be 8, 10, 12, 15 billion dollars in private and other insurance to reduce that number," he said.
To clean up the devastation in Lower Manhattan and rebuild there, Mr. Pataki wanted about $34 billion, nearly twice what the White House and Congress set aside last month for exactly those purposes.
The governor's comments reflected the difficulty he has faced in securing additional aid beyond the $20 billion that Washington has already allocated to New York, Virginia and Pennsylvania.
Last night, Mr. Pataki's spokesman phoned reporters to stress that the governor had no intention of backing away from his plan, though he acknowledged that the overall figure could come down, depending on how much of the reconstruction was covered by insurance companies. The spokesman, Michael McKeon, also noted that the point of the governor's trip was to drum up support for the part of his plan that seeks about $20 billion in federal aid to stimulate the state's economy.
Just a few days ago, Mr. Daniels ruled out the possibility that the Bush administration would provide any more aid to New York this year.
Members of New York's Congressional delegation have been urging the governor to scale back his numbers, arguing that he runs the risk of undermining the credibility of legitimate aid requests. In fact, a prominent lawmaker said that throughout the day, at various meetings, Mr. Pataki was "met with polite disdain."
The governor met with Mr. Daniels, the White House budget director, and his staff for about a half hour in the afternoon, then arrived at the Capitol for a 45-minute session with William M. Thomas, a Republican from California who is the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. Members of the New York delegation also attended the meeting.
Mr. Thomas told Mr. Pataki to "refine" his federal aid request, according to people at the meeting. Afterward, Representative John Sweeney of New York said that Mr. Thomas had given a general commitment of support. "We made our case, and the chairman indicated an interest in being as helpful as he can be," Mr. Sweeney said.
Mr. Pataki went over to the Treasury Department for a meeting with Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, and met separately with Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, the chairman of the Finance Committee.
Mr. Pataki's aides insisted that he did not expect to come away from today's trip with any specific commitments of support. Instead, they said, the governor wanted to ensure that Washington's focus did not drift away from the devastation in New York, at a time when it was suddenly grappling with other pressing matters, like the war in Afghanistan.
"He wanted to make sure New York doesn't fall off the radar," one Pataki aide said.
The governor's plan also seeks about $20 billion to stimulate the economy. That includes $12 billion in additional federal aid to make up for lost tax revenues, a proposal that has met with some skepticism here, since the federal government has not compensated local governments for lost revenues in other disasters.
Today, Mr. Pataki seemed to be trying to address that skepticism when he pointed out that the state had taken steps to put its fiscal house in order by moving to cut spending by $3 billion over 18 months. "We're not just looking to Washington," he said.

HEADLINE: National Party Hasn't Clogged The Airways For Schundler 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Just two months ago, national Republicans seemed ready to spend substantial sums of money on advertising in the New Jersey governor's race, prompting fears and a lawsuit from Democrats.
 But with less than two weeks until Election Day, the Republican National Committee has yet to buy a single penny of major television or radio advertising, either in support of Bret D. Schundler, the party's nominee, or against his opponent, James E. McGreevey. 
 Mr. Schundler's aides and Republicans in Trenton and Washington are quick to note that the national party has committed more than $2 million for direct mailings and get-out-the-vote operations -- more than it has ever spent on a New Jersey governor's race. But the absence so far of major-media advertising by the national committee has surprised both Republicans and Democrats, who by contrast have spent heavily on advertising in recent weeks. 
Given that the New Jersey race is one of only two gubernatorial contests in the country this year, many Republicans said they were stunned by the lack of advertising, even as they expressed gratitude for the other spending by the national committee. 
"The only thing that I have heard from our side is just the basic grumbling about why they aren't doing more," one Republican strategist said. 
Democrats said they thought the Republican Party leadership was walking away from Mr. Schundler. 
"There is pretty clear evidence that even the R.N.C. has come to the conclusion that Schundler and his campaign have not caught fire with the electorate in New Jersey," said Steve DeMicco, Mr. McGreevey's campaign director. 
National Republicans have been slow to rally to Mr. Schundler's side in other ways. Former Gov. Christie Whitman campaigned for Mr. Schundler tonight in New Jersey for the first time since he won the Republican nomination in June. Mrs. Whitman attended a women's rally in Parsippany.
And it is unclear if President Bush, who has voiced support for Mr. Schundler, will visit New Jersey to campaign with him because of the conflict overseas. 
Privately, many New Jersey Republicans say they have their fingers crossed both for a visit by President Bush and for a blitz of spending on advertising in the campaign's final days. Officials at the Republican National Committee declined to indicate what their plans were. 
"The R.N.C. has already committed over $2 million to a get-out-the-vote program for the elections in New Jersey," said Trent Duffy, a spokesman. "That's the starting point for the R.N.C.'s support."
Even if the Republicans decide to make a huge advertising push, it is unclear whether they will find available broadcast time, especially in New York, where there is a highly competitive mayor's race and where the World Series is about to start. 
Mr. Schundler's aides said they were not counting on help from Washington but would welcome it. "Would I love for the R.N.C. to come in and spend $2 million over the next 13 days?" said Bill Pascoe, Mr. Schundler's campaign manager. "Of course I would. But because that's an independent expenditure, something that's beyond our ability to ask for or control, that has never been a part of our winning strategy."
In August, the Republican Party seemed poised to inject a lot of money into the New Jersey race. The party sought guidance from the state's Election Law Enforcement Commission, which ruled that the national party could spend as much as it wanted on behalf of Mr. Schundler so long as it made "independent expenditures" not coordinated with the Schundler campaign. 
In response, the McGreevey campaign filed a lawsuit arguing that it was impossible for the national party to be independent of the Schundler campaign. 
The lawsuit was dismissed by Judge Arthur N. D'Italia of State Superior Court in Hudson County because the national Republicans had not spent any money on the race. Lawyers involved in the case said they had expected to be back in court on the matter, but so far there have been no expenditures by the national Republicans worth fighting over. 
Officials at Republican national headquarters said that they had, in fact, made some independent expenditures in the New Jersey race and that the expenses would be detailed in a report to state election officials due on Friday. Democratic strategists said the only expenditures they had seen by the national Republicans were large mailings of absentee ballots and an abbreviated purchase of radio advertising in Atlantic City several weeks ago. 
By contrast, the Democratic National Committee is expected to spend more than $3 million on Mr. McGreevey's behalf by the time the race is over, Democrats said. 
At the rally tonight, Mrs. Whitman, who is now the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, addressed a rollicking crowd of about 500 Republicans, most of them women.
"Unless we want to return to the days of high unemployment, high taxes and high anxiety," she said, "we need to make very sure that Bret Schundler is the next governor of New Jersey."
Mrs. Whitman was introduced by Mr. Schundler's wife, Lynn, and gave him a warm introduction as New Jersey's next governor. There was no mention of their past differences, including Mrs. Whitman's criticism over the summer of Mr. Schundler's positions on abortion and gun control.

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
As Time Runs Low, Bloomberg Runs Rough

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Hemmed in by an unusually brief campaign season and his own lack of experience in politics, Michael R. Bloomberg is encountering repeated difficulties as he moves into the final phase of his mayoral campaign, struggling to engage an increasingly confident and politically aloof Mark Green.
 In the course of a week, Mr. Bloomberg has tried three separate attacks against his Democratic opponent, at a time when aides to both candidates say their private polls show Mr. Green with a substantial lead. Mr. Bloomberg's campaign has been diverted by distractions arguably of its own making, most recently when it struggled to reconcile conflicting explanations from the candidate and his aides about his business dealings in South Africa. And he continues to be less than sure-footed as he travels the city, in a way that has stirred concern among some fellow Republicans because media attention to his campaign has been increasing in recent days. 
 At a news conference yesterday in which Mr. Bloomberg was endorsed by Gov. George E. Pataki, Mr. Bloomberg first criticized Mr. Green for being too liberal, and then a moment later responded to a question by declaring, "I am a liberal, yes." 
Mr. Pataki -- a self-described doctrinaire conservative who defeated Mario M. Cuomo in 1993 by hammering him as a "liberal" -- stared in astonishment into space.
The perception that Mr. Bloomberg is having trouble has encouraged Mr. Green to make his own strategic change over the past few days. He has returned to the unadventurous campaign course he followed for most of the primary season, offering either familiar or uncontroversial campaign proposals while trying to avoid the last-minute mistakes that might turn what he sees as the tide of an election breaking his way. 
If there are any attacks to be made, they will be pressed mainly by surrogates, as when he dispatched William J. Bratton, the former police commissioner, to go after Mr. Bloomberg's public safety credentials. And after a primary campaign in which he boasted about the number of times he had shared a stage with his Democratic rivals, Mr. Green has agreed to only two debates with Mr. Bloomberg.
At a news conference at Union Square Park yesterday, Mr. Green listened patiently as reporters pressed him to respond to a charge by Mr. Bloomberg's senior aide that he was a Stalin apologist, and another by Mr. Bloomberg that Mr. Green had played the "race card" by raising the issue of apartheid. 
"I don't really have to respond to him," Mr. Green said. "Today I am focused on the three large goals of rebuilding the economy, enhancing security and educating our children."
Mr. Bloomberg's advisers contend that he is presenting a strong case against Mr. Green, particularly in television advertisements, and that these episodes are not a meaningful distraction from his candidacy. A number of polls suggest that support for Mr. Green is not particularly deep, meaning that a hard-hitting week of TV ads could turn the tables.
Nonetheless, some Republicans expressed distress at the way Mr. Bloomberg's campaign has progressed recently. They said it underlined their concern that Mr. Bloomberg today, like Rudolph W. Giuliani the first time he ran for mayor, was not prepared for the peculiar difficulties that come with running for office in New York. And some Republicans said they were starting to worry about his prospects.
"It's the syndrome of a first-time candidate," said Nelson Warfield, a conservative Republican consultant with ties to New York, "and it's the syndrome of a candidate who before the race really didn't have any political beliefs. What he should do is stay inside the edit suite where the people are putting together the ads so they can change what he says before people hear him."
As it is, Mr. Bloomberg faces difficulty in trying to win an election in a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans by better than five to one. His task is complicated by the fact that he has less than three weeks to make his case against Mr. Green, in a general election season cut short because the Sept. 11 terrorist attack in New York forced a two-week delay in the primaries. And he is competing for attention with world events, not to mention the prospect of the Yankees' winning the World Series again.
The shorter campaign season means that Mr. Bloomberg has less time to turn public discussion away from unwelcome subjects -- like apartheid and Stalin -- to issues that seem more likely to hold sway with New York voters.
It also means that he has less time to find an effective message against Mr. Green. As a rule, in politics, candidates try to figure out their most effective line of attack and stick to it.
Mr. Bloomberg's initial argument against Mr. Green was that New York needed a business leader rather than a professional politician to guide it through the tough years ahead. Then he sought to undercut Mr. Green's support among black and Hispanic voters by contending that he had run a racially divisive primary campaign against Fernando Ferrer. Yesterday, he moved to attack Mr. Green as too liberal for New York. 
Mr. Bloomberg has hired some of the most experienced political professionals in the country, led by David Garth, a longtime expert in New York politics. (Mr. Garth has not returned telephone calls in recent days seeking comment about the state of his client's campaign.)
But for all that expertise, he has encountered logistical difficulties that are typical of less experienced campaigns. And he has found himself overshadowed by his own senior adviser, William Cunningham.
At a breakfast of business and civic leaders sponsored by Crain's, where Mr. Green was speaking earlier this week, Mr. Cunningham showed up and paced back and forth along the wall, staring intensely at Mr. Green. When Mr. Green jocularly said he did not want to do anything that might make him "look arrogant," Mr. Cunningham said loudly from across the hall, "Too late."
And it was Mr. Cunningham who suggested, based on an academic and generally unremarkable passage Mr. Green wrote about 20 years ago regarding Stalin's rule, that the Democratic candidate was sympathetic to Stalin. While many of Mr. Bloomberg's other advisers dismissed Mr. Cunningham's remark as absurd, it was potentially problematic for Mr. Bloomberg because, given its hyperbole, the remark made it harder for him to get his point across: that Mr. Green was too liberal to be mayor of New York.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE DISEASE; 
MORE CHECKED FOR ANTHRAX; U.S. OFFICIALS ACKNOWLEDGE UNDERESTIMATING MAIL RISKS

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Health officials here monitored increasing numbers of people for suspected anthrax today while John E. Potter, the postmaster general, acknowledged that he could not guarantee the safety of the mails. President Bush warned that the nation was "still under attack."
 Their statements reflected the growing sense that government officials had badly underestimated the threat posed by the anthrax contained in a handful of letters sent to Congress and news organizations in recent weeks. Two postal workers in Washington have died and at least two others have been infected. 
 Dr. David Satcher, the surgeon general, said that in hindsight, "we were wrong" not to have considered that a sealed envelope containing anthrax might pose a hazard as it passed through a post office. 
Officials are particularly concerned about the letter sent to the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota. Several top scientists said today that the powdery anthrax found in that letter was advanced and highly dangerous, contradicting officials who had suggested over the past week that the substance was relatively primitive.
In particular, the scientists said that it had been altered to reduce its electrostatic charge, making the spores less likely to clump together and more likely to float in the air. One expert said that only the United States, the Soviet Union, and Iraq were known to have developed the necessary technique to do this. Page B6. 
A government official said it was now clear that the envelope sent to Mr. Daschle was porous enough, and the spores inside small enough, that germs could have leaked out even though it was taped shut.
Health officials here and in New Jersey said they were investigating at least a dozen cases of possible inhaled anthrax, including at least one person linked to the Senate, in addition to the two confirmed cases and two deaths among postal workers here. Officials said another 20 people in the Washington area who might have been exposed to anthrax were being monitored.
But as a precaution, health officials expanded their recommendation for immediate antibiotic treatment to include all workers in 120 institutions that receive bulk mail, including the Library of Congress. The decision was based on concern that such mail might have been contaminated at the district's main processing center on Brentwood Road, which handled the Daschle letter.
Another suspected anthrax case was reported in New York. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said a second employee of The New York Post had probably contracted an anthrax infection of the skin. Page B7. 
It was another unsettling day as the government's top officials grappled with an insidious and invisible enemy. Despite a sprawling investigation, law enforcement officials said they now believed that additional anthrax attacks were a certainty.
Addressing the U.S. conference of Mayors, the F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said the anthrax attacks "were clearly meant to terrorize a country already on the edge."
Mr. Mueller was the first official to link the anthrax attacks with a warning of more expected terrorism issued by the F.B.I. on Oct. 11. 
Mr. Bush, in remarks at a Maryland printing plant to promote his economic stimulus package, repeated that he had no direct evidence connecting anthrax to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, but said, "There are some links."
"Both series of actions are motivated by evil and hate," Mr. Bush said. "Both series of actions are meant to disrupt Americans' way of life. Both series of actions are an attack on our homeland. And both series of actions will not stand."
Moving to grant new powers to law enforcement, the House of Representatives today passed a compromise version of comprehensive anti-terrorism legislation sought by the administration. Senate passage is expected as soon as Thursday. The measure would grant stepped surveillance and detention powers and crack down on money laundering. 
Inhalation anthrax has been diagnosed in six people nationwide this month, including the four postal workers here and two employees at American Media Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla. One of those in Florida, Robert Stevens, a photo editor, died on Oct. 5, but the other, Ernesto Blanco, 73, a mailroom worker, was released from the hospital late Tuesday, officials announced today.
Seven people, most of them employees of New York news outlets, have less threatening form of skin anthrax and are responding to treatment or have been cured.
A news employee who covers the Senate is among six people who have been admitted to Holy Cross Hospital in suburban Silver Spring, Md., for possible anthrax exposure, a Congressional official said today. The woman, who was not named, works for an electronic news organization, the official said. She is the first person to be hospitalized with a suspected anthrax case from exposure in the Hart Senate Office Building, where the Daschle letter was opened.
Though hundreds of workers have been tested, officials here and in New Jersey reported no new confirmed cases of either form of the disease today, but they offered new details on several patients hospitalized with suspicious, flulike symptoms.
A 2-year-old girl and an 11-year-old boy were admitted on Tuesday to Children's National Medical Center in Washington with "possible exposure to anthrax," and were in good condition, the hospital said.
With demand for antibiotics growing, Tommy G. Thompson, secretary of Health and Human Services, announced an agreement with Bayer A.G. to buy 100 million doses of its patented drug Cipro at the sharply reduced price of 95 cents each. 
In morning television appearances, Mr. Potter, the top postal official, said that risks from opening the mail were slim, but acknowledged that the mail's safety could not be guaranteed. "The chances are very, very slim, but, again, people should do things that are safe, and when they handle mail, they should wash their hands," he said.
Officials said the Postal Service, whose 800,000 workers make it the nation's second-largest private employer after Wal-Mart, was in the process of ordering new machinery that can irradiate mail to remove contaminants, in the same way food is treated.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is expected on Thursday to issue recommendations for protecting mail handlers. Among them will be the installation of HEPA filters and exhaust hoods for high-speed mail-handling equipment.
Increasingly, investigators said, they were finding evidence that the anthrax in the letter to Mr. Daschle, the Senate majority leader, had spread through machines. They said it left a trail of spores as it sped through automated sorters in the Brentwood station, and tests consistently found anthrax spores along the precise path taken by the Daschle letter and others bound for the same ZIP code.
In an appearance on NBC's "Today" program this morning, Dr. Satcher, the surgeon general, said experts had never expected that an unopened envelope passing through a post office could expose workers to anthrax. "Until a week ago, I think all of the experts would have said "no," he said. "The fact of the matter is, we were wrong, because we haven't been here before." 
On Capitol Hill, the Russell Senate Office Building, one of three Senate offices shut last week for environmental testing, reopened today, but the others, including the Hart building, remained closed. A new spot in the Hart building tested positive for anthrax today, police investigators said. 
All three House office buildings remained closed because tests were incomplete. But Capitol police said tonight that the Rayburn House Office building and garage and Cannon House Office building would be opened on Thursday.
At the White House, preliminary anthrax tests on some 120 mail sorting workers found no exposure to anthrax. Trace amounts of the bacteria were found in a remote mail screening outpost at Bolling Air Force Base, a few miles from the White House, on Tuesday, and though officials said they were confident no tainted mail reached the White House complex itself, a total of 200 workers who might have had contact with the mail were being treated with antibiotics protectively.

HEADLINE: Bill That Expands Gambling Is Approved by Legislature 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: ALBANY, Thursday, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
The State Legislature approved the largest expansion of gambling in state history early this morning after an impassioned debate, laying the groundwork for six Indian casinos in the Catskills and western New York. The State Senate voted 52 to 8 late Wednesday to approve a bill authorizing the six new Indian-run casinos, the inclusion of New York in the multistate Powerball lottery and the installation of video slot machines at horse tracks. After midnight the Assembly gave final approval to the bill, voting 93 to 40 in favor.
 Proponents say the gambling measures are expected to bring in as much as $1 billion in new revenue to the state within three years. They gained support in the Legislature after it became clear the Sept. 11 terror attack would severely curb state revenues. Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno argued on the floor that the state could no longer afford to let New York's gamblers spend millions in neighboring states and Canada. 
 "We are looking for revenue sources," he said. "Those dollars now are going into Canada, supporting education, into Connecticut, into New Jersey, not into New York."
As the Legislature wrestled with the gambling bill Wednesday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver feuded over the depth of Albany's commitment to New York City, touching on the lack of a casino for New York.
Mr. Giuliani complained that the final budget deal that legislative leaders had negotiated with Gov. George E. Pataki shortchanged the city on school aid and robbed it of $134 million in other subsidies. He also charged that the agreement between the Assembly's ruling Democrats and the Republican governor to allow three of the casinos in the Catskills and three in Western New York would further sap the city.
"The guy who we have to have in there fighting for us like a tiger is Shelly Silver, and he is nothing like a tiger," said Mr. Giuliani, a Republican. Mr. Silver, a Democrat, and the mayor have recently been at odds, with the speaker saying he would oppose extending Mr. Giuliani's term.
Mr. Silver, who had been seeking Wednesday morning to expand the Lower Manhattan zone that would get funds for rebuilding, said that Mr. Giuliani should lay the blame for the budget on his own party's leaders, the governor and the Senator Bruno.
"It's unfortunate he's being political in his waning days as mayor," Mr. Silver said. "He ignores the fact that George Pataki put forth the proposals."
The gambling measures were included in a bill putting in place a final budget agreement for the fiscal year ending in April. The agreement provides for about $500 million in new spending in an $84 billion budget for school aid, charity-run social programs and seed money for new industries. But the pact did not appropriate about $150 million for buying parkland and protecting the environment.
Environmentalists complained the Legislature's failure to reach an agreement with Mr. Pataki on how to spend $150 million in the Environmental Protection Fund meant a host of programs would not be financed until next year, among them recycling, landfill closures and parkland acquisition.
The two bills containing the gambling and budget measures were not printed and distributed to lawmakers until 7:40 p.m., minutes before debate began in the Senate. They contained several other provisions, like an extension of health benefits for indigent children, making them difficult to oppose.
While proponents of the bills said the terrorist attacks made it necessary to seek new revenues, opponents said gambling amounted to a tax on the poor and was a cowardly way to address a budget shortfall. They also complained the deal had been negotiated by the legislative leaders and the governor behind closed doors.
"I can't believe we are doing this here tonight, and to make it even worse, we are using the guise of the terrible tragedy of the terrorist attacks on New York to make New York one of the biggest gambling states in the nation," Senator Thomas K. Duane, a Manhattan Democrat, said Wednesday. 
But Senator Bruno and other proponents said the damage had already being done to New York society by casinos in neighboring states without the government benefiting. They pointed out gamblers voluntarily risk their money. "No one drags them," Senator Bruno said.
Many of the same arguments were made on the floor of the Assembly, with most of the speakers rising to vote no. Arthur O. Eve, a Buffalo Democrat, said he believed a planned casino in that city would further impoverish already poor neighborhoods. Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat, called the casinos "economic sponges" that would provide no boost to the economy. Other opponents said the governor's plan to install Indian-run casinos amounted to a blatant attempt to circumvent the state Constitution's ban on gambling and slot machines.
"What we are attempting to do is an end-run on the constitution," Assemblyman William Parment of Jamestown said.
As the bills were distributed, new details of the budget deal emerged. Of the $200 million in additional operating aid for schools, about $52.5 million will go to increase teacher salaries, $20 million will be spent on training teachers and $11 million for educating bilingual children.
The additions also include about $100 million for economic development, including $10 million in grants and $6 million worth of state-subsidized electricity to help businesses in the area devastated by the trade center. The governor has called the area the Liberty Zone and is seeking tax incentives from Congress to encourage businesses to remain there. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: State senators and an aide awaited the gambling bill text yesterday. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Leader's Aide In Chechnya Calls to Offer Peace Talks 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
A top aide to the political leader of Chechnya's separatist guerrillas proposed opening talks with the Kremlin on disarming the rebels and ending their two-year-old war, President Vladimir V. Putin's envoy to southwestern Russia said today. 
 The envoy, Viktor G. Kazantsev, said he received the offer by telephone this morning from an aide to President Aslan Maskhadov, who is in hiding. Mr. Kazantsev said in a television interview that the proposal had arrived without conditions and that he expected discussions to be held in Moscow in 10 days. 
 The offer could represent the first significant move toward peace since the war began in August 1999. It is one of several hopeful developments that appeared to spring from the Russian-American alliance that has grown since the attacks on Sept. 11. 
Mr. Putin's aide and chief spokesman on Chechnya, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, appeared later to scorn the proposal. He said discussions with Mr. Maskhadov's government did not rise to the level of a dialogue between the warring sides.
"Those who are hiding in mountains and forests are not in power in Chechnya," Mr. Yastrzhembsky was quoted as saying by the Interfax news service. 
Mr. Maskhadov was elected president of a quasi-independent republic of Chechnya in 1997 and was recognized by President Boris N. Yeltsin, who received him in the Kremlin. Under Mr. Putin, the Kremlin has insisted that Mr. Maskhadov is a figurehead in a war controlled by Islamic extremists and that his republic does not exist. 
That rebuff notwithstanding, Mr. Maskhadov's offer to talk joins a list of recent, if small, developments that together suggest that something more substantial is afoot in the conflict. 
Mr. Putin has long argued that Islamic outsiders exploited the semi-independent status given the breakaway Chechen province in the 1990's, in a drive to create a new extremist state on the model of Afghanistan. Until this fall, however, American officials have focused less on Islamic extremists than on Russia's brutal campaign to subdue Chechen guerrillas, an effort widely condemned by human-rights advocates and the West. As recently as March, the foreign minister of the Chechen republic was allowed to meet officials at the State Department.
United States officials continue to raise concerns about human-rights abuses in Chechnya. But since Sept. 11, they have also publicly begun to endorse Mr. Putin's view of Chechnya as a terrorists' refuge. In recent weeks, the United States is known to have privately sent Mr. Maskhadov a blunt message to renounce the extremists who have seized control of the rebellion and, Russia alleges, his political structure, or face American isolation as well.
Mr. Putin has appeared to soften, ever so slightly, his hard-line military and propaganda campaign against the separatists and Chechnya's beleaguered civilian population. In a nationally broadcast speech a month ago, when he committed Russia to a global antiterrorism coalition, Mr. Putin also issued an oblique demand, that within 72 hours separatists "and those who call themselves political figures" sever all ties to terrorists and contact Moscow to discuss disarming and returning to civilian life.
Although the Kremlin denied it, many saw the statement as a veiled invitation to begin talks on a political solution to the war. Mr. Maskhadov now appears to have accepted that offer.
In an interview today with the NTV television network, Mr. Maskhadov's aide, Akhmed Zakayev, said disarmament, the return of perhaps 150,000 war refugees from neighboring Ingushetia, a cease-fire and "economic issues" should be discussed at the talks.
In an interview today, a spokesman for Mr. Putin's envoy to southwestern Russia, Maksim Fedorenko, said the request for talks showed that "sober thinking tendencies" had gained the upper hand among Mr. Maskhadov's political supporters. Mr. Fedorenko said, however, that disarmament was the only issue on the table at the discussions. 
"The meeting will supposedly take place in a few days," he said. "And maybe then we'll learn more."
For its part, the Kremlin has recently begun addressing basic human-rights concerns about the conduct of Russian troops in Chechnya. The army suspended a number of officers in Chechnya this month after surveillance of 60 checkpoints on roadways found widespread extortion and abuse of civilians, a ubiquitous -- and long ignored -- complaint.
Last week, the military appointed a new commander for its forces in Chechnya, Gen. Vladimir Moltenskoi, who drew praise as someone "who strictly follows the letter and spirit of the law" from the head of the pro-Russian Chechen regional government.

HEADLINE: Bush Advisers Press for Help For Insurers 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
President Bush's senior economic advisers told lawmakers today that the nation would face an economic crisis if Congress failed to quickly guard the insurance industry against losses from any future terrorist attacks. But the administration's proposal, which would have the government pay at least 80 percent of any claims next year, ran into a storm of criticism from both Democrats and Republicans.
 Opening a series of hearings in the House and Senate on an assistance package for the insurers, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill and R. Glenn Hubbard, the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, warned of dire economic consequences if the government did not intervene. They said that construction, manufacturing and other projects in such industries as energy and transportation would grind to a halt as bankers and other lenders around the country stopped offering loans or raised their rates because insurers were unwilling to renew their coverage for terrorist attacks. 
 "We're facing a cliff," Mr. O'Neill said in testimony before the Senate banking committee, and largely repeated later in the day before a House subcommittee. "The administration believes the economy is facing a temporary, but critical, market problem in the provision of terrorism risk insurance. Keeping our economy moving must be our overriding concern. Leaving this problem unresolved threatens our economic stability."
"From our conversations with insurance company representatives, state insurance regulators, policyholders, banks and other entities which provide financing for property transactions, the next two months are critical," he added, asserting that the reduction in insurance coverage "has the potential to cause severe economic dislocations in the near-term either through higher insurance costs or higher financing costs."
While a clear consensus emerged today among senior lawmakers that Congress must do something in the few remaining weeks of the legislative session, there was widespread disagreement about how to proceed. Moreover, Mr. O'Neill conceded that the cost-sharing formulas advanced by the administration's proposal might not work, and therefore Congress should consider giving the White House the authority to adjust the figures without seeking new legislation.
The urgency of the situation could be seen in big and small ways today at the hastily convened hearings, which had to be held in the basement of the Capitol building because many Congressional offices remain closed to cleanse them of possible anthrax problems. The House proceeding was in such a cramped room that the treasury secretary shucked some of the formal niceties of typical hearings and testified in his shirt-sleeves. Many of his questioners were similarly informal.
But they did not temper their skepticism of the central details of the administration's plan, under which the government would pay at least 80 percent of the claims from the first dollar of losses in 2002. The plan also limits the industry's total liability for damages from any future terrorist attacks at $12 billion next year, $23 billion in 2003 and $36 billion in 2004.
Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Hubbard said that the formulas were designed to encourage the insurers to offer coverage at reasonable rates, but many lawmakers said they would never pass a measure that did not force the industry to bear the initial financial burdens of any future attacks.
"I think politically the members would feel more comfortable if the first dollar lost is private and the federal government serves more as a backstop," said Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, the ranking Republican on the banking committee. He and others said it would be far more palatable if Congress began the program with the contribution formula proposed by the administration for 2003, in which the industry would have to pay the first $10 billion in claims before the government stepped in.
"I have strong concerns about requiring the taxpayers to assume, even on a temporary basis, such a large percentage of the cost -- especially on the front end," said Senator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida, and a former state insurance commissioner. "A more responsible approach, in my view, would be to require the companies to cover terrorist-related losses up to a certain level before any federal help would kick in. The industry is flush right now with huge surpluses. Whatever our solution to this aspect of the terrorist crisis, we must require insurers to pay their fair share."
Other lawmakers were critical of the administration for offering to help the insurance industry and bailing out the airline industry, but doing nothing for many other industries and labor groups pleading for help in the wake of growing losses and layoffs.
"There is a growing danger that we are responding to this crisis and challenge in an unbalanced and inequitable way," Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who heads the Senate banking committee, sternly warned Mr. Hubbard. "The administration has to give careful thought to having a more balanced response so that there is a sense in this country that it is more equitable."
There was also widespread criticism of what some lawmakers said was basically socializing the costs of future attacks while privatizing the profits should there be no further attacks.
"I have a real problem with the federal government basically guaranteeing profits for the insurance industry," said Senator Jim Bunning, Republican of Kentucky. "You are basically guaranteeing that insurers will not lose over a certain amount."
Some House Republicans agreed.
"The administration's proposal is reminiscent of some of the government-sponspored enterprises," like the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, said Representative Richard H. Baker, Republican of Louisiana, who heads the Financial Services Subcommittee on Capital Markets, Insurance and Government Sponsored Enterprises. "If you lose money, you get a partner. If you make money, you get to keep it."
Still others raised questions about how the federal government, which has no oversight role over the insurance industry, could supervise an assistance package without imposing new federal regulations on the insurers. Some lawmakers have said privately that a system that relies on federal assistance for state regulated industry was eerily reminiscent of the savings and loan bailout a decade ago.
"If the federal government puts its toe in the water, we have got to make sure we have all of the appropriate federal safeguards," said Representative John J. LaFalce, Democrat of New York.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: WHITE HOUSE MEMO; 
Home Front Is a Minefield For President

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER and DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
When President Bush's helicopter touched down on the South Lawn of the White House in the early hours Monday, the president emerged fresh from solid victories abroad: He had cemented Russia as an enthusiastic partner in the war on terrorism, neutralized China's objections, and, by remote control from his hotel room, overseen the first operation involving ground troops in Afghanistan.
 If only things were so organized at home. 
 In his first 72 hours back, Mr. Bush discovered that the more complex and immediately dangerous front is here in what the White House calls "the homeland." As the president said in a speech today in suburban Baltimore, "It's something that, obviously, we're not used to in America." 
Perhaps for that very reason, the administration's response to the spreading threat of anthrax has been seen by even its supporters as ragged and confused. Officials have contradicted each other in competing press conferences. While the Pentagon seems to be anticipating how the Taliban will move from cave to cave, the White House seems less certain how toxic mail might move from building to building. 
Today, White House officials conceded that while the remote facility that receives all the mail addressed to 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue has been on "high alert" for bombs and chemical and biological threats since Sept. 11, no one notified the Postal Service's Brentwood facility -- where the same mail is first sorted -- to be on a similar alert. 
"The lesson we're learning," one administration official said today, "is that you can bomb the wrong place in Afghanistan and not take much heat for it. But don't mess up at the post office."
Today Mr. Bush was stretched across the war's two fronts. He spent hours in intelligence, F.B.I. and national security briefings, and had a session with the Joint Chiefs of Staff about the size and composition of America's arsenal of nuclear weapons. Then he flew to suburban Baltimore to promote his economic stimulus package.
Back in Washington, there were more reports of anthrax, and nothing seemed entirely under control.
The administration has come under intense criticism for not testing postal workers at the Brentwood facility -- which handles mail for Congress, the White House and much of residential Washington -- even while it was clearing Congressional office buildings and offering Cipro to hundreds on Capitol Hill. At least four employees at Brentwood have contracted anthrax, and two have died. 
And the White House abruptly reversed itself this week on Bayer A.G., the German pharmaceutical giant that makes Cipro, the anthrax antibiotic. Last week Tommy G. Thompson, the health and human services secretary, said it was illegal to break Bayer's patent to allow other companies to make generic versions. By Tuesday he was threatening to do exactly that, and he ultimately forced Bayer to sell the drug at about half the price it sought.
At the same time, the administration continues to send conflicting messages about how worried the public should be.
John E. Potter, the postmaster general, said this morning that he could not guarantee the safety of items delivered in the mail. But Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, said only hours later that the mail was "overwhelmingly presumed to be safe." By midafternoon, Mr. Fleischer had a slightly more refined riff. "People should feel safe opening their mail," he said. "People should also be alert as they proceed as they open their mail."
If the war at home seems more fumbling and disorganized than the war in Afghanistan, there may be a simple explanation: Americans are watching each anthrax case live on television, where every contradictory story and bureaucratic misstep is on display, while they are getting the Pentagon's sanitized version of the unseen battles half a world away.
It is hardly as if the air war in Afghanistan has been error-free. In the 18 days since the bombing started, American forces have mistakenly hit a residential area in Kabul, damaged a military hospital or a senior citizens' home (the United Nations and the Pentagon disagree) in Herat and a United Nations demining center, killing several employees. Yet the criticism has been relatively minor, especially compared with the reaction after civilians were killed in the bombing of a bunker in Baghdad in the Persian Gulf war. 
Why the difference? "We've been lucky that civilian casualties have been light," one senior administration official said today. But the White House has also been lucky that there are virtually no reporters or even independent observers in the Taliban-controlled sections of Afghanistan. That means no pictures of wounded or dead children, and it means the Pentagon's account of events trumps the Taliban's. 
The Pentagon has also thought out its public relations strategy. Briefings are often done by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, who sounds confident if curt, and the new chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Richard B. Myers, who inspires confidence because of his long experience in the Air Force and good relations with the press.
Of course, all this could change quickly. A major mistake in bombing, the loss of a large number of American ground troops, a failure to find Taliban leaders or Osama bin Laden could all turn public opinion.
But for now, Americans seem far more concerned about their mail and their paychecks than the grainy war videos released by the Pentagon.
At moments, so does the president. Mr. Bush has long told aides that he will not repeat the mistake his father made: neglecting the domestic economy during the gulf war, which contributed to his father's defeat in 1992.
So today, in a speech to employees of a box-making plant in Glen Burnie, Md., Mr. Bush said: "Some might ask why, in the midst of war, I would come to Dixie Printing. 
"And the answer is because we fight in the war on two fronts. We fight a war at home, and part of the war we fight is to make sure that our economy continues to grow."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush yesterday with Wendy Wilson, a worker at Dixie Printing and Packaging in Glen Burnie, Md., after a speech on his economic plan. (J. Scott Applewhite/Associated Press)(pg. B8)

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 Warnings and Precautions

UNDER ATTACK -- The postmaster general acknowledged that he could not guarantee the safety of the mail, and President Bush warned that the nation was "still under attack." Their statements reflected a growing sense that government officials had underestimated the threat posed by the anthrax contained in a handful of letters sent to Congress and news organizations. A1

MAIL PROTECTION -- The Postal Service plans to install devices in some threatened sites that would use powerful beams of electrons to kill anthrax and other deadly organisms in sacks of mail. B5

The Biological Threat

POWERFUL STRAIN -- Scientists in and out of government said that the anthrax attack on Capitol Hill involved an advanced powder that is quite dangerous and not relatively innocuous, as others have said. B6

The Federal Response
