HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Brazil in All Its Extravagant Glory

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
FOR the Guggenheim's "Brazil: Body and Soul," the French architect Jean Nouvel has painted the rotunda black and turned off almost all the lights except for spotlights on the art and a projection on the ceiling to suggest a canopy of leaves, as if in a rain forest. 
 Half the rotunda is occupied by an immense altar, in gold, made in the 1780's, rising almost to the top of the building. From Sao Bento de Olinda, the altar's arrival was delayed by legal problems in Brazil apropos of Sept. 11, and now the museum will need several weeks to assemble it. When you see the show you find workers, some of them hanging from scaffolding 40 feet in the air, fitting pieces of the altar together. 
 There's more, of course. Videos of Brazil and Brazilian films are in the stairwells, while the top of the rotunda, devoted to modern Brazilian art, is all-white, the light from this part of the museum shielded by wavy black baffles that nod (one of Mr. Nouvel's smarter touches) to the architecture of the Brazilian modernist Oscar Niemeyer, or so it seems. 
The upshot: part 1970's nightclub, part trade fair, part boutique, part construction site. Mr. Nouvel's installation is not especially friendly to people who have trouble seeing in the dark, not to mention that the installation, like earlier transformations of the Guggenheim by famous architects, vies with the art it ostensibly caters to.
But what can I say? It's aptly over the top considering the show is about a culture gloriously, self-consciously excessive, and you would be missing something if you didn't see it, which in the end is almost all any museum can ask of its exhibition designer. 
In this respect and others, "Body and Soul" conforms to previous Guggenheim extravaganzas, each having provoked detractors who see in the director Thomas Krens's museum the end of civilization as we know it. Civilization, however, should survive this show, too, which could also cause people to become intrigued by Brazil, people who had not thought much about it before. Inspiring interest seems the bottom line of an exhibition's success.
Organized by Edward J. Sullivan, who oversaw the curatorial team that produced an accompanying six-pound catalog (a Guggenheim standard by now), the show doesn't pretend to be a comprehensive survey of Brazilian art. It's more of a phenomenal sampler, glamorously packaged, concentrating on the Brazilian Baroque, which here encompasses the 17th century through the early 19th century, and on the modern era.
Portugal colonized Brazil, then brought slaves from Africa. The Dutch came, too. So European, indigenous and African sources mixed. That mixture, diversely manifested, produced an amazing melting-pot vivacity.
The 20th century brought a fresh influx of foreign ideas, again melded to local interests. Artists like Tarsila do Amaral went to Paris in the 1920's and translated the forms of Leger and Andre Lhote into a language distinct to Brazil.
This transformation of Cubism and Futurism evolved eventually into an original brand of performance and conceptual art, always with ties to the past.
You can see these connections between early and later eras throughout the exhibition. Religious processions and Carnival became sources for innovators like Lygia Clark and Helio Oiticica, shamans of Brazilian postwar art, and for contemporaries like Ernesto Neto, whose work invites audience participation, too.
Physicality, spectacle, eroticism married to spirituality, and excess: these cliches of Brazilian culture are all present in the exhibition. 
Did I mention that many of the objects are stunning to look at? Mr. Nouvel's idea to put Baroque art in a dark space is counter-intuitive, the art being about light. But it is also about theater, which is conveyed by the theatricality of these works as they are picked out of the darkness by spotlights.
I am referring to sculptures more than to paintings. Painting wasn't a medium that inspired Brazilian artists the way sculpture did, although Brazil inspired European painters who traveled there. Fortunately, the Guggenheim will be getting from Copenhagen (the loan has been delayed) several of the Dutch artist Albert Eckhout's enormous ethnographic portraits and still lifes, painted in Brazil during the 17th century. They should improve the argument for the medium.
As for what came: indigenous works, like feathered masks and crowns in multicolored configurations, are inanimate behind glass, despite having been conceived to be objects in motion on the people who wore them. But even out of context they are amazing to see.
So are the Afro-Brazilian totems by Agnaldo Manoel dos Santos: black polished figures, bullet-shaped and perfectly smooth, from the 1950's.
Ex-votos, wood heads, hands, breasts, hearts and stomachs, made as offerings for healing miracles, are further evidence of popular craft, as are the ships' figureheads, enormous carved animals, mostly lions, the big surprise in the exhibition. 
Most stupendous, of course, is the altar, which if you are a cynic is a stunt of exhibition planning, but which also makes an important point about scale. Size counts in Brazil, not least because many of the sculptures in the show come from churches whose size and complexity are integral to the art but hard to convey. The altar provides a context.
These sculptures dominate the exhibition, by sheer number: a polychromed wood Christ, all lightness and elegance, by Frei Domingos da Conceicao e Silva; Christ bloodied, in different gory versions by various anonymous carvers; a black St. Elesbao, resplendently decorated and clunky, also by an anonymous artist; a stiff St. Francis receiving the stigmata from an even stiffer Christ, improbably sweet; and processional figures, meaning figures made to be carried in religious processions, that are folk mannequins, painted wood objects of hypnotic weirdness. 
Then come the works by the most famous sculptor of the Brazilian Baroque, Aleijadinho, the Little Cripple. Antonio Francisco Lisboa's unidentified malady, or so the story goes, compelled him to carve with tools strapped to his arms. To him is attributed, among various works, a St. George, extravagantly decorated, deeply sincere, whose innocence brings to mind a giant Christmas creche figure or toy soldier. Magnificently homegrown, Aleijadinho's style, notwithstanding its eloquence, exemplifies the gap between the Brazilian Baroque and its sophisticated European counterparts, which is in no way meant to imply a qualitative difference. 
Brazil clearly cultivated genius eccentrics like Aleijadinho. At the Venice Biennale several years ago, Arthur Bispo do Rosario's mixed-media constructions and fabric pieces were on view in Brazil's pavilion. Bispo do Rosario was another eccentric, a seaman, boxer, doorman, bodyguard, jailbird and mental patient who died in 1989 at the age of 78. He made altars out of sneakers and rubber sandals. He sewed banners out of bed sheets and embroidered them with long incantatory lists of places and people, including a presentation mantle he made for himself to wear before God on Judgment Day.
His work, gloriously intricate and colorful, is here, too, where it fits neatly, as he no doubt never intended, with Lygia Clark's and Helio Oiticica's interactive clothing and performance pieces, all of them conveying the same joyous ethos.
From Bispo do Rosario, Clark and Oiticica it is a natural step to a younger generation: to Mr. Neto, with his huge stocking stuffed with lavender, which you are invited to smell, and to Antonio Manuel, whose "Phantom" is a white room with black coals hung from the ceiling, through which we may navigate.
El Museo del Barrio at the moment has an elegant survey of contemporary Brazilian art, which raises similar points about the importance of touch and smell, about weaving and sewing, about indigenous traditions, impermanence and spectacle. Summing up any national culture, especially over the course of 400 years, is a fool's game, and I wasn't surprised to hear someone suggest that the Guggenheim would not have tried this if the country were Italy or France. Maybe. But that argument seemed a little too clever to me. I'm just grateful for art I hadn't seen before.
Anyway, after Sept. 11, "Body and Soul" may be the last of its kind for a while. To organize huge, expensive shows, the Guggenheim depends on tourists, and on corporate sponsors who depend on tourists, and you can't ask airline companies for money when they have their hands out, too. What the new economy means for the museum's big picture (for a Frank Gehry-designed Guggenheim in Lower Manhattan or for the Guggenheim's new Las Vegas sites, on which the whole museum was counting for cash) can't be known yet. It may be that the drift of American museums before Sept. 11, toward expansion and commercial enterprise, abruptly ended that day. Necessity will dictate retrenchment.
If so, the Guggenheim's critics, who already are saying "Body and Soul" was put together only to promote the idea of a Guggenheim branch in Brazil, may celebrate. But don't be too surprised if you end up pining for the days of shows like this.
"Brazil: Body and Soul" is at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, through Jan. 27. "The Thread Unraveled: Contemporary Brazilian Art" is at El Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, East Harlem, (212)831-7272, through Feb. 3.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
A Collection Where Cultures Connect and East Meets West

BYLINE:  By HOLLAND COTTER 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE 

 BODY:
"We're all connected" is the big-picture story of art. It always has been. If you have any doubts, visit the Walters Art Museum here, where that message comes across soft and clear, and in exquisitely concentrated form.
 There's no better time to make the trip. The museum has just fully reopened after a three-year renovation. A large chunk of its permanent collection has been reinstalled, a move that puts one of the country's finest gatherings of Egyptian and Byzantine art back on view. Its recent acquisitions of Ethiopian art, probably the best assemblage outside of Africa, are taking their inaugural bow. 
 Finally, and first to some of us, one of the most important collections of South Asian material in private hands is making its full-dress public debut in a special show titled "Desire and Devotion: Art From India, Nepal and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection." Devotees of Asian art already have their pilgrimage gear packed and Amtrak tickets reserved. 
With such exemplary things to contemplate, it's a little reassuring to learn that the museum's collection is not the product of some superorganized master plan, but came together almost by accident. The man who amassed it, the Baltimore-born entrepreneur Henry Walters (1848-1931), was a learning-on-the-job shopper. He had eclectic tastes and picked up this and that from here and there over a period of nearly 50 years, sometimes without being exactly sure of what he was getting.
His single biggest buy, for example, was basically a glorified version of a sealed box lot at a country auction. In 1902 the contents of the Palazzo Accoramboni in Rome were put up for sale. Despite rumors about the dubious quality of some of the work in the collection, Walters trusted that there were treasures to be had and dashed over to take a peek.
He couldn't see much. The palace was so cluttered and murky that almost nothing was readily visible, certainly not enough to make an informed selection. So in one of those big-spender American gestures that still leave the rest of the world gasping, he bought the whole package for what was then the stupefying sum of $1 million, with the idea that he'd sort it out later.
The gamble paid off. Sure, there was junk. But the good items were unbelievably good. The prize was a group of seven marble sarcophagi, as deep as hot tubs and covered with dense, high reliefs of twisting figures dating from the second century B.C. Now on display together in one small room, they are an overwhelming, almost suffocating presence, with a sculptural energy that keeps pushing you back out the door.
They are among the largest of the 20,000 pieces that Walters bequeathed to Baltimore, but not necessarily the most spectacular. His real love was for extravagantly wrought small objects. Hundreds of them are included in the revamped permanent galleries on the second and third floors of the museum's Center Street building. But even before you get to them, there are riveting things to see in the special exhibitions gallery on the first floor, where "Desire and Devotion" appears.
Organized by Hiram W. Woodward Jr., the museum's curator of Asian art, the show begins with early Indian sculptures of women, among them a sandstone figure of a goddess or nature spirit, now headless. Her voluptuous form is the quintessential Indian image of candid sexuality, an emblem of relaxed joie de vivre, as much part of the natural world as ripe fruit or an undulating landscape.
In her the sensual and the spiritual, usually kept separate in the West, merge. And their union is the underlying theme of the Ford collection. In some images, like an 18th-century miniature painting of two lovers holding lighted sparklers as they embrace, desire is a lighthearted, festive affair. But in art associated with the esoteric forms of Hinduism and Buddhism known as Tantra, it burns with a beyond-the-fringe devotional fervor.
Tantra is based on a body of texts, images and practices used as instruments of salvation. And salvation is achieved by disrupting the rhythms of everyday life, turning the world inside out. One way to do this is through meditation, a kind of shutting down in order to be beamed up, an intensely dynamic form of passive resistance. Another is by deliberately flouting accepted social mores, breaking taboos, sexual and otherwise, to get beyond the impulses they suppress and control.
Some of the most dramatic Tantric images are from the Himalayas. "Desire and Devotion" is rich in them, with highlights including a hypnotic painted mandala from Nepal with the Buddhist goddess of wealth, Vasudhara, sitting enticingly at its center, and a fiery Tibetan depiction of the deity Raktayamari copulating with his consort, a transcendent union of wisdom and compassion that can be conveyed only in an image of physical bliss.
The collection, ornamented with a catalog by the art historian Pratapaditya Pal, will be on the road over the next two years, but its future lies at the Walters. The Fords, longtime Baltimore residents, are giving all the objects in the show, along with 50 more, to the museum, an act of largesse that automatically makes this institution, which already has superb Asian holdings, a major player in South Asian art.
The Ford pieces will be in cosmopolitan company. A museum news release describes the reinstallation of the collection as telling the story of Western civilization from ancient Egypt to medieval Europe, which it more or less does, though there's a point of contention right at the start: some historians would strongly resist bringing Egypt under the Western umbrella. At the same time, more and more scholars are acknowledging the deep debt owed by European culture to African achievements. So the debate balances out.
There's no question that the Walters's Egyptian material is exceptional, and it looks that way in an atmospheric setting that simulates the shadowy interior of a temple sanctuary. A limestone tomb carving of a singer named Enehey sits majestically near the front, a rattle in her hand. Items from daily life -- pots and pans and makeup jars -- are shown nearby. Haunting faces float behind her: a quartzite head of a king, as sleek as a cat, and a gilded mummy mask with quizzical, staring eyes.
Branching out from either side of the Egyptian galleries are others devoted to the ancient Near East and the Mediterranean Classical world, which were both linked to Egypt and to each other through trade. The Classical selection is outstanding not only for the great sarcophagi, but also for Etruscan bronzes and a display of powerhouse Hellenistic jewelry studded with egg-size gemstones in the Oriental style.
But it is on the third floor, with Byzantine art saturated in religious emotion, that everything comes into rhapsodic focus. Organized by Gary Vikan, the Walters's director, these galleries show the museum at the top of its form, fleshing out the complex cultural map of early Christianity with an economy, thoroughness and beauty that institutions many times its size can only envy.
The Christian world is introduced by a simulation of a seventh-century Syrian altar set with silver liturgical vessels. From there, one path leads through Roman Catholic Europe, from gilded Romanesque reliquaries to a Gothic altar to a tiny portrait, cut from an altarpiece by Hugo van der Goes, of a man praying as John the Baptist leans over his shoulder as if whispering instructions.
Orthodox Christianity took other, separate directions, and does so here. In an octagonal gallery devoted to international Byzantine culture, one route heads north, with Russian icons and Armenian Gospels, objects attributed with miraculous powers that are easy to believe in from the examples here. The other moves south to Ethiopia, represented by a charismatic cluster of upright processional crosses surrounded by illuminated books.
A few years ago, museums barely knew Ethiopian art existed; the Walters began collecting it only in the mid-1990's. Yet the work is beautiful beyond words, and Ethiopia itself plays a distinctive, symbolic role within the context of African-American culture, from the social vision of Marcus Garvey to the Rastafarian mysticism of Bob Marley. This is the first time the Walters has shown its Ethiopian art in depth, and this part of the collection is worth a visit in itself.
But the reinstallation doesn't close its cultural embrace there. Adjacent to the Ethiopian work, the museum has placed the 11th-century wooden door from the ark of the Torah in the Ben Ezra Synagogue in Cairo. Just beyond that is the door of a Muslim tomb from 16th-century Iran.
In fact, if you stand at a certain point in the third-floor galleries, you will see the Gothic altar, the Ethiopian crosses, the doors of the Torah ark and the Islamic tomb fall into perfect visual alignment, their forms, so different in shape but so similar in spiritual purpose, overlapping and echoing one another. Could any perspective speak more directly and hopefully to the moment we live in now?
"Desire and Devotion: Art From India, Nepal and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection" is at the Walters Art Museum, 600 North Charles Street, Baltimore, (410) 547-9000, through Jan. 13. It travels to the Santa Barbara (Calif.) Museum of Art (March 2-June 2); the Albuquerque (N.M.) Museum of Art (Sept. 7-Jan.5, 2003); and the Birmingham (Ala.) Museum of Art (March 9-May 25, 2003). "Wondrous Journeys: The Walters Collection From Egyptian Tombs to Medieval Castles" is on permanent view.

(Photographs from the Walters Art Museum)

HEADLINE: Sony Loss of $107 Million Adds to Gloom in Japan 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
The bad news pouring in from Japan's electronics industry is reinforcing fears about the depth of the global economic downturn. 
 The Sony Corporation, saying it saw little hope of a rebound in demand for electronics and components before spring, reported a net loss today of 13 billion yen ($107 million) in the quarter ended Sept. 30, not the small profit that analysts had expected. 
 Its sales of electronics, accounting for two-thirds of Sony's revenue, fell 4.9 percent from the period in 2000, more than wiping out gains made by its games and movie divisions. The company also wrote off inventory and costs related to reorganization of its Aiwa unit and other businesses and early retirement packages. 
"It's tough to see where the bottom is in the current environment," said Teruhisa Tokunaka, Sony's chief financial officer. "We have to be ready for this difficult situation to continue for some time." 
Even so, Sony stuck to its forecast for a 3 percent rise in sales and a net profit of 10 billion yen for the full fiscal year, which ends on March 31. The main reason is that its PlayStation 2 video game console is finally taking off: the company expects to sell 20 million of them by the end of the fiscal year and is doubling the number of software titles available for it, to almost 600. Sony's game division made money in the latest quarter for the first time since the console was introduced in late 1999.
Analysts say those forecasts will prove unrealistic if consumer demand for home electronics does not recover by Christmas, particularly in the United States, where Sony gets about one-third of its sales. Sony itself has said it expects a 10 percent fall in sales in the United States and Europe from now to March 31.
Sony announced some belt-tightening moves today, scaling back or closing 48 business units and looking for ways to reduce procurement costs by 15 percent, or 300 billion yen ($2.4 billion). Analysts said the moves would only partly offset the damage done to Sony's results by falling prices in important product categories like semiconductors, personal computers and display screens. Chip prices, for example, have fallen by about two-thirds in the last year, and Sony said today that its semiconductor sales fell by 25 percent just in the latest quarter.
The company's reputation suffered this year when it recalled more than a million cellphones because of software defects, taking a charge of 40 billion yen ($330 million). "Sony has lost a lot of credibility in the handset business in Japan," said Yukie Saito of Lehman Brothers in Tokyo. Sony has apparently also lost some credibility with investors: its stock price has fallen nearly 40 percent in Japan this year.
Sony still has hope for growth in the cellphone market outside Japan; it said it expected its new handset joint venture with Ericsson of Sweden to be profitable next year. 
Where Sony's fortunes depend on consumers buying gadgets, its rival Fujitsu, Japan's largest computer maker, needs a revival in business demand. On Wednesday the company reported a 4 percent decline in sales and a group net loss of 174.7 billion yen ($1.44 billion) for the half-year ended Sept. 30.
To cut costs, Fujitsu said it would add 4,500 more layoffs to the 16,400 it announced in August as part of a plan to refocus the company on more profitable software and services businesses and reduce the emphasis on hardware and components. 
The company said it now expected a loss of 310 billion yen ($2.6 billion) for the full year, including charges for reorganization and layoff costs and for write-offs in its semiconductor operations and staff reductions.
Analysts expect the news to be gloomy when another leading Japanese electronics company, NEC, reports results on Friday. NEC set aside plans for an American listing for its stock as the technology slump deepened over the summer.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fans trying out the Final Fantasy X video game last July in Tokyo. Such popular games are played on Sony's PlayStation 2, the main reason behind the company's hopes for a net profit of $25 million for the fiscal year. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: W.T.O. Says Trade Growth Will Be Virtually Stagnant 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
World trade, growing by leaps and bounds a year ago, has now all but stagnated, according to a study released today by the World Trade Organization. Meager growth of 1 or 2 percent is the best that can be expected this year, the study said.
 In its annual report on the state of world trade, the organization said that there was no sign of a return to the roaring 12 percent growth rate recorded in 2000. In May, the group forecast 7 percent growth in 2001, but demand in the global economy has since cooled much more quickly than the group anticipated, and the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attacks made matters much worse. 
 The subsequent slump in the airline, hotel, travel and tourism industries has shriveled international trade in services, the organization's analysts wrote. Furthermore, consumer demand in Western Europe has gone cold unexpectedly, and so have imports into the United States, the report said.
Another major contributor to the slowdown has been the worldwide fall in demand for information technology products, the 219-page report said. Worldwide sales of personal computers are expected to fall for the first time, and shipments of semiconductors in the first six months of this year fell 30 percent.
Asian nations have been hit hardest, because they conduct a large trade in such products. Only China appears to have escaped the downturn, posting a 9 percent increase in exports in the first half of the year.
Over all, the report said, based on performance in the first half of the year, Western Europe as a region could expect the most trade growth for the full year, at about 4 percent, while North America would be roughly flat or grow only slightly and Japan's trade would contract for the full year.
World trade has not grown as slowly as a 2 percent rate in any year since 1982.
The report sets a subdued stage for the organization's biennial conference next month, which is still scheduled to convene in Doha, Qatar, despite security concerns. One goal of the conference is to begin a new global round of talks on trade liberalization.

HEADLINE: Europe Holds the Line on Rates 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
Brushing aside signs of plunging business confidence and stagnating growth across Europe, the European Central Bank once again rebuffed widespread pleas today to reduce interest rates and stimulate the economy.
 The decision was a clear disappointment to investors and corporations, who have become more pessimistic than at any time in the last five years. It also puts the central bank on a collision course with European government leaders, who have already been pressing the central bank for easier money and are almost certain to become much more blunt in the weeks ahead. 
 Unlike the United States Federal Reserve, which has lowered interest rates nine times so far this year in hopes of rekindling growth, the European Central Bank is preoccupied with stamping out any hint of inflation and with maintaining the credibility of Europe's fledgling common currency, the euro. 
The result is that Europe's benchmark short-term interest rate, now at 3.75 percent, is significantly higher than the analogous rate in the United States, the Federal Reserve's overnight lending rate, even though inflation is slightly higher in the United States than in Europe.
The economic gloom over Europe has thickened and darkened considerably since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. Business confidence in Germany, Italy and Belgium has plunged in the last month, according to widely followed surveys in each country. Economic growth has all but stopped in Germany, Europe's biggest economy, and forecasters at Deutsche Bank warn that the 12 nations adopting the euro will not grow by more than 1 percent next year. 
Scores of German companies have announced plans to eliminate thousands of jobs each. They range from manufacturers like Siemens and MAN A.G. to chemical companies like BASF and banks like Commerzbank of Frankfurt. HypoVereinsbank said today that it would eliminate 9,000 jobs over the next year. BASF warned this week that it was sitting on huge inventories of chemicals that had gone unsold because business confidence had fallen so far.
Pressure on the European Central Bank has mounted from across Europe. Belgium's finance minister, Didier Reynders, has repeatedly goaded the central bank by insisting that it has room to relax monetary policy. France's finance minister, Laurent Fabius, has made similar remarks. 
Below the surface, the political pressure is much blunter still. "The markets expect a rate cut, and there is room to cut rates," an economist close to the Belgian government said. "If the situation deteriorates further and the E.C.B. does not react, this could have disastrous consequences."
Wim Duisenberg, president of the central bank, issued a brief statement about the decision today and refused to elaborate. But when he met with European political leaders last weekend in Ghent, Belgium, he said he did not want to act until the 12-country average annual inflation rate dropped to or below the bank's target of 2 percent. At the moment, it is more than 2.5 percent.
Many analysts think the central bank is moving far too slowly. After reducing interest rates in an emergency session shortly after Sept. 11, the central bank returned to its dogged opposition to easier money and ignored the Federal Reserve's move to flood the markets with new money.
"It is a great risk they are taking," said Holger Fahrinkrug, an economist in Frankfurt at UBS Warburg. "If the economy really gets much weaker in the next couple of months, people will blame it all on the E.C.B.
"The politicians in Germany and France won't say they got it wrong. They are going to say the E.C.B. got it wrong."
Under the treaties that govern the European Monetary Union, the European Central Bank is guaranteed political independence. Mr. Duisenberg has relished that independence, often going out of his way to gruffly reject advice from political leaders. 
But impatience and hostility to the bank's policies are on the rise. Gerhard Schroder, Germany's chancellor, acidly suggested that monetary policy had reached "the height of common sense." Germany, which accounts for one-third of the euro zone's economic output, has had no growth for months and will probably close out the year with an anemic showing of just three-quarters of 1 percent growth. Capacity utilization has plunged to its lowest level in years, and unemployment is rising steadily.
None of this has been helpful for the euro, even though the American economy is in much more dire straits than that of Europe, and even though a restrictive monetary policy often tends to strengthen a currency, to the detriment of exporters. 
The euro, wobbly against the dollar since Sept. 11, slipped immediately after the central bank announced its decision, but then regained its lost ground after a new statistical report from the United States showed an unexpectedly steep drop in orders for durable goods. In European trading, the euro rose a bit to 89.6 American cents.
Robert Hayward, a currency analyst at ABN Amro in London, said the euro could easily drop further in value if investors decide that pump-priming by the Federal Reserve is more likely to produce faster growth in the United States. 
"There is a real premium on economic growth," Mr. Hayward said. "What the market seems to be doing is looking forward to 2002 and saying that the Federal Reserve seems to be doing what is needed."

HEADLINE: WPP Is Rebuffed in Effort to Break a Deal 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
The WPP Group, the giant British advertising agency company, had a setback today in its attempt to abandon a deal to acquire the Tempus Group, a media-buying concern, when British regulators ruled that it must proceed. The deal is worth more than $620 million at current exchange rates.
 WPP said it would appeal the decision. 
 The company had asked regulators for permission to invoke an escape hatch, saying that the terror attacks of Sept. 11 had brought about adverse changes in Tempus's business.
The regulatory body, the Panel on Takeovers and Mergers, did not provide details of how it reached its decision. But analysts said the panel had probably concluded that a downturn affecting the entire advertising industry did not qualify as a valid reason for invoking the escape clause.
Shares of Tempus rose 3.9 percent yesterday, to 530 pence ($7.58).
Tempus, which buys advertising space and plans media budgets for clients, would account for only 4 percent of WPP's revenue. Some investors said they were more interested in what they considered a larger problem: how the overall economic slump would affect WPP's core advertising revenue.
"The advertising business is far more important and will determine the future of WPP much more than Tempus," said Mark Westwood, an analyst with Legg Mason Investors, the British arm of the United States fund management company.
WPP said today that it might miss profit targets, and that revenue for all of 2001 could fall 2 percent. It estimated that the Sept. 11 attacks reduced revenue the last three weeks of September by $30 million. The decline was so swift that WPP was unable to cut costs fast enough, the company said.
Sir Martin Sorrell, WPP's chief executive, said ensuing events like the anthrax attacks in the United States that have roiled the postal service, have raised fresh questions, especially for direct marketers.
WPP's third-quarter revenue rose 41 percent, lifted by last year's acquisition of Young & Rubicam.
The shares rose 5.6 percent yesterday, to 591.5 pence ($8.44).
"It is a relief bounce," Mr. Westwood said. "People are glad that things aren't worse."
In recent weeks, Havas, the French rival that WPP outbid for Tempus, and Cordiant Communications of Britain have both warned that profits for the year might fall short of expectations.
WPP and Tempus will now present their arguments to the takeover panel's governing body, some 20 executives from the financial community.
But some analysts remained skeptical that, without new information, the ruling would be overturned. "Given that WPP's argument had been rejected once, it's hard to see how it could win on appeal," Nicola Stewart, an analyst with Commerzbank Securities, said.

HEADLINE: WORLD SERIES PREVIEW; 
Schilling Builds on Father's Influence

BYLINE:  By TYLER KEPNER 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
There will be more than 48,000 fans at Bank One Ballpark when Curt Schilling throws the first pitch of the World Series on Saturday. At least one of the seats will be empty.
 That is the seat left for Cliff Schilling, who has had a ticket for each of the nearly 300 games his son has started in the major leagues. Cliff died in 1988, Curt's first year in the majors. His influence has never left. 
 "Mentally, I would like to think we're very close," said Schilling, the Arizona Diamondbacks' bulky and overpowering right-hander. "Physically, we're built alike. But my dad was a quiet person, very calm, never rattled. And I'm far from quiet." 
Except on the days he starts, Schilling is loud. His friend and former manager with the Philadelphia Phillies, Terry Francona, joked that the best days were when Schilling pitched, because he was all action, no talk.
A piece of paper titled "Patton's Address to His Troops" is taped to the side of Schilling's locker, next to a photo of George C. Scott as General Patton. It is evidence of Schilling's enthusiasm for motivating others, and it stems from a passion instilled by his father.
Schilling's father served 22 years in the Army, spending some time in the 101st Airborne and retiring as a Master Sergeant. Schilling was born in Anchorage, and the family moved around. "He was just your basic run-of-the-mill grunt," Schilling said.
Schilling, 34, grew up with a sense of history and feelings of national pride instilled by his father. He is so passionate about military history that he once published a magazine about a World War II board game and now owns a company, Multiman Publishing, that creates similar games for Hasbro.
"One of the things I've tried to understand and comprehend is why we have what we have and why we are what we are right now as a nation," Schilling said. "Starting with my generation and some of the generations that have followed, you could ask them what D-Day is and they would probably give you the name of a band or something."
After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Schilling wrote a column for ESPN's Web site and urged all players to donate one day's salary to relief efforts. On Wednesday, he left the Diamondbacks' clubhouse wearing an F.D.N.Y. T-shirt. He returned the next morning wearing a shirt with a patriotic message. He has written "God Bless America" in silver letters around the American flag on his cap this postseason and will visit the World Trade Center site on Monday.
Schilling is uncomfortable with the portrayal of the Yankees as the sentimental favorites because of how that role casts the Diamondbacks.
"I don't want people to think that it's us against them," Schilling said. He also rejects any comparison between wars and ballgames. "I don't look at the baseball field as a battlefield," he said. "That would be belittling what war really is."
In the strict baseball sense, though, Schilling's aggressiveness and mentality can make him seem like a warrior, in the way George Steinbrenner uses the term for Paul O'Neill. Schilling writes "Whatever It Takes" under the bill of his cap and has a passion for finishing what he starts.
Schilling has 71 complete games since 1992, matching Greg Maddux for the most in the majors. He has completed his last four starts in the postseason, including three this year, and in 1998 he pitched more complete games, 15, than 24 teams.
"You give him the ball before the game," Francona said, "and you've got to wrestle it away from him three hours later."
In the Yankees' last 75 postseason games, only one pitcher -- Cleveland's Bartolo Colon in the 1998 American League Championship Series -- has thrown a nine-inning complete game against them. Schilling could be the next. Lots of pitchers say they want to complete their starts, Francona said, but few really know how. Schilling has learned to economize his pitches and find something extra late in games.
Schilling might throw fastballs averaging 94 miles an hour for eight innings. Then, in a crucial spot in the ninth, he may show hitters something much harder. Randy Johnson, the Diamondbacks' other ace, is the same way.
"They can be their own closers," Arizona catcher Damian Miller said. "That's why those two have so many complete games, because they have the ability to change themselves physically to change the outcome of the game. Curt's throwing 94 and all of a sudden he'll throw one 99 miles an hour -- after 100 pitches, which is freaky."
There is no special sign he can give for that, Miller said. It is a level Schilling reaches on his own. Besides, while Johnson relies heavily on Miller to call a game, Schilling decides what to throw. 
His preparation allows him to do that. Schilling has extensive video clips of opposing hitters on his laptop and keeps a hand-written, detailed notebook on hitters' tendencies, which he and Miller consult on the bench between innings.
Before his start against Atlanta in the championship series, Schilling and Miller looked at video of Chipper Jones for 15 minutes, breaking down at-bats from Jones's entire seven-year career. This week, Schilling said, he has spent hours studying the Yankees, getting tips in telephone conversations with the Phillies coach John Vukovich and others.
"Curt's the most prepared player I've ever been around," Miller said. "When you study as much as he does and do all that kind of stuff, you have a tendency to trust him and trust what he wants to throw."
Schilling has a splitter and two breaking balls to complement his fastball, and he uses them to both blow away and baffle hitters. His style is nothing like Maddux's, but they are similar in one way.
"Greg Maddux was the smartest pitcher I ever played with until I met Curt Schilling," Arizona first baseman Mark Grace said. "Curt Schilling's the smartest I've ever played with."
Grace hit Schilling well when he played for the Cubs, but facing him was never fun. "And now I know why: because he knew everything about me going into it," Grace said.
It was not always this way. When Schilling came up with the Baltimore Orioles, he was a brash kid with a mohawk haircut and no plan for his starts. He was shifted to middle relief, traded to Houston and pitched decently. Then he met Roger Clemens, and everything changed.
Schilling and Clemens were both working out at the Astrodome one day after the 1991 season. Clemens, who had just won his third Cy Young Award for the Boston Red Sox, had heard Schilling, 25, wanted to meet him.
"I said I would love to talk to him," said Clemens, the Yankees' Game 3 starter, "but I didn't want to waste my time."
Clemens was an established star by the time he was 25, and he saw in Schilling a pitcher with a similar body type and style who had achieved almost nothing. Clemens was blunt.
You get out of baseball what you put into it, Clemens told him. If you don't work hard off the field, he said, you cheat yourself, your teammates and your family. Schilling said the lesson took hold immediately.
"It was like getting a third eye," Schilling said. "I looked at the game with a whole new approach, outlook, respect. I just realized that I couldn't continue to do things the way I had done them and put my head on the pillow at night and say I'd done everything I could. There was just so much more that I could do."
The Astros did not wait for the new Schilling. They traded him to Philadelphia for Jason Grimsley the next spring, and a year later Schilling was pitching in the World Series and embarking on a standout career. Clemens has watched with pride.
"He continues to want to get better, and that's something that you admire," Clemens said. "He doesn't look like he's wasting time, and he's knocking down new thresholds, finding out where he can go and how good he can be."
Schilling has tried to impart similar lessons on young pitchers, not always successfully. In Philadelphia, Francona said, he scolded Garrett Stephenson about his work habits and implored him to get more out of himself. Stephenson would blossom years later, but he did not understand Schilling's message at the time.
In Arizona, Schilling has tried again. After a bad outing by the rookie right-hander Mike Koplove in September, Schilling suggested he keep a notebook on opposing hitters. Koplove thinks he might. Arizona Manager Bob Brenly said he has seen a difference in the staff because of Schilling's influence.
"Maybe they approach their craft a little more seriously now, a little more diligently in their digesting of the scouting reports and looking at the video," Brenly said. "It just seems to me that as a staff, our guys have a much better idea of what they want to do."
The problem with young pitchers, Schilling said, is that so many of them fear failure. Why commit to extra work when it does not guarantee results? If Schilling has gotten through to teammates the way Clemens reached him, great, he said. But it is never really up to the person giving the lecture.
"It's not as much the talker as it is the talkee when it comes to stuff like that," Schilling said. "You have to have the strong desire to want to be good, and that's something I've always had. I've always wanted to be better than everybody else in the room. And I've never been afraid to take the steps to figure out if I could do that."

HEADLINE: Economic Data Are Suggesting Slower Recovery 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
With the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates and Congress vowing to pass a large stimulus package, economists have said that the current downturn could end up being a short one. The economic shock from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks would make the slowdown worse, many analysts said, but the reaction would have the economy growing again by the start of next year.
 That outcome has suddenly begun to appear less certain. 
 In recent days, a handful of economic indicators have been even weaker than expected, suggesting that a recovery could be difficult for policy makers to bring about quickly. Businesses continue to cut their spending, layoffs are still mounting and consumers are displaying growing signs of hesitation. 
After the release of a new round of statistics yesterday, bond prices rose as investors bet that the Federal Reserve was now almost certain to lower its benchmark short-term interest rate by another half-point before the end of the year. Stocks fell broadly in the morning but recovered in the afternoon, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing up 117.28 points, or 1.25 percent, at 9,462.90.
The Commerce Department said yesterday that companies' new orders for durable goods -- typically expensive items that last at least three years -- fell 8.5 percent in September, to $165.4 billion, their lowest level since 1996. Sales of existing homes, meanwhile, dropped 11.7 percent last month, the National Association of Realtors said yesterday.
The economy continues to suffer this month, too. Commodity prices, which reflect demand for raw materials, remain low. Jobless claims rose to 504,000 last week, climbing above 500,000 for the second time in recent weeks, the Labor Department said yesterday; the level had not previously been as high since 1992. 
With every other large economy in the world struggling as well, the United States could have difficultly emerging from its slowdown in the coming months, according to a growing group of investors and analysts. 
"We are in a global, synchronized recession," said Lakshman Achuthan, the managing director of the Economic Cycle Research Institute in New York. "Those are really hard to get out of," Mr. Achuthan added, because companies cannot shift their resources to economies that are still growing. The last recession to be so widespread occurred in the mid-1970's and lasted for almost a year and a half.
Today, government officials are trying to rouse the economy by cutting interest rates, lowering taxes and increasing spending. 
With the support of the White House, the Republican-led House of Representatives passed a $100 million stimulus package on Wednesday, consisting mostly of tax reductions they say will encourage new spending. Democratic leaders in the Senate are proposing a smaller bill -- about $70 billion -- that would give less money to businesses while subsidizing health care coverage for unemployed workers.
Already, the Federal Reserve has lowered its federal funds rate to 2.5 percent, from 6.5 percent, since the start of the year. That makes it less expensive for businesses and consumers to take on new debt and lowers the cost of their existing debt, giving them more cash to spend.
But even before the attacks, the economy seemed somewhat unresponsive to the Fed's push, and many economists blamed the unusual nature of this downturn.
Recessions in the United States typically begin with consumers cutting their spending, often in reaction to interest rate increases brought about by Fed officials worried about inflation. Sales then decline, businesses lay off workers and consumer spending drops further.
This year, however, companies were the first to cut their budgets, as many executives realized that their earlier sales projections -- made in the heady late 1990's -- had been far too optimistic. Having added more workers, more factories and more equipment than they need, companies have cut spending severely over the last year.
Still, only about 75 percent of the nation's industrial capacity is now being used, the lowest level in 18 years, and profits are still falling. 
"There will be further rounds of layoffs," predicted Michael K. Evans, the chief economist of the American Economics Group, a consulting firm in Washington. In the current circumstances, he added, lower interest rates and taxes will not be enough to convince many companies to increase spending immediately.
"There's no magic bullet," Mr. Evans said.
Consumer spending remains healthier, though it is weakening. 
Last week, the number of people applying for a mortgage to buy a house fell to its lowest level since last year, according to an index calculated by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. The decline erased the index's gains during late September. "It was a big enough drop that I would say it signifies something," said Douglas G. Duncan, the association's chief economist.
But even if a recession lasts longer than many economists had hoped -- into next spring, for example -- few doubt that the short-term recovery will be stronger than it would have been without the attacks. Eventually, economists say, the government's stimulus will have a significant effect and both consumers and businesses will decide they have delayed purchases long enough.
"Sharp recessions beget very strong recoveries," Mr. Achuthan said. "There is a larger amount of pent-up demand that at some point, when the floodgates open, comes out real quick."

HEADLINE: House Passes a War-Bond Bill, but Bush Is Not Enthusiastic 

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
Eager to strike a patriotic chord, the House passed a bill this week to offer old-fashioned war bonds for the first time since World War II.
 The Treasury Department, though, is reluctant to support the measure because it fears the bonds will encourage saving and discourage spending, making it harder for the country to recover from the recession many economists now say has begun. 
 The legislation, approved by a voice vote on Tuesday, would give the Treasury the authority to issue Freedom Bonds, a new class of savings bonds that would be offered along with its existing bonds. 
"These war bonds serve as an ideal vehicle for Americans to support efforts to bring those responsible for these attacks to justice," said Representative John E. Sweeney, Republican of New York, who sponsored the bill. "The bonds will provide the average citizen with a convenient option for exercising their patriotism and showing their support for our efforts."
The Senate has already passed a similar measure, sponsored by Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, as part of a bill to finance the Treasury Department.
While calling the bill a good patriotic gesture, the Bush administration is not going out of its way to promote the legislation, arguing that in today's economy it is important to encourage consumers to spend.
Under the bill, savings bond proceeds would go directly into the government's general spending fund.
"War bonds are one of several opportunities for Americans who wish to make patriotic gestures," said Betsy Holahan, a spokeswoman for the Treasury Department. "We certainly advocate direct giving to charities, as well as maintaining regular consumer spending, which is so critical to our economy. A strong economy is perhaps our greatest asset as we move forward in the efforts to fight global terrorism."
Jack Quinn, the chief operating officer of U.S. Savings Bond Consultant, a New Jersey company that analyzes government savings bonds, said war bonds made a lot of sense in the early 1940's, when consumer goods were scarce and Americans had few ways to use their money.
"Now the government is flush with money," he said, "and we're facing a recession. The only way you get out of it is by spending. Instead of investing in savings bonds, you ought to go buy a dishwasher or an automobile."
Mr. Quinn also points out that government-issued savings bonds are already available. The government offers the Series I, which yields 5.92 percent, and the series EE, which yields 4.5 percent.
The government first began selling savings bonds to pay for the Union effort during the Civil War. During World War II, Americans bought $185 billion in war bonds.
The House legislation empowers the Treasury to set the new bond's yield and maturity rate. Ms. Holahan said it would take the agency one month to set the program in motion.
Representative Amo Houghton, Republican of New York, said he originally opposed the bill because he wanted Americans to make purchases rather than buy bonds. "But then in thinking through what is happening here, everybody wants to be a part," he said. "I think this is a worthy cause and something which Americans can identify with, and I think it is the right thing to do."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Despite Dismal Economic News, Shares Post Solid Gains

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Stocks reversed sharp early losses and finished with solid gains yesterday as investors displayed confidence in the government's ability to stimulate the economy.
 Technology shares led the afternoon surge as investors overcame their initial discouragement, caused when new data showed that the Sept. 11 attacks had a harsher effect on the economy than Wall Street had expected. Investors have shrugged off many negative reports in the last week, but the latest reports were the most relevant and dismal yet, showing steeper-than-expected declines in September housing sales and orders for durable goods. 
 By the end of the day, though, the market had taken the data in stride, apparently seeing it as a sign that the government would work harder to stimulate the economy. The market has been driven by mood lately, with many analysts talking more about the fear over anthrax than earnings, and market strategists were somewhat hard pressed to explain the reaction to the new data. 
"I'm at a loss, a little bit," said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis, adding that the economic reports could lead the Federal Reserve to lower its benchmark interest rate for the 10th time this year, to 2 percent from 2.5 percent.
After falling as much as 167 points, the Dow Jones industrial average rebounded to gain 117.28 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,462.90. The technology-weighted Nasdaq composite index rose 43.93 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,775.47. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 14.89 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,100.09.
Yesterday's weak economic reports caused Lehman Brothers to predict a deeper recession than it had previously forecast. Since the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, the Fed has quickly reduced interest rates, cutting the federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks to 2.5 percent from 3.5 percent before Sept. 11. The government has, meanwhile, promised a package of extensive tax breaks and new spending.
Much of the economic deterioration from the attacks became clear for the first time yesterday in reports based largely on data gathered after Sept. 11. Orders for durable goods fell 8.5 percent, to $165.44 billion, the lowest level since August 1996; the drop was far steeper than expected. Sales of existing single-family homes dropped 11.7 percent, the biggest decline in more than six years. And initial claims for unemployment benefits last week hit their second-highest level in more than nine years.
"The recession that we're in will go a little bit deeper," said Charles L. Reinhard, a senior strategist at Lehman Brothers. "It's difficult to negatively surprise the market beyond what we saw on Sept. 11." But he added that investors discovered yesterday that "the fourth quarter is going to be a deep-negative G.D.P. quarter, it's going to be a deep-negative earnings quarter."
The bond market rallied on the weak data. The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose 14/32 , to 103 20/32 , while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 4.54 percent, from 4.59 percent on Wednesday. The 30-year bond rose 27/32 , to 101 12/32 , while its yield fell to 5.28 percent from 5.34 percent.
Shares of technology companies, their earnings outlooks among the least clear, posted solid gains, with semiconductor stocks showing unusual strength. Xilinx rose $4.15, to $33.30; KLA-Tencor jumped $4.39, to $45.25; and Applied Materials gained $2.09, to $37.43. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index rose 24.25 points, or 5.26 percent, to 485.10.
Microsoft rose $1.24, to $62.56, as the company introduced its Windows XP operating system.
Some Dow components fell in the morning but turned around and posted gains by the end of the day. American Express rose 68 cents, to $30.67; Disney was up 58 cents, to $19.02; and Intel gained 62 cents, to $26.10.
Among other issues, Dow Chemical said its earnings dropped 84 percent, and its stock fell 15 cents, to $34.85. Goodyear Tire and Rubber reported a 45 percent decline in earnings, which was not as bad as analysts had expected, and its stock gained 48 cents, to $19.23.

HEADLINE: News Helicopters Curbed by Air Restrictions 

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
Squirming restlessly, Aaron Fitzgerald spends much of his day at a desk now, flipping the channels of his three police scanners in the distant hope that he will come across something really worthwhile. A fire. A car chase, perhaps. Maybe even a bomb scare.
 The phone rings. From the stairwell of an office tower in Los Angeles, a man on a cellphone says thousands are being evacuated. Itching to take to skies, Mr. Fitzgerald, a helicopter reporter for KCBS television, merely grunts in frustration. The building is in the no-fly zone that covers the city like a blanket, forcing him to pass on yet another breaking news event. 
 "I would have been there to film the fire department arriving," said Mr. Fitzgerald, wistfully. "There are so many stories that we've just had to let go."
This week, the Federal Aviation Administration opened the skies over the nation's largest cities to virtually anyone who owns an aircraft, including recreational pilots, responding to Congressional complaints that the nation's economy had been grounded along with its private planes.
Yet news helicopters of every kind, whether peering down at traffic or hovering over crime scenes, still have to keep clear of most major metropolitan areas for reasons that have lobbyists and legislators guessing.
"If we don't get some information this week, we are prepared to subpoena the National Security Council," said Representative John L. Mica, a Florida Republican who chairs the House subcommittee on aviation. "They should at least give us a reason."
Publicly, the aviation agency simply says news helicopters, with a small group of other aircraft like sight-seeing tours and banner-toting planes, present unique threats to national security, but it has refrained from specifying what those risks are. In private, however, agency officials say that the erratic flight paths of news helicopters, which often change as quickly and significantly as the day's events unfold, make it hard to distinguish between legitimate pilots and potential terrorists.
Television and radio stations around the country complain that the restrictions strip them of an important news-gathering tool, depriving viewers of the type of instant information they take for granted.
"We've created this expectation for immediate news," said Barbara Cochran, president of the Radio-Television News Directors Association, which has been pressuring Congress to get the ban lifted. "And now at a time when our viewers need information more than ever, we can't bring it to them."
Without their helicopters, Ms. Cochran said, television stations were unable to cover a toxic spill at a chemical plant in Houston, because the roads around it were closed. Nor could they reach a wooded part of Orlando, Fla., where a student pilot, unfettered by the restrictions that news helicopters face, recently crashed his plane.
But perhaps no city has been as affected by the no-fly zone as Los Angeles, where the art form was born. Since its beginnings in the late 1950's, when pilots stuck a studio camera in the passenger seat and hovered 50 feet above a local parade, tethered to the ground by a ribbon of thick power cords, the news helicopter has practically come to define television journalism in Los Angeles, delivering some of the most striking and contentious images in the city's recent history.
The sight of O. J. Simpson's white Ford Bronco fleeing from the police in 1994, just like the live broadcast of a man committing suicide on a crowded Los Angeles freeway in 1998, drew huge numbers of viewers, proving the commercial importance of news helicopters even as it raised objections to their use.
And with seemingly endless swaths of highway that are often too congested for news vans to traverse, Los Angeles television stations say reporting the news or keeping watch on traffic is nearly impossible without the ever-present whirlybirds that previously speckled the city's skies.
"We're willing to do anything to ease the F.A.A.'s concerns," said Mike Nolan, a helicopter reporter for KFI-AM and KOST-FM in Los Angeles. "But they just won't give us a chance."
Helicopters can still skirt the city's periphery, as long as they remain at least 25 miles away from a major airport. In cities like Los Angeles, though, that eliminates nearly all of the metropolitan area, where news stations say more than two-thirds of the events they cover normally take place.
Knowing how important live images are to their competitive edge, some television stations say they simply choose not to cover events, like bomb scares at Los Angeles airport, if they cannot get pictures of the action in time. In a strange bit of luck for many news shows, the dry winds have spread brush fires throughout the outlying hills, giving helicopters plenty to chase outside the no-fly zone.
Traffic reports, however, are not so easily replaced, and because news helicopters cannot circle over downtown highways to see for themselves they are forced to rely on the California Highway Patrol's computers for road conditions.
During the temporary ban, some industry watchers hope that television stations will lessen their dependence on live feeds from helicopters.
"There's no question that they've been overused," said Joan Bieder, a senior lecturer at the Graduate School of Journalism at the University of California at Berkeley, who teaches television production. "The practice has less to do with journalism than marketing."
As for many of the Los Angeles residents who have grown accustomed to the clamor of rotors above their heads, the temporary ban is nothing short of a welcome relief. "It's so quiet it's wonderful," said Austin Ray, 42, a singer from West Hollywood. "We sleep much better now."

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Skating Along Despite Trying Times

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
AFTER the guys in moon suits appeared for the second time in our building to investigate powder-filled letters, I asked a clerk in the mailroom how he was coping with the new drawbacks of his job. He said he didn't like working with plastic gloves (too hot) or worrying that any piece of mail could be fatal. But what really bothered him was his commute.
 "Nothing scares me as much as taking the subway," he said. "Here we're taking precautions. Down in the subway you're helpless if someone releases something." 
 You could argue with that comparative risk assessment, given that anthrax has been found in mail at other news organizations. But he's right to recognize that the rest of the the city is potentially as dangerous as a mailroom. New York, unlike Afghanistan, is a target-rich environment.
We could use irradiation to kill bacteria in every piece of mail, and terrorists could find countless other ways to spread anthrax. We could search every subway rider, and terrorists could still attack restaurants and offices with germs or bombs. If we miraculously kept terrorists out of every building, they could go on murderous rampages using nothing more sophisticated than cars on crowded sidewalks.
At best, the precautions can stop some terrorists and prevent another mass murder so spectacular that it causes masses of people and businesses to flee the city. But the main effect of the measures will probably just be to divert terrorists to other targets. No amount of precautions can stop determined terrorists from killing New Yorkers.
We're vulnerable because there are so many of us crowded together. Randal O'Toole, an economist with the Thoreau Institute and a defender of suburban sprawl, notes how much less damage the sprawling Pentagon suffered on Sept. 11 compared with the World Trade Center towers, and he sees a similarity between Al Qaeda and suburbia.
"The very reason that terrorism is so hard to combat is that terrorists absolutely refuse to bunch up," he writes. "Though Americans may want to defy the terrorists, the notion that we should all subsidize New York's position as America's economic capital, effectively bunching ourselves up, is absurd."
He and others have argued that Manhattan is a dinosaur in the decentralized era of the Internet, and that terrorism now gives people yet another reason to prefer low-rise communities like Silicon Valley. But city dwellers have always faced special dangers. Their density made them vulnerable to crime and violence, to plagues (nature's bioterrorism) and to fires that routinely devastated huge sections of cities.
Yet cities survived and grew because the risks of density were outweighed by the benefits. Those benefits are still enough to keep people in New York -- if we don't respond to recent events by making life prohibitively inconvenient here. But so far, security precautions are probably doing more to discourage residents than terrorists.
DESPITE all the publicity, so far the odds of contracting anthrax in New York are small, even if you're a postal worker or a journalist. But the odds are quite high that you've been delayed by a checkpoint on the road or a shutdown of a subway line. Subway stations are closed every day as police investigate "suspicious substances" that turn out to be baby powder, Sweet'n Low or sugar from a doughnut. Yesterday there were six separate closings affecting nine subway lines between 7 a.m and 3 p.m.
These investigations don't seem to accomplish anything except to drive people like me and Andrea Truppin off the subway. I met her yesterday at a stoplight on 12th Avenue and 55th Street, as we were on our new commuting vehicles: Rollerblades. Rollerblades. Ms. Truppin, a communications consultant who commutes from the Upper West Side to Wall Street, had given up on mass transit.
"The 1 train just kept getting delayed," she said. "I'd never really been claustrophobic, but I got anxious when we kept stopping between stations. One day I tried going over to the East Side to catch the subway, but there was a police investigation going on there, too. I even went all the way crosstown to catch a ferry on the East River, but that just took too long."
We both knew that skating had its own risks -- probably greater than anything terrorists posed in the subways or the mails. But we also figured that the risks of getting hit by a car were small compared with the immediate benefit of not sitting in a stalled train for half an hour while the police investigated the remnants of a jelly doughnut.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Bayer Seen Breaking Even On Cipro Deal and May Profit
When Bayer agreed to sell 100 million tablets of its anthrax medicine, Cipro, to the government for 95 cents each, Bayer and the Bush administration said the deal assured an ample supply at a very low price.
 But executives at generic drug companies and suppliers of pharmaceutical raw materials say that Bayer is breaking even and may even be making a large profit. And some infectious-disease experts warn that Bayer remains unable to supply enough Cipro if terrorists start releasing anthrax strains that are resistant to other antibiotics. Page A1. 

Hospitals Unprepared for Any Surge
Public health experts and hospital industry officials say that many hospitals are far from ready for a surge of patients in the event of a major terrorist attack. B8.

Microsoft Introduces Windows XP
Microsoft introduced its Windows XP operating system, a product that carries the hopes of reviving sales for the beleaguered personal computer industry. The new operating system arrives amid new signs that the sides in the Microsoft antitrust case remain far apart, even as they are in settlement talks with a court-ordered deadline of Nov. 2. Shares of Microsoft rose $1.24, to $62.56. C5.

The Cost of Heightened Security
Tightened workplace security procedures add significant costs and reduce productivity in an already slowing economy. But economists said the phenomenon was likely to be less of a drag than they had first feared. C2.

Ford Ignition Settlement Approved
A judge approved a proposal by Ford to settle lawsuits in five states by reimbursing current and former owners who replaced flawed ignition systems on millions of vehicles. C2.

Cantor Begins Sending Out Bonuses
Cantor Fitzgerald, the bond trading firm, said that it had begun distributing more than $45 million in bonuses to the families of employees killed at the World Trade Center. B10.

Stocks reversed sharp early losses and finished with solid gains. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 117.28 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,462.90. The Nasdaq composite index gained 43.93 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,775.47. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 14.89 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,100.09. C7.

Head of Accounting Board to Retire
Edmund L. Jenkins, the chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, plans to retire when his five-year term ends in June. Under his chairmanship, the standards board completed a new rule on mergers and other combinations that ended the use of pooling, a form of merger accounting that was harshly criticized for allowing companies to keep the costs of deals off their balance sheets. C2.

Moody's Cut AT&T's Credit Rating
Moody's Investors Service reduced AT&T's credit rating to a level that may make it more difficult to issue commercial paper. C5.

Bankers Agree to Concessions
John J. Mack, the chief executive of Credit Suisse First Boston, has persuaded about 95 investment bankers to tear up contracts that guaranteed them large pay packages regardless of the company's profitability. C7.

Ads Sought in Spite of Bad News
Media companies whose properties provide news coverage are forcefully seeking to persuade marketers and agencies to reconsider a reluctance to advertise alongside the coverage of calamities. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C4.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Jupiter, Internet Research Firm, Is Being Bought by NetRatings

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Jupiter Media Metrix, the Internet research firm that once was one of the pillars of Silicon Alley in New York, agreed yesterday to sell itself to the much smaller NetRatings of Milpitas, Calif., in Silicon Valley.
 The deal values Jupiter at $71.2 million, or $1.95 a share. The company's shares traded as high as $65 in October 1999, but had fallen to 63 cents yesterday before the deal was announced. NetRatings shares closed yesterday at 13.09; its record high had been $53. 
Jupiter Media Metrix was formed in June 2000 as the combination of Media Metrix, which monitors a sample of Web users to tell advertisers and investors which sites are the most popular, with Jupiter Communications, a collection of young analysts that specialized in advising big companies about how to get hip to the Internet.
NetRatings, originally a spinoff of the electronics company Hitachi, was another attempt to measure the audience of Web sites. It combined in September 1999 with a similar effort from A. C. Nielsen, the company that measures television audiences. VNU, the Dutch firm that owns Nielsen, owns 70 percent of NetRatings and will own 58 to 60 percent of the combined company, which has not been named yet.
Jupiter Media Metrix had four times the revenue of NetRatings and its rating service was more widely followed both on Madison Avenue and Wall Street, but NetRatings was more fiscally prudent. NetRatings has actually been increasing its cash reserves, which are now at $335 million. Jupiter has been quickly burning through its remaining cash, which fell from $98 million to $49 million in the first half of this year.
Robert Becker, who was hired in July to be Jupiter's chief executive, said that the company needed to raise another $30 million to $40 million to stay in business long enough to turn a profit. That is even after slashing its payroll to 430 employees from 1,000 at the beginning of the year. 
Mr. Becker said that he had been looking at various deals that could raise that money, but that in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, none was forthcoming. Selling the company to its archrival proved to be his most attractive option.
The companies said there would be layoffs but would not say how many. NetRatings has 140 employees.
