HEADLINE: Twin Towers Job Fair Draws Thousands 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
"Jobs! Jobs! Jobs!" came the call outside Madison Square Garden yesterday, as the city's second Twin Towers Job Expo, conceived to help people who lost jobs as the result of the World Trade Center attacks, attracted 10,000 people seeking one of 13,000 jobs reported to be available from roughly 250 companies represented at the arena.
 Few of those in line needed anyone to tell them how hard it has been to find employment, because the New York economy was weak even before the attacks of Sept. 11. The New York State Department of Labor released statistics yesterday saying that the number of people applying for unemployment insurance last week grew to double the number of a year ago in New York City and New York State. 
 The number of people who have applied for Disaster Unemployment Assistance, a special benefit for city residents who lost job income because of the World Trade Center attack but who are not eligible for regular unemployment benefits, also rose sharply, by 10 percent in the week ended Wednesday, to 24,978 since the disaster. And nationally, a four-week average of unemployment claims rose to its highest level since March 1991, according to the Labor Department in Washington. 
"It's been a slow, painstaking process," one job hunter, David Diamond, 42, said of his four-month search for work since the textile company he worked for closed.
Standing near the end of a line that snaked six times the length of 33rd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, Mr. Diamond said he had heard that more than 4,000 people got jobs at the event last week.
"That can't be right," he said, "but nevertheless I thought I should come and see if a few companies here might interest me."
By the end of the day, city officials reported that the 250 companies taking part in the expo had made 6,217 "prospective hirings" from among the 8,000 people who made it inside. Organizers gave away 2,000 moretickets for priority entry to a third job fair, scheduled for Nov. 15, to people who showed up after the line was cut off at noon.
But both inside and outside the arena, prospects were not all that they seemed. The city reported last week that 4,368 prospective hirings occurred at the first Job Expo, on Oct. 17, from among 6,000 candidates who actually got into the arena. But some participating companies said they probably are going to hire far fewer people than was initially reported.
For example, Buck Consultants, a human resources consulting company that is part of Mellon Financial, was reported by the city last week to have made 30 prospective hires at the first job fair. But Cathy Gushue, director of human resources for the company, said Buck would hire just three candidates -- two administrative assistants and one actuary.
Diane Dooley, a recruiting director for Ernst & Young, said her firm expected to hire five people from last week's Job Expo. Told that city officials said the company reported 10 prospective hires last week, Ms. Dooley replied, "We said we had 10 openings. We did not say we were hiring 10 people to fill those openings."
On the other hand, Duane Reade, the drugstore chain, said it hired 45 people from last week's job fair, twice the number initially reported.
Anthony P. Coles, the deputy mayor whose office planned and oversaw the event, said the numbers of prospective hires reported by the city were compiled from questionnaires filled out by participating companies. Mr. Coles defined a prospective hire as a person to whom a company was likely to make a job offer, but it is not clear how companies defined the term.
Moreover, prospective hires do not directly translate to newly employed individuals, he said. Because each job seeker talked to more than three companies on average, individuals might have gotten multiple offers.
"What the number tells us," Mr. Coles said, "is that there are a lot of candidates coming here who are appealing to employers."
The executives from Ernst & Young and Buck Consultants said the event was well organized. Participating companies, which normally pay $2,000 to $3,500 to take part in events of similar size, were not charged anything. Among those at yesterday's expo were J. Walter Thompson, the advertising agency; New York Life, the insurer; Primerica, the financial services company and Pfizer, the drug maker.
So popular was the first Job Expo that promoters with less than altruistic motives showed up for yesterday's affair.
The sidewalk was thick with people marketing "work at home" schemes, multilevel marketing plans, motivational programs and fee-based job placement services.
Rufus Moody, for example, the man whose cry of "Jobs! Jobs! Jobs!" rang out over Seventh Avenue, actually was seeking candidates for a three- to five-day training program for "professional security guards" that cost applicants $100 to $300 each.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With work hard to come by and unemployment claims on the rise, about 10,000 people showed up yesterday to seek one of 13,000 job openings. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MAYORS; 
Ridge Deflects Pleas to Help The Cities Pay Security Costs

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
Tom Ridge, director of the Office of Homeland Security, turned away pleas from the nation's mayors today for help in paying millions of dollars in overtime to police and firefighters, even as he praised those same people for guarding the "front line of domestic security."
 In the still-nebulous world of homeland defense, the mayors and Mr. Ridge circled each other, agreeing they needed each other, but they were far from figuring out exactly how they would work together. 
 The mayors completed their emergency two-day meeting here by presenting Mr. Ridge with a list of their urgent needs, including money, cooperation on intelligence and help for urban workers who had lost their jobs since Sept. 11. 
For his part, Mr. Ridge said he would be the mayors' best friend in the White House.
"That's why I'm here," he said, "and that's what I want to be."
"This is the place and this is the group where the homeland security chief should be," he said after receiving a standing ovation when he arrived at the lectern.
But he postponed any talk of new aid for local officials until he completed his enormous plan for reorganizing the nation's homeland defenses. And he demurred on the other points like federal aid to shore up security for waterworks and transportation systems and putting the federal government in charge of airport security.
"I promise to be very open-minded once I present my national strategy," Mr. Ridge said and left to another standing ovation.
Undeterred, the mayors said they would go to Congress for money.
All said they were caught in a double bind of losing tax revenues in the economic downturn, which worsened after Sept. 11, while being asked to spend millions for new security that was not part of their budgets.
"We're going to have to get our money somewhere very quickly simply to ensure the financial integrity of our cities," Mayor Bill Campbell of Atlanta said. "They are calling on our police departments, in essence, to work 24 hours a day protecting mosques, water towers, airports."
Atlanta has already spent $15 million in overtime pay since Sept. 11, Mr. Campbell said.
Mayor John Street of Philadelphia said his budget planners warned him that the cost of all of the new security, including capital improvements, would be roughly $60 million.
The first delegation of mayors went directly from their meeting in downtown Washington to Capitol Hill to deliver what they called their "dispatch from the domestic front line."
"We just need reasonable help," Mayor Susan Savage of Tulsa said. "And we expect Congress will want to work with us and free up some money so we can go back to the front lines, whether that turns out to be the airports again or the post offices or just Main Street."
At another hearing, a number of senators agreed with that assertion, questioning the whole notion that the nation's underpaid and overworked nurses and police officers should be performing the front-line duties meant for the military.
"This was not a crime; it was an attack," Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, said. "Why are we relying on these 11 million first responders -- people as overworked as we are -- who were never meant for this new paradigm?"
Instead, Senator Landrieu and Senator Max Cleland, Democrat of Georgia, said the Department of Defense should be in charge.
"I start off taking the position that the Department of Defense is the key for defense of the homeland -- that's where we put our money, our time, our energy," Mr. Cleland said.

HEADLINE: Energy Problems, and Solutions 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Enlightenment on Energy" (editorial, Oct. 22): The 1974 oil shocks led to the first fuel economy standards, resulting in both decreased consumption and imports. But we also saw development of major new domestic sources, including Alaska's North Slope and the Gulf of Mexico. 
 By 2000, those areas supplied 1.7 million barrels of oil a day. Without them (and increased efficiency), imports would have reached 67 percent last year. 
 Fuel economy gains alone cannot control import growth. We need new supplies, including those from the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge's Coastal Plain, believed to contain a mean of 10 billion barrels of technically recoverable oil. 
For the last 24 years, North Slope oil has equaled 20 percent of domestic supply -- and the area's ultimate recovery estimate has more than doubled, to over 20 billion barrels, lending credibility to estimates that Coastal Plain oil can replace Persian Gulf imports for 10 years.

RED CAVANEY
President and Chief Executive
American Petroleum Institute
Washington, Oct. 22, 2001

HEADLINE: Port Authority Moves to Enhance Ferry Service 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has moved to bolster ferry service across the Hudson River in an effort to ease congestion on PATH trains and improve commuter access to Lower Manhattan in the wake of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.
 The agency announced during a meeting of its board yesterday that it had finished $3 million in work to create a new ferry landing on the west side of Lower Manhattan just west of Battery Park. The landing is expected to start operations next week. Within two months the agency expects to complete $5 million in work on another ferry landing on the New Jersey side of the Hudson, just a short walk from the Pavonia/Newport PATH station in Hoboken. 
 Boats using that landing will drop commuters off at three Lower Manhattan ferry landings. The new ferry service is intended to ease overcrowding on the PATH lines to West 33rd Street, which have had severe overcrowding after the shutdown of the World Trade Center PATH station on Sept. 11. 
Delays and lines of commuters switching at 33rd Street for downtown subways "have reached unacceptable levels," said Christopher O. Ward, chief of planning and external affairs for the agency.
The efforts were applauded by Commissioner David S. Mack and Chairman Lewis M. Eisenberg of the Port Authority. Mr. Eisenberg said that one of the agency's "clear missions is to make sure that Lower Manhattan is an economically healthy area again."
According to agency officials and New York City figures, some 27 million square feet of Lower Manhattan office space was either lost or damaged in the Sept. 11 attack. Of the affected businesses, 55 percent moved to temporary space in Midtown and 30 percent moved to New Jersey and elsewhere, while only 15 percent were able to find temporary space in Lower Manhattan.
"Sept. 11 has created new priorities," said Mr. Mack, a New York representative on the bistate agency's board. "It is very, very important that we restore the credibility to Lower Manhattan."
Other members of the board noted that the emergency expenditure of a total of $8 million for ferry operations was coming from a $22 million capital appropriation that was supposed to help expand ferry service throughout the region and relieve congestion on roads and trains.
Some board members feared that these other efforts would "fall off the table," as one put it, in the face of the needs growing out of the Sept. 11 attack. They all conceded that the agency would have to supplement the proposed ferry spending with new funds and did not know from where the money would be drawn.
But the figures on the need for new ferry services were striking. George L. Cancro, director of Port Authority ferry services, said that average weekday traffic had nearly doubled on the ferry services into the city, to 64,500, from 36,000 before Sept. 11. As the "red zone" around the cleanup and search effort shrinks and more businesses in the area move to resume or expand their operations, adequate ferry services for those who previously used PATH trains and other means of travel will be that much more important, officials said.
Currently, most of the ferry operations are run by New York Waterway, which has 35 boats and operates 15 routes from Weehawken, Hoboken and Jersey City to Midtown and Lower Manhattan. The company will operate out of the planned Pavonia/ Newport location, as well as use the just completed landing just below Battery Park, said Arthur Imperatore Jr., president of the company.
Mr. Imperatore's father, Arthur Imperatore Sr., founded the ferry service in 1986 amid skepticism.

HEADLINE: Changed Panama Banks Root Out Terror Funds 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: PANAMA 

 BODY:
When United States officials recently asked Panamanian banks to search for suspicious accounts that might have been used to hide terrorists' funds, responses came quickly. Had the same request been made a year ago, it could have languished for months because of lax banking laws that had landed Panama on an international blacklist.
 A recent overhaul of banking rules has persuaded foreign governments to remove Panama from the list, in time to assure American officials that no accounts linked to Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda terrorist network have been found here. Officials continue to investigate several suspicious corporations, but have yet to find anything illegal. 
 The worldwide hunt for funds stashed away by terrorists in offshore banking havens presents Panama with a fresh opportunity to prove it no longer is the freewheeling haven it had been during the government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The shared goal of cutting off the terror network's financial lifeblood also gives foreign governments leverage in ensuring that Panama's new rules are applied rigorously.
"They are dogged by a long history of neglect and indifference to the banking system," said one diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Panama is going to have to prove itself over time that it is building a credible barrier against illegal financial transactions. We are pushing Panama to do as much as possible."
Banking officials said they have adopted stronger guidelines in the last decade and that Panama's quick response after the Sept. 11 attacks was proof of their dedication.
"When the 11th happened, we immediately got in touch with all banks and said terrorist activities are now on the front page," said Mario de Diego, the executive vice president of the Banking Association of Panama. "We always said we were committed to helping in this fight. In the case of money laundering from drugs, and especially the international activities of terrorism, you need international collaboration. We are open to all collaboration."
Last year, however, Panama's failure to exchange information speedily with foreign governments tracking suspicious accounts was among the factors that landed the country on the uncooperative list of the Financial Action Task Force, a consortium established by the major industrialized nations in 1989.
With a dollar economy and more than 65 banks, Panama has been a popular financial center, especially among Latin Americans. But in the 1980's, Colombian drug cartels began using Panama to launder funds through construction, banks and even withdrawals from automated teller machines.
Banking officials insisted at the time that there was no systemwide money laundering, but Panama's reputation suffered badly during the scandal over the Bank of Credit and Commerce International in 1991, which was involved in laundering funds from drug and arms dealing. The bank was based in England but had an office here.
The decision to blacklist Panama as recently as last year came as a jolt to the banking community, which viewed the criticism as unfair because it did not take into account steps to toughen regulations.
In the past, money laundering had only been considered a crime if it involved narcotics trafficking, and cases were difficult to prove. The new rules expanded the list of money laundering crimes. The government also extended investigative power to other areas, like real estate, as well activities within the free trade zone. It also allowed Panamanian officials to exchange information with foreign investigators.
The effects of these changes were clear in the days after the attacks, when Dalys Teran, the head of Panama's financial analysis unit, met with both her American counterparts and local bankers. Compliance officers at banks posted not only names but photographs of suspects, she said. Traces were put on some transactions, too, but they turned up no evidence of illegal activity.
"Panama cannot afford to have a bad reputation," Ms. Teran said. "We are a service economy. You have to give service but with adequate controls. That is what we are doing."
Panama suffers from a lack of expertise in complex financial crimes within its law enforcement ranks, which can be further hindered by a lack of political will in sensitive cases. American officials have been unhappy in the past when the authorities blocked their efforts to investigate some Americans here with close ties to the Panamanian government.
One change involves the government agency that investigates financial crimes. It no longer has to channel its reports through the offices of high-ranking government officials, a requirement that in the past was seen as a means of quashing politically sensitive cases.
Under the new laws, Ms. Teran said, her office has developed 25 money laundering cases, several of which could soon be ready for prosecution. Under the old laws, she said, only two money laundering cases had been prosecuted in the previous 14 years.

HEADLINE: An Economy Keeping Its Guard Up 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Weyerhaeuser closed part of its saw mill in Barnesville, Ga., last week when some workers discovered a white powder on some new bandsaws they were unpacking. The men were quarantined for several hours until the saw maker assured Weyerhaeuser that the powder was just a rust preventative, not anthrax spores. Yet "the mill kept working," Frank Mendizabal, a Weyerhaeuser spokesman, said.
 Terror-induced jitters have affected a lot of businesses since the World Trade Center and the Pentagon were attacked and anthrax-laced letters began arriving in the mail. John Mills of MyHealthBank, a company that sells health insurance online, says he spends 10 percent of his week in airport delays and fire drills. Janitors and executives alike fumble for ID's to enter their own buildings. Mail can arrive days late, delayed by gloved workers checking for suspicious envelopes. Some people now call recipients to let them know a letter is coming. 
 "It's added hours of worktime to what used to be simple mailings," said Lynn Rubenson, a senior vice president in the San Diego office of the public relations firm of Fleishman-Hillard. 
Steps like these add significant costs and reduce productivity in an already slowing economy. But economists said the phenomenon was likely to be less of a drag than they had first feared. The reason, perversely, is the slowing economy itself.
"The substantial resources required to improve security are readily available without hindering more productive activities," James Glassman of J. P. Morgan Securities wrote in a report this week. "The use of labor and capital resources that would otherwise be idle will minimize the drag on the economy."
Against all fears and maybe against all odds, few companies are reporting huge bottom-line hits from increased security. Despite border backups and air cargo restrictions, raw materials and finished goods are still arriving close enough to schedules to keep from disrupting production lines. And offices and plants are, for the most part, taking the need for added caution in stride.
"Our employees don't perceive the added security as more oppressive or intrusive," said Jeffrey Simek at Merck-Medco, a subsidiary of Merck, the pharmaceutical company, with offices in Franklin Lakes, N.J. "The fun has been zapped, but the work is still getting done."
Even in New York City, where the preponderance of skyscrapers, the reality of mailed anthrax spores -- and, of course, the continued clean-up efforts downtown -- have added to a sense of vulnerability, most companies complain of inconveniences and sadness, not major dislocations.
For example, the MetLife Building near Grand Central Terminal was evacuated on Sept. 13 and 14 after police learned of a bomb threat to the station. Not surprisingly, billable hours for September were down a tad at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, a law firm in the building. But employees worked at home, and the work was done. Randy M. Mastro, a former deputy mayor of New York who is now a Gibson, Dunn partner, said his firm began a trial on Oct. 1, right on schedule. "This just hasn't affected our ability to perform," he said.
There have been costs, of course. "Security traditionally comes at the cost of functionality, and the need to deal with the growing number of threats is certainly causing a loss of function," said Fred J. Rica, a partner in the technology risk services unit of PricewaterhouseCoopers.
A few economists are trying to quantify that loss. Kevin M. Murphy, a professor of economics at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, estimates that the extra costs of stricter security at airports, coupled with the added waiting time at airports, will increase the real cost of air travel by $20 billion.
Still, many superficially unrelated factors have mitigated the impact on business in general. The economic slowdown has cut demand for most items, making it less troublesome if an order takes longer to process, or a product takes longer to make.
Companies are increasingly communicating with customers and suppliers by e-mail and interactive Web pages, so a slowdown in the regular mail is more nuisance than disaster. Many companies were already replacing face-to-face meetings with videoconferences. Personal computers, cellphones and text-messaging pagers have all made it easier for employees to work at home or at airports.
"I turn on my PC at home, and for all practical purposes, I'm sitting at my desk at work," said Richard T. McDermott, chairman of the personnel committee at Clifford Chance Rogers & Wells, another law firm in the MetLife Building.
He is typical, said Samuel B. Bacharach, director of the Institute for Workplace Studies, a New York research center affiliated with Cornell University. "To say that it is inefficient to work at home," he said, "is to give the terrorists more credit for disruption than they deserve."
Nor are antiterrorist measures at companies particularly new. Many businesses long ago installed metal detectors in their lobbies and insisted that employees and visitors alike show identification. Many also routinely scrutinize mail. Weyerhaeuser, for one, has done so for more than five years -- ever since the Unabomber and militant environmental groups like the Earth Liberation Front showed they were willing to use bombs to express their opposition to logging.
Other companies installed security to protect trade secrets. "Fear of corporate espionage has made any number of companies unwilling to have unescorted visitors wandering around," said Andrew McAfee, an assistant professor at the Harvard Business School.
Depressed morale has been harder to tackle. But many companies have deluged employees with e-mails, voice mails and intercom messages to inform them about security and to raise their spirits. At Clifford Chance, eight directors walked down from the 54th floor, the highest of the firm's five floors in the MetLife Building, and reported to all employees that it took them 18 minutes to get out.
No one is certain that bottom lines will remain immune to security issues. Companies are hiring more guards, clerks and consultants.
"You can't burden an economic system with additional overhead and get away scot-free, so productivity will take a systemic long-term hit," said Michael Hammer, a consultant in Cambridge, Mass., whose new book, "The Agenda: What Every Business Must Do to Dominate the Decade" (Crown, 2001), is about managing in tough times.
Others note that any slowdown in operations could erode competitiveness. "American companies pushed ahead of others in the world because of speed and agility, so anything that threatens that could blunt their global edge," said John D. Kasarda, a professor of management at the Kenan-Flagler Business School of the University of North Carolina. Still, most experts expect that the long-term effect will not be severe. Several draw analogies to the oil shocks of the 1970's, when many Americans feared that soaring oil prices would deal a death blow to the United States economy and way of life. Oil prices eventually dropped -- partly because businesses and individuals adopted energy-efficiency measures that many still use today.
"I think businesses will emerge from this period with better ways to invent, make and market their products," said Tom Duesterberg, president of the Manufacturers Alliance, a Washington research group.
Even Mr. Murphy, the economist who quantified the cost of airline delays, is optimistic. "In economics, we assume an ability to adjust," he said. "Airlines will discover it's better to spend $5 more on security than $20 in waiting time. The lines will get shorter, and people will adapt."

HEADLINE: Lead Narrows in Virginia Governor's Race 

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 25 

 BODY:
With Election Day less than two weeks off, the race for governor of Virginia has tightened as voters preoccupied with the war on terror finally take some time to focus on political personalities and issues.
 The Democratic candidate, Mark R. Warner, a wealthy venture capitalist who took an early lead in the campaign, is still ahead of his Republican opponent, former State Attorney General Mark L. Earley. But most polls show Mr. Earley gaining, mainly by accusing Mr. Warner of favoring tax increases. 
 As he makes his final rounds of the state, Mr. Earley has been telling audiences that the momentum has shifted to him. The latest independent polls indicate that he has whittled Mr. Warner's lead in half, to about three percentage points.
Mr. Warner, who says he favors only those tax increases that are approved in voter referendums, contends that his own polls still have him comfortably ahead.
A number of the state's political experts say that although Mr. Earley is a solid conservative in a solidly conservative state, he faces a difficult task in overcoming his opponent's lead, and a continuing struggle to hold on to his voter base in the face of a relentless conservative pitch from Mr. Warner. Just this week, they note, Mr. Earley began running television advertisements to remind supporters that he opposes abortion, even though abortion has hardly been an issue in the race. 
Mr. Warner has put together a basic message that seems to resonate unusually well in this heavily Republican state: he argues that while he is a Democrat, he is a "Virginia conservative." The analysts say the Warner campaign is as well run and financed as any the state has seen in many years. And they note that Mr. Warner is benefiting from a feud over the state budget that has divided Republican leaders and frustrated many voters.
"Mark Warner's support is a lot more solid than Mark Earley's, so the race is not as close as the numbers indicate," said Larry J. Sabato, a University of Virginia political scientist. "Warner's delivering the kind of reassuring, conservative message Virginians like to hear, and he's delivering it at a time when top Republican leaders have been fighting destructively among themselves over how to run a state facing an economic downturn." 
Both candidates are talking about a need for Virginia to have an experienced leader in the months and years ahead. The 47-year-old Mr. Earley argues that as a former attorney general and also a onetime state legislator, he is well positioned to take the helm.
"Mark Warner," Mr. Earley told a women's breakfast rally here on Tuesday, "is just a liberal Democrat who has never held public office, never had any such experience, period."
Mr. Warner, 46, counters by saying that he could never have become a multimillionaire were he not a good manager and that in a state whose economy is in decline, he knows better than a "professional politician" like Mr. Earley how to turn things around.
Mr. Warner has been able to exploit the bitter divisions between the incumbent Republican governor, James S. Gilmore III, and Republican legislative leaders over how to shape and finance the state's annual budget in the midst of an economic downturn. That feud so alienated some Republican voters that they joined with independents to form a group called Virginians for Warner.
The group further embarrassed Mr. Earley by putting up $1 million to help his opponent. (Mr. Warner, who has a personal fortune estimated at $200 million, has raised about $11.5 million in campaign funds, and added $1.5 million of his own money. Mr. Earley has raised $8 million, almost $2.5 million of it sent his way by national Republicans.)
Mr. Earley was embarrassed, too, by a decision from the National Rifle Association, a staunch ally in earlier campaigns, not to endorse either candidate. Mr. Warner took that Earley loss as his own victory and as ultimate proof that his "I'm a conservative too" message on the stump and on television was hitting home.
The race is one of only two for governor this year -- the other is in New Jersey -- and both are seen as possible harbingers of political things to come in 2002. 
Governor Gilmore can serve only a single term under state law.

HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF 

BYLINE:  By Jesse McKinley 

 BODY:
A Series Of Hiccups
 The New York theater had a case of the hiccups this week as several planned productions were delayed or otherwise sidetracked. 
 Lincoln Center Theater said yesterday that a possible February production of "The Last Five Years," the new musical by Jason Robert Brown ("Parade"), was being canceled because producers and Mr. Brown's representatives could not come to an agreement. The musical, about a failed relationship, was to play the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. 
"It's a lovely show, and we're incredibly disappointed we won't be producing it," said Andre Bishop, the theater's artistic director. Neither Lincoln Center officials nor Mr. Brown's lawyer, Mark Sendroff, would comment on reports that Mr. Brown's ex-wife had objected to the show's subject matter.
The replacement is likely to be "The Carpetbagger's Children," by Horton Foote, and to be directed by Michael Wilson. Mr. Wilson, the artistic director of the Hartford Stage, is currently directing "Necessary Targets," a new play by Eve Ensler, and has just won the Princess Grace Foundation Statue Award for sustained excellence. Expect "The Carpetbagger's Children" in March.
There were also changes for "The Retreat From Moscow" by William Nicholson, which had been considered a possibility for the spring. Mike Nichols, who had previously announced an interest in directing and producing the play, has since passed on the project, a development that has allowed other producers to snap it up.
Susan Quint Gallin and Sandy Gallin, her ex-brother-in-law, are the new producers. The team, currently represented by "The Shape of Things" at the Promenade, is talking to a new director, whom Ms. Gallin would not identify, though theater insiders say Daniel Sullivan may be the man for the job.
"We'd love to do it in the spring, but it depends on casting," Ms. Gallin said. Mr. Nichols had planned to cast Ralph Fiennes, Sir Anthony Hopkins and Sinead Cusack; no word yet on their replacements.

Short of Funds
The current challenges facing the Actors' Fund of America provide a good if somewhat chilling illustration of the ripple effect of last month's terrorist attacks on nonprofit institutions connected to Broadway.
Joseph Benincasa, the fund's executive director, said his offices had been flooded since Sept. 11 with emergency requests from actors and other performing professionals seeking help with rent, utility bills and health insurance.
"We were looking at a hard year to begin with," Mr. Benincasa said, citing the economy and other factors. "Now, since Sept. 11, a lot more people are coming to us for help, and a lot more people are asking for funds."
Beyond jobs lost when shows closed, Mr. Benincasa cited the loss of "survival jobs" -- the traditional day jobs like waiting on tables or typing -- as restaurants, hotels and temporary agencies have laid people off. The fund's career counselors are booked through January.
The fund's own fund-raising has also been hurt. It relies heavily on special benefit performances and its annual gala, which was postponed after the attacks. The gala usually generates $600,000; because of increased need and delayed fund-raisers, the fund anticipates a potential shortfall of anywhere from $1 million to $2 million.
"That was money we'd budgeted, spent and planned for," Mr. Benincasa said. 
The fund is accepting tax-deductible donations at (212) 221-7300.

Oldtimers
Try as they might, Heather Matarazzo and Hallie Kate Eisenberg are not normal. (But really, who wants to be normal?)
The two young actresses, ages 18 and 9 respectively, are appearing in the Roundabout Theater Company's production of "The Women," at the American Airlines Theater. But both are better known for roles they created in their, well, youth.
Ms. Matarazzo, cast as Cynthia Nixon's frustrated maid in "The Women," first caused a stir in 1995 when she played Dawn Weiner, the world's most miserable prepubescent, in Todd Solondz's cult film "Welcome to the Dollhouse."
The role, which Ms. Matarazzo won in a cold audition, jump-started the struggling career of the then-11-year-old.
"At first, they didn't think I was going to be able to be ugly enough," Ms. Matarazzo said. "But then they came back to me." The role won Ms. Matarazzo an Independent Spirit Award for best newcomer and led to a half-dozen more movies, including this year's "Princess Diaries."
Ms. Eisenberg, too, has done a few movies ("Beautiful" and, for television, "The Miracle Worker"). But she is perhaps best known for her appearance as the odd spirit-child in a series of ubiquitous Pepsi commercials, capable of channeling any voice in the universe in service of cola sales.
In "The Women," Ms. Eisenberg plays Little Mary, her first stage role. (Well, there was that preschool show, but it was non-Equity.)
How does she find The Theater?
"I love it," said Ms. Eisenberg, who is remarkably poised and polite. "On a movie, people come and go at different times. On a show, though, people come every day. You get to see them every day."
Indeed, that warmth seems apparent between these two, who hug each other a lot and seem generally sisterly. What will they do after the show closes? Well, Ms. Matarazzo will continue seeking roles; she just dropped out of the School of Visual Arts to pursue acting. Ms. Eisenberg, meanwhile, is writing a screenplay. (No kidding. Seriously. She is.)
"It's about three generations in a family," said the 9-year-old. Its title? "Three Generations."

Along the Way
*Martha Plimpton has joined Brian Murray in "Hobson's Choice," the next show at the Atlantic Theater Company. Previews begin on Dec. 18.
*"S.F.," a festival of plays about science fiction and horror, is on now through Nov. 4 at three downtown theaters. Topics include alien abduction, Einstein's dreams, and pumpkin pie. For information: (212) 539-7686.

HEADLINE: A Pragmatic Aid Plan 

 BODY:
The costs of recovering from the World Trade Center attacks are so enormous that many officials cannot imagine how New York City and the state will manage unless the federal government comes through with a huge amount of additional aid. Meanwhile the Bush administration, which has already committed nearly $20 billion for the city, is looking with alarm at suggestions that $50 billion or so more might be necessary. If New York is going to get the help it needs, its leaders are going to have to be both restrained and politically canny in what they ask for.
 At a time when almost every city and state is feeling financially threatened, New York's requests must reflect immediate needs. They must also be directly connected to the terrorist attacks. The rest of the country wants to help the city recover from the unprecedented disaster that everyone saw played out on television. Requesting aid for anything else might be seen as demanding more than New York's fair share. 
 The easiest job is getting federal aid to pay rescue workers and clean up the World Trade Center site. The final bill may well exceed the $20 billion set aside by the president and Congress, but New York does not need it all right now, and almost everyone working on the issue in Washington believes the money will be there when it is required -- either from the original appropriation or through the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
The next problem, economic recovery in Lower Manhattan, is a tricker sell in Congress. Gov. George Pataki, while well intentioned, got off the track earlier this month when he proposed a $54 billion package aimed at projects around the region and the state, from the Second Avenue subway to a railroad in Schenectady. It makes more sense to focus on the area below Canal Street in Manhattan. Senators Charles Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton are working on a promising $5 billion package that would grant tax credits to businesses and residents that stay in or move into the area, along with tax-exempt bonds for rebuilding. The Schumer-Clinton package is small and tightly focused on one area that everyone agrees needs immediate help, especially as businesses are now making decisions about whether to move away. It takes care of only a small part of New York's needs, but those limits should improve its chances of immediate enactment. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Mr. Pataki have proposed similar tax credit schemes, and their support is needed to get the backing of Republicans in Congress.
The biggest challenge is finding money to plug the enormous holes in the state and city budgets that have been caused by the economic consequences of the attack. Mr. Pataki's request that the federal government step in and make up for the lost revenues has met with skepticism, and even some hostility, from the Bush administration and some in Congress. 
The governor was not wrong to advocate a budget aid package, given the fact that the World Trade Center attacks have drained an estimated $9 billion in tax revenues from the city and state over the next 18 months. But the timing of his request seems a little off. The governor and the next mayor will have to work hard to get a consensus in Congress for such aid, perhaps by allying themselves with other mayors and governors whose governments are in the same fiscal straits. More than 40 states have been thrown into deficit because of the economic downturn, and some form of so-called counter-cyclical revenue sharing might be possible if all would support it.
It is most important for all of New York's elected officials to work together and agree on a package rather than squabble among themselves over differing approaches -- a habitual practice in New York's political culture. The tax-credit package being assembled by Senators Schumer and Clinton this week would be a good place to start. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: New York's Senators Outline Plan to Assist Lower Manhattan 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
New York's senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, today released the broad outlines of their plan to spur the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan in the wake of last month's terrorist attacks.
 Mr. Schumer and Mrs. Clinton said the plan was based, in part, on ideas offered by city and state officials as well as business leaders in New York. They said they were still hammering out details but hoped to submit a final package to Congress soon. 
 They said they had not determined the overall cost of the plan. But they estimated that it would provide $2 billion to $5 billion in incentives. 
"Everyone says that downtown is going to need a shot in the arm; otherwise it's not going to recover," Mr. Schumer said.
The plan calls for giving a $3,000 tax credit per employee to any business that agrees to return to Lower Manhattan or set up shop there for the first time. The credit would be offered for up to five years.
The plan also seeks to provide tax-exempt financing to help developers undertake reconstruction of buildings destroyed by the World Trade Center attack. The senators said the plan would allow developers to secure bonds from a government agency that has yet to be identified.
The buyer of the bonds would not be required to pay city, state or federal taxes, a move that would, in turn, result in lower interest rates for the developers. 
The plan would also offer tax credits for up to two years to anyone who maintains a primary residence south of Canal Street. The size of the tax credit, as well as who would qualify for it, has not been determined, according to the senators' aides.
Earlier this week, the Giuliani administration outlined the two main forms of assistance it is seeking from the federal government to help encourage the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan. The plan represents a small portion of the $54 billion that Gov. George E. Pataki has requested. 
Under the city's proposal, businesses that agree to remain or set up shop in Lower Manhattan would receive a $5,000 cash bonus per employee, and developers would have access to tax-free bonds to help replace buildings that were destroyed. The city estimates the cost of reconstruction at $8 billion to $15 billion.
Mr. Schumer said he and Mrs. Clinton had received general commitments of support from the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, and Senator Max Baucus, the chairman of the Finance Committee. 
Mr. Schumer also said he and Mrs. Clinton had received general words of support from the White House, but no specific commitments.

The Bush administration, moving to strike a deal on offensive and defensive strategic arms with Russia, has postponed three antimissile tracking tests that Defense Secretary Donald H. Searchers entered the hull of the raised nuclear sub Kursk, removing the bodies of 3 of the 118 sailors who died when it sank 14 months ago. Officials said the work would continue around the clock until they were sure no more bodies were inside. A12

While Palestinian claims of a massacre appear to be false, a reconstruction of the operation shows how closely the incursions, which Israel described as a police action to round up terrorists, resembled war. HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Microsoft Introduces New Operating System

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
With a concert by the rock singer Sting and the personal thanks of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Microsoft yesterday introduced its Windows XP operating system, a product that carries the hopes of reviving sales for the beleaguered personal computer industry.
 The new operating system arrives amid fresh signs that the sides in the Microsoft antitrust case remain far apart, even as they are in settlement talks with a court-ordered deadline of Nov. 2. 
 The gap stems from the quite different interpretations that Microsoft, the Justice Department and states that joined the suit have of the federal appeals court ruling in June -- and its implications for what sanctions against the company are appropriate.
The appeals court pared back some of a lower-court decision, but it affirmed that Microsoft was a monopolist that had repeatedly violated antitrust laws. The government regards the appeals court ruling as the basis for forward-looking remedies, not merely addressing the specific infractions in the suit, which are a matter of history in the fast-changing software industry. 
Microsoft views the ruling more narrowly. Any sanctions should "take the specific things and remedy those things," Bill Gates, the Microsoft chairman, said at a dinner Wednesday night.
As he reads the appeals court decision, not only did the ruling sweep aside the allegations that Microsoft illegally tied its Internet browser to Windows, the monopoly product, and that it tried to monopolize the browser market, but also "most of the monopoly maintenance was thrown out -- by far."
Microsoft did win a few challenges to the series of charges that the company's tactics were anticompetitive. But the appeals court also affirmed the lower court's finding that Microsoft violated the antitrust laws in its contracts with personal computer makers and with Internet services providers like America Online, as well as in the tactics that it employed with both partners and rivals, including Intel, Apple Computer and Sun Microsystems.
"The core of the case was monopoly maintenance and the core of the case was upheld," said Andrew I. Gavil, a professor at the Howard University law school. "I don't see how you can objectively read the appeals court decision any other way. I would respectfully disagree with Bill Gates's characterization of the ruling."
At another point in the dinner, Mr. Gates was asked if the fact that his father was a lawyer might have somehow helped him deal with the long-running antitrust case. Yes, Mr. Gates replied, "it helps me understand the injustice and the irony of it."
He then went on to say that what is "supergood" about Microsoft is its innovation and the way it has created a wealth of opportunity for other companies in the PC industry, which build hardware and software that works with Windows.
Mr. Gates, in sum, did not sound like someone ready to voluntarily make significant concessions in the way his company does business. Nor, according to his reading of the court ruling, does he think that he should.
The states involved in the Microsoft case announced yesterday that they had hired Brendan Sullivan, a prominent trial lawyer. The State of California is retaining Mr. Sullivan on behalf of the 18 states in the Microsoft case, according to Bill Lockyear, the attorney general of California.
Mr. Sullivan's hiring is seen variously by legal experts as a sign that the states do not expect a settlement or that if the Bush administration settles with Microsoft on terms that the states regard as too lenient, the states are willing to litigate alone to try to obtain tougher sanctions.
At the Windows XP introduction yesterday morning, Mayor Giuliani appeared on the stage of a Manhattan theater and thanked Mr. Gates for deciding to keep the product's coming-out party in New York after the Sept. 11 attacks.
Events sponsored by PC makers and Microsoft, including the Sting concert, were held throughout the city in the last two days. "It shows tremendous confidence in New York," Mayor Giuliani said.
Backed by a marketing budget of more than $200 million, Windows XP will certainly get a lot of attention. But most analysts expect sales to build slowly this year, held back by the economic downturn. 
Nevertheless, Microsoft holds 95 percent of the market for PC operating systems and there are 400 million Windows-based computers in use worldwide. As they age and users upgrade, they will inevitably move to Windows XP.
Microsoft will sell 70 million copies next year, the International Data Corporation estimates, and 101 million in 2003 and 112 million in 2004.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bill Gates, left, Microsoft's chairman, plays a game of "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" with the TV show's host, Regis Philbin. The game was one of several events in New York heralding Windows XP. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: U.S., Awaiting Putin, Delays Missile Defense Tests 

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER and DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
The Bush administration, moving to strike a deal on offensive and defensive strategic arms with Russia, has postponed three antimissile tracking tests that Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today might be interpreted as violating the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.
 The announcement came only four days after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, speaking alongside President Bush in Shanghai, said the two nations had an "understanding that we can reach agreements," a comment widely interpreted to mean that they were headed toward a major amendment of the treaty. 
 President Bush and his senior national security advisers have maintained that the treaty is wildly out of date -- Mr. Bush used the world "dangerous" in Shanghai -- and must be drastically rewritten or scrapped. Mr. Rumsfeld's announcement today appeared to be intended to give Mr. Bush maximum negotiating flexibility in the days leading up to Mr. Putin's arrival here, on Nov. 12, for a three-day meeting that may result in an accord redefining the strategic relationship between the two countries. 
On Wednesday, Mr. Bush met with the Joint Chiefs of Staff and his national security team on the other element of the equation: a review of the nuclear posture of America that may include proposals for large cuts in its arsenal of strategic weapons. 
The White House will most likely describe that proposal to Russia in the next few days, to meet Mr. Putin's demand that missile defense be linked, at least loosely, with cuts in offensive arsenals.
At a Pentagon news briefing today, Mr. Rumsfeld said that three missile defense tracking tests -- two that had been scheduled for Wednesday and one for Nov. 14 -- were postponed while discussions between the two presidents are under way.
"We have said we will not violate the treaty while it remains in force," said Mr. Rumsfeld, regarded as the administration's most unwavering advocate of a policy to "move beyond" the treaty. "In recent days, to keep from having it suggested that we might not be keeping that commitment, we have voluntarily restrained our ballistic missile defense test program."
Two senior White House officials said today that while the idea of delaying the test originated with Mr. Rumsfeld, it was, in the words of one, "heavily coordinated here." 
"There was no need to do something that some in Russia might view as provocative, especially at this delicate moment," one official said.
While a series of meetings with Russia are planned before Mr. Putin's visit, it seems increasingly likely that whatever deal emerges -- if a deal emerges -- will be negotiated by the two presidents next month. 
Mr. Rumsfeld's announcement today may have served two political purposes. It allowed the outspoken defense secretary to put the Defense Department in sync with the White House's clear desire to reach an agreement with Russia next month. But it also served as a caution to advocates of the missile defense system that unless the treaty is abandoned, expanded or neutered, he cannot go ahead with the kind of aggressive testing necessary to deploy an effective system.
Senior administration officials confirmed that Mr. Rumsfeld had written to Mr. Bush in recent days to address his desire for accelerated research into missile defenses.
"The note expressed the opinion that we should make the public aware of the fact that we held back because of the treaty," a senior administration official said. "The note expressed the opinion that we should make the public aware that we continue to be constrained by the A.B.M. Treaty."
One administration official, who would not speak for attribution, said today: "I think there have always been some who just wanted to get out of that treaty -- period. The broader view has been to get relief from it. Not partial relief. Not limited relief. Not constant renegotiations, but substantial relief. If we find a mutually acceptable arrangement with the Russians to move beyond the treaty, fine. It could take a variety of different forms. But if we are unable to get something that is mutually acceptable, we will exercise our right to withdraw."
Mr. Bush, who has called the treaty a "relic of the cold war," did not threaten imminent withdrawal from the pact when he met with Mr. Putin on Sunday in Shanghai, officials said.
Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, said that "no deadlines" were given to Mr. Putin at the meeting. However, Mr. Bush reiterated his dedication to missile defenses, saying that the attacks of Sept. 11 made it all the more important that the United States be protected against a full range of potential threats. Both sides understand that the deadline for reaching a deal is nearing, with a pending schedule of missile tests that would violate the treaty.
Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said in an interview today that he sensed a significant change in administration policy in favor of a negotiated accommodation with Russia. "I think that the odds are they are going to work out a deal," said Mr. Levin, who favors missile defense testing, but within the limits of the treaty. 
Mr. Levin said the value of the postponed tests was "very, very slight, compared to the negative fallout that would occur if we pull out of an arms control treaty with a country whose support we surely want in Afghanistan and with whom, hopefully, we will have a whole new relationship."
All of the postponed tests would utilize an Aegis radar on a surface ship to track a ballistic missile and interceptor, and collect other data. No previous test has involved such a shipborne component, which is banned by the treaty. A Pentagon panel, the Compliance Review Group, which has to certify that all current work remains within the bounds of the treaty, advised against going ahead with the test.
Even so, Wednesday's test is now scheduled for late November or December, but without using the shipborne radar, said Lt. Col. Richard Lehner, spokesman for the Ballistic Missile Defense Office. 
President Bush's view of the A.B.M. Treaty appears to have evolved since the campaign, when he came out wholly in favor of scrapping the pact. But after meeting Mr. Putin in Genoa in July, Mr. Bush ordered his national security team to link the consultations -- not negotiations -- on missile defenses and a major reduction of both nations' arsenals. Mr. Bush envisions a framework of relations that would dispose of treaties and seek to bind the two countries more broadly and more loosely through trade and economic and military ties.

HEADLINE: In Yet Another Mystery, North Korea Has Suddenly Turned Testy 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 26 

 BODY:
In an unusual statement even for a country known for frequent rhetorical excesses, the North Korean government said today that it was no longer interested in dialogue or improved relations with the United States.
 The comment in the official North Korean government newspaper was the latest in a string of similar statements that most South Korean analysts have tried to shrug off but that seem to have been prompted by the turn of events since Sept. 11. 
 Early after the attacks, North Korea, one of the most tightly sealed countries in the world, seemed to go out of its way to express sympathy, even showing signs of understanding for American military reprisals. 
Lately, though, the government in Pyongyang has all but halted cooperation with South Korea. It has canceled previously scheduled reunions of families separated by the heavily armed border between the two countries and sharpened its tone toward the Bush administration.
The most common explanation for the recent flush of North Korean hostility has involved comments made by President Bush during the Asian economic summit last week in Shanghai.
There, he called on the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, to lead his country toward greater engagement with the United States and South Korea. "This is a moment in history where he can prove his worth," Mr. Bush said.
The president then warned against threats from the North, saying, "We will be prepared to defend and stand side by side with our longtime friend, the South Korean people."
Today, North Korea responded in print by saying its people are determined to make Mr. Bush "pay dearly for his remarks."
But the statement did not seem to raise concerns in South Korea. "We believe the recent North Korean responses are largely rhetoric, rather than a substantive policy response," said Kim Euy Taek, a spokesman for the South Korean foreign ministry. 
"Because of the nature of the North Korean regime," he added, "one has to read between the lines, and we believe that North Korea is still interested in dialogue with the United States."
Analysts of North Korean affairs note that Sept. 11 has changed the context for diplomacy from the North, which Washington still classifies as a terrorist state.
Until the final days of the Clinton administration, North Korea was working feverishly to engineer its removal from Washington's terrorist list, which would help the country qualify for financial aid from organizations like the World Bank.
Condemning the World Trade Center attack may have been a gesture aimed at remaking North Korea's image. Yet the most important clients for North Korea's weapons exports continue to be found in Central Asia and the Middle East and have included Iraq and Pakistan.
For this reason, beyond its strong ideological differences, North Korea is uncomfortable hewing close to American positions. "Right now, North Korea doesn't want to appear to be too inclined toward any party, whether it is the U.S. or the Islamic countries," said Park Young Ho, analyst at the Korea Institute for National Unification Relations, in Seoul.
He urged the United States to ignore today's editorial comment. "Washington must offer North Korea a wide-open door to resume talks at any time, without preconditions," he said. "That is the best hope for improvement in inter-Korean relations, which has benefits for the United States itself."

HEADLINE: Talks Fail to Entice Montenegro to Stay Yugoslav 

BYLINE:  By CARLOTTA GALL

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 26 

 BODY:
Long-awaited talks between the presidents of Yugoslavia and of the tiny independent-minded republic of Montenegro broke off today without agreement on how to run a federal Yugoslav state, and the two leaders said Montenegro must hold a referendum on independence next spring.
 "We have tried today to bring closer our two platforms and we concluded that this is not possible," Vojislav Kostunica, the Yugoslav president, told reporters after meeting with Milo Djukanovic, the Montenegrin president. 
 "The public in Montenegro will give its opinion on this issue," he said. "We have concluded that this should come as soon as possible." 
Mr. Djukanovic said the two sides "agreed that there is no need to develop arguments any more, to waste time."
He said his government would start talks with opposition parties in Montenegro to organize a referendum, "to see what is the mood in Montenegro." The poll should take place in the spring, he added.
Serbia and Montenegro are the only remaining republics in the truncated state of Yugoslavia. Relations between them have long been strained by Montenegro's rejection of current federal arrangements and its push for independence.
Mr. Djukanovic made a strong bid for independence for his coastal republic of 650,000 people immediately after the fall of the former Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic, just over a year ago. But he has encountered opposition from European powers and the United States, and his plan only managed to win the support of some 50 percent of voters in Montenegrin general elections in April.
Mr. Kostunica and the other leaders of the reformist alliance now in power in Serbia have supported keeping the two republics together in one state but have repeatedly said Serbia will respect the decision of the Montenegrin people.
European states are worried that a change in borders within the Balkans could provide a precedent for others. Kosovo, still formally part of Serbia, wants independence, as do many Serbs living in the Serbian-held part of Bosnia.
Mr. Kostunica said that he and Mr. Djukanovic had agreed in their talks that the people of Serbia would not be consulted on the issue of Montenegrin independence and that it would be a matter only for the Montenegrins. People in Serbia have proved largely indifferent to the fate of Montenegro, and there is even growing impatience on the question, with some arguing that the issue is delaying reforms and economic development.
Although nominally a federal state, Yugoslavia has operated essentially as two separate countries for some time. Two years ago, Montenegro declared the German mark legal currency, and the Yugoslav dinar is now barely accepted in the republic. The Yugoslav Army, commanded from Belgrade, remains the only institution that operates across the two republics.
Mr. Djukanovic has for the last year sought a "union of independent states." He has said he wants Montenegro to have its own seat at the United Nations. After today's talks, Mr. Djukanovic repeated his determination to lead Montenegro on its own path. "It is impossible to establish the harmonious functioning of two disproportionate states like Serbia and Montenegro within the scope of one state," he said.
Montenegro broke with Serbia in 1994 and under the rule of Mr. Djukanovic won enthusiastic support from the West while it was seen as a plucky opponent of Mr. Milosevic's rule. Since Serbia's return to international acceptance, however, Montenegro has lost favor in the West and been criticized as having weak democratic institutions and serving as a haven for corruption and smuggling.

HEADLINE: Confidence Of Consumers Is Up a Bit, Survey Shows 

BYLINE:  By Reuters

 BODY:
Consumer sentiment improved slightly in October, a survey by the University of Michigan showed yesterday, but economists warned that confidence remained fragile. 
 The university's closely watched sentiment barometer rose to 82.7 in October from 81.8 last month, matching analysts' forecasts. But sentiment deteriorated in the last two weeks from the midmonth reading of 83.4, in line with weekly surveys and showing there was a risk consumer optimism could again erode should bioterrorism spread. 
 "Household assessments of economic conditions remain fragile," said Steven Wood, an economist with FinancialOxygen, adding that confidence levels were "sharply below where they were just a year ago."
Evidence that consumers remain wary was provided by a separate report on housing. The Commerce Department said sales of new homes fell 1.4 percent in September, showing that the once-resilient housing industry is beginning to falter.
New-home sales dropped to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 864,000 in September from the revised rate of 876,000 in August, the Commerce Department reported.
Still, the sales pace exceeded the forecasts of many economists.
"Yes, it didn't drop quite as much as expected, but it is a sign that home buyers are more hesitant about purchasing a new or existing home," said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist for PNC Financial Services Group in Pittsburgh.
New-home sales rates varied by region. The sales pace tumbled 26.6 percent in the Northeast but rose 21.2 percent in the Midwest. The rate fell 8.2 percent in the West and 1.4 percent in the South.
The University of Michigan consumer sentiment survey is based on roughly 500 telephone interviews with Americans across the country. The midmonth reading captures roughly 250 of that month-end total.
The current conditions index, which gauges views of the present financial situation, fell to 94.0 in October from 94.6 in September. The midmonth reading was 92.1.
The expectations index, which tracks attitudes about the coming year, rose to 75.5 in October from 73.5 in September.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Rally in Shares of Military Companies Lifts Blue Chips

BYLINE:  By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose yesterday, helped by a rally in military stocks in expectation of a huge government order for fighter jets, but technology stocks slipped on a dim sales outlook from the fiber optics maker JDS Uniphase.
 Most market indexes, closing out one of the busiest weeks of the third-quarter earnings season, surpassed levels before the Sept. 11 attacks. Wall Street is betting that the tax cuts from the government and the Federal Reserve's rate cuts will bolster the lagging economy and stimulate profit growth for corporate America in the coming months. 
 "The stock market is six months ahead of the economy," said Phil Foreman, who helps oversee $1.3 billion for Evergreen Investment. "There's no doubt we're in a bad recession now, but that's old news. We should focus on the probability of a recovery in 2002." 
Companies have reported the worst earnings in a decade -- down almost 22 percent -- but Wall Street is unfazed. For now, investors are jumping into stocks battered by a slide that has gone for a year and a half.
"We've had tax stimulus, the biggest interest rate cuts in a long time and an 18-month bear market," said Joseph Williams, a portfolio manager with the Commerce Trust Company, which oversees $10 billion. "Looking out a year, things are going to be much better."
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 82.27 points, or 0.9 percent, to close at 9,545.17, bolstered by the fighter jet engine maker United Technologies.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.52 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,104.61. 
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index slipped 6.51 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,768.96.
For the week, the S.& P. 500 advanced 2.9 percent, the Nasdaq rose 5.8 percent and the Dow gained 3.7 percent.
Military stocks rallied in advance of Washington's selection of the Lockheed Martin Corporation over the Boeing Company to build its next-generation fighter jet in a program that could be worth more than $200 billion, the richest bonanza in military history.
Lockheed rose $1.02, to $49.92, while Boeing gained $1.78, to $37.68. United Technologies, which makes engines for both companies, surged $2.54, to $57.01.
The fiber optics components maker JDS Uniphase posted a steep loss for the quarter and said it expected sales to drop further as it completed a revamping to survive a downturn in the telecommunications industry. JDS fell $1.19, to $8.77.
VeriSign, which provides Web address and security services, fell $10.52, to $42.82, after Bear, Stearns downgraded the stock, saying deterioration in the company's domain name business may hurt profits.
Amgen rose $1.20, to $59.45, after it reported that earnings rose 5 percent. Amgen, a biotechnology company, said it expected double-digit earnings for the year.
Investors paid little heed to the latest economic news. A government report showed new-home sales fell 1.4 percent in September, to their lowest since August 2000 as the weak economy weighed on the housing sector. September's seasonally adjusted annual rate of 864,000, however, exceeded the expectations of analysts polled by Reuters, who had forecast a rate of 856,000.
The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index rose to 82.7 in October from 81.8 in the previous month, as expected, indicating that consumers shook off the gloom from the terrorist attacks and rising joblessness.
Treasury prices rose yesterday. The 10-year Treasury note gained 5/32, to a price of 103 25/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.52 percent from 4.54 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 7/32, to 101 19/32. The bond's yield declined to 5.27 percent from 5.28 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: North Bend Journal; 
Seeing Treasure in an Oregon Wreck

BYLINE:  By The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH BEND, Ore. 

 BODY:
All that remains of the freighter New Carissa is 2,300 tons of rusting steel: a severed engine room leaning heavily to starboard and a crane mired in the breakers near the passage to Coos Bay.
 They are just a shadow of what was for some time the region's most notable tourist attraction. 
 For North Bend, a town of 9,500 suffering from downturns in fishing and logging, the New Carissa was 639 feet of economic stimulus when it ran aground in February 1999 while en route to Coos Bay. Hotels and restaurants in North Bend and nearby filled to capacity with tourists, reporters and salvage experts. 
The townspeople gathered on hills overlooking the bay as the ship was broken by surf, then set on fire with napalm to burn off excess fuel oil.
"Right then it was kind of hot and heavy," one North Bend resident, Rod Baker, recalled.
Now, two and a half years into a stalled salvage operation, the ship is a shadow of its former self. The forward two-thirds of the hull were long ago towed 300 miles to sea and sunk.
Gov. John Kitzhaber sees the remainder as an eyesore on unspoiled public land, and has been adamant that it be removed. Green Atlas Shipping, the Panamanian company that owns the New Carissa, is drafting an environmental impact report for any remaining salvage options. 
But away from the state capital, Salem, and closer to the South Coast communities around the wreck, Oregonians sound increasingly hesitant to dispose of their new landmark.
"My personal opinion on the matter is they should just leave it," said Mr. Baker, who manages a dune-buggy rental company. "This isn't going to hurt anything; if anything it's going to attract more tourists in here. To this day, I get tourists inquiring about it."
Mr. Baker's business boomed after the wreck. He shuttled reporters to and from the site on a winding road of soft sand, in a converted school bus. The bus still makes the same run for large groups.
The sand road, almost impassible in summer, may be the New Carissa's way out. Most agree any salvage operation must go over land, which would require a temporary pier out to the wreck and a more substantial road over the sand. The wreck would be dismantled. The pieces would then have to cross a delicate coastal ecosystem, over land controlled by two state agencies and the federal Bureau of Land Management.
Because of environmental concerns, it will be at least two years before new salvage efforts can begin. That is just fine with Sharon Powell. She still displays four versions of New Carissa shirts in her North Bend silkscreening shop. 
"Can you send another ship and ground it?" she asked. "This town was hopping. It was actually one of the best times I've had in my life."
There is no formal effort to save the New Carissa in North Bend. But, without fail, it comes up at Chamber of Commerce meetings, and someone usually stands up to defend the broken ship's right to rest in peace. Receptionists at the local visitors center direct people there as readily as to a golf course or lighthouse. As one local marketing agent put it, "Everybody associates Coos Bay with the New Carissa."
A July report from Green Atlas Shipping agreed. "Shipwrecks have an appeal about them, as evidenced in local and state publicity material and restaurant menus," the company's salvage consultant wrote in response to lingering concerns over threats to wildlife. The state, dissatisfied, hired its own consultant.
The wreck has caused extensive harm. Clausen Oysters, a locally owned company, sued Green Atlas Shipping over oil-damaged harvesting grounds. Clausen lost most of its customers. And a federal report showed that oil killed 2,358 coastal birds, including 262 marbled murrelets, an endangered species. Green Atlas Shipping has already spent well over $30 million for recovery.
Small amounts of oil are almost certainly still inside the wreck, but no oil has been found on the beaches for more than two months.
Oregon is protective of its beaches, all of which are public property. But the coast is dotted with older wrecks visible at low tide. Alan Hoffmeister, a spokesman for the Bureau of Land Management, thinks the most recent should be folded into the landscape.
Surveying the wreck in the coastal winds, Mr. Hoffmeister, like many in North Bend, was at peace with the ship. "Over time, the sea will reclaim it, bit by bit," he said.

(Doug Beghtel/The Oregonian) Map of Oregon highlighting North Bend: The New Carissa wreck attracted more tourists to North Bend, Ore.
