LENGTH: 2451 words

HEADLINE: Art/Architecture; 
Power, Imagination And New York's Future

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
HOW great is New York. Even amid uncertainty, a stroller in midtown can walk through the door of, say, the Royal Athena Galleries on East 57th Street and fall back into the mythology of the ancient Mediterranean world.
 They call the merchandise here ancient art, but in fact it is ancient religion. Freud, who collected statuettes like those displayed at Royal Athena, called them "my dirty gods." The phrase was a double entendre. Some of the miniatures had been unearthed on archaeological digs and were stained by age and filth. For Freud, they also represented society's capacity to manage the most primitive human drives by incorporating them into daily cultural practice. Psychoanalysis aimed to be a new management system -- a new religion, if you like -- for modern, scientific times. Society had buffed up the little gods and called them classical antiquities. Freud showed how the tiny terrors keep popping up in our psyches. 
 It's shocking to be reminded how new modern times are. Power goes down, phones are cut out, elevators stop running, music stops and the rescue of a modern city begins to resemble the excavation of an ancient one. One half expects figures of Persephone, Osiris and Dionysus to be uncovered with the remains of the terrorists' victims. Actually, they're already here. Now called death, regeneration, separation and continuity, they're circulating inside grief-stricken minds. 
Power, power, who's got the power. Since the terrorist attack, groups of architects and planners have been working on concepts for rebuilding Lower Manhattan and for other projects, like improved regional transportation, from which the financial district would benefit. But the groups have been operating in a void. At this writing, no city or state agency has been named to oversee a rebuilding effort. The groups hope to be ready when the politics are sorted out.
Even if their efforts come to nothing, they are already an important part of cultural history. The last six weeks have witnessed the rapid formation of an archaeological record: this is how some New York architects responded to a local and global crisis. If the desire to rebuild the financial district becomes a political reality, this record should be taken into account.
Less than two weeks after the disaster, a coalition was formed by three private professional organizations: the New York City Partnership, the Real Estate Board of New York and the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects. Now called the NYC Infrastructure Task Force, the coalition is directed by a committee that includes executives from leading real estate companies and corporate architecture firms familiar to readers of real estate news.
The Infrastructure Task Force can be reached at www.nycrebuild.org. It has been fascinating to follow the evolution of this Web site. Public relations filters have been in heavy use since the site went up. "Infrastructure" is an addition, and possibly a diversion. Nobody doesn't love infrastructure. There is also a new disclaimer: "It is not the intention of the task force to propose specific designs." Perhaps the intention is to be seated at the table later, when design commissions are passed around? 
The composition of the group's executive committee is a drastically shortened version of the list that appeared only a week ago. At that time, the committee was a Who's Who of major real estate developers and corporate architecture firms. The architecture firms included Fox & Fowle, Hellmuth, Okata & Kassabaum, Skidmore Owings & Merrill, and Kohn Pederson Fox. Even in its pared-down form, the committee recalls an Egyptian tomb painting. It is a hierarchical power structure whose members anticipate the arrival of the Ka or other magical intervention -- some turn of political and economic events -- that will throw the switch and allow the current to flow. 
JEAN GARDNER, a historian and theorist at Parsons School of Design, has lately been urging students and colleagues to go back to the history of medieval Florence, when the city's population had been decimated by plague. Survivors didn't know where to turn for authority. They had to make things up as they went along. They were very good at making things up. Before long, they made up the Renaissance.
"They" were mainly two groups of people: artists and politicians. I urge upon readers Lauro Martines's book "Power and the Imagination." If you can't obtain the book, just keep the title in mind. The interaction between these two groups establishes a good framework for evaluating the Infrastructure Task Force.
The original Web site revealed that the imagination has no place in this power structure. The group's executive committee, for example, broke down into two groups: developers and architects. Superficially, these groups might be taken to represent, respectively, power and the imagination. If you set our imagineers next to Florence's, however, the New York lineup was pure stand-up tragedy. 
Florence team: Brunelleschi (the Duomo, Spedale degli Innocenti; Santo Spirito), Vasari (the Uffizi), Michelozzo (San Marco); Michelangelo (Laurentian Library), Alberti (Palazzo Rucellai), etc., etc.
New York team: Skidmore Owings & Merrill (Worldwide Plaza); Fox & Fowle (Conde Nast Building); Kohn Pedersen Fox (U.S. Courthouse, Foley Square ); Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum (Federal Office Building, Foley Square), etc., etc.
It would be cruel to tax the New York team with a 21st-century renaissance. 
Initially, the task force Web site spoke of the need for "the city's architecture and planning community to speak with one voice." This has been rephrased. The revised goal of the task force is to "establish the framework that will allow planning, design and construction to move forward while allowing concerned constituencies to have a voice." (An early, unposted Statement of Purpose recommends "pragmatic implementation strategies that engage concerned parties before they coalesce into opposition.") These are political, not cultural, concepts. People of creative temperament don't think this way.
There is no such thing as an architecture and planning community in New York. There are some leading architecture schools here. There are museums that regularly present architecture exhibitions; nonprofit groups that sponsor shows, lectures and panels; hundreds of small architecture studios where good work is being done; and major outlets of the design press. Not least, there is a large public audience for contemporary architecture that has grown in size and sophistication in recent years. The architectural culture centered in New York has begun to rival that of many other cities around the world.
Yet the corporate firms who want to speak for the city's architecture and planning community are not part of that culture. They belong to corporate culture. In business terms, they are "professional service producers." With an average 300 to 450 employees, a corporate firm typically provides planning, design and construction documents, and in some cases engineering and interiors, for large-scale office buildings. None of these firms can claim credit for enlarging the public's interest in contemporary design. At best their work is out of touch. Architecture has moved light years away from the retrogressive focus-group sensibility embraced by corporate firms. 
The Sept. 11 attack threw into stark relief the chasm that exists between contemporary architecture and the corporate firms listed at the top of the task force hierarchy. Over here, we've got this messy, fragmented, all-over-the-place architectural culture. Over there, we've got these folks who want to speak, in one voice, for New York's architecture and planning community. Over here, Imagination. Over there, Power. Never in the city's history have these forces been so far apart. This is the crisis the city's architects now face.
In the past, it was possible to defend retrogressive architecture by asserting that the public found it pleasing. Architects should try harder to accommodate popular taste, it was believed. People were bored with International-style glass boxes. This line of thinking was exhausted some time ago. There is a growing public appetite for work with the energy to lead popular taste, not meekly follow it. Last summer, people were not breaking down doors to get into the Congress for the New Urbanism's weekend gathering in New York. They were lining up to see the show on Frank Gehry's work at the Guggenheim Museum. They were aroused by work that, like Wright's, or Brunelleschi's, found a way out of the box.
Why should this public, which takes pride in New York's image as the world's cultural beacon, be compelled to settle for cast-stone boxes? Because developers are comfortable with them? Because politicians, who depend on developers' financial support, are comfortable with them? Because corporate architects, who are dependent on developers' good graces, have fooled themselves into thinking that their work is not inferior to products of the imagination but simply different from them? Over here, developers, politicians, corporate architects and their clients. Over there, the public. That's another way to state the crisis.
We mustn't let fundamentalists scare us away from the metaphysics of urban space. They're not the only people who are entitled to talk about protective forces, angels, saints, benign interventions, duendes, dirty gods and clean ones. These entities are our neighbors. They're familiar faces to all of us who live down in Lower Manhattan.
The best thing about the financial district is that the New York Stock Exchange is housed in a pagan temple. Look up. The skyline is as packed as Freud's cabinet with ancient religious icons. There, atop the J. P. Morgan building, at 23 Wall Street, is a reproduction of the Mausoleum in Halicarnassus (what is now Bodrum in southwest Turkey), one of the Wonders of the Ancient World. The Cities Service building, at 70 Pine Street, bears aloft a quartz crystal cube. A gold pyramid caps the summit of 40 Wall, the former Bank of the Manhattan Company. A Roman brazier once flamed atop the Standard Oil Building, at 26 Broadway. The Gothic arches of the Brooklyn Bridge rival those of Chartres. If we want to talk about rebuilding downtown, let's start by putting the golden Spirit of Communication back atop the old AT&T Building, at 195 Broadway.
There are totems down here on the street, too: Palm Pilots, laptops, reflections in shop windows, ticker-tape parades, press conferences on City Hall steps, eyeglass frames at Lenscrafters, factory-fresh digital cameras, still in the box, designer suits at Century 21. Why come here if not in search of glamour, glory and gold? There is nothing shameful about such fantasies. In ancient times, temples were built to them. The contemporary imagination can barely function without them.
In certain fields, like product design and advertising, corporations can be as imaginative as you like. Corporate architecture, however, is seldom one of those areas. This has not always been the case. In 1954, Gordon Bunshaft and Henry Dreyfuss stuck a safe in the window of Manufacturer's Bank. The result was one of the most striking images in 20th-century architecture: a glass temple dedicated not to money but to the desire for whatever lies just out of reach. It has been a long time, however, since corporate architects were capable of such brilliant gestures.
This is what we're reminded of when we look at the lineup of firms on the Infrastructure Task Force Web site. It's a class portrait of architects who've put corporate marketing strategy where imagination ought to be. They are at most a production system waiting for the idea people to show up.
Just thinking about architecture in relation to the events of Sept. 11 is a major imaginative challenge. People died on that site. Even if their bodies are removed to Staten Island, this is where 6,000 people lost their lives. Corporate culture has no way of dealing with this. In corporate culture, no one ever dies. Everyone is young and glowing. The older we get, the younger we look. The fear of death is thus forestalled. Yet here is death.
Corporate America has encountered similar problems in the past: product recalls; class action suits; structural failures; hazardous wastes. It will find ways to deal with this, too. Time and space will be found to organize a competition to design a memorial. The making of memorials, in fact, has lately become an industry itself. Consultants will be enlisted from Hiroshima, Vienna and Oklahoma City. The memorial and new office towers will be artfully combined. There will be something for everyone. Everything will have been thought about, except thought itself.
There is something comforting, therapeutic, perhaps even divine about the determination to carry on. Only maniacs want the economy to fall apart. Only nut cases want cities to crumble, modernity to shrivel up, dreams to die. Even with the smoke still heavy in the air, it's desirable to live inside the world's most powerful economic engine. That desire is intrinsically healthy.
But the terrorist attack did not just create a crisis; it also exposed one. There is a cultural contradiction between the aims of corporate architects and the needs of the city they claim to represent. Here is money, here is death. Carrying on can be traumatic, even violent, as well as healing. The imagination thrives on such contradictions. The inclination of the status quo is to deny their existence, or to trivialize them into problems of design. 
The Florentines embraced the contradictions of their day. The result was humanism. Through learning, the powerful undertook to support the imaginative. Arts formerly considered satanic were allowed free expression. Creativity was back. Life was affirmed. Princes didn't pretend to be artists. They hired artists. And artists didn't have to wear suits. To paraphrase Iris Murdoch, artists had the dirty, Orphic job of venturing down into the dark, hellish regions where ideas and images are formed. They came back with flawless beauty.
A sophisticated local and international audience is prepared to see how a great modern city could possibly wrap its imagination around money and death, ice cream and fate, success and terror. That audience is willing to wait. There is no rush to satisfy its expectations, certainly not while the world is still at war. The city is not a video game. Eros and Thanatos are in the air, along with heroism, connection to others, sacrifice, self-deception, grandiosity, paranoia and greed. At this early date, why should we think that any of these drives are ready to be contained?

HEADLINE: REBUILDING; 
Include Community

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Herbert Muschamp's excellent "fantasy" on how civic groups compile development design proposals is a painfully real description of discussions about rebuilding the World Trade Center site "A Rush to Complete Plans for Downtown," Oct. 14 . 
 Our collective strength as a nation and as New Yorkers is rooted not in power or tower, but in the love evidenced in the rescue efforts. 
Community breeds such devotion. Neighborhoods, not architectural statements, create bonds among people. Neighborhood residents, workers and visitors share needs, pleasures, adversities, celebrations and commemorations.
Instead of replacement, we can and should expand on a trend well underway in lower Manhattan, where an influx of residential development is transforming the area from a nighttime desert to a vibrant neighborhood of around-the-clock activity. To design a multipurpose locale with community creation as its driving force presents a far more arduous architectural challenge than that of attempting to scrape the sky.

MARY BRENDLE
Manhattan

The writer is a former chairwoman of Community Board 4 in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM; 
The SandwichGeneration Takes a New Gulp

BYLINE:  By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
MY generation is one of labels. Around my parents' house, we were called brats, then baby boomers. A few years ago, we became the sandwich generation, because we took care of our young children while assisting our elderly parents. Well, now it's time for another label, because our adult children, out of work and broke, are moving back home.
 How about the Dagwood sandwich generation? 
 "A lot of my clients are taking care of their parents and taking care of their kids," said Larry P. Ginsburg, a financial planner at Associated Planners Investment Advisory in Oakland, Calif. "Many of them who thought they would be empty nesters are finding out that their kids have not been able to establish a career as fast as they had hoped."
A close look at the last census shows that older children have been clicking their ruby slippers together for a while. Some 10.5 percent of young adults aged 25 to 34 were living at home last year. If you look only at the 25-to-29 group, the percentage rises to 12.1.
And the numbers could grow. Companies have announced hundreds of thousands of layoffs this year; more than a half-million people have filed unemployment claims since Sept. 11 alone. Steven W. Kaye, president of the American Economic Planning Group in Watchung, N.J., says young people who are just starting out may be hit especially hard. "The children don't have the euphoria of their job prospects that they had a year ago," Mr. Kaye said. "That tide has changed dramatically."
Even my wife, Christine, who worked a few blocks from the World Trade Center, was laid off less than two weeks after the attacks. Christine is welcome to live with me as long as she wants, but the children should not take seriously my fatherly lament that I never want them to leave. I don't mean it. The day the last of my four leaves home, probably around 2018, when I'm 66, I plan to celebrate if my doctor lets me. The thought of one of them or, yikes, all of them coming back because they can't find jobs is frightening. But plenty of parents are letting their children return.
"This has been happening over the last 10 years and we didn't notice it," said Benjamin Schlesinger, the co-author, with Suzanne Kingsmill, of "The Family Squeeze: Surviving the Sandwich Generation" (University of Toronto Press, 1998). "The major reasons are economic. It costs so much for a single person to have their own housing that it is much cheaper to stay at home. Parents say 'Why not stay home?' Parents are encouraging it, not discouraging it.
"People are being laid off by the thousands," he said. "Where are they going to go? The nice thing about family is that they will take you back."
Diane Hall, 54, of Pleasanton, Calif., has taken her adult daughters back several times for economic reasons. Now she has gone a generation further: she is now helping one daughter by caring for her 13-year-old. "I have been part of the sandwich generation for years," Ms. Hall said with resignation. "I thought at this age I'd be living the same wonderful life my family had led: have three wonderful children who would bring me babies to enjoy, that I would be able to stay home and bake cookies and have lunch with my friends. Just what I saw my mother doing. But my life has taken me another way."
A 52-year-old father in New Jersey, who asked that his name not be used, has both of his adult children living at home. Housing costs are the main reason. His son, 24, who has used his time at home to save his paychecks toward a condominium, is scheduled to move into it this week. His daughter, 22, is working part time.
"The economy stinks," the father said. "It is not the kind of position she had envisioned."
He is not complaining about having them around. Sure, there's a lack of privacy for everyone, but he said he enjoyed having his children there. "They do chores," he said. "My daughter goes grocery shopping; my son cuts the lawn. It's really nice. They're grown-ups now and fun to talk to. I will miss them when they're gone."
While adult children are at home, Mr. Kaye said, they should be working, "even if it is not the child's chosen career path."
"I don't care if it is baby-sitting or house-cleaning, it sends a message to the child that the clock is running and they do have the need to produce some income," he said.
Setting ground rules is important, Mr. Schlesinger said: Will they pay rent? How much? Will they be allowed to use the family car? Should they pay for groceries? He cautioned parents not to become "serving parents"-- cleaning their children's rooms or doing their laundry. The children should do those things, and other chores, too, he said, "so they feel part of the house."
He has another caution. Don't dump all the rules on them right away. "You have to realize that this young adult has different needs than when he left," he said. "Remember, they are embarrassed they are living at home."
Indeed. The New Jersey dad, for example, wanted his name withheld because his children had requested it. They were, he said, uncomfortable about the whole thing.

HEADLINE: The Relentless Urge to Refinance 

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
NOT since 1990 have home owners been saddled with mortgage interest rates in double digits, although a couple of times the rates crept back within sight of that alpine territory. But for the last month 30-year, fixed-rate mortgages have carried rates below 7 percent in New York state, and they are among the lowest in a generation. 
 "Lots of adults today were born, raised, graduated from college, are parents of 5-year-olds and they never saw such rates," said Keith T. Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates in Butler, N.J., which publishes information on the mortgage market. 
 If current mortgage rates remain this low through the end of the year, as expected, said Robert Van Order, chief economist of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac), annual average interest rates in 2001 will be the lowest in the 30 years that Freddie Mac has been surveying them. 
The inevitable upshot has been a break-neck rush to refinance -- that is, to pay off mortgages and replace them with loans carrying lower interest rates. With a majority of American homeowners paying down home loans carrying interest rates of 7 percent or more, Americans by the thousands have lined up to apply for low-mortgage home loans, much the way eager settlers lined up for free land during the the Oklahoma Land Rush of 1899. 
Last week, for example, applications to refinance existing mortgages rose 11.5 percent above the previous week, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association, and refinancing accounted for 73.8 percent of the total. That refinancing rate was not only 7.1 percentage points higher than a week earlier but the highest percentage since 1992. 
For the week ended Oct. 12, the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dropped to 6.58 percent, the lowest since October 9, 1998 when it stood at 6.49, and the ninth consecutive week that it has been below 7 percent. The average for the fixed-rate 15-year mortgage dropped to 6.06 percent, down 7.52 from last year and the lowest since Freddie Mac began tracking it a decade ago. The one year adjustable mortgage rate declined to 5.26 from last year's 7.23 average, the lowest since the week that ended Feb. 16, 1996 when it averaged 5.19 percent.
Some homeowners have been so eager to take advantage of the lower rates that they financed several times in the past decade, during which mortgage rates fell every three years or so. Mortgage brokers say that it is not unusual for homeowners to have refinanced more than once this year alone.
Until recent years, mortgage specialists say, it was uncommon for rates to vary sufficiently to make it worthwhile for homeowners to refinance more than once a decade or so, A big reason for this, Mr. Gumbinger said, is that refinancing back then usually meant having to pay 2 points (each point is one percent of the loan) and hefty fees at the closing that could easily take up to five years to recoup. Points are still around, but the competition among mortgage brokers and online lenders has rendered them comparatively rare.
In addition, according to Joseph L. Romano, Jr., president of A. J. Romano Mortgage Company in Stratford, Conn. the size of mortgages rarely came anywhere near the high six- and seven-figures that are not uncommon today, so homeowners stood to save only small sums by refinancing, not the four- and five-figures a month they often save today. 
One couple who refinanced twice this year is Lev Verbitsky and Katharina Guel, a husband and wife from Hamden, Conn. They refinanced this February and their new refinance, already approved, was scheduled to close Oct. 24. After buying a $160,000 three-bedroom house in Hamden in January 2000 with a $148,500 30-year, 8 percent mortgage, they noticed early this year that rates had fallen below 7 percent. So they consulted with Mr. Romano and found they could save a bundle by refinancing, whereupon they took out a 15-year, $148,500 mortgage with a fixed rate of 6.875 percent. Because of the shorter term of the loan, their monthly mortgage payment increased to $1,324.40 from $1,089.64. But also because of that shorter term, they stand to save $153,000 in interest over the life of the loan.
Last month, seeing that mortgage rates had fallen again, the couple contacted Mr. Romano again. This time they wanted a 'no-cost' loan, for which borrowers are not required to pay closing costs at settlement -- costs that, depending on where one lives, usually run between $1,500 and $2,500. The term "no-cost" is something of a misnomer, since the closing costs are simply added to the loan and repaid over time. 
This time Mr. Romano found a "no cost" 15-year fixed rate mortgage with an interest rate of 6.25 percent. Had they paid the closing costs at settlement, their rate would have been a quarter of a percentage point less.
In this case, a 6 percent rate over the same 15 year term, coupled with the borrowers paying the closing costs at settlement, would have reduced their mortgage payments by $12.66 a month, or $1,219.37. As it is, their 6.25 loan, which includes closing costs, will require a monthly payment of $1,232.03. Mr. Verbitsky and Ms. Guel were aware of that, but neverthelsss preferred it that way. "If we had to pay $2,000 to $2,500 out of pocket, we'd have to think about refinancing again," Mr. Verbitsky said. As it is, their new loan will lower their monthly payment by $81.14, and with additional equity in their house, they will save an additional $61 a month from no longer having to pay the private mortgage insurance that lenders require of borrowers whose equity is below 20 percent. Moreover, their new loan will save them $11,000 in interest, in addition to the $153,000 they saved in their first refinancing. 
Their refinance loans not only put more money in the couple's pockets, it added to the further debunking of the traditional advice not to refinance unless the spread between the old and new loans is at least 2 percentage points. And it is why Mr. Verbitsky said without hesitation, "We think we did the right thing."
Adjustable-rate mortgages have waxed and waned in popularity, depending on their rate of interest during the initial three, five, seven or other number of years agreed upon. While ARM's rates typically start out lower than those for fixed rate mortgages, after their initial fixed term they can be changed annually for the remainder of the loan. But with fixed-rate mortgages currently as low as they are, Frank Nothaft, deputy chief economist for Freddie Mac, said there is little interest in ARM's, which are expected to command no more than 14 percent of morgage loans during this fourth quarter. Moreover, "we don't forsee ARM's being more than about 15 percent of the market next year," Mr. Nothaft added, "because the 30-year fixed rate is expected to be almost as low and affordable in 2002 as it has been in 2001."
"I did a mailing to 600 clients and acquaintances over a month ago saying this is the time to refinance, with interest rates near a 34-year low," said Richard J. Russell, president of Richland Equity Reserve, a Manhattan mortgage broker. "We got a 10 percent response, which is good for such mailings," and which he added led to "many refinances." 
What attracted most respondents, Mr. Russell added, was telling owners of expensive condos that if they had a mortgage greater than 8 percent a year they could save as much as $1,000 a month on a refinance, and telling owners of less expensive homes that they could save as much as $500 a month. A $200,000 loan over 30 years at 8.25 percent would require monthly payments of $1,502.66, while refinancing to pay back the same amount over the same term at 6.5 percent would result in payments of $1,264.32, a savings of $238.34 a month.
It should come as no surprise that most people, regardless of income or where they live, want to save money. "It's just been crazy," said Joseph L. Romano, president of A. J. Romano Mortgage Company, which has an office on Main Street in Stratford, Conn., and a Web site (www.ajromano.com) that has proven handy for applicants who do not have time to stop by. With barely enough time in the day to handle all the recent inquiries, Mr. Romano said that it is not uncommon in these hectic times to be filling out paperwork until 2 a.m. But he does not seem to mind. "In our business you also have slow periods," he added, "so when it's busy we don't mind working long hours." 
The pace is much the same almost everywhere. John P. Brady, senior executive vice president of S. I. Bank and Trust, said its 33 branches in Staten Island, Brooklyn and North Jersey have all been busy with mortgage applications. And the Ivy Mortage Corporation in Branchburg, N.J., which is owned by S. I. Bank and Trust and which operates in 42 states, "has also been very, very busy," Mr. Brady said, adding that more than 70 percent of its loan volume has been for refinancing.
While predatory lenders still abound, it is far easier than ever for borrowers to know for certain whether they did the "right thing" in refinancing their mortgage loan. In addition to the many reputable lenders who take the time to explain how a particular loan will result in lower monthly payments, shorter durations or lower interest costs, that information is also widely available to the public from the mortgage calculators on the Web sites of numerous financial institutions, realtors, mortgage lenders and brokers, as well as on the Web sites of newspapers, magazines and television networks. (Mortgage calculators can, of course, just as easily calculate the cost of first mortgages as of refinances.) 
Like the more reputable lenders and mortgage brokers, the better mortgage calculators can also explain why it makes more sense for a borrower to take this loan or that. For choosing the right mortgage involves more than merely crunching numbers, it also depends on the borrower's income, expectations, aspirations and approach to financial planning. 
They can explain, for instance, why a 30-year mortgages might be preferable for younger borrowers, who may not be able to afford the higher monthly payments that would be required to repay a 15-year loan for the same amount. Conversely, the 15-year term might be preferable for middle-aged or older borrowers who can afford the higher monthly repayments. 
Mr. Russell of Richland Equity advocates that borrowers with 30-year mortgages pay an additional monthly payment each year, which he said has the effect of shortening a 30-year loan by seven years, thereby saving many thousands of dollars. 
Many mortgage analysts and economists are of the opinion that, as Mr. Gumbinger put it, "mortgage interest rates and Fed cuts don't march in lockstep." Mortgage rates had been dwindling over the past month, Mr. Gumbinger said, and the economy had not recovered much if at all on news of the series of short term interest rates. 
But neither do they discount the likelihood that the nine Federal Reserve rate cuts this year, with another one widely predicted by the end of this month, have some effect on mortgages. On the contrary, many think that the Fed's half-point rate reduction on the morning of Sept. 17 -- just hours before the New York Stock Exchange re-opened after having closed for six days after the terrorist attacks six days previously -- helped unlock a lot of pentup demand for refinancing. Two weeks ago, Phil Colling, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, attributed some of the spurt in refinancing to "continued low interest rates" together with "new uncertainty in the economy."
At the same time borrowing for refinancing has soared, applications to buy houses have slumped to their lowest level this year. And at a time when the National Association of Realtors has calculated that the value of existing single-family homes in the United States has risen an average of 6.3 percent each year since 1968 (from $20,100 to $139,000), it is little surprise that many refinances are taken for the purpose of "cashing out" -- that is, taking a loan based on the increased value of the house and paying off the existing mortgage while using the remainder of the cash to pay off medical bills, credit card debt, tuition, home equity loans or to remodel their house.
Some people who are worried they may be laid off are apparently taking the cash while they are still employed, according to Doug Duncan, chief economist of the Mortgage Bankers Association. Saying that the only evidence of this trend is anecdotal, he cited the example of a friend who owns a travel-related business, and every two- to-four years sells his house and plows the equity into his business. 
Mr. Romano told of a client who was recently laid off by a Connecticut-based marketing research company, who when he saw it coming cashed out -- not for debt consolidation but because he had since started his own business, and, Mr. Romano said, "Once you're unemployed, lenders want to see your track record for at least two years before they'll give you a mortgage."
Dolores and Oscar Ruiz bought their three-bedroom Cape Cod house in New Milford, N.J. five years ago with a 30-year loan at 7.75 percent interest. Nine days ago the couple -- she works in public relations for Weber Shandwick Worldwide in Manhattan, Mr. Ruiz is a news director for WNJU-TV, the Spanish-language station in Teterboro, N.J., which is owned by the Telemundo Communications Group -- refinanced a $205,000 mortgage with a 30-year term at a rate of 6.85 percent.
The new mortgage will cost the couple a lot more over the term of the loan, compared with that of a 15-year term, but the lower interest rate for the new 30-year term will result in Mr. & Mrs. Ruiz paying $1,815.40 a month, $400 more than before. But they have paid their credit card debt of $57,000, for which they were repaying about $3,500 a month. Now they expect to save enough to eventually expand their house, which suddenly became smaller 16 months ago with the birth of their son Daniel.
"Had we taken a 15-year loan, we'd be laying out the same just for the mortgage as we'll now lay out for the mortgage and the credit card debt," Mrs. Ruiz said. Besides, she added, "Daniel wants a little brother or sister, so we have to think about saving for that every possible way."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Unions Rethink Links to Undocumented Labor

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
SHOULD organized labor reach out to the undocumented worker, even when met with suspicion or hostility? Or should labor view illegal immigration as a force that depresses wages and threatens to reverse the movement's hard-won gains in higher wages, greater benefits and improved work conditions? 
 On a sparkling day in early October, a group called the Coalition to Save Long Island Jobs held its third annual conference at the de Seversky Conference Center in Old Westbury. Where Alfred I. duPont once entertained guests in gilded Jazz Age luxury, the coalition devoted a morning to discussing some of the significant issues facing the labor movement. 
 Among the most important, and often the most divisive, is the issue of labor's proper position on the undocumented worker. 
"A number of unions are changing their position, and now are supportive of undocumented workers and are trying to organize them," said Tony Macagnone, a Town of Oyster Bay councilman as well as council representative of Local 7 of the Empire State Council of Carpenters.
The old guard, however, views the workers' willingness to work at far lessthan union rates as threatening the union's bargaining position.
For the Coalition to Save Long Island Jobs, a movement organized by the Long Island Progressive Coalition during a strike by King Kullen workers in 1997, the topic is emerging as a hot-button issue.
Judy Pannullo, director of the Progressive Coalition, said the King Kullen strike achieved a breakthrough in terms of public support for the Long Island labor cause. Since then, she said, it has been noticeably easier to raise labor issues among Long Islanders and find supportive responses.
"Take globalization," said Ms. Pannullo, who doubles as executive director of Save Long Island Jobs. "That threatens Long Island workers. A company can take away your job and move it somewhere cheaper. We're against that." She said she got more sympathy for that position now.
Still, it was not globalization that was the focus of this conference. On Long Island the issue of undocumented workers made headlines last year when community opposition to illegal aliens in Farmingville culminated in violence and angry denunciations of the workers and their supporters. Active community opposition to the immigrants, who gathered mornings at curbside locations to meet potential employers, made Farmingville a flash point in the national debate over America's immigration policy.
For labor, the issue is no less divisive. While some old-school unionists resent spending union funds to help undocumented workers, a number of national and local leaders are initiating recruitment drives and other outreach efforts. Often these efforts are accompanied by free social programs, like English conversation classes. Historically, such programs have improved relations between the newcomers and the established work force, and are often a precursor to successful union recruitment.
Mr. Macagnone moderated the hourlong panel, called "The Problems of Undocumented Workers on Long Island," and was optimistically subtitled "A Constructive Dialogue." According to Ms. Pannullo, the more strident voices that have been heard on the issue were intentionally excluded. She said the reason was to keep the meeting from getting ugly.
Those who deal honestly with the issue, Mr. Macagnone said, are walking on a razor's edge.
"You oppose these guys as being here illegally and you're called a racist," he said. "But if you try to bring them into the union, where they'll be paying taxes like everyone else, you're criticized for helping people who are breaking the law."
Mr. Macagnone said his union was nevertheless on the side of offering services to workers, regardless of legal status or union affiliation. In Glen Cove, the city arranged to build a hiring site that reduced public visibility and inconvenience; the carpenters' union supported the effort, and the city's policy was commended by several speakers that morning.
"Undocumented workers have become an essential part of the work force," he said. "It's the duty of organized labor to represent all working people, whether they're union or not."
Mr. Macagnone's views are not universally shared among union leaders. John Kennedy, president of the 60,000-member Building and Construction Trades Council of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, warned against providing help to workers before resolving their legal status. 
"Something has to be done to help these people in terms of getting them the housing, benefits and safe working conditions they need," Mr. Kennedy said. "But first things first. They have to become documented. Then we will organize them, if we have to."
He said his union took no position on how undocumented workers could obtain legal residency status. "That isn't our problem, that's the federal government's problem," Mr. Kennedy said. He blamed federal immigration authorities for failing to keep American borders secure.
The panel discussion on undocumented workers got underway with a presentation by John Brock, representing an organization called the Tristate Immigration Moratorium. He mentioned his Slovak roots on his mother's side before launching into an anti-immigration argument. He cited several books opposing immigration and attempted to win the audience over by repeating the standard economic justification that large numbers of new workers depress wages for established ones.
"Big business loves mass immigration, because it rationalizes the labor market," he declared. "From the free-market point of view, the American worker is vastly overpaid. Open borders bring immigrants here who are happy to do your work for far less money. In the past, they've put entire industries out of business. Meatpacking used to be a good job; now, it's all done by immigrants and pays miserably. Why do you think that The Wall Street Journal editorializes in favor of open borders?"
John Scaffetta, a member of Mr. Macagnone's carpenters' union, spoke next. "We find a tremendous influx of Hispanic workers in construction," he said. "Whether we like it or not, we believe they're the work force of the future."
Acknowledging that in the past the union "has practiced the politics of exclusion," he said that today his union was attempting to recruit Hispanic workers and was doing some things differently, including hiring a Hispanic organizer. He said it was too soon to talk about the new organizer's results.
Another speaker, John Bingham, a Catholic Charities social worker, sought to make the point that being an undocumented worker was a legal condition, not a moral one. Laws, he noted, can be amended.
"Laws ought to reflect reality," he said. "Businesses need workers. And workers need jobs."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Judy Pannullo, director of the Progressive Coalition, speaks with Darren Sandow of the Long Island Unitarian Universalist Fund. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Latino Laborers Turn a Camera on Themselves 

BYLINE:  By SHANDRAY GABBAY 

DATELINE: STONY BROOK 

 BODY:
UNTIL recently, Luis Bernal-Estrada of Farmingville did not know how to use a camera. But the 26-year-old carpenter by day and rookie photographer in his free time has taken more snapshots in the past year than he can count. And now he has two photographs on display at an exhibition at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.
 For Mr. Bernal-Estrada, who left Mexico less than two years ago and has since been living on Long Island, the camera has become a tool and photography the means to share his life as a Latino laborer with a society that does not seem interested. 
 His introduction to photography began a year ago. That was when he and nearly a dozen other Latino workers on the Island were offered spots in a photography class at Stony Brook in exchange for shooting a roll of pictures each week that would capture everyday moments on the job or at play. The workers were participants in programs sponsored by the Workplace Project, a Hempstead organization founded in 1992 to address problems of low-wage immigrant workers on the Island.
"Everyone only knows us as workers," said Mr. Bernal-Estrada, who was interviewed through a translator from the Hempstead group. "They only know what other people tell them about us, and they're not able to go any further."
Some of the snapshots are part of the exhibition at Stony Brook, which is at the Union Art Gallery until Oct. 31. The show also includes dozens of other images taken by workers from Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, the country's largest building service union and Local 23-25 of the Union of Needle Trades, Industrial and Textile Employees, which is comprised mostly of Chinese garment workers.
The show is part of a larger project, "Unseen America," organized by Bread and Roses, the nonprofit cultural arm of Local 1199, the National Health and Human Services Employees Union, which represents health care workers in New York City. The project aims to document the lives of the working class through photography.
Carlos Canales, a staff member of the Hempstead group, said the purpose of the photography classes, and the Stony Brook exhibition, was "to show the community that these people have art and expression inside -- a soul, a spirit -- even though most can't read or write."
The images of workers on the Island were mostly shot in black-and-white. They are of friends, family or fellow Latinos engaged in everyday activities. There are photographs of friends enjoying a game of cards, a weary worker sleeping on an uncovered mattress, three men grilling tortillas on a barbecue, and a group of men standing around on a cold, snowy day awaiting work.
Mr. Bernal-Estrada has two pictures in the show, including one taken at the house in Farmingville where he lived when he first moved to the United States. It shows his former housemate, Pedro, dancing with a woman, Ouri, who cooked for them.
"I think that this is a picture that would help everyone else know that we come to this country not to do bad things like people say," he said, holding back tears. "But we come here to work and have fun."
Some pictures have a more serious undertone, like one of a protest by Latinos in Melville, objecting to the decision of Joseph M. Trudden, mayor of Farmingdale, to shut down a site in that village where day laborers were hired.
The photography classes were financed by Bread and Roses and several other organizations. An interdisciplinary campus group founded by an economics professor, Michael Zweig, provided darkroom and class space.
"Unseen America" is one of dozens of Bread and Roses projects, and is scheduled to travel to 40 sites across the nation, including Chicago and Washington. Some of the pictures will also be on display through December at Stony Brook's Latin-American and Caribbean Studies Center.
"It's another way of reaching out about work and the lives of working people to encourage them by using photography," said Moe Foener, the 86-year-old founder of Bread and Roses. "It is an unusually effective way of projecting their needs and interests through to large audiences."
For some of the participants, the experience was far more than just learning the basics of how to load batteries into a camera or process film in the darkroom.
"It always interested me to take pictures," said Aaron Cruz, 23. "But I never had the opportunity. For many of us it was a dream come true to have a class like this."
Even the instructors walked away with something to remember. 
"To show, to tell, to humanize people who have sometimes been demonized," said Jim Cassidy, a teacher. "To me, that is one of the best uses of photography."
Rodolfo Sorto, a 30-year-old maintenance worker from El Salvador, described the darkroom as "a garden."
"With each picture I feel like a gardener," he said. "When you take the film, each roll is like a seed and when you see your creation, it is a flower."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Luis Bernal-Estrada, below left, a carpenter, took a picture, far left, of his former housemate and a woman who cooked for them in their Farmingville house. The photograph is in an exhibition of snapshots by Latino workers at the State University of New York, at Stony Brook, part of a project that documents working-class life. Other photographs in the project include views of workers preparing a meal, left, grilling tortillas, below, and in a church. (Photographs by the Workplace Project; Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: University Develops Housing in Chicago 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT SHAROFF

DATELINE: CHICAGO 

 BODY:
In an effort to both expand and enhance its downtown campus, the University of Illinois has teamed up with a consortium of private developers to transform a formerly blighted Near South Side neighborhood into a community with almost 1,000 new homes. About 80 percent of the homes will be sold at market rates, the remainder at lower prices with income ceilings for buyers.
 The project, called University Village, also encompasses new and renovated buildings for the university, including two dormitories with rooms for 750 students and a new home for the campus security force in a historic police station. In addition, the university is developing 120,000 square feet of new retail space, and it has tentative plans for two new academic buildings on the 85-acre site, including a possible new home for the business school. 
Over all, the project is to cost about $750 million, with the housing component accounting for about $300 million. 
"For most of our history," said Ellen M. Hamilton, the university's director of real estate, "we've been considered a commuter university. There's long been a desire on campus to create a 24-hour neighborhood, where everyone doesn't leave at night."
The project, which has been in the planning stages for more than a decade and which broke ground last year, is the latest step in the growth of a campus that began after World War II as an offshoot of the main University of Illinois campus in the downstate cities of Champaign and Urbana.
The Chicago campus was originally at Navy Pier, a onetime steamship wharf just north of downtown, and moved to its current location just southwest of the Loop in 1965. The campus grew considerably after merging with the University of Illinois Medical Center in 1982 and today has about 200 acres within a larger zone bounded roughly by Eisenhower Expressway on the north, 16th Street on the south, Halsted Street on the east and Damen Avenue on the west. 
The institution's involvement in a commercial development aimed at revitalizing its neighborhood is not unique. According to a study being done by the Lincoln Institute of Land Policy in Cambridge, Mass., at least 60 such projects are under way at urban universities around the country.
"There's no question that there's an element of enlightened self-interest on the part of universities in these projects," said Terry Foegler, president of Campus Partners, a nonprofit real estate company set up by Ohio State University in Columbus to do neighborhood development in that city. "Unlike businesses, it's tough for universities to relocate when neighborhoods start deteriorating, so it makes sense for them to partner with various entities to try and revitalize these areas."
One of the most extensive programs of this type in recent years is in Philadelphia, where the University of Pennsylvania has spearheaded the redevelopment of a 63-block area. Among the projects it has undertaken is the construction of more than 1 million square feet of new commercial space, including a hotel, a grocery store and a multiplex movie theater. "We brought a lot of private capital as well as university investment to the table," said Dr. Judith Rodin, the university's president. "The neighborhood has been truly transformed." 
The University of Illinois has similar aims in Chicago. University Village is at the southeast corner of the campus, a neighborhood with both a lot of history and a lot of problems. A century ago, the area teemed with Jewish immigrants, who founded the Maxwell Street Market, a colorful market and bazaar that endured in its original site until the early 1990's. "It was like Orchard Street on the Lower East Side of New York," said Eve Kronen, managing broker of a Coldwell Banker office in the area.
By the end of the 20th century, however, the neighborhood had deteriorated into a ramshackle area of largely one- and two-story flats and stores punctuated by a large number of vacant lots.
The developers who have teamed up with the university are the Chicago-based Mesirow Stein Real Estate Inc., the Harlem Irving Companies in suburban Norridge and the New Frontier Companies in Springfield, Ill. They have formed a partnership known as the South Campus Development Team.
"We're wearing two hats," said Larry D. Justice, project executive of the consortium. "We're the developer of the private housing component and the program manager for the university's part of the development." 
The consortium is constructing 930 new housing units on 26 acres at the southern end of the site. About 186 of the apartments will be contained in two old concrete warehouse buildings, while the rest will be a mix of new town houses and apartment buildings. Prices range between $165,000 for a 671-square-foot loft to $696,000 for a 3,000-square-foot town house. About 366 apartments have already been sold, and the first residents will move in early next year.
About 196 units are classified as affordable, meaning they are priced for buyers who make 80 to 120 percent of the median income for the metro area. Median income for a two-person household in Chicago, for example, is $56,400 and for a four-person household, $70,500. The affordable units are priced between $143,000 and $228,000. 
"The location is very good," Ms. Kronen said. "Neighborhoods become successful when they are attached to other successful neighborhoods, and this one is in close proximity both to the West Loop and the Near South Side."
The project itself is what attracted Rafi Arbel, an attorney with West Group, a legal research firm. "What we liked about it is that the developers are building an entire community from the ground up right next to the university," said Mr. Arbel, who with his wife, Jennifer, recently purchased a 2,800-square-foot town house in the the project. "I like being near the university."
The university's part of the project is also well under way. The first of the two dormitory buildings opened this fall, while the second will be ready in 2003. "We're currently about 10 percent residential and 90 percent commuter," said Mark Rosati, the university's associate chancellor. "We want to increase residential to 25 percent by 2012. This project is a big step in that direction."
Work is also progressing on the construction of a retail district at Halsted and Maxwell Streets. Like the housing, the district combines new and old space. After a bruising fight with a neighborhood group determined to save what was left of the Maxwell Street Market, the university agreed to preserve eight buildings on Halsted Street and the facades of another 13 buildings in the area. The facades are being applied to the exterior of several large new structures that combine retail and parking space.
In addition, an old brick Chicago police station at the western edge of the site is being renovated as the new home for the university's campus security force. The station, a two-story red-brick affair that dates from 1889, will be familiar to many television viewers. During the 1980's, the facade served as the exterior of the police station that was the focus of the long-running series "Hill Street Blues." The station was vacated by the police in the late 1990's.
The new academic buildings will follow in 2004 and 2006 but must be preceded by additional fund raising.
"We feel we're a rising academic powerhouse," Mr. Rosati said. "But to service the city and state as we would like, we need facilities. University Village will benefit the campus on many levels. It will address some of our needs for academic space, enhance the teaching and research environment, alleviate the campus housing crunch and make the university a more attractive destination for students."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The new University of Illinois dormitory, with the Sears Tower behind. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Home Sales Have Been Generally Strong in October

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
CONTRADICTORY, complex, as hard to analyze as Tony Soprano on or off Prozac, the New Jersey residential market stumbled hard immediately after the Sept. 11 attack, but has since revived. At least in some towns. At least for now. 
 "Your ball is as good as my ball," Jean Olcott of Burgdorff ERA, who has been a sales agent in Bergen County for 29 years, said with a laugh. It is hard to be a swami in never-before-seen circumstances, she pointed out. 
 The Sept. 11 attack in Manhattan did have an immediate measurable impact in New Jersey. The number of sales contracts signed for homes was off 16 percent in September, compared with September 2000, according to the Garden State Multiple Listing Service, which has 555 member companies in eight counties. 
Coldwell Banker, a brokerage that does business in those eight counties and four others, experienced a 13 percent drop in contracts signed in September compared with last year. The number of canceled contracts was up 14 percent for the month, said Coldwell Banker's president and chief operating officer, Maureen Passerini.
"But for October so far," Mrs. Passerini said, speaking during the fourth week of the month, "we've been quite busy." Coldwell Banker held a Meet the Builder program in New Jersey last Sunday, showing 400 new-home sites, and had 40 signed contracts by Wednesday. The prices of homes under contract ranges from $200,000 to $1 million or more, she said.
In the top price range, Mrs. Passerini said, the market sputtered but is now spurting. Coldwell Banker sold only one home worth $1 million or more in September in New Jersey, she said. In October so far, it has sold 10.
The situation is "patchy," several brokers observed. Certain sectors of the market, notably starter homes, and certain sought-after towns with a perennially tight inventory of homes for sale -- Ridgewood, Montclair, Millburn-Short Hills, Mountain Lakes -- seem immune to jitters in consumer confidence since Sept. 11. 
Before the terrorist attacks, a Montclair real estate broker, Jay Schweppe, was publicly predicting a slowdown in the residential market, because he believes homes are routinely overpriced in Essex County. Then, September turned out to be the "best month ever" for Schweppe & Company, Mr. Schweppe said.
Worries about worsening economic times appear to be nearly universal, though -- along with relief that so far the impact has been relatively minor.
A slide from record high sales prices in northern New Jersey had begun by late August. Ms. Olcott of Burgdorff said, "We already knew before the tragedy in New York we were not going to see those numbers again." 
Prices have been climbing about 5 percent a year across the Northeast, according to the National Association of Realtors. In much of New Jersey, prices were climbing faster than that. In Bergen County earlier this year, the median sales price for existing homes ranked in the nation's top 20.
Still, New Jersey residential prices do not approach those in Manhattan. This may help buoy the market here despite an economic downtown, realtors said, especially if there is a wave of New Yorkers relocating in the wake of the attack.
"I was showing a couple from Manhattan a $1.8 million home in Mendham earlier this month," said Lindy Peteet, a luxury property specialist with Weichert. "Her eyes got so big. I wasn't sure what she was thinking, so I asked her: 'Are you pleased with what you're looking at?' "
"It turned out she was amazed at the value," Ms. Peteet said. "They live in a brownstone, and this was 6,500 square feet on three acres." 
IN the days after Sept. 11, realtors and brokers reported, the generally robust sales activity abruptly diminished to nearly nil.
"There was a dramatic drop-off, for about 10 days," said Gary J. Stefanoni, sales and marketing manager for Pulte Homes, a builder of upscale town house communities in Paramus, Holmdel and Warren.
Jacelyn Botti, Weichert Realtors' senior vice president for the tristate area, said, 
"The first week, everybody was traumatized, and very little at all went on.
"But as we began to move away from that," Ms. Botti said, "the same thing happened with real estate as with the stock market. We gradually got in the back-to-work mode, the buying cycle mode."
Average attendance of prospective buyers at Weichert Sunday open houses in New Jersey continues at seven or eight, Ms. Botti said, and the pace of sales has rebounded. Weichert's rate of sales for the first half of October was virtually even with October 2000 in New Jersey. Ms. Botti said she computed monthly "revenue units" (a measure of the value of properties put under sales contract) as being 2,508 at mid-October 2001 compared with 2,515 a year earlier.
"Certain offices have had a flurry of sales activity," Ms. Botti said. She cited Fort Lee, across the George Washington Bridge from Manhattan. Ms. Botti said there had also been spurts of activity in towns farther away from New York City, like Rumson, which lies south of Red Bank, more than a hour from New York City. Generally, though, residential sales have been strongest in areas closest to New York, she said.
Ms. Botti's company deals mainly with sale of existing homes. Mr. Stefanoni of Pulte described roughly the same pattern of recovery in the market for newly constructed housing. "After a huge slowdown, people are coming back and making purchases," he said, noting that the second week in October set a record for sales at Pulte's three town house developments. "Buying a home is a big decision, not a frivolous decision. People who were in the midst of selling, downsizing or adding to their families -- their lives can't stop, even though the tragedy will never be forgotten."
Mr. Stefanoni and other real estate experts said the state's tight inventory of available housing remains the dominant factor affecting the market. "The fact that interest rates keep going down is a good thing, emotionally," Mr. Stefanoni said. "It makes people think: What better time?"
But he said that at luxury communities like Brettonwoods in Paramus, where the average sales price is in the mid-$500,000's, interest rates do not determine whether a home is affordable. "It's more a question of how much more people will buy, or what luxury items can they install?" 
Ms. Botti, the Weichert vice president, said she was startled by a sudden jump in the number of homes listed with the company in the first half of October. "We're tracking 11 percent more listings than the same period a year ago -- and we've been tracking below the previous year for two and a half years," Ms. Botti said.
She said she could report only that some sellers were confiding that they thought they should put homes on the market now while New Yorkers may be actively considering relocating from the wounded city. "They say, 'I don't know where this is going, but I'm going to get in the market now and see,' " she said.
Of course, even an 11 percent increase in listings won't change the picture much, Ms. Botti observed. "That's equivalent to about two months' standing inventory. At normal levels, a marketplace has about four or five months inventory," but New Jersey has been much tighter than that for some time.
Hundreds of New Jersey residents were killed in the World Trade Center, and Ms. Olcott of Burgdorff noted -- "horrible, but true" -- this may lead to house sales. Ridgewood, like other towns that have traditionally attracted those who commute to Manhattan's financial district, has had a number of terror victims and is expected see such sales, she said. 
But tragedy and encroaching recession are not the only factors at play, Mr. Schweppe asserted. For example, in Montclair, new nonstop rail service to New York City begins operation in January. "New transit options for commuters always provide a boost to a community, and this will certainly provide a buffer against price drops," Mr. Schweppe said.
"The tie to New York is crucial," Mr. Schweppe added, "in ways that are double-edged right now, I guess."

HEADLINE: Business; 
Sharing the Wealth, for Capitalism's Sake

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN 

 BODY:
 LIKE most people, Diane Coyle was shocked by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. But in her new book, "Paradoxes of Prosperity: Why the New Capitalism Benefits All," she describes conditions that, in retrospect, could have invited violence. In a recent telephone interview, Ms. Coyle discussed the implications of the attacks and their aftermath. Following are excerpts from the conversation.
 WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN

Q. Were the terrorists motivated by more than anti-American ideology?

A. Perhaps we should not have been surprised that the success of capitalism should have also created violent hostility among those who've been left out -- people with no power in the world of international diplomacy. They feel that the squalor and poverty of their lives is something being done to them by those who do have the power.

Q. Do the attacks mean that the West must retreat from open flows of people and goods -- important pieces of globalization?

A. The terrorist attacks make it now a matter of urgency to ensure that as many countries as possible thrive from globalization, and that the top international policy priorities are the reduction of poverty, improvements in health in developing countries, access for poor traders to rich markets and so on. This adds up to more globalization, not a retreat from it.

Q. So somehow the affluent West must do more to extend economic gains?

A. If the benefits are not seen to be spread increasingly fairly, it will not be possible to win a war on terror or isolate nations like Afghanistan and Iraq that breed it. None of us will reap the fruits of prosperity unless all of us do.

Q. Do you think the way the Western nations broadcast their culture helps fuel resentment?

A. There are countries where almost everybody lives in poverty. They can see what is going on in America because of global television. I think it must make people feel powerless. I saw a picture in a magazine recently of an African man who had just bought a pair of beat-up used shoes. He painted the Nike symbol on them. He had seen it somewhere on television. He wanted the same lifestyle and comfort that he'd seen.
At the same time, we put our deepest fears on display in Hollywood movies. The terrorists seem to understand very well how easy it is to make people afraid. It is fear itself that could do the most damage.

Q. Millions of people from those lands have emigrated to the West. Does it now seem like the West will tighten up?

A. It would be damaging and sad. America's fantastic economic strength has been built on drawing in immigrants, with their energy and determination to make a new life. I firmly and passionately believe that diversity of experience is a really important element of economic success. That's why New York and London have been thriving.

Q.. You say the power of governments will wane. Why is the United States assuming more power?

A. I still think there will be a decline in the way governments influence economies. The security issues are separate. It's quite natural that governments should be taking on those responsibilities. I think our concern for our liberties won't allow it to go too far.

Q. Do you feel that the "new economy" can keep moving ahead?

A. The technology is there. The trends toward greater globalization are not going to be put into reverse.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Diane Coyle says a war on terror cannot be won if economic gains are not spread fairly.

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Canadian Company Moves Workers to Purchase

BYLINE:  By Elsa Brenner 

 BODY:
A Canadian company is relocating 90 employees who were displaced on Sept. 11 from 1 Liberty Plaza near the World Trade Center to Purchase.
 The company, RBC Dominion Securities, the investment banking division of RBC Financial Group, formerly Royal Bank of Canada, has taken a long-term lease on space in RiverView at Purchase, said Frank Boccanfuso, the managing partner for FMB Real Estate Services. 
 As many as 200 of the company's employees could move into building at 287 Bowman Avenue until they can return to the bank's New York City offices.
Salvatore J. Carrera, director of economic development and real estate for the county, said other displaced companies have signed leases in Westchester, but he would not identify them. "They don't want any publicity," Mr. Carrerra said.
The Toronto-based company lost four floors of space in New York City. Elsa Brenner

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ORCHARD BEACH; 
An Aging Beauty Could Get a Needed Nip and a Tuck

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
Orchard Beach, once famously known as the Riviera of the Bronx, is shrinking. Acres have been lost to erosion since the 1930's, when Robert Moses oversaw the creation of the crescent-shaped beach that gave Bronx residents an accessible summertime retreat. No new sand has been added since 1964. 
 But now, steps are being taken to reverse that loss. The Army Corps of Engineers has completed a plan to bring in 300,000 cubic yards of sand by barge, probably from South Amboy, N.J., to restore the beach. The additional sand would add 12 acres of beach to the current 25 acres at high tide, and eliminate dangerous underwater drop-offs that have also been caused by erosion. 
 The restoration is crucial, said Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern, because the beach has become more popular in recent years. On summer weekends, the place is so packed that some beachgoers have to set up chairs on the promenade instead of the sand. 
"It's blanket to blanket," said Olga Quintana, describing the summer scene. She should know: a retiree who lives in Soundview, Ms. Quintana visits the beach with friends almost every day, year round. (As temperatures approached 80 degrees on Wednesday, she wore an orange bikini and sported a stellar late-October tan.)
In February, the Army Corps of Engineers will present its plan to rebuild the beach, including economic and environmental impact assessments, to state and local officials. The plan would be submitted for public review in the spring.
Money for the next step, design of the rebuilt beach, is already set aside. The total cost would be $7 million or $8 million, said Anthony Ciorra, project manager for the Corps of Engineers. Some $2 million in federal funds has already been set aside for the construction phase. 
Financing is complicated because the Corps of Engineers cannot use its own money for projects that are mainly recreational, and federal funds must be matched by state and local agencies. 
"This is not a done deal, but I am optimistic," Mr. Ciorra said. Restoration of the beach could begin by September 2003. 
"We want to make it a normal, pretty beach again, the way it was when it was a youngster," Mr. Stern said. "It's certainly showing signs of age, and it's been subject to the ravages of the wind and the waves for two-thirds of a century."
Ms. Quintana and her friends like the plan, although Leo Vazquez, who lives in the north Bronx, and who refers to the beach as the Puerto Rican Riviera, had a few additional suggestions. "It needs some palm trees, and a bar called the Hungry Soldier," said Mr. Vazquez, 75. "That would make you feel like you were in Puerto Rico." SETH KUGEL

GRAPHIC: Photo: Orchard Beach has become more popular in recent years. On some days, it's blanket to blanket. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Anthrax Aside, A Postal Play On Growth

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
NINE million jobs. A $900 billion market, representing roughly 8 percent of gross domestic product. 
 Those numbers describe the mailing industry, a business that anthrax in envelopes has suddenly jeopardized. 
 Edward M. Wolfe, a transportation, logistics and supply chain software analyst at Bear, Stearns, talked last week about changing conditions at the United States Postal Service and its competitors. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. What future do you see for the Postal Service?

A. Postal rates will go up some and there will be a major restructuring. Last December, the Postal Board, a group of appointed officials, produced a memo stating for the first time ever that they favored postal deregulation. It needs to be privatized.

Q. Which national postal services have been privatized?

A. The Dutch post office, TPG N.V., which trades as an A.D.R. in this country, and Deutsche Post, which trades on the London and German exchanges. Both were privatized and to some degree deregulated.
And the European Union is considering liberalizing all member post offices. Initially, they plan to open up competition for mail weighing over 150 grams and plan to reduce that figure over time.

Q. Has traffic shifted from the Postal Service toward its competitors?

A. Right now, volumes are extremely weak. That has been the case since December of last year. Since Sept. 11, it has gotten even worse. The service sector, which had held up well before then, was impacted by that event. But we are not seeing a major uptick because people are afraid of using the United States Postal Service. But if the post office shut down, there would be some shifts.
U.P.S. just reported third-quarter air and ground volumes that were down about 3 percent. They are a pretty good indicator of overall economic activity, and because of that I wouldn't be surprised if we saw the economy contract by about that amount.

Q. Do United Parcel Service and Federal Express offer greater security?

A. U.P.S. and FedEx have terrific technology to track their packages. They have tight information and generally know their customers. I don't think FedEx or U.P.S. want to do regular mail, but they do want to do priority or express mail. Both are probably safer than the Postal Service because they have terrific information flow from when the product gets picked up. The Postal Service doesn't always have control over its own product. Historically, they have put it in the belly of a commercial aircraft.

Q. Is a U.P.S. or FedEx jet less susceptible to hijacking than a commercial airliner?

A. They have increased safety regulations since Sept. 11. There is more paperwork, more locking up aircraft on the ground. And there are now major restrictions on who can ride in jump seats in the aircraft. Generally, there are only two or three people on those planes. And they control the freight that goes on the planes. When you are on an airliner, the airliner controls the passengers, but most of the freight comes from other people.
Going forward, there are going to be much greater restrictions on freight moving in the cargo of passenger planes, like 24-hour holdover periods. That will benefit companies like FedEx and U.P.S.

Q. How have transportation companies done since the attacks?

A. They are about where they were before Sept. 11. But I think the stocks are a little bit ahead of themselves because of the weakness in the economy.

Q. How do you see the business evolving?

A. There are a handful of infrastructures for moving parcels and mail: Deutsche Post, which has a majority stake in DHL and many freight forwarders; Federal Express; U.P.S.; TPG; the United States Postal Service, which is a $70-billion-a-year revenue company; and some form of cooperation between other major postal services. Out of this there will be some consolidation.

Q. Who might want to make a purchase?

A. A rumor that has been heating up recently is that DHL is going to buy Airborne Express. That may face some difficulty, because there are regulations preventing foreign ownership of more than 25 percent of an airline. Since it went public, U.P.S. has made a number of small acquisitions. Within the next couple of years, I think they will use their stock or cash to make a large overseas acquisition.

Q. You aren't recommending these stocks now, but which do you like long term?

A. U.P.S. generates the most free cash, followed by TPG and then Federal Express. Long term, I think these are terrific names. They are a play on world trade, which I believe will continue to grow.
