HEADLINE: THE AGE OF DISSONANCE; 
Our Town

BYLINE:  By BOB MORRIS 

 BODY:
SOMETIMES, when I get really tired of being concerned and vigilant, or supportive of political leaders whom I otherwise might not support in times of less import, I think back to the good old days in New York before Sept. 11. 
 That was a time when nothing seemed inappropriate in this city. Halloween was a time for giddy satirization of silly current events, and if the holiday was at all threatening, it was because you might get hit with an egg or covered in shaving cream. It doesn't seem fun or threatening now. 
 And the reality TV shows that were such a big deal last year don't seem so gripping. What's the point of "Survivor" and "The Fear Factor" exactly? Isn't making someone eat bugs or lie with rats kind of silly in the context of now? In a new show, "The Amazing Race," perky Americans on a global trek face their scariest moments when their flights are canceled. 
Oh, for the days of the old kind of air rage.
Back then, we lived in a world when no frivolity was too frivolous. We could whine freely about having too many parties to attend. No scandal was too arcane to warrant a line in the gossip columns. In those days we didn't have to apologize for obsessing over celebrity and other silly things. Silly things, after all, like the glossy-magazine industry, awards ceremonies, lavish movie premieres, boutique hotel design and competitive dining were a serious part of the economic life of New York. 
They still are, but we can't quite take them so seriously anymore. 
If you were to go back to the days before, what day would you choose? 
I would choose Sept. 10. It was Fashion Week -- remember? -- and I was more than a little pleased with myself for getting my niece, Madeleine, into the Betsey Johnson show at Tavern on the Green. I have to say, there couldn't have been a prettier venue. The outdoor restaurant was a Seurat-like dapple of light under big trees, and the greenhouse-like room where the show was taking place was a souffle of pretty people.
"Did I tell you how lucky you are to be here?" I asked.
"Yes, two times," said Madeleine, who is 9.
The theme of the collection was La Munequita, which means "little doll" in Spanish, the perfect atmosphere for a 9-year-old's first runway experience. She took in the crowd -- the phalanx of anxious photographers, the department store executives and top editors who cultivate looks that seem to want you to know that looking at clothes is important and serious work.
When the show began, taking things seriously became difficult. As the models strode past in diaphanous skirts and frothy little chiffon tops, Madeleine asked, "Why are they showing their underwear?"
I had taken her to her first fashion show expecting her to be swept up by the whimsy, the glamour, the privilege. All she saw was underwear. I was so miffed I didn't hear her thank me for bringing her.
That night, I went to a fourth-anniversary party for Rocco DiSpirito's restaurant Union Pacific. I talked to a nice, fresh-faced guy from northern Michigan named Bing Brown. It was his very first day living in New York. He had spent it opening a checking account at Citibank and riding his scooter around. Then he found himself at a celebrity chef's party. 
"Wow, is this what New York is going to be like?" Mr. Brown asked. "Are there parties like this all the time?"
I told him yes.
In Thornton Wilder's "Our Town," Emily, a young woman who has died, is given the chance to return to the world for one day, and it ends up being too heartbreaking to bear, the wonder of daily life. "So all that was going on and we never noticed," she says. "Do human beings ever realize life while they live -- every, every minute?"
The last I remember of my former life in our town on Sept. 10, I was leaving the party, mad at myself for drinking too much and eating too many hors d'oeuvres. 
I look back and pine for such meaningless anxieties.
I long for the times when underwear issues mattered, when we could skim the newspapers with the carelessness of the invincible, care about our Halloween plans, and be scared only by what we saw in the movies.
I long for the days when we could take things for granted.
Now we are more aware of everything. Consciousness has a steep price.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: CAREER ARC; 
The Company Was Downsized. Now You're Upsized.

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
FROM the day he joined UGO Networks nearly three years ago, Alexander Loucopoulos relied on the company's sales director for guidance on moving ahead in his career. 
 Mr. Loucopoulos moved up the corporate ladder, all right -- into the position of his mentor, who was one of 40 employees laid off early this month in a third round of job cuts since last year by UGO, an online entertainment company. Actually, Mr. Loucopoulos, who was hired to help raise venture capital, took over two jobs; he is now a senior director in charge of both sales and strategic planning. 
 Although his friend found another job quickly, the incident was emotionally draining. "This guy and I were, and still are, very close," said Mr. Loucopoulos, 27, of Manhattan. 
Career experts say his experience reflects a trend: as the economy weakens, more employers will tighten their work forces, and many of the remaining employees will find themselves catapulted into the jobs of their bosses, or even their bosses' bosses.
"When you cut so many people, somebody's got to step in and pick up some of the slack," said Barry Lawrence, senior career adviser at CareerBuilders, a Web site for job seekers that is based in Reston, Va. Nearly 60 percent of the 1,200 full-time workers it surveyed in August said their workloads had increased within the last six months because of layoffs.
While those who survive the corporate ax may find career opportunities, they may also face potential problems.
First is the issue of money. Even though they may receive fancy new titles, some people promoted during these tough times may not receive fatter paychecks. Mr. Loucopoulos, for one, said he did not get a raise after his promotion, although he was given stock.
Danielle Rampino, 23, was promoted recently to account manager from customer service representative at a New England manufacturing company that she declined to identify. She said she did not dare to ask for more money. "Salaries have been cut, so a raise is out of the question," she said. Her promotion came after the company laid off 11 percent of its workers in a third wave of cuts last month.
SUCH situations are all too common, said Bill Coleman, vice president for compensation at Salary.com in Wellesley, Mass., which tracks pay. "It's very awkward for companies to hand out raises after they've just canned people or handed out pay cuts," he said. "So people are getting lots of new responsibilities but taking home the same money."
Although the newly promoted may not care to seek more money now, they may want to revisit the subject with their superiors later, as financial conditions improve, career experts say. They recommend keeping a record of accomplishments -- listing sales totals, for example, or new business brought in. 
They also suggest that instead of requesting raises, employees can initially seek other perks and benefits -- perhaps an extra week of vacation or partial tuition reimbursement, if outside training is needed for their future work.
Even more unsettling for some promoted workers are the reactions of others. "If the person you're replacing was well liked and seen as more experienced, you're going to have a huge challenge on your hands," said Emory Mulling, chairman of the Mulling Companies, an outplacement firm in Atlanta. "People won't feel like you deserve the job."
Peggy Klaus, a career coach in Berkeley, Calif., said that one of her clients, a bank executive, had that experience after her recent promotion to vice president. The woman's 30 new subordinates were not only furious that their old boss had been fired but also skeptical about their new boss's ability to handle the job.
"Pretty soon, they were undermining her authority every chance they could get," Ms. Klaus said. Some subordinates made important decisions without consulting her, while others were downright rude, she said.
Ms. Klaus advised her client to call her new team together for a frank conversation. "I call it 'acknowledging the pink elephant in the room,' " Ms. Klaus said. "If you don't let people air their grievances and fears, then you give them license to go around spending an inordinate time whining about it at the water cooler."
Once the new vice president allowed her employees to open up about why they felt resentful, Ms. Klaus said, they became more comfortable with her.
Mr. Loucopoulos used a similar strategy to win over his five employees after his promotion. "I took the tack of overcommunication," said Mr. Loucopoulos, who has watched his company shrink to 35 employees from 240. "I let them know I felt bad, too, about these people leaving. I think my openness resonated with them."
Perhaps the biggest problem for layoff survivors who are promoted is that many do not receive the training or resources needed to succeed in their new positions. After all, the people most equipped to train them, their predecessors, are gone.
Ms. Rampino said that when she recently asked her superiors for help in figuring out what prices to quote her customers, her request fell on deaf ears. Her manager was too overloaded with work to help. One associate said he could not assist her, but offered the name of his golf pro in the event she wanted to play a few rounds with clients. "That was real helpful," she said.
Because she has received so little training, she has had to learn her new job through trial and error, she said. For example, she said she did not know that it was customary for account managers to pad the shipping deadline by several days. "I had no idea that the production floor was accustomed to completing the product later than the due date shown in the system," she said.
As a result, Ms. Rampino said, she stayed at work on one recent night until after 10 p.m. to ensure that an order was completed, then delivered it to the customer the next morning. "I am trying to pretend as best as I can that this is my job," she said.
Ms. Rampino said she was considering leaving the company and enrolling in an M.B.A. program so she could develop the skills to become an account manager. "I just don't have the resources I need to be good at this job," she said.
Of course, not all promoted employees have to fend for themselves. At HighPoint Solutions, a World Wide Web development company in Tacoma, Wash., three people who were promoted recently, after a hiring freeze, were paired with mentors to help them learn their new jobs. One such worker was Nicole Fritts, 20, of Lakewood, Wash., who joined the company in June 2000 as a receptionist. In June 2001, she became an associate producer.
"Being a producer was a future goal, but I never expected to be promoted this quickly," said Ms. Fritts, who handled client billing and other administrative tasks before tackling the new job. Now she works side by side with clients daily, helping them to develop strategies for new Web sites.
To smooth the transition, Steven Brock, the chief executive, first let Ms. Fritts sit in on client team meetings. After a few weeks, she began participating in brainstorming sessions to help clients work out new marketing plans. "I just kept my eyes and ears open and really paid attention to how our producers interacted with clients," she said. She also made a habit of reading industry trade publications. Eventually, Mr. Brock gave Ms. Fritts her own clients, although he continued to pair her with more senior producers to hone her skills.
"Everyone here has made it clear I can come to them with any question," she said. "That's helped a lot."
ANYONE without a mentor should find one, career experts say. "Take company executives out to lunch and ask them as many questions as possible," Ms. Klaus said. "Grill them about their successes and failures, as well as company politics that you might not be aware of."
If there is no one available at work, consider joining a local trade organization, she added. "Get coaching from as many people as you can," she said.
The payoff can be significant. Although his promotion was bittersweet, Mr. Loucopoulos said he thought it had helped his career. In addition to managing a sales team, he works directly with the chief executive to explore new business partnerships and strategies. "I've gained more confidence and all kinds of managerial skills," he said. "And I'm helping create a vision for this company. This is big, big stuff."

GRAPHIC: Photo: For Alexander Loucopoulos, the layoff of 40 employees at UGO Networks provided an unexpected opportunity for advancement. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: URBAN TACTICS; 
A Lost City, Reborn for Now

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
NEW YORK is forever disappearing. We live amid many lost cities: F. Scott Fitzgerald's glittering, white boomtown. E. B. White's hot, haunting August of 1948. The small society of the midcentury eccentric Joe Gould. Dan Wakefield's Greenwich Village of the 50's.
 There's also that perennial vision of a livable place with quiet museum galleries and uncrowded sidewalks, where it's easy to get a good seat at the movies. That city always seems just out of reach. 
 It's hard to say exactly when it disappeared, or whether it ever really existed. Certainly, the advent of the blockbuster art exhibition in the 1970's forever altered the museum experience. With the decrease in crime of the last decade, and a booming economy, the world came rushing into New York, especially tourists, both domestic and foreign. According to NYC & Company, the convention and visitors bureau, more than 37 million people visited the city last year, up from about 23 million in 1991. 
But, now, at certain moments -- not always and not everywhere -- it is possible to find that lost, livable place.
At first the darkened theaters, the shuttered museums and hushed streets brought about by the events of Sept. 11 came as a rebuke. Now, the emptiness is not quite so stark. It seems, instead, like a sudden expanse. The crowds are escapable. The noise sometimes disappears. For a brief interlude, the city has returned to roughly habitable dimensions. It comes in flashes, this more nimble city, which has been relieved -- at horrible cost -- of the weight of tourism.
There is room once again for wonder, especially at art museums. Last Wednesday, 8,600 people visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art, down from 12,000 a year ago. In the previous fiscal year, nearly 1.3 million people visited the Museum of Modern Art, an average of 3,530 a day. Since Sept. 11, average daily attendance has fallen by 40 percent (although the new Giacometti exhibition has buoyed the numbers). At the Frick Collection, which drew 290,000 visitors last year, attendance has dropped by 30 to 40 percent.
Since the observation deck at the Empire State Building reopened on Sept. 29, weekend attendance has been off 30 percent.
Last weekend, the Pieter Bruegel exhibit at the Met was packed, but the European galleries weren't. No one was looking at the Fragonards. Caravaggio's ripe young musicians played in an empty room. The climate-control system hummed. It was so quiet that a woman could be heard clearing her throat.
In the museum's Robert Lehman wing, the strange elation of silence grew. Seven lonely chairs sat before a wall lined with paintings by Bonnard, Braque, Chagall, van Gogh, Gauguin and Vuillard. No one looked on Degas's rooftops or Cezanne's naked trees lining the road to Tholonet. The Renoirs had been abandoned.
Outside, there was not much pedestrian traffic in Central Park, despite the magnificence of the day. An occasional horse-drawn carriage clopped by. Sheep Meadow was dotted with sparse clusters of people, which only seemed to highlight the vastness of the green expanse. Sounds seemed to come as if from a distance: the merry-go-round, the children, the radios, the laughter and recriminations of strangers.
Downtown, at the Museum of Jewish Heritage, at 1 Battery Park Plaza, visitors were greeted by a passage from Deuteronomy: "Remember. Never Forget." Voices from the past bounced around the deserted galleries.
"It's eerie," said Thomas Vinson, a photographer who lives on the Upper West Side and visited the museum one day last week. "When you walk out of a little room into a hallway and all you see is a security guard, it reinforces the solemnity. It's double-edged. It's good, but the reason it's like that is bad."
Nearby, Battery Park was heavy with history but otherwise empty. Beneath an enormous Apple Computer advertisement featuring images of Churchill, Martin Luther King Jr., Gandhi and Franklin D. Roosevelt, visitors could look on the Statue of Liberty in solitude. Ellis Island was dark. All that could be heard was the slow traffic of boats and the even slap of the sea.
Last week, a person could also hear the ticking of the 18th-century mantle clock in the library of the Frick Collection.
"We've been wanting to come here for a long time," said Joe Pantigoso, who was at the museum with his wife, Jane King. The couple, who live on the Upper West Side, had recently visited the American Museum of Natural History, which normally throbs with children.
"It was empty," Ms. King said. "We were with our daughter, and she could run around."
Her husband, a marketing executive, added: "It's better for New Yorkers. Every place has become more like the Frick. You can take your time without having to fight for space in front of a painting."
On Monday evening, a thin stream of people could be seen heading east over the Brooklyn Bridge. Among them was Leslie Farrar, wearing business clothes and sneakers, who first had walked the three miles from her job in Lower Manhattan to her home in Cobble Hill on Sept. 11. "I felt like a refugee," she said of that first trip. "Then I realized it wasn't such a bad commute."
The bike lane was, miraculously, free of people taking photographs. "There's less tourists, less gawking," said Albert Stern, an editor who has been walking over the bridge from his Water Street office to his Boerum Hill home for three and a half years.
 NEW YORK has become a place where it is possible to simply show up, buy a ticket and walk into a theater. On Tuesday, 20 minutes before curtain, only two-thirds of the tickets to New York City Opera's production of "Macbeth," with the soprano Lauren Flanigan as Lady Macbeth, had been sold. The night before, it was possible to arrive at 7:42 for a 7:45 showing of "Bread and Tulips," a gentle Italian comedy at the little Quad Cinema on West 13th Street, buy some Jujyfruits and get an excellent seat. With only 18 people, the audience was small enough for camaraderie. A slow night in the old world might have drawn at least 25 people.
There was also camaraderie in the elevator of the Empire State Building, which reopened its observatory full time on Monday. "Let's not talk about scary," a woman said. At the 50th floor, ears began to pop. A man extolled the benefits of skyscrapers in Minnesota. "They're three stories tall," he said, laughing.
The wind on the observation deck was vicious. Beneath the night sky, the city spread out her jewels.
Conversation hummed along in German, French, Spanish, English and Japanese: Where's Brooklyn? Is that Times Square? Is that Broadway? Remember Godzilla? Look, they're still smoking.
The sky was big. Airplanes passed nearly at eye level. After Pearl Harbor, volunteer "spotters" were stationed on the observation deck of the Empire State Building, part of a network that tracked airplanes as they flew over the city's blacked-out streets. Watching the planes fly past the moon, it was hard not to think of the spotters and even harder not to envy them. They knew what they were looking for.

HEADLINE: New Yorkers on Welfare 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Since we are currently witnessing the greatest outpouring of altruism in our country's history, it strikes us as tragic that 50,000 of New York State's poorest residents will have their cash welfare benefits terminated in December (editorial, Oct. 25).
 A hundred thousand jobs have been lost, and the economy is facing a serious recession. 
Are we to expect that moving people off welfare now will have a benign effect on their lives? 
 We fear that terminating benefits will result in destabilizing families, increasing homelessness and adding to the foster care rolls. Given the cooperation between the city, the state and the federal government in light of the disaster, it is reasonable to expect our elected leaders to find a way to put a moratorium on welfare time limits. Calling for a smoother transition to a so-called safety-net program is simply not adequate.

ROBERT S. SCHACHTER
New York, Oct. 25, 2001

The writer is executive director, National Association of Social Workers, New York City Chapter.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Looking for Hints in the Treasury's Next Move

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
ON Wednesday, when the details of the next quarterly auction of government securities are announced, the Treasury should offer some hints about how it will handle the swing from huge government budget surpluses to none at all. But the Treasury is not expected to make any drastic changes in the way it does business.
 For one thing, the Treasury is assuming that any budget deficits will be temporary. If surpluses return in future years, the need for increased borrowing wouldn't last long. 
 That assumption is partly political. But it is too soon for the Treasury to decide otherwise, with forecasters expecting the economy to recover sometime next year. The Treasury also does not want to do anything that might send longer-term interest rates higher and thus hinder the prospects foreconomic recovery.
Peter R. Fisher, the undersecretary of the Treasury for domestic finance, noted happily last week that the threat of additional borrowing by the Treasury had not yet pushed longer-term rates higher.
"My own reading of the yield curve gives me cause for optimism, not pessimism," he said in a speech in New York. "Ten-year yields are lower now than they were in August, so we have not seen any backup in long-term rates that might suggest anxiety about our long-run fiscal prospects." He also said the additional borrowing would "easily be absorbed by our capital markets."
Treasury officials are not talking on the record about their thinking before the announcement, scheduled for Wednesday, on the quarterly auction of 5-year and 10-year notes on Nov. 6 and 7. But it appears that the announcement will set in motion a plan to cover as much as $300 billion in extra borrowing by selling additional Treasury bills and short-term notes, like the two-year note.
The size of the monthly two-year note auction has already been increased to $19 billion from $10 billion in May. And the weekly auctions of six-month Treasury bills have jumped to $17.8 billion from $13.6 billion during that time. The Treasury has also begun selling a new four-week bill -- $8 billion of them last week.
Because of this additional short-term borrowing, the size of the five-year note auction will rise just $1 billion or $2 billion above the $13 billion in May. The 10-year note auction will be around $5 billion, less than the expected $10 billion because of the unscheduled auction on Oct. 4 of $6 billion of additional 10-year notes. That was done to relieve distortions in the Treasury market in the wake of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11.
In addition, the Treasury is expected to continue buying back longer-term debt, although the total may decline each year. Those buybacks, suspended in September because of the disruption in bond market trading, resumed on Oct. 18.
Concentrating its borrowing in shorter-term securities fits well with two Treasury goals. One is to try to move the average maturity of the government debt back toward five years. As government deficits declined and became surpluses, the Treasury reduced its borrowing, and many of those cutbacks were in short-term securities. So the average maturity of government debt is now six years.
Another goal is to reduce the cost of borrowing for the taxpayer over time. Issuing Treasury bills with yields just over 2 percent and two-year notes with yields of 2.6 percent should do that. Selling two-year notes now also fills a void in 2003 and 2004, when the amount of maturing government debt is due to decline.
The yield on the 10-year note, now 4.52 percent, is near its 1998 low of 4.16 percent, and some people may say that such low longer-term interest rates should be locked in for future savings. But Louis Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson Associates, said greater long-term savings could be achieved using lower-yielding maturities, especially if the return to government deficits is brief.
James R. Capra, president of Capra Asset Management and chairman of the Treasury's debt advisory committee, agreed. "The short-term debt is cheaper and there is no urgency to make major adjustments," he said.

HEADLINE: Magazines Fly the Flag Offering Upbeat Chic 

BYLINE:  By RUTH LA FERLA 

 BODY:
IN the editor's letter she plans to put in the December issue of Harper's Bazaar, which will appear on newsstands the middle of next month, Glenda Bailey, the new editor in chief, asks pointedly, "What is it we're supposed to feel for fashion right now?"
 It's a question she and her peers in magazine publishing are asking, along with designers, retailers and readers: what is the appropriate response of fashion when world events seem to render its normal concerns petty or escapist? Putting it bluntly, how can one think of being chic at such a time? 
 For Ms. Bailey, the issue is even more pressing than for others, since she arrived at Bazaar only in June, charged with making over the magazine at a difficult moment for it and many of its competitors. Hit hard by a faltering economy and a growing disenchantment among readers, Bazaar has had a significant drop in circulation and newsstand sales. 
Now many consumers, anxious and vulnerable at a time of national crisis, are placing fashion ever lower on their roster of priorities. Industry watchers point out that even the most devout readers of America's scented style bibles may find themselves wondering whether the magazines bear relevance to their lives. "The magazines have been living on borrowed time," said Simon Doonan, the creative director of Barneys New York. "The consumer wants to be intrigued, and she hasn't been a bit."
The response to Ms. Bailey's question is evident in the November fashion magazines now on newsstands and in the plans of editors for future issues. It is nearly unanimous: this is no time for sackcloth and ashes. Readers are being served a large helping of upbeat escapism, wrapped in red, white and blue, its visual content bearing no more relation to their lives than Bali does to Queens.
"The most important part of my job," Ms. Bailey said last week, "is to reflect what the reader wants. My vision of giving her what she wants is to send her the very best fashion and beauty that addresses the need for pure fantasy. What she wants, now more than ever, is to live in the moment."
For her December issue she plans a cover with Meg Ryan posed against an American flag. An article titled "Rock Stars," photographed by Hiro, will lavishly showcase what Ms. Bailey called "diamonds to desire -- very fantasy-inducing, very luxurious and very beautiful."
In the November Vogue, meanwhile, models cavort gamely, their smiles cheerily vacant as they show off clothes that only a well-dressed sylph might wear. Rather than being dressed in black, the chic color this fall even before it became a season of mourning, the models are vividly decked out in red, white and blue -- designers' hopeful colors for spring, accessorized with American flags pinned to sleeves and lapels.
The magazine seems intent on helping readers rationalize a lust for over-the-knee calfskin boots, envelope bags and gilt charm bracelets. Even in moments of great stress, Anna Wintour, the editor in chief, writes in the issue, "fashion is essential in these difficult times, paradoxically, to keep us in touch with our dreamy, fanciful, self-pleasing natures."
Last week, in an interview, Ms. Wintour said, "I don't think any of us can pretend we are feeling it's business as usual." And the November issue, adroitly revamped in the days after Sept. 11, includes an obituary of Berry Berenson, the fashion icon who perished on American Airlines Flight 11, and a profile of Dr. Bernadine Healy, the president of the American Red Cross, who is photographed at ground zero, a grieved expression on her face.
But tellingly, the new fashion features hurriedly conceived to capture the moment all strike a resolutely upbeat chord. On the Vogue cover Britney Spears stretches languorously atop the Stars and Stripes, a pose that Ms. Wintour said is meant to evoke Betty Grable rallying the troops in World War II. "We acted on pure instinct and decided to jump in as fast as we could," she said.
Inside, Vogue's fashion pages promote Americana. A portfolio featuring the Seventh Avenue spring collections includes an image of a model encased in a Calvin Klein corset, posed against a Manhattan skyline and robustly waving a flag. Future issues, Ms. Wintour said, will continue to replace dour gray and black with clothes that are colorful and fanciful.
Similarly, the editors of W pulled together a 12-page portfolio, a portrait of Manhattan viewed through the lenses of its fashion photographers, some reflecting patriotic themes, like an American flag draped over a pickup truck. "We wanted to respond to the moment in a manner that was provocative but not sentimental or false," said Dennis Freedman, the magazine's creative director.
Gilles Bensimon, the publication director of Elle, professed a reluctance to tug at readers' hearts in an obvious or calculated manner. "Who is editing these magazines, Norman Rockwell?" he said.
Readers, he cautioned, are quick to see though such ploys, the reason he said Elle prefers a more subtle approach. All the same, its current cover includes a postage-stamp-size American flag above the legend "United We Stand," an echo of Vogue's cover from July 1942, which had the same slogan.
Fashion magazines have traditionally operated in a hothouse climate, one in which staff members meet covenlike in posh conference rooms, debating such arcana as the shape of a sleeve, the width of a cuff or the optimum height for a Cossack hat. In her November editor's letter, the first Ms. Bailey wrote at Bazaar, where she in the process of a months-long retinkering of the magazine, she declared, "Our aim is to share the thrill of finding the ultimate handbag, or the perfect shoe."
It's an open question whether, in the current world, that thrill can still make women's hearts race. Fashion magazines have been been "talking mostly to themselves," said Mr. Doonan of Barney's, offering consumers little more than a parade of models -- "Jane Birkin wannabes, who look hit on the head with a frying pan."
"That vacant approach has lost its resonance completely," he said.
Ms. Bailey, who arrived at Bazaar after a successful run as editor of the more populist Marie Claire, began putting her stamp on her new magazine in the November issue, with such signature features as a detailed peek into the closets of four real women, under the headline "What Does Your Style Reveal About You?"
For the December issue she assigned an essay, "Getting On With It," on how to live with fear. But the visual content, she promised, will offer readers flights of fancy. "That's what you come to Bazaar for," she said. "Beautiful images which really are inspiring."
"If I were editing a fashion magazine now," said Marian McEvoy, the editor in chief of House Beautiful, "I would keep away from kitsch, camp and vulgarity and humanize the way fashions are shown." Ms. McEvoy, a former editor at Elle and W, envisions articles that take readers into the homes of fashion designers, affording intimate glimpses of their lives. "I want to see Ralph Lauren in his bedroom slippers before a fire," she said, "and Miuccia Prada and her husband cooking penne in their kitchen in Milan."
As for fashion, "it has to be more comfortable, that's for sure," Ms. McEvoy said, "but that doesn't mean more casual or sad."
"Once people get over the shock and the feeling that they have to sacrifice something," she said, "they will want to give themselves a treat. Women don't like to suffer too much or too long." 
She might have been describing Helen Schifter, a New York social figure. "Fashion magazines make a good break from other, intense, reading," Ms. Schifter said. "A good antidote to bitter times, and in some strange way a reminder that life goes on."

(pg. 1); RED, WHITE AND YOU -- This spread from the November Vogue shows what the fashion glossies think readers want, in a climate that's anything but business as usual. (pg. 7)

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
The Risk Of Not Weighing Risk

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
CERTAIN that government stimulus and multiple interest rate cuts will put the steel back into stock prices, bullish strategists are advising investors to buy now so that they won't miss the inevitable and imminent turn. Never mind that many of these brokerage-firm carnival barkers have been predicting the end of the bear market since the Federal Reserve began its easing action in January.
 Typically, stocks do begin to recover well before an impaired economy does. Since 1960, according to statisticians at Standard & Poor's, the stock market has bottomed, on average, seven months after a recession has begun. But averages can be deceiving. While the market bottomed just three months after the 1990 recession started, it took 13 months of recession before stocks started their recovery from the 1980-81 downturn. 
 Like Leo Tolstoy's unhappy families, every slump is different. And the terror attacks will give this recession a nature all its own. That's because corporate earnings, already in decline, will be further stunted by the increased costs associated with life among the terrorists. 
Investors do not yet seem focused on how much higher the costs of doing business will be in the harrowing new world. Soon, they will have to be.
Even before Sept. 11, insurance costs were on the rise. The business is extremely cyclical: prices fall when insurers try to gain market share and rise when they try to bolster their profits. Add to this the not-yet-measurable costs of increased security and you have a big drag on earnings. 
Alice Cornish, an analyst at Prudential Securities in Boston, has done a thorough analysis of the higher costs to cover risk that American companies will face in coming months. Those costs will not be clear until the government decides how much of the bill for Sept. 11 it will pay and how much it will make insurance companies cover. Still, Ms. Cornish expects pretax profits for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index will drop by an average 2.5 percent in 2002 because of higher insurance prices.
"There is a very high probability that the insurance market next year will be the most difficult ever for finding affordable coverage," Ms. Cornish said. Why? Corporations will not only find insurance more expensive to secure, they will also have to agree to higher deductibles.
FOR years, companies have enjoyed low insurance costs. In 1999, premiums were lower than they were in 1984, Ms. Cornish pointed out. Earlier this year, they began to rise. Technology companies, for example, started experiencing large jumps in professional liability insurance, like directors' and officers' insurance, which is used to cover the costs of shareholder lawsuits.
Ms. Cornish has assessed the likely rise in several industries' cost of covering risk next year. Costs include business interruption and property insurance, workers' compensation premiums and payments for consulting services. 
The results vary widely. While Ms. Cornish estimates that such costs will rise 36.6 percent at communications services concerns, pretax earnings should decline, at most, by only 2.3 percent. But at health care companies, whose risk costs are already high, costs may jump 35.5 percent, causing an 11.5 percent hit to pretax earnings. 
Increased costs will also drag down earnings at cyclical consumer companies, like car makers and appliance manufacturers, where earnings could decline as much as 8.2 percent, and makers of consumer staples -- food companies -- which could see their pretax profits fall 5.4 percent.
Although Ms. Cornish reckons that technology companies' costs of risk will rise 44.1 percent next year, they are starting from a very low base and will have a muted impact on profits. Financial companies are in similar circumstances, she said. 
Some companies will be hurt more than others, because risks vary. But Ms. Cornish said: "Insurance premiums now need to return to a level more commensurate with the risk. Sept. 11 has influenced this perception."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Peter J. Quinn; 
UAM Clipper Focus Portfolio

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
PETER J. QUINN, co-manager of the $250 million UAM Clipper Focus Portfolio, calls himself a contrarian investor.
 "We look for companies that are out of favor for what we believe are temporary reasons," Mr. Quinn, 40, said from his office in Beverly Hills, Calif. 
 The strategy has helped the fund return 14.3 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with 4.1 percent for its peers in the large value category and 2.2 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar Inc. For the last 12 months, the fund ranked No. 1 among 785 large value funds by returning 20.1 percent, versus an average loss of 4.9 percent for the group and a decline of 18.4 percent for the S.& P. 500. 
Mr. Quinn also manages about $3 billion in institutional accounts for Pacific Financial Research, the fund's investment adviser. Pacific Financial Research was acquired in 1997 by United Asset Management, which in turn was acquired last year by Old Mutual P.L.C., a financial services group based in London. 
He works with four other co-managers and two equity analysts to pick the fund's 25 to 40 stocks from among 800 or so companies with market capitalization of $2 billion or more.
In one computer screen, he looks for companies that have repurchased 3 percent or more of their shares in the last 12 months.
"This is a way that management can demonstrate its willingness to invest in the current infrastructure," he said.
Another screen seeks low ratios of price to free cash flow, going back as far as 10 years. Free cash flow measures how much a company can earn after it reinvests what is needed to expand its business, he said. "We look beyond accounting earnings to determine the real profitability of a business," he added.
Still other screens measure debt levels and revenue streams. He hopes to find companies whose operating earnings may be temporarily depressed because of new product introductions, for example, or capital investments.
Two of the fund's co-managers research companies that emerge from the screens. One aims to prove that a stock is worth buying, Mr. Quinn said; the other tries to discredit the idea. Then they average their estimates of the stock's intrinsic value, based on the company's cash flow over five years. If the shares sell for a discount of at least 30 percent to that figure, the fund buys the stock. Shares are sold if they rise to the intrinsic value.
Falling stock prices after Sept. 11 led Mr. Quinn to buy shares in United Technologies, whose units include Pratt & Whitney, the jet engine manufacturer; Otis, the elevator company; and Carrier, the air-conditioner maker.
"We're very comfortable with how management allocates capital," he said. It makes significant share repurchases, he added, and reinvests to enhance the company's dominant market positions.
The fund paid an average of $46.30 a share for the stock; it closed on Friday at $57.01. He calculates its intrinsic value at $65.
Mr. Quinn began buying shares of American Express, the financial, banking and travel services giant, at an average of $34.78 in March and has been adding to the stake. "This is a company with a very strong global franchise and an extremely valuable brand name," he said.
Because the company is somewhat dependent on travel, he added, valuations became attractive as the economy slowed.
On Friday, the shares closed at $30.72; he says their intrinsic value is $50.
He also likes Pitney Bowes, which offers mailing products and services.
"The company has done reasonably well in past economic times because it has high recurring revenue streams," he said, partly because many of its products are leased rather than sold outright. Management controls costs aggressively, he said, and is benefiting from lower interest rates.
The fund bought shares in October 2000 at an average of $27.64; they closed on Friday at $34.91. He puts their intrinsic value at $45.

HEADLINE: Business; 
With Aircraft Idle, Income Reads Zero

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

 BODY:
THE roar of propellers and the whir of chopper blades have returned to airfields, heliports and landing pads across much of the country as the federal government has gradually eased a blanket ban on small aircraft enforced in the weeks immediately after Sept. 11. "Much," however, is the operative word.
 In 30 major cities, a wide range of small aircraft, from blimps to traffic-monitoring helicopters, remain grounded. And in New York, Boston and Washington, no-flight zones remain in force for all small private aircraft. Some restrictions may be made permanent, to help minimize the chance of airborne terrorism. 
 Most people, especially in congested parts of the Northeast, may not have noticed far fewer small aircraft buzzing about, save for police, military and medical emergency helicopters. But the small-aircraft segment of the aviation industry has taken a terrific blow. 
From Maine to the Washington suburbs of Virginia, the no-fly order has cost private pilots and companies hundreds of millions of dollars in lost business. And it has rendered largely useless the helicopters that many big companies keep for ferrying executives from urban meetings to suburban outposts and back.
No longer can Donald Trump's helicopter whisk him from one of Manhattan's three heliports to his Atlantic City casinos; instead, Mr. Trump, along with hundreds of other executives, must now deal with clogged streets and highways like everyone else. Trips from Manhattan to suburbs in New Jersey or Westchester County, which took 15 minutes or less by helicopter, can now take two hours or more.
"You have a whole lot of irritated C.E.O.'s," said the vice president of finance for a Fortune 500 corporation based in New Jersey, who asked that neither his name nor that of his firm be used. "It really brings the great ones down to the level of the rest of us."
Manhattan's downtown heliport, now basically idle, reported 28,692 takeoffs and landings last year, an average of 78 a day, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Companies with helicopters based at the heliport include DHL and Dow Jones; dozens of others rented helicopter services at the site.
From there, Washington is less than an hour away by helicopter, said Phillip M. Ozenick Jr., chief executive of Heliflite Inc. of Fort Worth, a seller of fractional helicopter ownerships, similar to the time-share deals for business jets. Prices for a big, twin-engine Bell helicopter with a pilot and co-pilot start at just under $500,000 a year for a one-sixteenth share, including maintenance and 50 flying hours a year -- enough for 25 round trips between Manhattan and Washington.
Before the attacks, Mr. Ozenick's company did 95 percent of its East Coast business in and out of Manhattan. His corporate customers, whom he declined to identify, travel not only for business, but to weekend homes in the Hamptons, New England and Virginia. "They've been greatly inconvenienced," Mr. Ozenick said. But he said he had not heard whining about it. "These are pretty extenuating circumstances. Everybody has been pretty patient."
THE Manhattan heliports contribute $140 million to the New York economy each year, according to the Port Authority. In the five days immediately after Sept. 11, helicopter operators around the country lost $30 million, said the Helicopter Association International, a trade association representing 3,000 corporate helicopter operators worldwide. The group did not have an estimate for total losses since the attacks, but said New York helicopter operators lost about $6 million.
"One thing that's been brought out from this terrible tragedy is how much the country depends on general aviation," including helicopters, said Roy D. Resavage, the association's president. He expressed frustration at the continued restrictions.
"There's been a lot of aircraft left on the ground for a long time, and we don't understand how it increases security and safety," he said. 
Continued appeals by lobbying groups to the Federal Aviation Administration, Congress and the Transportation Department have achieved some results. The F.A.A. was working Friday on a proposal that would lift most small-aircraft restrictions in cities except for New York, Washington and Boston. If security officials approved, a phase-in could begin as early as this week.
The decisions in these cases, federal officials say, are up to the National Security Council and federal law enforcement agencies. And with new anthrax scares spreading, war in Afghanistan and other national concerns, restrictions on private aviation are hardly considered an issue of vital importance.
"My sense is that it's not the No. 1, 2, 3 or 4 priority," said Kevin Mitchell, president of the Business Travel Coalition, which represents corporate travelers, including those on private planes.
Bruce McNeely, senior vice president of aircraft management services at Jet Service International, said, "The N.S.C. and the other agencies don't really understand general aviation." His company operates at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey, 15 miles from Manhattan.
The restrictions have prompted Steven P. Bussmann, of Manassas, Va., to consider abandoning his fledgling aviation business. During the summer, Mr. Bussmann, 44, spent $500,000 on a used helicopter and put it into service flying aerial photographers over Washington. He had hoped to clear $10,000 a month this fall, when skies are generally clear and the autumn colors spectacular.
But he has not flown since Sept. 9, the date of his last job. And with no sense of when officials may lift the restrictions, he said, "It would make better sense to cut my losses, sell my aircraft and shut down."
THE restrictions obviously have the biggest impact in the Northeast, where more than 10,000 private plane and helicopter flights originated from the Boston, New York and Washington airports in August, or one-seventh of the national total. But pilots elsewhere are hurting, too.
The plane that Wade Goetz rents to Denver broadcasters for traffic reports has been grounded since the attacks, costing him $10,000 a month in income. Mr. Goetz, the owner of Altitudes Flight Training in Englewood, Colo., also trains pilots for the Air Force Academy. Commanders there interceded with the government, obtaining an exemption for him so the training could continue.
Before the attacks, Mr. Goetz had been thinking of expanding his fleet by 25 to 35 planes, from his current 48, so that he could pick up more Air Force business. But given the restrictions still in place on other types of aircraft, he fears even tighter limits if there is another terrorist attack.
"I'm 40 years old, I've finally made a few dollars, and now I'm looking at it and doubting myself," he said. If his aircraft were grounded again for a lengthy period, he said, "I'd go bankrupt."
Even pilots whose aircraft have not been grounded are worried about the possible long-term economic impact of the restrictions. 
The limits at various East Coast airports have forced Jack Roush, an automobile racing executive based in Plymouth, Mich., to divert to locations he would not normally use for his fleet, which includes three Boeing 727 jets and a half-dozen smaller aircraft. For Mr. Roush, his drivers and crew, using the highways is too impractical and time-consuming to reach the Nascar, truck and other races in which his business, Roush Racing, competes. In his opinion, the limits must be lifted at all airports, and on all types of craft, if the country is to rebound.
"As a practical matter, we have to have the airways open to make our economy work," he said. "If we don't have people like myself and businesses like mine moving our people around, we stop spending money and then we stop being competitive."

HEADLINE: This Mr. Sunshine Sees More Rain 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
DOUGLAS R. CLIGGOTT, the senior stock market strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, is a born optimist.
 At 44, Mr. Cliggott, peppers his conversations with "Cool!" and "O.K.," and when he ends a call with "Great to talk to you," he sounds as if he means it. Asked what part of the workweek he likes best, he replies: "Fridays are my favorite. I shouldn't say that. No, I like all the days" -- without self-consciousness. 
 But Mr. Cliggott, who forecasts the equity market's direction for J. P. Morgan Securities, the investment banking arm of J. P. Morgan Chase, is anything but cheery about stocks. Since the spring of 2000, he has been more pessimistic about corporate earnings and the stock market than just about any other strategist. With the average stock in the Standard & Poor's 500 down about 30 percent over that span, his worries have proved all too real. 
Now, with stocks trying to rally for the third time this year, Mr. Cliggott is again warning his clients to be cautious. The market's recovery in the last month puzzles him. He believes that investors are underestimating how far corporate earnings will fall in the next few months and overestimating the speed at which they will recover.
His concerns increased on Sept. 11, though he has not tried to quantify the effect that further terrorist violence might have on the economy or on stocks -- the risk of more attacks is simply unknowable, he said. But by forcing businesses and the government to spend more money on security and defense, the attacks will probably slow economic growth and increase inflation for several years.
"The strength of the bounce in the market has certainly been a surprise for me," he said in an interview earlier this month in his modest office in Midtown Manhattan. As earnings plunge over the next few months, the market will follow, he said.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which includes most big American stocks, could fall to 800 by next spring, Mr. Cliggott said. At that level, the S.& P. would be TK percent below its Friday close of T,KTK, and almost 50 percent below its apex of March 2000.
His view is hardly common on Wall Street. Most strategists at other big securities firms say earnings could recover as early as the first quarter of 2002 and that a full-bore economic recovery will be evident by spring. The average strategist expects the S.& P. 500 to stand at 1,330 by the end of next year, 21 percent above Mr. Cliggott's forecast of 1,100. 
But for the last two years, the consensus has been wrong. As a result, Mr. Cliggott is catching the ears of investors who once listened closely to more bullish strategists like Abby Joseph Cohen, the chief United States stock strategist at Goldman, Sachs, and Jeffrey Applegate, the chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers. At her peak, Ms. Cohen, the star strategist of the late 1990's, moved markets with a few words. 
Mr. Cliggott is not nearly that influential -- at least not yet. But when Institutional Investor magazine listed its All-America Research Team on Oct. 17, based on a survey of professional money managers, Mr. Cliggott was ranked among the top strategists for the first time. He placed No. 3, behind Michael L. Goldstein of Sanford C. Bernstein and Edward M. Kerschner of UBS Warburg.
Mr. Cliggott was not the only bear on Wall Street during the last two years. But many of the others are dismissed by professional investors as "perma-bears," pessimists who have called stocks overvalued for a half-decade or more. Mr. Cliggott has been both bullish and bearish over that span.
"He's a great strategist," said Scott B. Schermerhorn, who manages $3 billion for Liberty Funds in Boston. Some strategists make up their minds about the market's direction, then search for data to support their views, Mr. Schermerhorn said, "but Doug just looks at data and interprets what the data seems to be telling him."
That strategy served Mr. Cliggott well in January, when the Federal Reserve made the first of nine cuts in short-term interest rates. Most of his rivals predicted that the cuts would prompt a strong recovery in the economy and in corporate earnings, which began to fall in the last months of 2000. But based on trends in corporate investment and commodities prices, Mr. Cliggott correctly said that earnings would remain weak and that the rally would not hold. His prediction that a late spring rally would fizzle also proved correct.
"He's been out there, in a bearish position, and he's been correct," said Jon D. Brorson, director of equities for Northern Trust, which manages $100 billion in United States stocks.
Mr. Cliggott says the secret to his accuracy over the last 18 months has been his focus on the direction of short-term corporate earnings. Predicting earnings more than a few months away is extremely difficult; most investors do not look more than two quarters ahead, he said. Other strategists also think corporate earnings are a vital indicator of the direction of stock prices, but they spend more time trying to determine what earnings may be in a year or two. Mr. Cliggott says that exercise is largely wasted. "Everyone wants to believe the market trades off earnings 18 months from now," he said. "It doesn't."
SO while other strategists, like Ms. Cohen, look at a broad basket of indicators, Mr. Cliggott has lately focused on corporate investment in the United States and commodity prices worldwide, the two statistics that J. P. Morgan has found are most closely correlated with short-term earnings trends.
Higher commodity prices are a sign that business activity is quickening, Mr. Cliggott said, while investment in computers, new plants and other equipment helps to increase productivity, driving the long-run growth of the economy.
Thanks to a quirk in accounting rules, rising business investment also gives a strong short-term boost to corporate profits. If Compaq sells new computers to Exxon Mobil, for example, Compaq can book the entire sale immediately as revenue. But because the computers are an investment that will lose value over time, Exxon Mobil can write off their cost gradually over several years.
As a result of the difference in the ways that the seller and the buyer treat the deal, periods of rising business investment are very good for corporate profits, Mr. Cliggott said.
The process works in reverse if business investment falls, as it has in recent months. Then companies like Compaq may see their sales fall, while companies such as Exxon Mobil will still be writing off investments they made in previous years.
Together, the direction of commodity prices and business investment accounts for about 65 percent of the short-term swings in corporate profits, Mr. Cliggott figures.
Unfortunately for investors, both commodity prices and business investment are still falling, and there is no sign that a turn is imminent. So Mr. Cliggott expects earnings to skid at least until the spring of 2002, and to recover only moderately for the remainder of that year.
He predicts earnings in the next 12 months will sink as low as $37 per share of the S.& P. 500, compared with a high of $55 a share in 2000. Using a price-to-earnings ratio of 22, which he considers fair, given the current long-term interest rate of 4.6TK percent on 10-year Treasury notes, he calculates that the S.& P.'s fair value now is only about 800.
Of course, stocks do not always trade at fair value, and Mr. Cliggott could be wrong for any number of reasons. Interest rates could fall, enabling stocks to trade at higher price-to-earnings ratios. The market could move sideways while investors wait to see how 2002 unfolds. Or earnings could recover quickly.
Mr. Cliggott says he is aware of all those possibilities. But for now, he says, stocks are so overvalued that he is not worried that he will miss a big rally. "It's far more likely that the market could be down 20 or 25 percent than up 20 or 25 percent."
And that, Mr. Cliggott said, does not factor in the risk of more terrorist attacks, though Sept. 11 has raised risk for the economy and stocks.
Those risks include too much government interference in the economy, he said. He grew up in a Boston suburb and is a Democrat -- he jokes that anyone from Massachusetts is born a Democrat and a Red Sox fan -- but like most people on Wall Street, he thinks the federal government should usually stay out of the way of private business: "The risk is that government starts taking on a bigger role in America, or a bigger share of the economy, rather than a smaller share."
Spending on security and the military may cause inflation to rise, Mr. Cliggott said. Businesses buy computers, or add to their sales forces, because they think the spending will increase their revenue or profits. But improving security is a strictly defensive measure that forces businesses to spend more to produce the same product or service they previously did. That is inflationary, and higher inflation is typically a drag on stock prices, he said.
To divine longer-term trends in interest rates, the economy and stocks, Mr. Cliggott reads the Journal of Economic Literature, the Journal of Economic Perspectives and the Journal of Portfolio Management. But he says his most important feedback comes from investors, and he spends most of his time talking to customers. "Clients won't let you stay on the wrong side of things for too long," he said. "The key is to listen to your clients."
TO make sure that he does not repeat what other strategists say, he does not read his competitors' reports. He said he figures that if another strategist unearths an important new statistic or trend, his clients will tell him. In a typical week, Mr. Cliggott will lead a dozen or more hourlong conference calls or presentations with big investors, and spend much of the remainder of his time responding to questions from other clients. His list of business contacts is almost 300 names long.
On Fridays, he works at home, writing a pair of weekly research reports that are distributed to clients each weekend. One report covers specific industry sectors, while the other offers a broader picture of the market.
In the wake of Sept. 11, Mr. Cliggott has changed a few of his own habits. With his wife, Annemette, and his three children, aged 6 to 11, ensconced in Larchmont, N.Y., he has curtailed his travels in the last month -- because he wants to remain close to home and fears that further attacks could snarl air transportation. "I was never envious of people with their own Gulfstreams until last month," Mr. Cliggott said.
With his outlook, he is again advancing an opinion that is well outside the Wall Street consensus. If the market holds its recent gains or rallies further, his view will be proved very publicly wrong.
Mr. Cliggott says that standing alone does not bother him. "I got hugged a lot as a kid," he said, only half-joking. If his indicators show that earnings are turning higher, he said, he will not be afraid to turn more bullish. Otherwise, he does not plan to change his outlook.
His biggest risk is that the indicators on which he relies will lose their effectiveness as earnings predictors -- or that he will become so focused on them that he misses other important changes in the market. But he has shown that he can be both bullish and bearish, so if he finds that he is out of sync with the market for more than a few months, he will rethink his strategy, his fans say.
"Doug's the first person to doubt himself and his analysis, which is helpful," said Jeff Rose, who manages $2 billion invested in large United States growth stocks for Credit Suisse First Boston. "He's just a very calm guy. That humility and that aw-shucks personality will serve him well over time."
For now, Mr. Cliggott plans to stick to his guns.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 30, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Money & Business on Sunday about Douglas R. Cliggott, senior stock market strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, omitted two figures in citing the percentage change that would result in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by next spring if it were to fall to 800, a development that he believes possible. The index would be nearly 28 percent below its close of 1,104.61 on Friday. 
The article also misstated the yield on 10-year Treasury notes. It was 4.52 percent on Friday, not 4.6.

HEADLINE: Business; 
For Coffee Traders, Disaster Comes in Pairs

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
ONLY days after the World Trade Center collapsed on top of the evacuated New York Coffee Exchange, obliterating the most important coffee auction in the Western Hemisphere, traders moved into backup office space across the East River and quickly put the exchange back in business. 
 At first, all was not well. Trading was limited to just 90 minutes, and the low ceilings in the building that is the exchange's temporary headquarters make the trading pits as noisy as the elevated subway that rumbles overhead in Long Island City, Queens. But order was restored with impressive speed, and contracts for most of the $18 billion of coffee consumed annually in the United States were bought and sold at the same volume as before. 
 Trying as it was, responding to the crisis in the coffee exchange may have been the easy part of handling the crisis in coffee. 
The price of raw coffee -- in decline for several years -- plummeted to a record low last week. The fall has been dizzying. Futures contracts on the coffee exchange, the benchmark for prices around the world, had been as high as $3.05 a pound, in May 1997. But last Monday, they bottomed out at 42.5 cents a pound, then rose slightly. And the future looks no brighter. 
Bountiful rainfall in coffee-growing regions of South America is expected to help produce a record coffee harvest of more than 44 million bags next year in Brazil, the largest coffee-growing country in the world. Each bag weighs 132 pounds. 
The emergence of Vietnam as a major coffee producer contributes to the oversupply. The Vietnamese government has helped farmers in the central highlands plant coffee trees by the thousands. A minor coffee exporter just a decade ago, Vietnam will swamp the market with 12 million bags of generally low-quality coffee this year, which could drive prices to new lows.
"Coffee is dead," said Dov Blumenthal, a trader whose pit name on the trading floor of the coffee exchange is Bear. He said the absence of frost, floods or other natural disasters in South America, good news for the people there, spells disaster for the oversupplied coffee industry. "I've never seen things as bad as this," he said. 
And the glut could prolong the boom-bust cycle that has haunted coffee for decades. As prices fall, farmers stop fertilizing and pruning trees. Eventually, they may yank out trees, reducing future supply. An unexpected frost or hurricane could wipe out the crop, causing shortages that would push prices sharply higher. 
FOR now though, crumbling prices are causing havoc in the coffee-producing countries, which are on the verge of shutting down the cartel they formed a few years ago to control supplies and support prices. The impact on countries like Nicaragua and Ivory Coast has been devastating, as many farmers sell coffee at less than the cost of production. Some have to choose between starvation and switching to other crops, including illicit harvests like coca.
To the dismay of American consumers, the price collapse has not made its way to supermarket shelves. Prices for the most familiar brands -- including Folgers, Maxwell House, Chock Full O' Nuts and Nescafe -- which account for more than 65 percent of the retail market in the United States, have dropped only slightly. According to Information Resources, a market research company based in Chicago that tracks sales nationwide, the cost of a can of one brand, Yuban, is selling for $3.77 a pound, only 16 cents, or 4 percent, less than it was in January 2000. But the price of green coffee has been slashed by about 50 percent during that time. 
"If the income of coffee producers is less than half of what it was a year ago, why hasn't any of that been passed on to consumers?" asked Deborah James, a director at Global Exchange, an organization that supports better treatment for coffee farmers and other agricultural workers. "We're in the midst of a profit bonanza right now." 
Although they often cite sharp increases in the cost of green coffee supplies when they raise prices, the big coffee-roasting companies refuse to discuss their pricing now that unroasted coffee is cheaper than at any time in the last 30 years. "We never discuss our pricing," said MaryJane Kinkade, a spokeswoman for Kraft Foods, which produces Maxwell House and Yuban coffees.
Margaret Swallow, a spokeswoman for Procter & Gamble, which produces the Folgers brand, said the company had cut prices to retail chains seven times since March, 2000, but she declined to say what those decreases were. According to Information Resources, the supermarket price of Folgers ground coffee has declined about 16 percent in that time and most recently has sold for $2.80 a pound. 
The price disparity between producers and consumers is nowhere greater than at the gourmet coffee level. Starbucks, the largest specialty coffee chain with 2,900 company-owned stores in the United States, actually raised its prices 5 to 10 cents since January 2000 and does not plan to lower prices this year. 
"Pricing takes into account many elements, not just the cost of coffee beans," said Audrey Lincoff, a Starbucks spokeswoman. Labor costs, rent for high-traffic locations and even the cost of milk and sugar must be factored into the total package, she said. 
Starbucks still charges $11.45 a pound for coffee in its stores, although the company has acknowledged the plight of farmers who receive less than 50 cents a pound for their crops. The company promised this month to provide $1 million in financial support to coffee farmers. Starbucks also plans to buy one million pounds of coffee under Fair Trade, an international program that sets a minimum price of $1.26 a pound.
Starting next spring, Starbucks plans to increase its use of Fair Trade coffee by making it the "Coffee of the Day" one day each month.
Amid the coffee industry's problems, Americans are showing no sign of surrendering their claim to being the world's biggest coffee consumers. They spend $9.2 billion a year on retail coffee in supermarkets and specialty stores and an additional $8.7 billion for brewed coffee, espresso and cappuccino in restaurants and coffee bars. According to the American Coffee Association, a trade organization based in New York, orders for roasted coffee beans -- an indication of coffee consumption -- took a fall immediately after the terrorist attacks but have recovered.
As for the New York Coffee Exchange, its trading floor was at 4 World Trade Center, a nine-story building at the foot of the twin towers. When the towers came crashing down, tons of debris fell on the building, which had already been evacuated. Cocoa, sugar, cotton and some other commodities also were traded there. Mark Fichtel, chief executive of the New York Board of Trade, which oversees the trading for coffee and all the other commodities, said it would have been technically possible to resume trading on Sept. 12, because a duplicate trading floor had been built in Long Island City five years ago in response to the 1993 bombing of the trade center. The delay of four trading days was caused by logistics, Mr. Fichtel said.
The cost of keeping that backup system equipped and ready to go, with duplicate files and computer systems, was about $300,000 a year. Mr. Fichtel said there was some resistance to the concept "especially around the time the bills had to be paid." But having such a detailed contingency plan meant the exchanges could resume trading soon after the disaster, and did not have to fear losing business to competing exchanges like the London Coffee Exchange. 
RIGHT now, the two 300-square-foot carpeted trading pits are used in rapid-fire 90-minute sessions by traders buying and selling futures and options on coffee and all the other commodities. Before Sept. 11, each crop was traded for five hours a day in its own trading pit. Now there are only two pits for all of the commodities. Mr. Fichtel said that by the middle of November, two additional pits would be opened, increasing daily trading time to two hours for each commodity. By the end of January, two more pits will be added, lengthening the daily trading sessions to three hours. 
While that will help restore the trading process to normal in New York, it will not help resolve the serious problems in the world coffee market, which is of vital importance to 50 developing countries. "There's definitely a temporary glut that's driven prices so low it's become a crisis," said John M. Talbot, an assistant professor of sociology at Colby College in Maine, who is writing a book on coffee. "Chances are that after a few years, supply will be brought back into balance with demand. But the devastation that will happen in the meantime is morally unacceptable."
Mr. Talbot said the instability in coffee prices had been caused in large part by the cancellation of the International Coffee Agreement in 1989. The agreement was an attempt by the United States and other democracies in the cold war to support the economies of developing countries and prevent the Communists from making political inroads. The agreement kept prices high and established production quotas to balance supply and demand. 
By 1989, with the cold war almost over, the United States pulled out of the agreement. Free global competition was introduced, and prices began to fall. But a 1994 freeze in Brazil reduced the supply and sent prices soaring. The higher prices encouraged impoverished farmers to plant more coffee trees. 
It takes three to five years for a coffee tree, sometimes called a bush, to start producing fruit. With the aid of good weather, and demand for coffee growing at only 3.5 percent a year, coffee soon started backing up in warehouses. As prices slid, supply continued to grow, further depressing prices. An attempt this year by the Association of Coffee Producing Countries to stabilize prices failed when members refused to withhold one-fifth of their harvest from the market. The head of the organization said recently that the fledgling cartel would shut its doors in January, the victim of selfishness, born of desperation, among the coffee-producing nations.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Honoring,And Paying, All Those Who Serve

BYLINE:  By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
GRAB a copy of Vanity Fair on the newsstand, and instead of facing the usual glamorous movie star, you first will see four soot-stained New York City firefighters gracing the striking black-and-white cover of a supplement to the November issue.
 These days, even as wealthy sports idols like Tiger Woods and Venus Williams have declined to compete overseas merely to avoid flying on airplanes, poorly paid firefighters, police officers, soldiers and postal workers are risking their lives by simply doing their jobs. 
 Does the post-Sept. 11 thirst for genuine heroes, not just those who play them, mean an end to the celebration of "success" and the culture of celebrity?
Not a chance. They are too deeply ingrained. But maybe the newfound respect for real work and the sacrifices of regular workers will finally lead to profound misgivings about just how far the rewards of the American economy have tilted in recent years toward the favored few. 
In a recent issue of The Milken Institute Review, Edward N. Wolff, an economist at New York University, reports on his latest findings concerning the striking contrast in the last two decades between the fortunes of the upper tier of the wealth rankings and the broad middle class.
Mr. Wolff looked at the most recent available data from the Federal Reserve on the wealth of American households, which goes through 1998. Not surprisingly, he found 1983 through 1998 -- when the economy prospered and the stock market boomed -- produced many millionaires.
The number of households with a net worth of more than $1 million nearly doubled, to 4.78 million from 2.41 million. At the same time, the ranks of the truly rich exploded even more, with those worth more than $10 million nearly quadrupling, to 239,000 from about 67,000.
That's great. A rich society like the United States should have plenty of rich people -- and the more the merrier. But what is disturbing is what happened to just about everybody else.
"The richest 1 percent accumulated 53 percent of the total gain in marketable wealth over the 1983-1998 period," Mr. Wolff wrote. "The next 19 percent received another 39 percent, so that the top quintile accounted for 91 percent of the total growth in wealth, while the bottom 80 percent accounted for a mere 9 percent."
"The results indicate rather dramatically," he added, "that the fruits from economic growth in the last few decades were enjoyed by a surprisingly small part of the population -- the top 20 percent, and particularly the richest 1 percent."
WHO'S in that 20 percent? Well, it may well include people like you. The line dividing the top fifth from everybody else fell somewhere around $250,000 in 1998, meaning that anybody with solid home equity of say, $100,000, modest savings and investments of at least $50,000 and a retirement account of more than $100,000 belongs to the winning upper crust.
And who's not? Many of the firefighters and rescue workers, of course, who rushed into the World Trade Center inferno. But it also includes millions inside government and out -- teachers and nurses, social workers and telephone repair people -- whose worth has been steadily devalued in the nation's excessive pursuit of private gain over public service.
"There's been an enormous rush of recognition that working people are immensely more valuable than the rewards they've received in recent years," said Robert H. Frank, an economics professor at Cornell University, whose book, "The Winner-Take-All Society," (The Free Press, 1995) written with Philip J. Cook, explored why cultural and technological trends have lately concentrated so much more wealth and influence in the economy's top positions.
"But unless the change in attitudes kindled by the assault is translated into a change in public policy, nothing will be different," Mr. Frank said. "We need to pay our public servants more and treat them with better respect. We have to recognize the impoverished level of many basic public services and confront our nation's big inventory of unmet needs. That's where our politics have failed us." 
Judging by the current debate over how best to put together an economic stimulus package, our politics still have a long way to go. The House of Representatives just passed a bill that includes a host of tax breaks for business and speeds up individual tax cuts -- but only for families with incomes of at least $65,000.
That seems backward. Not only is the war demanding real sacrifices from the working Americans who will be fighting it, but the recession will invariably hit hardest at the most vulnerable in society. Shouldn't those who already have the most be called on to sacrifice something, too?

HEADLINE: Better Energy Sources 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Enlightenment on Energy" (editorial, Oct. 22):
 A Union of Concerned Scientists study released last week found that establishing a national standard of 20 percent of American electricity coming from non-hydropower renewable energy by 2020, if combined with energy efficiency programs, would save consumers at least $70 billion, stimulate the economy, reduce the vulnerability of our energy infrastructure to terrorist attack, and greatly reduce air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. 
A bill to achieve this has been introduced by Senator James M. Jeffords, and should be adopted as part of the Senate's overall energy package. 
 Developing wind, solar, biomass, geothermal and other home-grown energy sources, along with increasing energy efficiency, is the best way to diversify America's energy supply.

ALAN NOGEE
Director, Clean Energy Program
Union of Concerned Scientists
Boston, Oct. 25, 2001
